column1: FlowInputMappingException results in broken persistent HttpSession
column91:
18/Dec/17 9:11 PM;rstoya05-aop;It's not enough to mark {{DefaultMappingResults}} with seriaizable. To follow through the object graph we would also need to mark {{MappingResult}},and also {{Mapping}}, which brings in {{Expression}}, and its sub-classes, and fields they contain...

Certainly that direction does not seem feasible but either way some kind of fix is needed to avoid the failure. I'm going to set a fix version for this but am unsure yet what the solution should be? Perhaps we could persist only a simple toString representation, e.g. {{new FlowException(mappingEx.toString())}} instead of the actual mapping exception.

Can you show some snippet of the flow definition that shows what's triggering the {{TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler}}? Is this happening at the very entry to the flow in which case I'm wondering why not let the flow fail rather than remaining within the flow and possibly redirecting (if I understand the scenario)?
column92:
20/Dec/17 8:37 AM;raqueta;I see why making DefaultMappingResults is not an option. Some String representation would be fine for us. The name of the Exception is usually enough for us to detect the cause. 
The exception is raised at the entry of the flow. We found the easiest way to reproduce the problem is by calling a flow with input parameters directly from the browser. The flow is designed to be called as a subflow and will fail when called directly from the browser. The same error happens when such a flow is called from an embedding flow with broken parameters, but that is harder to reproduce.
As for the Errorhandler, we use a global on-error transition to provide a rather generic error page to our users. Here is a simplified code snippet from one of our flows, but it is really pretty generic.

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">
    <input name="foerderhoeheberechnungId" type="java.lang.Long" required="true" />   
...
    <global-transitions>
        <transition on-exception="java.lang.Exception" to="fehler" />
...
{code}
column93:
20/Dec/17 6:59 PM;rstoya05-aop;On second thought this affects both FlowInput~ and FlowOutputMappingException's and some flows may be configured to not serialize at all, which means re-mapping the exception quietly during a transition may lead to regressions. Instead I've made MappingResults and MappingResult seriazable with the Mapping in AbstractMappingResult excluded as transient. This preserves the current behavior and goes as far as possible when serialization is involved.

If you could give this a try using 2.4.7.BUILD-SNAPSHOT to confirm, that'd be very helpful.
column94:
22/Jan/18 3:32 PM;raqueta;Thank you for providing this patch. This fixed the original NotSerializableException, but now we came across the next NotSerializableException:
org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[localhost].[/fvs]] - [M: Cannot serialize session attribute webflowConversationContainer for session D0C9BB315C6D23E77785A8C5AD43A992-] 
java.io.NotSerializableException: org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.RequestControlContextImpl
                at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject0(ObjectOutputStream.java:1184)
                at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.defaultWriteFields(ObjectOutputStream.java:1548)
...
I do not know where and why a RequestControlContextImpl ist put in the session, but this class is also not serializable and thus seemingly not supposed to be stored in a session.
column95:
23/Jan/18 2:15 PM;rstoya05-aop;This fix was released as part of 2.4.7 but I forgot to close the ticket.

I don't think RequestContext is meant to be stored in the session and I don't believe it's anything Web Flow does. If needed you'll need to open a new ticket.

column1: combination of SWF and MyFaces Trinidad may set flag 'JsfRuntimeInformation.myFacesInUse' to wrong value
column42:
If combination of SWF and MyFaces Trinidad is used, the flag JsfRuntimeInformation.myFacesInUse may be set to wrong value in method JsfRuntimeInformation.isMyFacesInUse().

Reason: facesContext.getClass() may be org.apache.myfaces.trinidadinternal.context.FacesContextFactoryImpl$CacheRenderKit (depending on the order of wrapped FacesContexts) which is interpreted as "MyFaces Core" by code 
{code:java}
facesContext.getClass().getPackage().getName().startsWith("org.apache.myfaces.")
{code}

Bet solution of solving this inside method JsfRuntimeInformation.isMyFacesInUse() seem to be:
walk through a potential stack of FacesContextWrapper instances until you reach a non-FacesContextWrapper FacesContext which should be good for deciding if it's MyFaces Core or not.

column1: SWF 1.0 to 2.4 - upgrade - missing enabling capability of single snapshat
column42:
Problem:
SWF 2.4 does not have option to set/override DefaultFlowExecutionRepository.alwaysGenerateNewNextKey in webflow definitions.

we need to have alwaysGenerateNewNextKey to false to fix our problem.

Team, we are upgrading spring webflow from 1.x to 2.4.

In 1.x, we created flowExecutor like below, one of the options in creation here is setting "repositoryType" to "SINGLEKEY" which will disable generating new next key for each flow.

"SimpleFlowExecutionRepository#setAlwaysGenerateNewNextKey(boolean)"


{code:java}
~<bean id="flowExecutor"
		class="org.springframework.webflow.config.FlowExecutorFactoryBean">
		<property name="definitionLocator" ref="flowRegistry" />
		<property name="executionAttributes">
			<map>
				<entry key="alwaysRedirectOnPause">
					<value type="java.lang.Boolean">true</value>
				</entry>
			</map>
		</property>
		<property name="repositoryType" value="SINGLEKEY" /> Changed from simple to singleKey to disable Back button
		<property name="maxContinuations" value="1" />
		<property name="maxConversations" value="1" />
	</bean~
{code}

We need to have the similar behavior in SWF 2.4 as well,

As per the documentation, we created flow executor through webflow config elements like below,

{code:java}
<webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor" flow-registry="flowRegistry">
		<webflow:flow-execution-repository max-executions="1" max-execution-snapshots="0"/>
		<webflow:flow-execution-attributes>
			<webflow:always-redirect-on-pause value="true"></webflow:always-redirect-on-pause>
		</webflow:flow-execution-attributes>
	</webflow:flow-executor>
{code}

But webflow:flow-execution-repository element doesn't have an attribute to update the field "alwaysGenerateNewNextKey".


Please share if there is a workaround for this case or are we doing anything wrong.

column1: Dynamically added components to data table not restored.
column42:
Dynamically added components to data table not restored.

*Environment*
JSF - 2.2.12
Spring-web-flow : 2.4.2.RELEASE
spring-framework : 4.2.0.RELEASE
prime-faces : 5.3.5

In the data table the paginator and columns are added dynamically using java code.
Attached sample application to reproduce.

Steps to reproduce
a) Access the application
b) Click on "Dynamic Table" link
c) Data table is shown with two columns and paginator. 
d) click on NEW  button present below the table
e) In the new page shown, click on BACK button
f) When the data table is shown, the paginator is missing,

when BACK is clicked, the previous snapshot is restored in the RESTORE_VIEW phase
and the component values are present. During the RENDER_RESPONSE, the restored component s not used and new components are created again.

com.sun.faces.facelets.tag.jsf.ComponentTagHandlerDelegateImpl -> apply() method  is invoked.
The component is not found and new components are created.

Note : the same works with JSF - 2.2.4
column91:
07/Jul/16 10:07 PM;rstoya05-aop;I don't have a root cause explanation but what you're doing with setting a "RE_RENDER_TABLE" flash scope attribute from various transitions and then checking it in your custom {{TableEventHandler}} seems very brittle. Along the same lines for the custom FlowExecutionListener checking for the "BACK" event and then manually issuing a "requestFlowExecutionRedirect" vs simply declaring the transitions in the sub-flow.

Whatever the intent, removing the check for the "RE_RENDER_TABLE" flash scope attribute in your custom {{TableEventHandler}} makes it work. I am not going to spend more time. If you want to re-open this ticket still please provide a small, focused example without all these extras.

column1: Ajaxified updating a bound value not possible when using input component within c:forEach
column42:
In a spring webflow project that uses MyFaces as view technology the update of MyFaces from 2.1.17 to 2.2.7 breaks the ajaxified update of a bound value within a c:forEach tag. Project Setup: * spring-context: 4.2.3.RELEASE * spring-webmvc: 4.2.3.RELEASE * spring-webflow: 2.4.2.RELEASE * myfaces: 2.2.7 *Example:* {code:title=View}
container.checked = #{container.checked}
{code} {code:title=Controller.java} public class Controller { public static final class Container implements Serializable { private boolean checked = false; public final boolean isChecked() { return checked; } public final void setChecked(boolean checked) { this.checked = checked; } } private final List containers = Arrays.asList(new Container()); public List getContainers() { return containers; } } {code} A complete example can be found in the attached file. Steps to reproduce the error: # Ensure the selected {{myfaces.version}} in the {{pom.xml}} is *2.2.7*. # Start the application and open the respective website. # Select _c:forEach (ajax)_. # Activate the checkbox. The text should change to _container.checked = true_. This works as expected when using MyFaces 2.1.17. If the items-expression is evaluated within the flow and saved as viewScoped variable the update also works as expected: {code:title=Flow} {code} {code:title=View}
container.checked = #{container.checked}
{code} The project contains further examples: * An c:forEach example including a non-ajaxified version (working with _MyFaces 2.2.7_) * An ui:repeat (ajaxified) example (shows an exception but works with _MyFaces 2.2.7_)

column1: Flow restart on any browser but firefox
column42:
I have flow defined like this:

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
      xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
      xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">

    <view-state id="start" view="secure.view1" model="flowModel">
        <on-entry>
            <evaluate expression="actionbean1.setupForm"/>
            <evaluate expression="actionbean2.setupForm"/>
        </on-entry>
        <transition on="action1" to="actionState1"/>
        <transition on="action2" to="actionState2"/>
    </view-state>

    <action-state id="action1">
        <evaluate expression="actionbean1.action"/>
        <transition to="start"/>
    </action-state>

    <action-state id="actionState2">
        <evaluate expression="actionbean2.action2"/>
        <transition to="start"/>
    </action-state>

</flow>
{code}

The page has 2 submit buttons and 2forms that handle 2 actions defined in the flow (they call events). When I'm trying to execute those actions twice, ie. I choose my options, execute action 1, I choose my options again and execute it again, the form object is getting lost and new form object is created. This behaviour only occurs on Chrome, Safari and IE. Firefox preserves the form object state. Maybe i'm missing something here, but I have strong feeling this is a bug.

column1: development mode does not recognize changes in parent flows
column42:
Activating development mode according to http://docs.spring.io/spring-webflow/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/#builder-development to true shoud 'switch on hot-reloading of flow definition changes'. Unfortunately this does not work, if not the flow itself, but it's parent flow definition is changed. If the file itself is not changed, parent flows should be checked, too.

From the perspective of XmlFlowModelBuilder.hasFlowModelResourceChanged(): If this resource's lastModified is not bigger than lastModifiedTimestamp, it should check its parent's lastModified value and it's parent's parents.

column1: JSF CompositeComponent causes PropertyNotFoundException
column42:

I'm trying to replace my company's "old" (selfmade) page control with SWF. But as soon as I try to refresh or transit from a view state containing a JSF-XHTML with some CompositeComponents SWF throws an exception:

{code:java}
Caused by: javax.el.PropertyNotFoundException: Target Unreachable, identifier 'cc' resolved to null
	at org.apache.el.parser.AstValue.getTarget(AstValue.java:72)
	at org.apache.el.parser.AstValue.setValue(AstValue.java:148)
	at org.apache.el.ValueExpressionImpl.setValue(ValueExpressionImpl.java:249)
	at org.apache.myfaces.view.facelets.el.ContextAwareTagValueExpression.setValue(ContextAwareTagValueExpression.java:153)
	... 51 more
{code}

Some CompositeComponent seem to work fine but as soon as I include certain other ComponentComponents (f.e. a CC-DataTable) this exception occurs. I should add that it worked fine with the old dialog control but unfortunately not with my current SWF-config:

My config:
SWF 2.4.1
MyFaces api+impl 2.2.8 (company's requirement)
Mojarra jsf-impl 2.2.8 (SWF requirement for the CompositeComponentStackManager)
PrimeFaces 5.2
Spring 4.1.6

I know that the use of MyFaces with Mojarra may lead to incompabilities but due to the CompositeComponentStackManager I need Mojarras jsf-impl ([SWF-1652|https://jira.spring.io/browse/SWF-1652]) and as I said it works fine until I add certain CompositeComponents.

This issue seems related to [SWF-1639|https://jira.spring.io/browse/SWF-1639] but version 2.4.1 didn't fix it for me.

06/Aug/15 2:53 PM;rstoya05-aop;When you say an exception occurs during rendering, can you provide more details, perhaps a stack trace? 

If the underlying HTTP response is committed because bytes were actually sent to the client, then indeed there isn't much that you can do at that point. The client has already received an HTTP status code, all headers, and some bytes from the response. It's too late to change the response then to anything else.

column1: Odd WebFlow + SpringLoaded flow-serialization-failure behaviour
column42:
I wasn't sure whether to create this issue under WebFlow or SpringLoaded, but I think it's WebFlow-specific enough to warrant being created here.

The problem is:

When attempting to store attributes in Flow Scope that are not Serializable while running with a Spring Loaded java agent, instead of failing with a NotSerializable exception, WebFlow silently proceeds to view rendering (where attributes referenced in Flow Scope can now be null without having been notified).

I've created a demo Spring Boot project on github to demonstrate the errors (even more muddling, the error states differ in Java 8/7 - this is detailed more specificly in the demo web app).
column91: 03/Jun/15 11:57 AM;rstoya05-aop;What are the steps for reproducing the problem? I presume you're modifying a class and it gets reloaded at some point?
column92:
03/Jun/15 1:36 PM;etsmith;Hey Rossen! Thanks for getting to this.

No need to reload a class; you just need to be running with the springloaded javaagent (I've tested with the spring-instrument javaagent and that was normal).

1. Create a class, not implementing Serializable
2. Attempt to store that class in Flow Scope (this would normally trigger an exception, but with the springloaded agent, does not)
3. Likely the view state that gets rendered after attempting to store the non serializable object will fail (since it's trying to access an object that wasn't successfully stored in Flow Scope).

I've set up a project on github you can quickly clone/run which explains the issue and demonstrates it:

git clone https://github.com/edward-smith/spring-webflow-springloaded-bug-demonstration.git
mvn spring-boot:run
(this demonstrates the normal, expected Web Flow failure behaviour)
then
mvn spring-boot:run -PwithAgent
(this runs with the springloaded javaagent, and shows how the failure doesn't occur where we expect it to)
column93: 06/Aug/15 2:22 PM;rstoya05-aop;hi [~aclement], sounds more related to Spring Loaded java agent. I'm happy to take a look still, just wondering if you had any comments off the top of your mind.
column94:
06/Aug/15 4:20 PM;aclement;Hey Rossen - yes, I'd be inclined to agree. If there is different behavior with/without the agent then it is likely the agent (I see this a lot with grails). There is nothing special in spring loaded for spring web flow but there is special handling for serialization in general, that is where I'd suspect the problem is. I raised an issue over there that points back to this one:

https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-loaded/issues/133

Actually, depending on the version of spring loaded being used here it might be worth trying with the recent 1.2.4 release - there have been serialization changes in the last few months IIRC.
column96: 07/Aug/15 7:39 AM;rstoya05-aop;[~aclement] see my comment above. I'm resolving as invalid here as it seems pretty clear it's not anything in Web Flow. Thanks.
column97: 07/Aug/15 7:40 AM;rstoya05-aop;On second thought, works as designed seems better :)

column1: After a submit with p:commandButton with ajax="false" and validation error, all values are cleared in form
column42:
After a submit with p:commandButton with ajax="false" and validation error, all values in fields are cleared.

Using the same example with mojarra 2.2.6 the behavior is correct! All the values remain after a submit with ajax="false".

I have isolated the test so starting with JSF first, then adding PrimeFaces, then adding Spring, and finally adding SWF, the problem becomes only when SWF is incorporated!!

I try it with h:commandButton instead of p:commandButton and the problem persist!

What I can't understand is why downgrading to Mojarra 2.2.6 the problem dissapears! Can be something broken in SWF when working with Mojarra 2.2.7 and 2.2.8!

The environment used is:JDK 1.7.0_25, Tomcat 7.0.40, Primefaces 4.0, SWF 2.3.3, Spring 3.2.8, JSF 2.2.8
column91: 15/Jan/15 8:44 AM;annihilate;Can confirm the exact same issue is happening for me. It is broken if using any JSF version above 2.2.6, so 2.2.7, 2.2.8 and 2.2.9.
column92:
06/Aug/15 1:14 PM;rstoya05-aop;This should be fixed now with [commit 2aa99e|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow/commit/2aa99ec0d00876ab82d17a04b1a33eadf27b3c6a]:

{quote}The JSF com.sun.faces.facelets.tag.jsf.ComponentSupport in 2.2.7
started using FacesContext#isPostBack to check if a new component
tree is being built prior to attempting to find a child component.

In Web Flow where we redirect prior to rendering, and hence lose
the value of isPostback (because ResponseStateManagerImpl no longer
finds the parameter with the view state), it causes components to
be re-created and lose their local values.

This change overrides isPostback in FlowFacesContext in order to
return true in cases where the UIViewRoot has been restored from
flash scope and is fully built.{quote}

If you have a chance, please do give it a try to confirm it works for you.

column98:
01/Aug/14 4:47 AM;dbucek;We tried to fix that bug (if it's bug). But we are very unsure by solution. This is code from JsfViewFactory from package org.springframework.faces.webflow. We use it by <faces:flow-builder-services id="flowBuilderServices" view-factory-creator="fixedJsfViewFactoryCreator" /> in applicationContext.xml.

We made changes on lines 159 (+3 lines) and 178 (+3 lines).

I hope it will be helpful.
column99: 01/Aug/14 6:23 AM;dbucek;We made some investigations and the problem probably is that the variable {{cc}} may be processed several times in one xhtml page (because the page contains several composite components) and during that time the variable could be changed and refers to another object. This is done that the variable {{cc}} is valid only during the processing of the tag of the concrete component. Then the variable {{cc}} of context {{CompositeComponentStackManager}} is removed. Method {{processTree}} is called outside the processing scope of the page then. It tries to handle the "binding" attributes referring to {{cc}} variable, but it doesn’t exists any more at that moment. We therefore fix {{processTree}} method by code that cares about adding variable {{cc}} to {{CompositeComponentStackManager}} and removal afterwards as I described at previous post.

column1: Web Flow 2.4.0 broken with Hibernate 3
column42:
Possibly related to the changes for SWF-1534 using the Spring Web Flow 2.4.0 release with Hibernate 3 I get this in a flow end state:

{code}
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.hibernate.SessionFactory.getCurrentSession()Lorg/hibernate/Session;
	at org.springframework.webflow.persistence.HibernateFlowExecutionListener$1.doInTransactionWithoutResult(HibernateFlowExecutionListener.java:163)
	at org.springframework.transaction.support.TransactionCallbackWithoutResult.doInTransaction(TransactionCallbackWithoutResult.java:34)
	at org.springframework.transaction.support.TransactionTemplate.execute(TransactionTemplate.java:133)
	at org.springframework.webflow.persistence.HibernateFlowExecutionListener.sessionEnding(HibernateFlowExecutionListener.java:161)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionListeners.fireSessionEnding(FlowExecutionListeners.java:208)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImpl.endActiveFlowSession(FlowExecutionImpl.java:400)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.RequestControlContextImpl.endActiveFlowSession(RequestControlContextImpl.java:238)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.EndState.doEnter(EndState.java:103)
{code}

Works fine with Hibernate 4.

Relates to https://jira.grails.org/browse/GPWEBFLOW-93

28/Apr/14 5:14 AM;rstoya05-aop;A sample project would be most welcome indeed. You can add one to the [repro repository|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow-samples] where you'll also find some template projects to get you started.

Note that 2.4 (currently RC1) has dropped JSF 1.2 support and has been simplified a little as a result. So a sample would help us confirm if it is an issue in Web Flow, what the issue is, and also whether it affects both 2.3.x and 2.4.
column92:
08/May/14 12:30 AM;zschorn;Sorry for the delay, the issue persist. It is an extremly simple project. 
You can access the page via http://localhost:8080/dynamiccomponent-showcase/spring/home.
The button makes an ajax request an rerenders two areas. After the second ajax request the dynamic created component disappears for the reasons I explained.

In this example an inner ui label is created first time. In our real world examples we are creating quite a lot UI components programmatically during ajax request.  For example context menus, panels. The problem persist  in webflow 2.4.0-RC1. It works if you downgrade the jsf impl to 2.1.15, in 2.1.16 it does not.

column1: JsfViewFactory.getViewStateViewRoot() calls static method FlowResponseStateManager.hasState() => doesn't work with Trinidad CoreResponseStateManager
column42:
Combination of SWF 2.4.0.RC1 with JSF 2.2.4 and MyFaces Trinidad 2.0.1 doesn't function because JsfViewFactory.getViewStateViewRoot() calls static method FlowResponseStateManager.hasState() but FlowResponseStateManager.saveState() isn't called because Trinidad's render kit uses CoreResponseStateManager.

As dirty workaround I have tested an own StateManager (extends FlowStateManager) which stores a dummy Object[2] in view scope with key FACES_VIEW_STATE in its method writeState(). This functions but is really a dirty hack.
column91:
15/Apr/14 6:48 AM;rstoya05-aop;So is the FlowResponseStateManager not getting plugged in properly with Trinidad's render kit used instead? If so how did you get your own StateManager plugged presumably instead of Trinidad's and wouldn't that be an issue in itself? 

Would you be able to provide a small sample project in the [repro repository|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow-issues]?
column92:
15/Apr/14 7:38 AM;malzahn;My own StateManager is a sub class of FlowStateManager which is a javax.faces.application.StateManager, but FlowResponseStateManager is a javax.faces.render.ResponseStateManager. StateManagers can be exchanged by an own javax.faces.application.Application but ResponseStateManager are configured in the render kit.
Trinidad's org.apache.myfaces.trinidadinternal.renderkit.core.CoreRenderKit returns FlowResponseStateManager in its getResponseStateManager().
I know how to customize renderers of an existing render kit, but don't know a possibility to replace CoreRenderKit by an own sub class without writing a complete own render kit.

To provide a small sample project would take some time. Wouldn't this issue occur with other libraries like PrimeFaces too?
column93:
15/Apr/14 8:04 AM;rstoya05-aop;I did not encounter any issues in [our examples|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow-samples]. The booking-faces and the primefaces-showcase are both using PrimeFaces.

The repro repository has template projects so it should be simple to create a project:

{code}
$ git clone git@github.com:spring-projects/spring-webflow-issues.git
$ cd spring-webflow-issues
$ ./create-repro-project.sh SWF-0000-jsf SWF-1630
{code}

column1: No exception handling for fireRequestProcessed in FlowExecutionImpl.start and FlowExecutionImpl.resume
column91: 21/Jan/14 6:30 PM;rstoya05-aop;handleException is specifically for exceptions that occur while a flow is executing. What are you trying to do?
column92:
21/Jan/14 10:35 PM;galda;If there is an exception after the flow execution the exception-handling defined in the flow could be executed. 
For example to remove success messages written during the flow execution and display an error message to the user.
column93:
22/Jan/14 9:11 AM;rstoya05-aop;Have you experimented how well the change works? I'm afraid it won't work well in all cases as the flow is not guaranteed to be active still. It also raises the question of whether other listener lifecycle methods surrounding flow execution should be invoked as well.

You have access to the RequestContext in the listener. It's probably best for it to deal with it's own exceptions.

column1: Programatically added DataTable childrens are removed after AJAX request
column42:
If we add columns in DataTable programmatically on preRenderEvent then on performing AJAX request columns are removed and empty DataTable is displayed. 

Code present in org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfView.saveState() is causing this issue. 

I have tested this with Webflow 2.4.0M1, JSF 2.2, PrimeFaces 4 and able to reproduce in attached sample WAR file.

Please note sample works fine if we change the Webflow version to 2.3.2 and JSF to 2.1.10.

Step to reproduce:

1) Deploy attached war file.
2) Access flow /spring/datatable
3) Click on Refresh button to hit flow transition.
4) Again click on Refresh button flow transition.
Now please notice that the DataTable's columns are removed.
column91:
31/Mar/14 8:44 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for providing a war. However without source code it is of limited use. Ideally provide a [rerpo project|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow-issues] (there are various template projects available.

bq. Code present in org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfView.saveState() is causing this issue.

Have you identified an issue, can you be more specific if so?

column1: NPE when using RichFaces 4.3.3 rich tree in restore view phase
column42:
Corresponding issue in RichFaces JIRA:

https://issues.jboss.org/browse/RF-12533

Seems as though the webflow code to restore the UIViewRoot in the class:

org.springframework.faces.webflow.TreeStructureManager

doesn't set the view root on the faces context, or the render kit id on the view root, early enough.  Subsequent restore of child components blows up because they are not accessible via faces context.  The attached patch resolves the error by setting the faces context/render kit id as soon as UIViewRoot is constructed; before processing of child components.
column91: 17/Mar/14 8:05 AM;rstoya05-aop;The referenced RF ticket says "when partial state saving is disabled". Is that the case?
column92: 17/Mar/14 8:15 AM;rawlingsd;Yes, that is correct, partial state saving disabled.
column93: 17/Mar/14 8:27 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks, is it not recommended to use partial state saving? I.e. what is the specific reason for turning it off?
column94: 17/Mar/14 8:32 AM;rawlingsd;It was my understanding that partial state saving isn't supported for myfaces in webflow 2.3.1 - its only supported for the mojarra implementation.  I thought webflow 2.4 was introducing support for myfaces partial state saving.
column95: 31/Mar/14 6:53 AM;rstoya05-aop;Yes partial state saving should work with myfaces. See [this commit|https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-webflow/commit/706490c4dc065eb2c3b50fd04d3303bd2e62801b]. Have you tried it?

column1: Race condition in webflow
column91:
16/Aug/13 10:29 AM;musikolo;Exactly, I'm having the same problem. The flow is passing in a parameter to the invoked method coming from the request. Once inside the method, we read again the same parameter also coming from request and compare them. Under high workload, they are sometimes different. We've been able to find out the right value is the one read from the request inside the method. This clearly evidences there is a concurrency problem in the expression evaluation within the flow.

We have currently Spring 3.1.4 + Spring Web Flow 2.2.0. After upgrading SWF to 2.3.1 and later to 2.3.2, the problem persists.

Is there any solution for this in the short term?
Is there any workaround we can apply?

Best regards.
column92:
17/Aug/13 10:28 PM;musikolo;Hi guys,

Good news, we have found the root cause. When we upgraded to SWF 2.3.1, we didn't do it in all our modules, doing the upgrade ineffective. Now hat we have upgraded to SWF 2.3.1 all our modules, the problem has vanished and everything works good.

Best regards.
column93: 17/Aug/13 10:32 PM;fernandezpaco;Yes, please close this issue
column94: 17/Aug/13 10:37 PM;klr8;Closed on request of the reporter.

column1: Slash problem in Linux & Windows
column42:
Deploying an Spring application in bitnami produces an slash problem with the URL interpreted by spring than deploying in Windows.

As you can see in the attached image, Windows is interpreting one slash (/) but ubuntu read double slash (//), so the interpretation fails in bitnami.

<servlet-mapping>
        <servlet-name>playtheguru</servlet-name>
	<url-pattern>*.view</url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

column1: Booking faces demos 'cancel booking' button doesn't work anymore
column42:
After creating a hotel booking it is not possible to delete a booking.
The cancel button doesn't work work. Debugging shows that the table datamodel is empty.

Also creating the datamodel in the on-entry instead of the on-render phase will just show an empty list.

It seems to be a problem with the <evaluate> tag.

I changed back to webflow version 2.3.2 and it is working without any other changes.

column1: Display a message when Session Expiration forces the flow to restart
column42:
I apologize if this is a duplicate, but I didn't find one.

When the HttpSession has expired and the user re-submits a page in the flow, he/she is sent back to the beginning of the flow. All I need to add to this behavior is a message explaining why it occurred. "You were inactive, so you have been restarted..."

We've done various workarounds for this with a Filter or Interceptor, and even dug further into the FlowHandlerAdapter, but none of these solutions is as simple or robust as we'd like.

I have to think that anyone else using SWF would consider this an expected capability, thus my classifying it as a Bug rather than an Improvement. But I don't really care which if it can be addressed.

The simplest solution I envision is a default message key that can be overridden if necessary, that will cause text to be placed in a default variable on flow or flash scope to be used if a page wants to, and to be cleared automatically after this initial view after restart is displayed.
column91:
27/Sep/17 2:49 PM;breaux;Stack Overflow question as well: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9909774/gracefully-handle-expired-httpsession-in-spring-webflow

But also revisiting just to see if anything can be done here.
column92: 15/Dec/17 6:13 PM;rstoya05-aop;[Custom FlowHandler|https://docs.spring.io/spring-webflow/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/#spring-mvc-config-flow-handlers] is the extension point for an expired session. You can redirect to the flow and append a query param, something like {{restarted=true}}, and then in the flow declare an {{<input name="restarted" type="boolean" value="flashScope.restarted" />}}.

column1: global-transitions can only be defined after all states
column42:
the element <global-transitions> can only be defined after all state-elements.

In my opinion, it would be better to define them before the states.

column1: HTTP session expiration doesn't ends active flows this caues memory leaks when we have started flow sessions.
column42:
When user starts a flow (or number of flows) and the user is inactive the natural behaviour of HTTP session is that it expires. 
Started flow session are not removed causing the memory leak. All the data attached to flows still remains in the flow session and will never be removed.
column91: 10/Apr/13 8:40 AM;jssandersjira;We are encountering this same problem. Please look into this.
column92: 01/May/13 6:55 AM;bytecodesbr;Is there any workaround?
column93: 07/Apr/14 11:54 AM;johnypok;This issue is confirmed? I wanted to use SWF in quite big project but such problems without a response for about a year are quite deterrent.
column94: 09/Apr/14 5:53 AM;rstoya05-aop;What server and version are you using? Also would you be able to check what is holding on to the data stored in the HTTP session after it expires, e.g. using a tool like YourKit or you could also obtain a heapdump from the JVM.
column95: 23/Apr/14 11:27 AM;timander;We encountered this problem when we tried to upgrade Webflow from 2.0.9.RELEASE to 2.3.3.RELEASE. Our test suite gets a java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space. We reproduced the problem by writing a JUnit test that starts a new flow over and over again in a loop and monitoring it with jvisualvm. When we use 2.0.9.RELEASE, our memory usage stays steady at about 100m no matter how many flows are executed. With version 2.1.0.RELEASE and above, it uses all available memory until the GC thrashes and it runs out of memory. We tried this experiment with the flow execution reaching an end-state and without reaching an end-state, and that didn't seem to matter. Based upon our experiments, I believe the memory leak bug was introduced in 2.1.0.RELEASE and affects all subsequent versions.
column96: 23/Apr/14 11:30 AM;timander;Screenshots of jvisualvm looping over our flow execution from JUnit (integration tests that load the spring context and save to the database, but do not run in an application container)
column97: 20/May/14 10:52 AM;rstoya05-aop;So what are the simplest steps to reproducing this with a running application (as opposed to a unit test)? Can you find out with jvisualvm what are the paths to GC roots? I.e. what's holding on the state? Or if I can get a reproducible case going, I can find out with Yourkit.
column98: 21/May/14 7:39 AM;Guitarkalle;This seems very serious and should probably be fixed ASAP. I'll try to find some time to try to recreate the issue.

column1: JpaFlowExecutionListener causes JDBC connection leaking, can cause running of of connections from the Connection Pool
column42:
Attaching JpaFlowExecutionListener to the Spring Webflow's configuration will cause JDBC connections leaking.
Here is simple usecase (I assume that JpaFlowExecutionListener has been attached in the configuration) 
1. Start the flow (you can monitor connection pool of the application, number of the current active connections should be 1)
2. Close the browser - still we have open JDBC connection
3. Wait for HTTP session to die (change session time out in web.xml to make it faster) - still we have 1 opened connection.

The problem disappear when we end the flow - but the HTTP session expiration doesn't ends active flows.

Of course if we take into consideration hundreds of concurrent users our connection pool will run out of connection very quickly and application will be unavailable.

column1: org.springframework.web.servlet.ModelAndView#addObject(String,Object) doc incorrect
column42:
Is:

	/**
	 * Add an attribute to the model.
	 * @param attributeName name of the object to add to the model
	 * @param attributeValue object to add to the model (never {@code null})
	 * @see ModelMap#addAttribute(String, Object)
	 * @see #getModelMap()
	 */

Should be:

	/**
	 * Add an attribute to the model.
	 * @param attributeName name of the object to add to the model (never {@code null})
	 * @param attributeValue object to add to the model
	 * @see ModelMap#addAttribute(String, Object)
	 * @see #getModelMap()
	 */

column94:
05/Mar/13 7:27 AM;martyjones;I tracked down the request parameters for the request that caused the NullPointerException and found the culprits.  Here are a list of the request parameters and their values:

execution = e1s2
_eventId = submit
last4Ssn = xxxx
yearOfBirth = xxxx
lastName = a name
__ua[] = [Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE ]
__ua[] = [8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4]
__ua[] = [.0)]
__screen[] = [1024x768]

As you can see the parameters "__ua[]" and "__screen[]" are causing the NullPointerException.   I am trying to figure out where these request parameters are coming from since they are not in my form.  The "__ua" parameter looks like the user agent string.  I reviewed our audit logs and these two parameters don't normally come over as part of the request so I am not sure how they are being added in.  

The biggest question is how do I handle parameters that have bad names that come over on the request that are not part of my model object?

column1: Myfaces with always-redirect-on-pause=false, navigation issues, browser redirect is not trigerred

3. Trigger transition from submit button

column1: Portlet FlowHandlerAdapter config samlpe incorrect in Chapter 14

isn't correct, since FlowHandlerAdapter's constructor is parameterless

<bean id="flowHandlerAdapter" class="org.springframework.webflow.mvc.portlet.FlowHandlerAdapter" >

</bean>	

works fine

please update doco

column1: Composite components displayed at bottom of page after clicking commandLink
column42:
When using Web Flow (2.3.1.RELEASE) in combination with JSF, I have a rendering problem when using a composite component of any kind and e.g. an component on 1 page after clicking a . The contents of the composite component are always displayed at the bottom of the page! When refreshing the page, rendering is fine again... I can very easily reproduce this using this code: My facelet: {code:xml}
{code} testComponent looks like this: {code:xml} {code} My suspicion is that the ordering of components is messed up when Web Flow restores the view after resuming the flow. When using the above code in a simple JSF facelet (without using Web Flow), all is working fine. I've debugged through the internals of Mojarra and Web Flow and can see that the order is being mixed in the buildView(FacesContext ctx, UIViewRoot view) method of FaceletViewHandlingStrategy when using Web Flow and not when using plain JSF. See the attachments for the output of the example code. Before: ok.png, after clicking link: nok.png. Thanks in advance for having a look!
column91:
30/Jan/13 12:54 PM;pwebb;It seems like the main cause of this issue is the {{com.sun.faces.facelets.tag.jsf.ComponentTagHandlerDelegateImpl.adjustIndexOfDynamicChildren()}}. Adding a conditional breakpoint (on {{parent instanceof UIForm}}) shows how the child order is changed.

It appears that {{com.sun.faces.context.StateContext}} is tracking dynamic changes via a {{SystemEventListener}} inner class. The listener is added to the {{UIViewRoot}} when {{startTrackViewModifications}} is initially called. There seems to be a mismatch between listener used when the 1st postback is received and the one used after the redirect:

* Postback is received
* JSF View is restored and {{startTrackViewModifications}} starts
* Event are processed
* A redirect is issued
* The redirect GET is received
* The JSF View is restored but the previous {{StateContext$AddRemoveListerner}} appears to already be attached
* There are now two {{StateContext}} in play, a new one that gets added and the previous one referenced via the {{AddRemoveListerner}}
* Calls to {{startTrackViewModifications}} now only update the newer {{StateContext}}

In order to fix the issue we need to ensure that the {{StateContext.release()}} method is called before the redirect. This method will trigger {{unsubscribeFromViewEvent}} on the {{UIViewRoot}}. It seems that {{StateContext.release()}} is only called via {{StateManagerImpl.saveView}}. Since Spring Web Flow has its own statemanagement this method is currently not always called.
column92:
01/Feb/13 4:55 AM;slambert;Thanks for solving!

In the meantime we could solve this by disabling "redirect in same state" as explained in the reference guide http://static.springsource.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.3.x/reference/html/ch13s10.html

column1: Prevent NPE in Mojarra when creating initial view
column42: When partial state saving is disabled(javax.faces.PARTIAL_STATE_SAVING=false), NullPointer exception is thrown during restore view of any webflow rendered view. Please see logs attached and sample application
column91:
13/Nov/12 9:37 PM;pwebb;[~rstoya05-aop],

I think I might have got to bottom of this but it is a bit tricky to work out why it fails only when partial state saving is disabled.  I actually think this is Mojarra bug in {{StateContext.startTrackViewModifications}}.  That class should support a {{null}} view root.  The reason that it does not occur with partial state saving is that {{FaceletViewHandlingStrategy.restoreView}} calls {{vdl.buildView}}, this has the side effect of setting the {{modListener}} in {{StateContext}} meaning that any subsequent calls never access the {{root}}.

Looking at why the bug does not surfaces with standard JSF, it appears that we work slightly differently to the {{FacesServlet}}.  The {{FacesServlet}} only calls {{restoreView}} for postbacks, initial requests always calls {{createView}}.  Looking at {{JsfViewFactory}} we work differently, we always call {{restoreView}} then fallback to {{createView}}.

One possible solution might be to change {{JsfViewFactory}}.  We could peek to see if we have state and then create or restore as appropriate.  I have tried this on an experimental branch [1] but it needs more testings.

What do you think of that approach?

-Phil

PS issues app is at [2]

[1] https://github.com/philwebb/spring-webflow/commit/9adf6b55ae7531bc7352c53378a403f5a75f54fe
[2] https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/tree/SWF-1571
column92: 16/Nov/12 1:39 PM;pwebb;See related Mojarra issue: http://java.net/jira/browse/JAVASERVERFACES-2610
column93:
16/Nov/12 2:24 PM;pwebb;{quote}
{noformat}
commit d31900e5f961828791c1e65095c3df698b327db4
Author: Phillip Webb <pwebb@vmware.com>
Commit: Phillip Webb <pwebb@vmware.com>

    Prevent NPE in Mojarra when creating initial view
    
    Refactor JsfViewFactory to only attempt a restoreView when state is
    available. This prevents a NullPointerException from being thrown
    when using Mojarra with partial state saving disabled. This change
    also makes Web Flow behave in a similar way to the standard
    FacesServlet.
    
    Issue: SWF-1571
{noformat}
{quote}

column1: IllegalStateException on double POST
column42:
The WebFlow handle "action" requests in portal environment with redirect (e.g. receive POST (action phase), redirect to browser, receive GET (render phase)

But in case of AJAX call along with submit in some cases the browser sends two POST requests (one for AJAX, one for Submit) and ignore redirect for AJAX. So instead of normal flow: AJAX POST - redirect - AJAX GET, submit POST - redirect - submit GET, the flow looks like AJAX POST - redirect - nothing, submit POST - redirect - submit GET.

The following exception appears on the second POST, because webflow expect the get (render request) but receive the POST instead.

column1: A redirect with spring.js not work as expected
column42:
I use spring.js with tiles in my web app. I found there's a very strong assumption on redirect.

If my outcome is in same page, is only reloaded the fragment. 
But if I use spring.js and tiles.
Image I have a 3 step page, and i always have ajax load, so my page name in the url never change. When I call redirect I want redirect, not make a partial load, otherwise I specified the fragment.

I propose this patch in javascript.

column1: f:viewParam not working with Spring Web Flow
column42:
When adding Spring Web Flow to a project, f:viewParam tags are not working any more.

With some debugging I found the following root cause.

The Class org.springframework.faces.webflow.Jsf2FlowViewHandler delegates (in my case) to com.sun.faces.application.view.MultiViewHandler. 

But the following method is not delegated: String deriveLogicalViewId(FacesContext context, String rawViewId)

When viewHandler.deriveLogicalViewId(..) is used, the default method from the abstract class javax.faces.application.ViewHandler is called. This method just returns the entered paramater rawViewId. So the correct viewId is not determinded.

In the end, the the viewId is not derive and a JspViewHandlingStrategy is used instead of the expected com.sun.faces.application.view.FaceletViewHandlingStrategy, the f:viewParam tags will not be processed.

To fix the problem, it is nesessary to also delegate deriveLogicalViewId.

I attached to corresonding patch.

Regards,
Nils Eckert
column91:
16/Aug/12 6:39 AM;nils_eckert;Similar problem in an other project:

http://java.net/jira/browse/GLASSFISH-16111?focusedCommentId=310998&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_310998
column92:
14/Nov/12 3:53 PM;pwebb;Hi Nils,

Thanks for the bug report and the patch.

Starting with Web Flow 2.4 we are planning to drop JSF 1.2 support and as a result many of these Jsf2xxx classes have been replaced. IT would be helpful if you could try the latest {{2.4.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT}} of the project to see if the issue still exists.  If you are using maven the Spring snapshot repository can be found at http://repo.springsource.org/snapshot.

Cheers,
Phil.

column1: secured transitions not working
column42:
I have a transition that is secured:

{noformat}
<transition on="saveSetup" bind="true">
			<secured attributes="hasPermission( 'null', 'SOME_PERMISSION' )" />
{noformat}

and the following configuration of webflow w/ spring security:

{noformat}
	<bean id="securityFlowExecutionListener" class="org.springframework.webflow.security.SecurityFlowExecutionListener">
		<property name="accessDecisionManager">
			<bean class="org.springframework.security.access.vote.AffirmativeBased">
				<constructor-arg>
					<bean class="org.springframework.security.web.access.expression.WebExpressionVoter">
						<property name="expressionHandler" ref="webSecurityExpressionHandler" />
					</bean>
				</constructor-arg>
			</bean>
		</property>
	</bean>
{noformat}

The webSecurityExpressionHandler is using a custom implementation of a permissionevaluator.

column1: Documentation: Rich Faces Integration (JSF 1.2)
column42:
It appears that the configuration mentioned at the referenced Springsource URL to activate the RichFacesAjaxHandler is incorrect. I was having trouble getting RichFaces partial updates working with SWF 2.3.0, RichFaces 3.3.3 and JSF 1.2.

After some research, I found a JBoss RichFaces bug report that explained that the RichFacesAjaxHandler should be a property of FlowHandlerAdapter instead of FlowController: https://issues.jboss.org/browse/RF-6463

I made the change (for me, I added the property to JsfFlowHandlerAdapter) and this got partial updates working. Here's my config:

<bean class="org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfFlowHandlerAdapter">
	<property name="flowExecutor" ref="flowExecutor" />
	<property name="ajaxHandler">
        <bean class="org.springframework.faces.richfaces.RichFacesAjaxHandler"/>
    </property>
</bean>
column91: 14/Sep/12 8:28 AM;rstoya05-aop;A FlowController and FlowHandlerAdapter are mutually exclusive. On a given request you use either one or the other. This is why both have that property. I suspect in your configuration, the FlowController wasn't mapped to incoming requests.
column92: 04/Oct/12 8:10 AM;redparham;Understood. It might still be worth mentioning on the same doc page that RichFacesAjaxHandler can be used with both FlowHandlerAdapter and FlowController.

column1: JsfManagedBeanPropertyAccessor causes early release of FacesContext
Set resolved Spring locale for JSFViews instead of the Request ones
column42: The JSFViewFactory sets the ViewRoot locale from the external request during view generation. Instead of that the Spring resolved locale should be used (LocaleContext.getLocale()) for a more consistent locale handling.
column91: 05/Jul/12 6:56 AM;rstoya05-aop;Wouldn't that interfere with the choice of an application that sets the locale through JSF?

column1: Replace ${...} with #{...} in expression examples in Flow XSD
column42: Spring Web Flow 2.3 requires to use a new xsd file for the flow definitions. The "spring-webflow-2.0.xsd" referes to ${...} for EL expressions but with the introduction of Spring EL only #{...} works anymore.

column1: Primefaces resources access failed for root servlet mapping
column42:
I want to map my controllers/flows to the root servlet context instead of using a subcontext like /app/* shown in the Web Flow Primefaces showcase. So I used the <mvc:default-servlet-handler> declaration to support that. Unfortunately the primefaces (JSF) resource access does not work in that case.

Using a subcontext the generated resources request look like:
/app/javax.faces.resource/theme.css?...

Using the root context:
/login/javax.faces.resource/theme.css?... instead of /javax.faces.resource/theme.css?...

Login is the name of the controller in that case. So the resource access failed using the root context, with a resource not found error in the log. So I tried to remove the <faces:resources> declaration and used an SimpleUrlHandlerMapping mapping with this expression "**/javax.faces.resource/**" mapped to the JSF resource handler, but without any success. The subcontext mapping works as expected.
column91: 14/Jun/12 4:07 AM;rstoya05-aop;Last time I looked into this, I found out it was a limitation of JSF, which assumes you have a mapping by extension or by prefx. Feel free to prove me wrong though. And by that I mean making it work in an app without Web Flow. You can re-open the ticket in that case.

column1: JSF Composite Component causes NPE during deserialization
column42:
*Steps to reproduce* (or apply attached patch to [issue project|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/tree/master/SWF-1468] SWF-1468)

# Create composite component that contains a composite:insertFacet or composite:insertChildren
# Create a flow with one view-state
# Create a view that uses the composite component
# Run the application and load the page
# Reload the page *twice* (in the same flow state)

The NPE is thrown during unmarshaling the flow snapshot. Mojarra's Resource implementation tries to obtain a _ResourceManager_ from the current _FacesContext_. The FacesContext, however, has not been set at this point since _FlowFacesContextListener_ would get notified *after* a the snapshot is restored.

This issue has already been reported for version 2.2.1 but SWF-1468 has been set to "Resolved" as of inability to reproduce.

column43:
Spring 3.1.0 + Spring Web Flow 2.3.1
Mojarra 2.1.7 + PrimeFaces 3.3
vFabric 2.6.5 Tomcat 7.0.26
column91: 21/May/12 6:13 AM;rstoya05-aop;An [issue project|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues#readme] would be much appreciated and help speed up the resolution.
column92: 21/May/12 1:37 PM;pelzrutsche;Done, I just sent the pull request.
column93: 22/May/12 12:44 AM;pelzrutsche;Alright, here's the [issue project for SWF-1544|https://github.com/pelzrutsche/spring-webflow-issues/tree/master/SWF-1544]
column94:
22/May/12 7:41 AM;rstoya05-aop;A JSF ResourceImpl is getting serialized and stored with the custom component and it looks like its custom deserialization method ({{readExternal}}) relies on FacesContext. However, a FacesContext is not available until the FlowFacesContextLifecycleListener is invoked, which occurs when the FlowExecution is resumed (and after being restored). Arguably a low-level operation such as serialization and de-serialization, which can occur independent of web request should not rely on the presence of a FacesContext.

Tracing back the history of Mojarra, the dependency on FacesContext during deserialization was ["fixed"|https://svn.java.net/svn/mojarra~svn/tags/2_0_0_B09/jsf-ri/src/com/sun/faces/application/resource/ResourceImpl.java] in [JAVASERVERFACES-911|http://java.net/jira/browse/JAVASERVERFACES-911] but then removed (or perhaps lost) in the very next commit r6845.

Actually, I recall now opening this ticket [JAVASERVERFACES-1690|http://java.net/jira/browse/JAVASERVERFACES-1690]. So it looks like this is the same problem actually. The fix version is 2.2 but adding your vote wouldn't hurt.

You can try [the patch|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/blob/master/SWF-1544/src/main/java/com/sun/faces/application/resource/ResourceImpl.java] I added to the issue project in your own application. That'll confirm if the expected fix in Mojarra 2.2 will work.
column95: 22/May/12 1:28 PM;pelzrutsche;Thanks a lot for the detailed information. I voted for JAVASERVERFACES-1690 and hopefully the fix will make it into the next release. My current workaround uses a Servlet filter which sets up a FacesContext with an empty Lifecycle as I wasn't sure if the bug was in SWF or JSF but I'll try your patch as well.

column1: web flow using too much memory
column42:
Hi,

We are running Spring Webflow 2.2.1 (from Maven Repository) on JBoss 6.1 and evaluating the average memory usage with Yourkit Java Profiler.

We have noticed if one user visit all application screens, we get an increase of 1Gb for the JVM Heap. 
Only when this user exits (logout), this 1Gb is released.

Our setup is : <webflow:flow-execution-repository max-executions="1" max-execution-snapshots="0" /> 

Doing a quick and dirty analysis on FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.java , it looks like the destroy method is not working properly. 

Thank you for your support.
column91: 26/Apr/12 6:55 AM;rstoya05-aop;Seems unusual. I just deployed one of our issue repository [template|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/tree/master/SWF-0000] projects to Tomcat and then looked at the memory usage. See the attached screenshot that shows the memory use as I stepped through the very basic flow.
column92: 26/Apr/12 12:56 PM;boaglio;The biggest objects in memory are from Spring Webflow.
column93:
26/Apr/12 12:56 PM;boaglio;
Rossen,

Your template is pretty simple (one flow only), our application has almost three hundred. 

I've attached two screenshots which is one user browsing most of app. pages and then loggin out. 

Please take a look...
column94: 27/Apr/12 6:50 AM;rstoya05-aop;Yes it is very simple and you provided very little detail so that's all I can go on. I'm afraid you'll need to do some more digging since I don't have access to your application. You'll need to find out how much of the memory for example is taken by Web Flow and how much is due to application data stored in flow scope or other scopes?
column95:
16/May/12 2:28 PM;boaglio;Hi Rossen , we noticied all memory that our application uses is released right away, but it looks like org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl stores every one of our almost three hundred flows at application scope, mostly with 13Mb each, and one with 28mb.

Is it correct to say that if I have one user visiting all flows or three hundred users, these flows will remain the same size ?

Is there any way to estimate how much heap will webflow use if our applications grows for example , more one hundred flows ?

Thank you for your support so far.
column96: 17/May/12 10:21 AM;rstoya05-aop;It is surprising to me that a flow definition would be 13Mb. Those are just the static definitions of the flows, what views they contain, what stats, actions, etc. There is no actual data so it's unclear why they are as large. Have you been able to see a further breakdown of that?
column97: 25/Apr/13 12:33 PM;rstoya05-aop;The FlowDefinitionRegistry is merely a holder of flow definition metadata and actual flow data. Just like the HTTP session is a holder of objects. The memory is as big as the data you put in it.

column93:
05/Apr/12 5:53 AM;mscheibe;Seems like {{org.hibernate.SessionFactory}} does not support {{openSession(Interceptor)}} any longer. It's used in {{HibernateFlowExecutionListener.createSession}}

{code:java}
private Session createSession(RequestContext context) {
		Session session = (entityInterceptor != null ? sessionFactory.openSession(entityInterceptor) : sessionFactory
				.openSession());
		session.setFlushMode(FlushMode.MANUAL);
		return session;
	}
{code}

column94: 05/Apr/12 6:25 AM;mscheibe;HibernateFlowExecutionListener always uses: import org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.SessionHolder;
column95: 05/Apr/12 6:38 AM;rstoya05-aop;Did you see the linked issue? If you look under the "source" tab you can see the actual changes made in the Spring Framework to address this same issue.
column96:
07/Jan/13 2:34 AM;pomelko;As workaround you can override {{org.springframework.webflow.persistence.HibernateFlowExecutionListener}} implementation by your own, which is using {{org.springframework.orm.hibernate4.SessionHolder}} instead of {{org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.SessionHolder}}.

After that register your listener:

{code:xml}
<webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor">
	<webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
		<webflow:listener ref="myHibernateFlowExecutionListener" />
	</webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
</webflow:flow-executor>

<bean id="myHibernateFlowExecutionListener" class="my.HibernateFlowExecutionListener">
	<constructor-arg ref="sessionFactory" />
	<constructor-arg ref="transactionManager" />
</bean>
{code}

column1: Database connection leak using JPA and loading lazy initialized entities using WebFlow's presistence context
column42:
When entities have lazy-initialized relations and they are loaded using WebFlow's persistence context (without transaction) then database connection is not closed but at the same time is not reused later - i.e. it's just lost. This problem initially appeared in working project and I was able to reproduce it in small test project (attached). 

About sample. 
This project is based on booking-faces example. The main changes were done in {{webflow-config.xml}} (added {{jpaFlowExecutionListener}}), {{data-access-config.xml}} (using MySQL and tomcat-jdbc connection pool (original application with this problem used DBCP pool)) and {{main-flow.xml}} (greatly simplified). Also a new entity, {{Suite}}, was added as one-to-many relation to {{Hotel}} in order to add lazy initialization. On start of the main flow a {{Hotel}} instance is loaded using transaction method from service and then its lazy relation is initialized using WebFlow's entity manager.

How to reproduce problem. 
Deploy and start application (also start mysql server with {{booking_faces}} database). On start page click "Start your Spring Travel experience". That's it, one connection is leaked (this was checked using a heap dump). Now click on top Spring logo at the top to return to main page. Do the same two more times. Now when you'll click on start link for the forth time (maxActive connections for the pool is set to 3) an exception will pop up:

{noformat} 

This issue is basically the same as SWF-1210 (was not sure whether I should just comment there?). Rossen Stoyanchev commented: ??JPA does not provide a configurable connection release mode and providers should always eagerly release JDBC connections??. Indeed, setting {{hibernate.connection.release_mode}} to {{after_statement}} resolves described problem. Is this a supposed solution? If it is then it should probably be documented, because Hibernate's documentation suggests using {{after_transaction}} for non-JTA environments.

column96:
31/Jul/12 3:45 PM;staromeste;I had the same problem, but setting _hibernate.connection.release_mode_ to _after_transaction_ seems to have fixed it. The connection release mode was set to _on_close_ by default.
Reading the Hibernate documentation I found out that when set to _on_close_ the connection should be closed when the session is closed or disconnected. And indeed it is closed just after the view is rendered, but if there is some lazy loaded collection hibernate asks for a new connection to load the collection and then it fails to close it!
I am wondering if I'm leaking the session instead of the connection now...

column1: LockTimeoutException occurring for a Single request transaction
column42:
In the production environment, we have been facing a lot of LockTimeoutException: Unable to acquire conversation lock after 30 seconds. We have already tried increasing the time out value to 60 seconds but it doesn't seem to help.The basic problem is we are unable to identify why actually the lock is occurring. There are few case we have found as application issue and we have fixed those. But some of them it is not at all clear why the lock is happening,when there is a single request to the application server. Also, it some times happen on accessing the home page itself. 

Is there a way to put a identify the activity for which lock has been put in place ?


I have already referred to below listed jira for the this issue.
Related JIRA:
https://jira.springsource.org/browse/SWF-1059 
https://jira.springsource.org/browse/SWF-1107 
https://jira.springsource.org/browse/SWF-1213

column1: When view has a parent, inherited global transitions does not work
column42:
When view has a parent (as shown in testView below), inherited global transitions does not work in this view.

abstractFlow.xml:
{code}
<flow>
  <global-transitions>
    <transition on="sth" to="sthElse" />
  </global-transitions>
</flow>
{code}

specificFlow.xml:
{code}
<flow parent="abstractFlow">
  <view-state id="testView" parent="pathToThirdFlow#otherView" />
</flow>
{code}

thirdFlow.xml
{code}
<flow>
   <view-state id="otherView" />
</flow>
{code}

column1: SWF JSF2 Bound UI Components loosing state
column42:
When using a UI component value binding such as {noformat}<h:inputText binding="#{facesRequestScopedBean.component}" />{noformat} the state is lost when a validation error occurs for another input on the same form.

Note we are using a JSF managed request scoped bean as the component tree can't be serialised and stored in a flow bean.  Even though the bean is request scoped,  SWF is creating new instances within the lifecycle of a single request.  

This could be related to {{JsfView.getUserEventState()}} returning null instead of the ViewRoot when JSF2 is in use.

This could be considered a limitation of combining SWF with JSF2 rather than a bug but I haven't come across any mention of this problem on the forums or Jira.

column1: view-state "redirect" is has "true" semantics by default, and not "false" semantics as specified by documentation
column91:
05/Mar/12 10:40 AM;rstoya05-aop;bq. When unspecified fall back to the behaviour as is (check ajax and embedded, then check flow execution attribute). When true, perform execution redirect, when false not.

Isn't that exactly the current behavior of shouldRedirect()? If the redirect flag is specified it is used, true or false. If unspecified, the remaining logic takes place.

The only thing I see is to update the schema documentation to discuss alwaysRedirectOnPause and other settings that define the default behavior.

column1: Object validation error not binding to error in taglib.
column42:
Using the form taglib "http://www.springframework.org/tags/form" I can display
object validation errors in Spring MVC with

   <form:errors/>

i.e. with no path element.

When used with Webflow, this no longer works.

Using this tag causes getGlobalErrors() to be called.

Spring webflow's implementation of this method in BindingModel looks for a Message with a status of null.
However object validation errors created with Hibernate Validator hava a status of "" and are not matched.

column1: Accessing a local variable in a JSF view resolves to flowScope variable instead.
column42:
I was developing an application which manages a list of subjects, the main entry point flow renders a list of subjects and the user is able to view and edit subjects.

The JSF contained the following fragment:-

{code:xml}
<p:dataTable var="subject" value="#{subjects}">
    <f:facet name="header">
        Subjects
    </f:facet>
    ...
</p:dataTable>
{code}

The flow definitions are follows:

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">
	
	<!-- the main entry state for the subject flow -->
	<view-state id="index">
		<on-render>
			<set name="flowScope.subjects" value="subjectBean.findAll()" />
		</on-render>

		<!-- view a subject -->
		<transition on="view" to="view">
			<set name="flowScope.subject" value="subjectBean.find(requestParameters.id)" />
		</transition>

		<!-- create a subject -->
		<transition on="create" to="edit">
			<set name="flowScope.subject" value="subjectBean.create()" />
		</transition>

		<!-- edit a subject -->
		<transition on="edit" to="edit">
			<set name="flowScope.subject" value="subjectBean.find(requestParameters.id)" />
		</transition>

	</view-state>

	<!-- view subject state -->
	<view-state id="view" />

	<!-- edit subject state -->
	<view-state id="edit" />

	<end-state id="finish" />

</flow>
{code}

When I enter the flow a list of subjects is correctly populated on the screen. However, if I select a particular subject and then hit the back button, the list contains the name of the selected subject. This is occurring because my flow is using the flowScope variable "subject" and my view is also using a variable called "subject" (the dataGrid var attribute), the resolver is oddly resolving the value to the flowScope variable in the page and not local var variable which dataGrid should have created.
column43: Windows x64 Ultimate, Tomcat 7.0.23, JDK 1.6, Spring Web Flow - 2.3.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT (25-JAN-2012), Mojarra - 2.0.6
column91: 26/Jan/12 6:53 AM;rstoya05-aop;Web Flow does resolve variables through a scope searching algorithm. Whatever the behavior of that algorithm you effectively have two variables with the same name. I would recommend that you resolve the ambiguity explicitly by using different variable names.
column92:
26/Jan/12 7:03 AM;arshadm;That is the solution I have adopted, by using _subject in that particular view. But I assume there is a bug in the scope search algorithm, unless JSF is placing the variable in the wrong scope itself. 

The algorithm I believe searches in the following order request, flash, view, flow, and conversation scope. I have nothing in conversation scope, so I don't see how it's finding the wrong version of "subject", because it searches for flow last.
column93:
26/Jan/12 9:07 AM;rstoya05-aop;bq. The algorithm I believe searches in the following order request, flash, view, flow, and conversation scope.

These are Web Flow-specific scopes. The resolver for JSF-managed beans is ordered after the resolver for Web Flow scopes, this is by design.

column1: SecurityFlowExecutionListener not compatible with SpEL expressions in Spring Security 3
column42:
When SecurityFlowExecutionListener is supplied with an AccessDecisionManager, the authorization decision is left over to the AccessDecisionManager.
However, when using Spring Security with SpEL (<security:http use-expressions="true">) a WebExpressionVoter is registered with the AccessDecisionManager.
At the moment, this AccessDecisionVoter is generified and explicitly wants a FilterInvocation as parameter.
The interface of AccessDecisionManager is not adjusted, and still takes Object as parameter (which is a bit strange).

public class WebExpressionVoter implements AccessDecisionVoter<FilterInvocation> {
    private SecurityExpressionHandler<FilterInvocation> expressionHandler = new DefaultWebSecurityExpressionHandler();

    public int vote(Authentication authentication, FilterInvocation fi, Collection<ConfigAttribute> attributes) {


What happens is that the SecurityFlowExecutionListener passes along a TransitionDefinition, FlowDefinition or StateDefinition to the AccessDecisionManager.
Which is legal, since its contract is Object.
In combination with the WebExpressionVoter this will result in a ClassCastException, as a FilterInvocation is expected.
With the RoleVoter there is no problem, as the type there is <Object>. The role voter also doesn't seem to do anything with the object by default.

Also, wiring in the AccessDecisionManager is a bit of a pain, since it is created by the Spring Security NS configiration and has no 'normal' bean id.
Maybe this could be solved by implemeting a PostProcessor or ApplicationContextAware.
(or it could be solved at Spring Security level making the AccessDecisionManager available under a normal bean name)

The easiest workaround I found at the moment is not to define the AccessDecisionManager, so that the "else" is used an a RoleVoter is created by the SecurityFlowExecutionListener.
This means that it is not possible to use SpEL in flow security.
At that point it is not possible to use 'fullyAuthenticated' or other advantages the SpEL way offers.

The other workaround is a custom SecurityFlowExecutionListener. 
I made a first effort to write something, that appears to be working, see attachment.
column91: 20/Jan/12 7:29 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for reporting. If you can put together a minimal project that demonstrates the issue that would be of great help. See these [instructions|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues#readme].
column92:
06/Sep/15 11:21 PM;neilmcguigan;Having same bug w Spring security 4.0.2.RELEASE and Web Flow 2.4.2.RELEASE

Created an AffirmativeBased AccessDecisionManager so I can use hierarchical roles. Set this on the SecurityFlowExecutionListener

Get ClassCastException: org.springframework.webflow.engine.Flow cannot be cast to org.springframework.security.web.FilterInvocation

column91: 14/Dec/11 6:23 AM;rstoya05-aop;Sandro, could you attach the results of running 'svn diff <path-to-Spring-Dojo.js>' or just plain diff on the file before and after the changes?
column92:
14/Dec/11 7:01 AM;sandro.roeder@googlemail.com;Hi here is the diff:
diff src/main/webapp/static-files/spring/Spring-Dojo.js.uncompressed.js src/main/webapp/js/Spring-Dojo-Cusom.js > diff_dojo.txt
column93:
14/Dec/11 7:14 AM;sandro.roeder@googlemail.com;Notes:
dojo.requireIf(this.widgetModule != null, this.widgetModule);

1.)
if you use just dojo.require(this.widgetModule) in a cdn environment, dojo scans all dependent files for dojo.require and executes them. In this case the var "this.widgetModule" is null and dojo throws an error and stops processing of declare.

2.)
In a cdn environment everything is loaded lazy and the require may not loaded the requested dojo source. Therefore I surrounded the followed lines with a "dojo.addOnLoad(function(){ ...} " to ensure the requested source is loaded.

I'm not a dojo specialist there may be a better solution. Due to this changes both versions (cdn and jar --> spring-js-resources-2.2.1.RELEASE.jar) are working.

column1: Incorrectly filled form is blank after submit when ajax="false" on commandbutton

29/Feb/12 12:43 PM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for the detailed analysis and the link to the JSF issue. The issue has been fixed by allowing the view root to survive the redirect.

Note that you can also control the redirect behavior for this case with the "redirect-in-same-state" flow execution attribute:

{code:xml}
<webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor">
	<webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
		<webflow:listener ref="facesContextListener"/>
	</webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
	<webflow:flow-execution-attributes>
		<webflow:redirect-in-same-state value="true"/>
	</webflow:flow-execution-attributes>
</webflow:flow-executor>

{code}

column1: The @ListenerFor annotation for PostRestoreStateEvent doesn't work with Spring Web Flow
column42:
The @ListenerFor annotation for PostRestoreStateEvent, as well as some other ones, doesn't work with Spring Web Flow.

I've tested the @ListenerFor annotation for a custom component in a modified Spring Web Flow sample application, and has found out that it works only for PostAddToViewEvent, but not for PostRestoreStateEvent, which I needed in the first place, and other events as well.

I've also tried to subscribe to the same events using the subscribeToEvent() method, but it works in the same way as the annotation - only for PostAddToViewEvent

To doublecheck my findings, I've tried the same component in a simple JSF application without Spring Web Flow, and the PostRestoreStateEvent and other ones (PreValidateEvent, PostValidateEvent) do get invoked, so this confirms that the problem is somehow introduced by using the Spring Web Flow.

I've attached both of my test projects:
- the modified SWF "booking-faces" sample, where the problem is reproducible;
- a simple application named "tmpCheck" without SWF, where PostRestoreState event does get fired properly.

Here are the changes that I've done to modify the original "booking-faces" SWF sample:
- Added a very simple one-class org.components.Label component, which uses the @ListenerFor annotation to get component system event notifications;
- Registered this component at faces-config.xml, and created the tags.taglib.xml file where the tag for this component is registered;
- Modified the enterSearchCriteria.xhtml page to use the new Label component, and added a test submit button to it.

Here's how the described bug can be reproduced in the "booking-faces" application attached to this request:
- Extract the project, build it with "mvn package", and deploy it;
- Go to http://localhost:8080/swf-booking-faces/spring/intro
- Click on the "Start your Spring Travel experience" link
- When the page has been loaded - click the "Submit" button. The Label component prints out its restoreState and processEvent invokations to the console, and in a properly working case we should have seen both the "method restoreState() invoked" message, and a message saying that processEvent for PostRestoreStateEvent has been invoked, but as you can see on the console, we don't receive the PostRestoreStateEvent here, and only PostAddToViewEvent is fired, which is a problem.

To test "tmpCheck", follow these steps:
- Extract, build and deploy the project;
- Go to http://localhost:8080/tmpCheck/index.faces
- Click on the "Submit" button. Now we can see both the restoreState method invokation notification, and two processEvent method invokations for PostAddToViewEvent and PostRestoreStateEvent, which is correct.

For future reference, it is preferable to use the [issues repository|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/readme] if possible rather than attaching them as zip files (there are a few good reasons listed there for that) but of course zip attachments are fine as well.
