column1: DefaultFlowUrlHandler does not strip jsessionid from request URL when resolving the flowID
column42:
When the client requests a flow with the JSESSIONID path parameter set:

/app/main;jsessionid=BF18D19ED62BB5F78E519018E618FB64?execution=e1s1

Webflow looks for a flow in the repository with ID:

main;jsessionid=BF18D19ED62BB5F78E519018E618FB64

Obviously, no such flow is registered and a 404 is returned. 
SWF should remove the jsessionid path param. 

(Aside: is it correct that it should then add the jsessionid to the flowExecutionUrl even if the request.isRequestedSessionIdFromCookie property is true??)
column91:
07/Oct/11 4:49 AM;pawilson;See:
https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=51833

Regarding the aside, the algorithm in DefaultFlowUrlHander#createFlowExecutionUrl seems wrong, shouldn't the JSESSIONID be added using HttpServletResponse#encodeURL? (Since this will not add the jsessionid if the session is Cookie based).
column92:
10/Oct/11 1:32 AM;pawilson;Also, I noticed that, in ServletExternalContext#getFlowExecutionUrl(..), response.encodeURL is being called on the flow URL, which causes the following to be rendered in my page:

/app/main%3Bjsessionid%3D4912B32AF919195D3C8E1309C7EA0431?execution=e1s4

Note that the '%3B' is used to delimit the path parameter, which is incorrect - causing the container to ignore it.
column93:
11/Oct/11 4:24 AM;pawilson;Relevant for the discussion:

 * requestURI = contextPath + servletPath + pathInfo
 * getContextURI will never be null (empty string for default context)
 * getContextURI will not return path parameters on Tomcat, but may on other containers
 * getServletPath may return null
 * getServletPath will not return path parameters on Tomcat, by may on other containers
 * getPathInfo may return path parameters (and may be null), however latest Tomcat 6/7 does not
 * getRequestURI will return path parameters on Tomcat 6.0.33 and (possibly) Tomcat 7.0.0 onwards
 * This affects 'getFlowId', whereby path parameters may be present in pathInfo
 * This affects 'createFlowExecutionUrl', where 'getRequestURI' is called
 * Since getServletPath may return null for mappings '/*', surely there's also a bug in 'createFlowDefinitionUrl'?
column94:
11/Oct/11 4:49 AM;pawilson;Tomcat discussion raised Servlet specification clarification request:

http://java.net/jira/browse/SERVLET_SPEC-18

Original expert group discussion:

https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25015
column95: 31/Oct/11 9:03 AM;rstoya05-aop;I'll consider this for 2.3.1
column96: 31/Oct/11 9:13 AM;pawilson;To summarize, Webflow uses 'getRequestURI' to determine the flow execution URL. This now contains path parameters such as ;jessionid=... The execution URL is then passed through 'HttpServletResponse#encodeURL', and so the path parameter gets encoded as %3Bjsessionid=... Subsequent requests do not work since the flow Id contains ;jsessionid.
column97: 31/Oct/11 9:33 AM;rstoya05-aop;Spring MVC uses UrlPathHelper.getRequestUri(..), which removes the jsessionid. We can either re-use that or do something similar.
column99:
31/Oct/11 10:05 AM;pawilson;My workaround constructs the request using:

 requestURI = contextPath + servletPath + pathInfo

I remove path params from each component as they're appended.
column100:
31/Oct/11 10:42 AM;rstoya05-aop;Yes, I believe jsessionid is appended to the path and not to any path segment. The servlet spec has an example of it and for what it's worth Spring MVC is pretty widely used across various containers. 

That said removing everything after the first ";" is also not ideal since it discards any other matrix params that may have been submitted. It's something we'll need to address as part of matrix param support SPR-5499.

bq. request.setRequestURI("/foo/bar?list=a%3Bb%3Bc");

The query string shouldn't matter. UrlPathHelper.getRequestURI() considers what is returned by request.getRequestURI(), which does not include the query.
column101:
01/Nov/11 2:26 AM;pawilson;Okay - fair enough. UrlPathHelper seems a good choice then, both now and in the future. 

From my discussions on users@tomcat it seems that the change to getRequestURI was introduced in Tomcat 6.0.33, however I was seeing issues on 6.0.29, so I'm not 100% confident that I've got a full picture of the situation. I'll have chance later in the week to do some testing against different versions of Tomcat with the DefaultFlowUrlHandler implementation.
column102: 27/Feb/12 1:26 PM;rstoya05-aop;I wasn't able to reproduce the issue with Tomcat 6. Please have a look at [the project|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues/tree/master/SWF-1496] I created. I turned off cookie support in my browser, jsessionid appeared in the URL, but the flow worked fine. On the server side, in {{DefaultFlowUrlHandler.getFlowId(request)}}, the call to {{getServletPath()}} returns the path without the jsessionid. What am I missing?
column103: 28/Feb/12 3:33 PM;pawilson;What version of Tomcat 6 did you use?
column104: 28/Feb/12 4:39 PM;rstoya05-aop;I've tried with 6.0.26 as well as 7.0.23.
column105: 14/Mar/12 9:53 AM;rstoya05-aop;Postponing to allow more time to reproduce the issue.
column106: 15/Mar/12 3:43 AM;pawilson;Agreed - reading back it's probably going to be a bug in our client implementation rather than an issue with SWF. Wireshark shows the client encoding the ';' to '%3B' in subsequent requests, I'll reopen if further investigation shows an SWF bug.
column107: 15/Mar/12 5:25 AM;rstoya05-aop;Resolving for now but you can re-open it.

25/Feb/13 7:05 AM;bacsik;We have reproduced an equivalent issue where the Tomcat 6.0.33 getRequestURI returns a jsessionid in the path parameter, so our issue is:
- doing a session.invalidate in the on-start of a flow
- rendering a view-state, the second GET because of redirectOnPause=true yields something like context/flow.wf;jsession=oldSess;jsessionid=newSess?execution=e1s1
- above nasty url caused firefox to cancel the request because of an endless loop

column1: Embedded mode ignored for sub-flow sessions
column42:
In webflow reference it states that we can use <input name="mode" value="'embedded'"/> in a subflow definition to prevent the POST-REDIRECT-GET (e.g. in a popup). However this attribute is never verified by the implementation on subflows.

The only way to start a flow in embedded mode is to provide the ?mode=embedded request parameter at flow start. In this case, the whole flow will be in "embedded" mode, instead of only the required subflow.
column91: 15/Sep/11 1:10 AM;rstoya05-aop;I presume you've seen the [webflow-primefaces-showcase|https://src.springframework.org/svn/spring-samples/webflow-primefaces-showcase] project? It contains a [top-flow-with-embedded-subflow|https://src.springframework.org/svn/spring-samples/webflow-primefaces-showcase/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/flows/top-flow-with-embedded-subflow] example. Does the <input> attribute not work for you?
column92:
15/Sep/11 5:21 AM;yanaga;Hi Rossen,

I've seen each example available on the internet, and also the webflow-primefaces-showcase. The example in webflow-primefaces-showcase works because the parent flow is started with the request attribute ?mode=embedded (see the h:outputLink). You can remove the <input name="mode" value="'embedded'"/> in the flow.xml definition and it will keep working the same way (I've already tested it). That's because the attribute "mode" is only checked on flow start, and not on subflow start.

We should check the attribute "mode" and put it under an inner scope. Currently if I start the parent flow as "embedded" then ALL transitions will be done in embedded mode, and not only the subflow one.
column93: 15/Sep/11 6:03 AM;rstoya05-aop;Ok, I'll have a closer look. By the way there was another related issue (SWF-1459) that may have come into play at some point in your tests.
column94: 28/Feb/12 3:02 PM;rstoya05-aop;Modified title (was: FlowExecutionImpl only looks for attribute "mode" and value "embedded" at flow start: should also look on subflow start)
column95:
28/Feb/12 3:08 PM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for raising this issue. The embedded mode flag is now stored as a flow session attribute (as opposed to a flow execution attribute), which makes it independent of any parent flow session and the flow execution.

I used the above mentioned showcase to verify the change and have removed the model parameter in the output link.

column1: Issues during session replication - Flow object not injected/set properly in flow engine or possibility of flow object being null is not handled.
column43:
Os: Windows 2008 - 64 Bit
Software Platform: JBoss EAP 5.1.0, 
Java Version: Sun JRE 1.6
Spring Framework: 3.0.4
Spring WebFlow: 2.2.1
column91:
24/Jul/13 6:04 AM;aptesameer;Would appreciate if someone can comment on Dheepson's questions.

I have come across exact same issue but with tomcat6 and spring-webflow-2.3.1.RELEASE. 

My observation is as follows:
1. User initiates a web flow on tomcat instance A
2. Tomcat instance A replicates stuff getting added into session to instance B
3. Instance A goes down
4. User *has not continued* with web flow meanwhile. (May be he answered a telephone call)
5. Instance A comes up.
6. Instance B fails to serialize FlowSessionImpl as 'flow' variable is not yet initialised.

Note that if in step 4 user *continues* with web flow and causes a server trip then Instance B replicates information correctly to Instance A.

column1: MockViewFactoryCreator$MockView.getFlowEvent() doesn't give attributes to created Event
column42:
When running tests on a flow, it seems user can't mock an event with attributes, since MockViewFactoryCreator$MockView.getFlowEvent() doesn't give attributes to created Event (for exemple, to mock user input).
Worse, it seems user can't use another ViewFactoryCreator since :
* MockViewFactoryCreator.createMockView() is called from TestFlowBuilderServicesFactory.getServices(), which is static and hence can't be overloaded
* TestFlowBuilderServicesFactory.getServices() is called from MockFlowBuilderContext constructor, which could be sort of overloaded, but
* MockFlowBuilderContext is instanciated statically (not using a factory) in AbstractExternalizedFlowExecutionTests.buildFlow(), which is final.

So I could not figure out a workaround allowing me to mock an event with attributes. I may have searched the wrong places, but if it's the case I would greatly appreciate any help.
column91:
15/Aug/11 1:07 AM;rstoya05-aop;What about using the configureFlowBuilderContext hook in AbstractExternalizedFlowExecutionTests? You can get access to the FlowBuilderServices and the ViewFactoryCreator from there:

builderContext.getFlowBuilderServices().setViewFactoryCreator(...);
column92:
17/Aug/11 8:43 AM;fenrhil;Right, that worked! Although I had to re-implement (copy-paste) the MockViewFactoryCreator$MockView class entirely, since MockViewFactoryCreator has package visibility.
Anyway, thanks a lot for the tip, and sorry for that useless issue. I tried to close it (mark it as "unrelevant", or close it, or something like that), but it seems I can't.

column1: LazyInitializationException with SWF+JPA+JSF 2.0
column42:
OpenSessionInView filters nor interceptors doesn't work correctly with lazy collections in swf jsf 2 environment.

Try to create lazy reference to any entity in booking-faces and try to envoke it from xhtml page:
#{controller.entity.lazyEntity}

you will get hibernate LazyInitializationException.

column1: No Programmer Error Message when 2 actions are configured in an action state
column42:
When more than one action is configured into the same action state, the second action is not executed, resulting in failures further down the web-flow food chain.

{code:xml}
    <action-state id="doSomething">
        <set name="flowScope.name" value="service.findName(someValue)"/>
        <set name="flowScope.address" value="service.findAddress(someotherValue)"/>
        <transition to="doSomethingElse"/>
    </action-state>
{code}

We would like to see the typical Programmer Error when this happens, which would be consistent with how you handle no set actions being configured.

We do have the following work-around.
{code:xml}
    <action-state id="doSomething">
        <on-entry>
             <set name="flowScope.name" value="service.findName(someValue)"/>
        </on-entry>
        <set name="flowScope.address" value="service.findAddress(someotherValue)"/>
        <transition to="doSomethingElse"/>
    </action-state>
{code}
column91: 25/Jul/11 9:11 AM;bkiefer;It would also be acceptable to be able to configure multiple sets. Just didn't want to rule that one out...
column92:
29/Feb/12 2:06 PM;rstoya05-aop;This is actually expected behavior. In an action state the outcome of each action is checked to see if there is a matching transition and if there is one, it is executed regardless of whether there are more actions or not. This is documented in [the section|http://static.springsource.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.3.x/reference/htmlsingle/spring-webflow-reference.html#action-state] on Action states in the reference docs. In your case the transition does not define an on="" event and hence it is executed after the first action.

One thing you can do, in your example is add an on clause that evaluates to true when the address is present and also change to evaluate because otherwise the event generated from set is always the same (i.e. "success"):

{code:xml}
<evaluate result="flowScope.name" expression="service.findName(someValue)"/>
<evaluate result="flowScope.address" expression="service.findAddress(someotherValue)"/>
<transition on="#{flowScope.address}" to="view" />
{code}

column1: Fileupload doesn't work in Richfaces 4.0.0 Final
column42:
Hi,

Richfaces fileupload doesn't work in Spring Web Flow 2.3.0. After selecting a file and pressing the "Upload" button a "Server error" message shows up.
This error message originates from an exception in Richfaces method MultipartRequest.initialize() and states 
"org.richfaces.exception.FileUploadException: The request was rejected because no multipart boundary was found".
It seems like MultipartRequest.initialize() is passed twice??? The FileUploadException occurs in the second pass.
Outside Spring Web Flow Richfaces fileupload works fine.

Regards
Gerhard Hofmann
column43: Spring 3.0.5, Spring Web Flow 2.3.0, Richfaces 4.0.0 Final
column91: 12/Jul/11 1:41 AM;rstoya05-aop;Do you have a MultipartResolver configured in your Spring MVC configuration? If so the DispatcherServlet will detect and process multipart requests possibly interfering with RichFaces.
column92: 12/Jul/11 2:23 AM;ghofmann;No, I haven't.
column93:
12/Jul/11 4:31 AM;rstoya05-aop;Ok so no interference from there. Something else to confirm is that you're not using Servlet 3.0 with multipart-config enabled. Probably not the case but worth verifying.

It would be very helpful if you could verify if MultipartRequest.initialize() is indeed called twice by placing a breakpoint and attaching the stack traces for each call. It might also help to post a question on the richfaces forum. Even though it works without Web Flow, the error occurs in RichFaces and understanding what can cause it would help to resolve it more quickly.

column97: 14/Jul/11 12:55 AM;rstoya05-aop;In the log file there are two places marked "upload button pressed". I'm wondering if both of the above two stack traces occur each time a button is pressed. That would be puzzling since as far as I can see in the log, the web flow lifecycle occurs only once after the button is pressed. The stack traces above lead me to believe that the FlowFacesContextLifecycleListener.requestSubmitted() was somehow called twice for a single click, which would be odd.
column98:
14/Jul/11 3:58 AM;ghofmann;Indeed, you get the two above stack traces each time the 'upload' button is pressed.
It looks like that the multipart request is handled twice within FlowFacesContext.newInstance(). At first handled by FacesContextFactoryImpl.getFacesContext() and once again by the constructor of Jsf2FlowFacesContext:   

first call 
MultipartRequest.initialize() line: 329

FlowFacesContext.newInstance(RequestContext, Lifecycle) line: 85 
...
column99:
14/Jul/11 7:08 AM;rstoya05-aop;Ok I see. We create the "default" FacesContext first and then wrap it with an instance of FlowFacesContext (or in this case Jsf2FlowFacesContext). That causes PartialViewContext to be created twice. Probably not an issue most of the times except with multipart requests, which should be parsed just once. The first access to PartialViewContextis in ExceptionHandlerFactoryImpl, which makes a call to facesContext.getPartialViewContext() and the second in Jsf2FlowFacesContext, which creates the PartialViewContext in order to provide with an instance to itself. 

I don't see immediately what we can do here other than try to change the order of creation so that Jsf2FlowFacesContext itself creates the "default" FacesContext only after it has set itself as the current thread local instance and has also created the PartialViewContext. 

There may be an option to delay the parsing of the request on the RichFaces side but I haven't looked at the source code.

column1: Partial Rendering problem with Richfaces 4
column42:
Partial rendering problem when integrating Web Flow with Richfaces 4. As described here (http://community.jboss.org/message/610573#610573) , it appears FlowPartialViewContext.getRenderIds() returns an immutable collection , but reference states this collection should be mutable : /** *

Return a * Collection of client identifiers from the current request * with the request parameter name {@link #PARTIAL_RENDER_PARAM_NAME}. * If there is no such request parameter, return an empty Collection. * These client identifiers are used to identify components that * will be processed during the render phase of the * request processing lifecycle. The returned Collection is * mutable.

* * @throws IllegalStateException if this method is called after * this instance has been released * * @since 2.0 */ public abstract Collection getRenderIds();

column1: messageSource bean defined in application context configuration file is never used by Spring Web Flow
column91:
19/May/11 1:36 PM;art;Later I found that the chain to the parent's messageSource is actually made at initMessageSource method (what will be called by refresh method) of org.springframework.context.support.AbstractApplicationContext. 
And the initMessageSource method seems to have been called later than the registerMessageSource method in down the time according to the log files I have.
Thereby, even the chain to the parent messageResource bean is established at the initMessageSource method, since the ReloadableResourceBundleMessageSource object is created, configured and assigned as messageSource bean in flowContext as I mentioned in the bug, as long as message.properties files resides each flow directory as recommended, it won't delegate to the parent messageSource bean what have been defined in application context configuration file (applicationContext.xml.)
column92: 29/Jul/11 3:04 AM;cpesch;I found your monolog at http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?108926-i18n-ReloadableResourceBundleMessageSource-problem-with-UTF-8-resources-on-Web-Flow on my way to set fallbackToSystemLocale for the MessageSource to false. It seems to be impossible to do this and this is really annoying if your Locale.getDefault() is not "en" but your default language is "en".
column93:
30/Mar/14 1:40 PM;rstoya05-aop;bq. As you see that there isn't the pathway to negotiate the beanFactory in parent context here. 

This isn't quite so. The ApplicationContext created in {{createFlowApplicationContext}} is passed to the protected method {{registerFlowBeans}} which can register a messageSource. It is true that there is no way to provide a custom FlowBuilder. The original intent for this method appears to be on testing support side. 

Using the booking-mvc sample, I add {{"/WEB-INF/messages.properties"}} and create a {{ReloadableResourceBundleMessageSource}} with basename set to {{"/WEB-INF/messages"}}. This works as expected. If the flow-local resource bundle {{"/WEB-INF/hotels/booking/messages.properties"}} does not contain a code, the one from {{"/WEB-INF/messages"}} is used.

As mentioned above, {{AbstractApplicationContext.initMessageSource}} sets up a hierarchy of MessageSource's so the messageSource bean defined in the web application context is used. What am I missing?

If anyone has any suggestions, otherwise I see nothing further to do here.

column1: view state transition using EL expression and the validation attribute is ignored
column42:
<view-state id="test" view="test" model="testForm">
  <transition on="#{T(my.super.package.TestFormEvent).FETCH_STUFF.getValue()}" validate="false">
    <evaluate expression="...." />
    <render fragments="...." />
  </transition>

  <transition on="#{T(my.super.package.TestFormEvent).SAVE.getValue()}" to="...">
    <evaluate expression="...." />
  </transition>
</view-state>

If I'm using an EL expression for the transition 'on' attribute; the 'validate' attribute is ignored and the model is validated!

I've got a Java Enum for my different transition events to be able to handle nicely different validation based on a specific transition.

public void validate(ValidationContext validationContext) {
		
  switch (TestFormEvent.find(validationContext.getUserEvent())) {
    case SAVE:
       // do some validations on top of the JSR 303
       break;
    case UPDATE_STUFF:
       // do some different validation
       break;
  }
}

The different type of validations is to manage my child AJAX forms.

The work around for this issue; is to clear the message context on my FETCH_STUFF event. It'll be far better if SWF handles correctly the transition parsing so the validation is not processed.
column91: 01/Apr/11 5:40 AM;rstoya05-aop;Hm, I don't see why the expression on the transition would cause validation to take place. What do you mean by "the model is validated"? Is it that the transition doesn't take place or that Web Flow invokes a validation method?
column92:
01/Apr/11 6:05 AM;cedricb;basically the validation is NOT in-forced with :
<transition on="fetchStuff" validate="false">

...but it's in-forced if I'm using EL :
<transition on="#{T(my.super.package.TestFormEvent).FETCH_STUFF.getValue()}" validate="false">


It looks like the attribute is not parsed or ignored, I don't know that's the end result... :-)
column93:
04/Apr/11 1:44 AM;rstoya05-aop;If you put a break in AbstractMvcView.shouldValidate(..) on line 525, I suspect you'll find out that checking the flag isn't the problem. That's why I'm still wondering what you mean by "the model is validated"? 

From some of your other comments above it sounds like you're invoking your own validation. If you're registering errors, that will prevent a transition and will as a result cause the flow to remain in the same view state -- because there are errors that have been raised. That has nothing to do with the validate flag, which controls whether Web Flow invokes validation methods or not.
column94:
04/Apr/11 5:59 AM;cedricb;Do you want a test case? :-)

I can only do my own validation if the "validate" method is called... but if the flag is ignored then the validation is called every time...

What I meant by "model" is my form object which contains the different fields. That class is using the JSR 303 and defines an additional "validate" method. This is just standard as described in the documentation.

My custom validating for my AJAX form is just another level of validation, that's why I'm using an Emum for the different transition values. So I can do specific validations based on the transition. Anyway the problem is not there... :-)

I haven't done any debugging of the Spring WebFlow... Have you tried to add an EL expression like the above for a view transition?

column1: Webflow Configuration Documentation Shows Old Version of XSD
column42:
The reference guide references an old version of the XSD for configuring webflow:

http://static.springsource.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.3.x/reference/html/ch10s02.html

should read:

http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow-config/spring-webflow-config-2.3.xsd

This may cause confusion for those following the reference and hoping to take advantage of the new validator facility in SWF 2.3.0.
column91: 18/Mar/11 2:34 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for point out. We do have an issue to track this. See SWF-1456.

column1: JpaFlowExecutionListener shouldn't assume that EntityManager is Serializable
column42:
JpaFlowExecutionListener stores EntityManager into Flow Scope, assuming it will be Serializable (each object stored into this scope should be Serializable, according to the documentation). This assumption is wrong, EntityManager doesn't extend Serializable, and doesn't have to implement this interface. 

Using EclipseLink 2.2 I'm getting following exception in this case:

org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SnapshotCreationException: Could not serialize flow execution; make sure all objects stored in flow or flash scope are serializable
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.<init>(SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.java:75)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshotFactory.createSnapshot(SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshotFactory.java:70)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.AbstractSnapshottingFlowExecutionRepository.snapshot(AbstractSnapshottingFlowExecutionRepository.java:75)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.impl.DefaultFlowExecutionRepository.putFlowExecution(DefaultFlowExecutionRepository.java:126)
	org.springframework.webflow.executor.FlowExecutorImpl.launchExecution(FlowExecutorImpl.java:145)
	org.springframework.webflow.mvc.servlet.FlowHandlerAdapter.handle(FlowHandlerAdapter.java:193)
	org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doDispatch(DispatcherServlet.java:790)
...
java.io.NotSerializableException: org.eclipse.persistence.internal.jpa.EntityManagerImpl
	java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject0(ObjectOutputStream.java:1164)
	java.io.ObjectOutputStream.defaultWriteFields(ObjectOutputStream.java:1518)
	java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeSerialData(ObjectOutputStream.java:1483)
	java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeOrdinaryObject(ObjectOutputStream.java:1400)
...
	java.util.HashMap.writeObject(HashMap.java:1001)
...
org.springframework.webflow.core.collection.LocalAttributeMap.writeObject(LocalAttributeMap.java:327)
	sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
...
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowSessionImpl.writeExternal(FlowSessionImpl.java:154)
...
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImpl.writeExternal(FlowExecutionImpl.java:312)
...
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.serialize(SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.java:173)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.<init>(SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshot.java:70)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshotFactory.createSnapshot(SerializedFlowExecutionSnapshotFactory.java:70)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.AbstractSnapshottingFlowExecutionRepository.snapshot(AbstractSnapshottingFlowExecutionRepository.java:75)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.impl.DefaultFlowExecutionRepository.putFlowExecution(DefaultFlowExecutionRepository.java:126)
	org.springframework.webflow.executor.FlowExecutorImpl.launchExecution(FlowExecutorImpl.java:145)
	org.springframework.webflow.mvc.servlet.FlowHandlerAdapter.handle(FlowHandlerAdapter.java:193)
	org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doDispatch(DispatcherServlet.java:790)
column43: Tomcat 5, Web Application build using Spring Framework 3.0.5 and Spring Webflow 2.3.0, with EclipseLink 2.2.0 as persistence provider
column91:
17/Mar/11 12:53 AM;vardlokkur;It looks like there is some thread related to this issue in forum - http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=59443 - Keith wrote in it: "I would bring this up with the EclipseLink team--perhaps they have this capability factored into their feature roadmap" - This issue has nothing to do with the EclipseLink :) - If you demand from the developers to store only Serializable objects to the Flow Scope you have to follow this guidance yourself ;) Today we have problem with EclipseLink, tomorrow we will encounter the same with OpenJPA, or any other JPA provider you can imagine (well, except the Hibernate maybe ;) ) 

In short: The reason of this issue is wrong assumption that all implementations of EntityManager should be Serializable, while they don't have to.
column92: 17/Mar/11 2:31 AM;rstoya05-aop;Lowering the priority since you have the option of merging your flow variables with EntityManager rather than using the persistence-context feature.
column93:
07/Jan/12 7:29 AM;koen.serneels;Rossen: as I understand it correctly, the <persistence-context> feature is broken if the provider does not offer Serializable EntityManger.
What do you mean with "you have the option of merging your flow variables with EntityManager" ? 
Is this an alternative somehow? Can you explain this in more detail please with maybe a small example?

I'm facing the same problem with Hibernate 4.0 final and using the Spring embedded database:
Caused by: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.springframework.jdbc.datasource.embedded.EmbeddedDatabaseFactory$EmbeddedDataSourceProxy

As far as I can see, the EmbeddedDatabase is a DataSource, so the EntityManager is trying to serialize a reference to a DataSource, which should be rather transient instead...
column94:
09/Jan/12 7:00 AM;rstoya05-aop;Koen, the flow managed PersistenceContext is indeed stored with other flow-scoped data and by default is expected to be serializable. It makes it easy to implement a "long conversation". However, I've personally ran into cases where persistence provider specific classes are not serializable, which means you can't use the feature. It is possible to turn off snapshotting by setting max-execution-snapshots=0 but that also effectively disables the back button.

The alternative to not using a flow managed PersistenceContext is to obtain and release an EntityManager instance on every request. Objects stored in flow or other scopes longer than request scope would need to be merged with the current EntityManager instance on the last step before being saved. 

That said the error you mention above is from a Spring class and maybe within our control to address. Helping to [reproduce the issue|https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-webflow-issues#Readme] would accelerate the process if this is important to you. Have you tried using a different database?

column1: Trinidad's CoreResponseStateManager can't restore the serialized view in a "redirect after post" request
column42:
In a "redirect after post" GET request CoreResponseStateManager._restoreSerializedView tries to restore the view but fails because the expected request parameter "javax.faces.ViewState" is missing (a NPE is thrown). I have tried to add "javax.faces.ViewState" by myself by overwriding FilenameFlowUrlHandler.createFlowExecutionUrl but then the GET request executes the use event again because org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfView.userEventQueued() returns true (and the request was interpreted as postBack - I don't know if that makes trouble in the GET request).

What is the correct way to give Trinidad a chance to restore the view but without interpreting the GET redirect request as the original POST request?

column1: FlowExecutionFactory creates FlowExecution instances with same map of attributes
column91:
25/Nov/11 4:53 AM;henning.scholz;Hi Rossen,

I'm sorry but your fix does not work as the underlying Map of the AttributesMap is still shared between the FlowExecutionFactory and the FlowExecution instances. A good test case is the embedded mode, which once set applies to all flow executions. I can't reopen this issue though. I will attach a patch shortly.

Yours Henning
column92: 25/Nov/11 5:08 AM;henning.scholz;A patch in which the factory creates actually new maps.
column93: 07/Dec/11 1:37 AM;henning.scholz;The same problem occurs during the restoreFlowExecution() method. I'll attach another patch which fixes this issue too.
column94: 07/Dec/11 1:47 AM;henning.scholz;This fixes the issue in a minimal invasive way. For webflow 3 I'd personally add a putAllExecutionAttributes method into the FlowExecutionImpl, if this is still needed.
column95:
28/Feb/12 3:22 PM;rstoya05-aop;@Henning, you are absolutely correct that the flow execution attribute map was still being shared. That said as you found out from the additional fix in restoreFlowExecution the flow execution attributes get set to the content of the global map each time the flow is restored, which means any other attribute stored in the mean time would not survive a redirect. 

I'm resolving this as Won't Fix for now since a different solution was needed for the embedded mode flag anyway (see SWF-1493). The ticket can be re-opened however if there is another case that requires it.

column1: Method 'shouldValidate' should be protected in AbstractMvcView
column42: The method org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.AbstractMvcView#shouldValidate(,) should be qualified as 'protected' to offer subclasses the ability to override the default validation behaviour.
column91: 11/Mar/11 3:36 AM;pawilson;Just to add to the description, I've written my own view implementation extending from AbstractMvcView, but model validation doesn't make any sense for my scenario since page re-rendering isn't an option. Hence, I don't want applications to have to always suppress validation for each transition, and doing that at the view level makes sense. The restriction on the 'shouldValidate' method as private makes this trickier that it should be.
column92: 14/Mar/11 3:19 AM;rstoya05-aop;Validation can prevent a transition causing the flow to re-render the same view. Isn't this generally necessary? Or to put it differently when would validation occur otherwise?
column93:
14/Mar/11 4:12 AM;pawilson;My view technology is not web-related and rerendering is not technically feasible in my case. Validation is taken care of before the transition is triggered via 'ajax-style' requests with special event ids that I intercept within my custom view implementation. I can perform JSR303 validation *before* the postback actually occurs.

This becomes a larger issue because JSR303 validation is being invoked automatically for each transition. Prior to this validation is more explicit since certain methods have to be written with special names for validation to occur. So now I need to explicitly suppress validation within the view, but I cannot override 'shouldValidate'.
column94:
15/Mar/11 3:46 AM;rstoya05-aop;JSR-303 validation isn't that automatic. It has to be explicitly enabled by plugging in a LocalValidatorFactoryBean through the flow-builder-services config element. This is not any more automatic than writing validation methods that follow conventions.

It sounds like you do perform validation. Hence I don't follow why model validation doesn't make any sense in your scenario? The main consequence of validation is that the flow remains in the same view. Is that what isn't appropriate for your scenario? If you need to process the event regardless of validation errors why not override AbstractMvcView.hasFlowEvent()?
column95:
15/Mar/11 6:01 AM;pawilson;True, but an AbstractMvcView implementation that wants to do its own validation is likely to retrieve its Validator instance via the flow-builder-services mechanism anyway. So if it wants to bypass webflow's transition validation step, it's going to have to suppress webflow from doing so via some other mechanism. Overriding 'shouldValidate' is the natural point to do this for me. 

In my scenario, all the validation is done before the page submit via something that appears like AJAX (but isn't). This is handled by overriding processUserEvent() as well as hasFlowEvent(), writing the response directly to the response writer and then setting 'recordResponseComplete()' on the external context. Once the user has entered all their information and it's been validated (successfully or not), a flow event it triggered. If the information could *not* be validated, a 'not_validated' style event will be raised in webflow. In either case, I don't want webflow to validate the model on these events because it is either unnecessary or because it will trigger a page reload which makes absolutely no sense for my scenario. 

All I need to do is override 'shouldValidate' but I can't. Look at the comment on that method: "Subclasses may override."
column96:
16/Mar/11 2:24 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for elaborating. I am still not sure what you mean by model validation triggering a page reload. Validation only prevents a transition from taking place and that is orthogonal to view rendering. In other words if model validation is turned off you're still in a view and depending on what the view does there is rendering.

I suppose we can add a hook for sub-classes to get invoked from shouldValidate() but only after the validate flag check. A complete override of shouldValidate() would otherwise make the validate flag useless and that doesn't seem ideal even if it fits in your scenario. Would that meet you needs?
column97:
16/Mar/11 5:42 AM;pawilson;Sorry, I may have misunderstood how webflow deals with validation errors. My understanding was that if a validation error occurred, the transition would not execute, and webflow would rerender the view (forward to JSTLView in my case) with the messageContext available to display error messages. In other words it's like a transition action returning false (from the docs): 

"If an error result occurs, the view will re-render and should display an appropriate message to the user" 

So if the event id matches a transition, but validation fails what happens? The documentation isn't clear from what I can see. If there is some way that the developer could guide transitions based upon the violations present in the message context, that would be useful for my scenario.
column98:
16/Mar/11 6:47 AM;rstoya05-aop;If validation fails then AbstractMvcView.hasFlowEvent() returns false (i.e. state not exited) and that is then handled in ViewState.resume. Generally it results in either rendering or redirecting. 

I presume you don't want either of those but consider also what happens on successful validation. AbstractMvcView.hasFlowEvent() returns true which results in a transition to the next view state and results in rendering. I.e. whether you remain in the same view state or transition to the next, a call to View.render() will result. It's what every view state does.
column99:
16/Mar/11 7:16 AM;pawilson;If validation is successful a transition to a *new* view will occur, which is fine. But I should already know before submit whether or not the binding values are valid, so I really just want to turn off webflow validation (although still get the JSR303 validator from the flow-builder-services). 

Thanks for your attention to my scenario by the way; it's very much an edge case!

column1: Flow Url and snapshots issue
column42:
I have two flows defined, flowA and flowB. I would typically start these by using the URL's

.../flowA which results in .../flowA?execution=1&snapshot=1
etc.

if I continue with flowA for example to a page midway through the flow so that the snapshots are /flowA?execution=1&snapshot=6 then change the URL to access flow B with the same parameters. /flowB?execution=1&snapshot=6 or any other number within the range of 1 to current active flow snapshot I am actually still within flowA's pages and can carry on executing as if the URL still contained flowA.

I believe it would be beneficial to ensure that an exception such as SnapshotNotFoundException was thrown in the above circumstance. So if a flow already exists then the url needs to be checked to look at which flow the user is trying to access.
column91: 01/Mar/11 7:29 AM;gregsimons;Please refer to the Spring forum reference for a complete description of the reason for raising this issue. I have included a few sample scenario's where I believe this could arise.

column1: Spring JS 2.X.X Internet Explorer ajax redirect bug
column42:
Hi there,

I think that I've come across an bug related to Internet Explorer catching when using ajax submit calls.

This is the scenario:

1.- I've a form and decorate it like this:

Code:

<script type="text/javascript">
Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.AjaxEventDecoration({
	elementId:"boton${project.id}",
	event:"onclick",
	formId:"projForm${project.id}",
	params: {fragments:"bookingsTable"}
}));
</script>

2.- I process this ajax call in the Controller and redirect it to another handler in the same controller this way:

Code:

return "redirect:projects";

3.- The loadForm handler reloads the list of objects shown on the page and initializes de backing bean for the form.

When using firefox the callings made are:
a) post
b) get
So everything is ok

However in IE(8): After the post:
Spring-Dojo.js
(Spring.AjaxEventDecoration|submit) -> (Spring.RemotingHandlerFollowing|submitForm) ->

(Spring.RemotingHandlerFollowing|submitForm|handle Response)->
It tries to perform the redirect:
Code:

if (location == window.location) {
Spring.remoting.getResource(location, ioArgs.args.content, false);
}

->(Spring.RemotingHandler|getResource)->
Code:

dojo.xhrGet({
	url: resourceUri,
	content: params,
	handleAs: "text",
	headers: {"Accept" : "text/html;type=ajax"},
	load: this.handleResponse,
	error: this.handleError,
	modal: modal
});

At this point, when executing dojo.xhrGet, you realize that, as you are asking for a redirect to the same page, no calls are made because IE caches the page.

A workaround for this is having preventCache:true:

Code:

dojo.xhrGet({
	url: resourceUri,
	content: params,
	handleAs: "text",
	preventCache: true,
	headers: {"Accept" : "text/html;type=ajax"},
	load: this.handleResponse,
	error: this.handleError,
	modal: modal
});

This way, IE actually makes the second call reloading the page.

I'm attatching the files Spring-Dojo.js and Spring-Dojo.js.uncompressed.js that solve this issue. They are form version 2.1.1.RELEASE

column1: flowRedirect doesn't encode non-ascii characters correctly
column42:
When I do a flowRedirect and add a GET parameter with a non-ascii character, the parameter arrives badly encoded (or decoded) at the destination flow.

Example:
{code:xml}  <end-state id="finish" view="flowRedirect:newflow?param=#{criteria}" />
{code}

When #{criteria} resolves as "ü", it arrives at flow "newflow" as 2 different characters.

The following works correctly:

{code:xml}  <end-state id="finish" view="externalRedirect:contextRelative:/spring/newflow?param=#{criteria}" />
{code}

column1: Conversion fails for genric typed class
column42:
I have a class implementing a generic Entity<T extends Serializable>. The interface is defining a setId(T):void and a getId():T method. On the implementing class I define T as being a Long (giving setId(Long):void and getId():Long). I have an error whenever there's a binding to the id field.

Stacktrace:
org.springframework.core.convert.ConverterNotFoundException: No converter found capable of converting from 'java.io.Serializable' to 'java.lang.String'
at org.springframework.core.convert.support.GenericConversionService.convert(GenericConversionService.java:180)
at org.springframework.expression.spel.support.StandardTypeConverter.convertValue(StandardTypeConverter.java:70)
at org.springframework.expression.common.ExpressionUtils.convertTypedValue(ExpressionUtils.java:67)
at org.springframework.expression.spel.standard.SpelExpression.getValue(SpelExpression.java:98)
at org.springframework.binding.expression.spel.SpringELExpression.getValue(SpringELExpression.java:78)
at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getFormattedValue(BindingModel.java:228)
at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getFieldValue(BindingModel.java:142)
at org.springframework.web.servlet.support.BindStatus.<init>(BindStatus.java:120)

The problem happens on windows machines (both xp and win7) while all works well on linux (ubuntu 10.10).

This problem is almost identical to the one of issue https://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-881, that is closed as resolve in Web Flow 2.1.0.M1. I've also added a comment to it.

column92:
24/Feb/11 3:39 PM;kroe;We saw the NullPointerException on getValueInternal, but also found a much more severe effect of this bug: objects placed in a variable in one session can be returned when evaluating from another session.  This happened intermittently under all load levels, but was more frequent under periods of high load.  The issue would show up consistently after an app server restart when a bunch of requests were queued up in the load balancer, and released to the app server all at once.  Both of these are instances where concurrency is higher than normal, so no surprise that high load and server restarts brough these cases out.

Depending on the latest 2.3.0 snapshot resolved these concurrency issues entirely.

I have seen similar effects in an application which uses that version, i.e. objects from one session being returned in another session under heavier loads, but I have yet to find a reason in our own code to explain it.

column1: Spring.ValidateAllDecoration validates all form elements on the page, rather than just in its own form
column42:
Using the Spring.ValidateAllDecoration on a form submit button causes all Dojo widgets to be validated across all forms on a page, rather than just the form containing the button with the decoration.

Reproduction steps :
1. Create a page with multiple forms
2. In each of the forms, place several Dojo widgets that require validation
3. On any one of the forms, add a submit button with a Spring.ValidateAllDecoration.
4. Attempt to submit the form with the Spring.ValidateAllDecoration applied to its submit button.

Dojo will not allow the submission to take place.

column1: JsfAjaxHandler does not set content type when sending a partial response with a redirect instruction
column42: After clicking "Find Hotels" in the booking-faces sample, the resulting response (which contains XML) doesn't have a Content-Type header. As a result the redirect works in some situations but not all. In particular it doesn't work in MSIE and it doesn't work if the app is fronted by Apache httpd which adds a stock text/html content-type (apparently browsers won't recognize this as XML).

column1: input parameter with type="boolean" should default to false instead of null
column42:
In my main flow, I use a boolean input param, as follow:

<input name="create" type="boolean"/>

Later in the flow I use the ternary operator to pass an input param to a subflow, here is how:

<subflow-state id="edit" subflow="address/edit">
   <input name="address" value="create ? addressService.newWithDefaults : address"/>


But it breaks, saying that it cannot coerce null value to target class.
In previous version of SWF or Spring, not sure at which point, it was working.

I think the best fix would be to default all boolean input to 'false'.
Currently it defaults to null... and I was not able to set myself a default value.

To make it work, I use the following workaround using on-start:
    <on-start>
        <evaluate expression="create == T(java.lang.Boolean).TRUE" result="flowScope.create"/>
    </on-start>

column1: SnapshotUnmarshalException
column42:
While I'm developing, I notice that after a server restart, I get quit often a SnapshotUnmarshalException when I reload the webpage (which contains the execition key)

Below I post the full stacktrace.
Several things are interesting:
1. ]It says "SnapshotUnmarshalException: IOException thrown deserializing the flow execution stored in this snapshot -- this should not happen!" -> maybe a bug?
2.The cause is "java.io.InvalidObjectException: Could not find a SessionFactory named: null", so I guess it's got to do with accessing a sessionFactory that doesn't exist anymore.

It seems to be related with the session persistence.

My confirmed workaround for this is to put the following in context.xml:

Code:
    <Manager pathname="" className="org.apache.catalina.session.PersistentManager" 
debug="0" saveOnRestart="false"/>

column1: View transition through the CommandLink fails if the CommandLink is not located in the first page of a PrimeFaces' paginated datatable that is partially rendered
column42:
This happens only when PrimeFaces' paginated datatable is partially rendered. Whenever user click on any CommandLink that is not located on the first page of the datatable, the view transition will fail to progress to the next screen (instead it will just refresh the current screen). I tried to inspect the element of the CommandLink using Safari Developer tools, but the link seems valid (for both partially rendered and non-partially rendered). I also checked the log and found that the transition actually correctly handled  according to the log and it managed to visit the targeted view. But what appeared in the browser was still the original screen. 

Here is the Facelets template of a dataTable located in search.xhtml view:
{code:xml}
  <p:dataTable id="invoiceSummaries"
        value="#{invoiceSummaries}" 
	var="invoiceSummary" 
	rendered="${not empty invoiceSummaries}"
	paginator="true" rows="5">
	<p:column styleClass="center">
		<f:facet name="header">
			 Summary No
		 </f:facet>
		 <p:commandLink action="modify" ajax="false">
			<f:param name="invoiceId" value="#{invoiceSummary.id}" />
			<h:outputText value="#{invoiceSummary.documentNo}" />
		</p:commandLink>
	 </p:column>
   </p:dataTable>
{code}

Below is the web flow setting:
{code:xml}
	<view-state id="search" model="invoiceCriteria" parent="parent-flow#common-view-state-with-data">
		<var name="invoiceCriteria" class="erpsuite.invoice.InvoiceCriteria" />
		<transition on="find">
			<evaluate expression="invoiceService.findInvoiceSummaries(invoiceCriteria)"
					  result="viewScope.invoiceSummaries" result-type="dataModel" />
			<render fragments="invoiceSummaries" />
		</transition>
		
		<transition on="new" to="edit" />
		<transition on="modify" to="edit" />
	</view-state>
	
	<view-state id="edit" parent="parent-flow#common-view-state-with-data" model="invoice">
		<on-entry>
			<evaluate expression="invoiceService.findInvoice(requestParameters.invoiceId)" result="viewScope.invoice"  />
		</on-entry>
		
		<transition on="save">
			<evaluate expression="invoiceAction.saveInvoice" />
			<render fragments="invoiceForm" />
		</transition>
		
		<transition on="createInvoiceDetail">
			<evaluate expression="invoiceAction.createInvoiceDetail" />
			<render fragments="invoiceForm:invoiceDetails" />
		</transition>
		
		<transition on="deleteInvoiceDetail">
			<evaluate expression="invoiceAction.deleteInvoiceDetail" />
			<render fragments="invoiceForm:invoiceDetails" />
		</transition>
		
		<transition on="exit" to="search" history="discard" />
	</view-state>
{code}

Thanks a ton.

Regards,

Donny

column1: test - unable to register subflow definition unless setCurrentState was called.
dojo.require may not have sufficient time to load under some circumstances
column42: dojo.require is executed asynchronously. Code that depends on the required module should run inside dojo.addOnLoad() or should have dojo.addOnLoad invoked immediately after it as shown here http://docs.dojocampus.org/dojo/require#id5. Alternatively the dojo.require could be moved further up to the ElementDecoration constructor.
column91: 06/Dec/10 3:03 AM;rstoya05-aop;Ensured a dojor.require() is called for a widget as soon as an ElementDecoration is created and not within dojo.addOnLoad().

column1: Browser back in Portlet environment
column42: We are testing back functionality in liferay, and have problems with restoring the right portlet state, GET-After-POST is enabled on the portlet and putting the executionKey as Render Parameter (so it is submitted as a GET Request Parameter, if back is pressed) does not help either. We have seen that the executionKey ist stored in the javax.ViewState parameter. I suggest that the only information is the executionKey and is stored as a request parameter and is read as a request parameter, as is in a non portlet environment.
column91: 10/Nov/10 12:49 AM;rstoya05-aop;Redirect is intentionally turned off in a portlet environment where rendering happens in a separate, second request. Could you comment on why you want to enable redirecting?
column92:
10/Nov/10 1:21 AM;bacsik;In liferay 5.5 we had the problem, that the last browser request was a POST, so a browser refresh resubmitted the values of the form, so we configured in the liferay-portlet.xml:
{code}
<liferay-portlet-app>
    <portlet>
        <portlet-name>xyz</portlet-name>
        <action-url-redirect>true</action-url-redirect>
        <instanceable>true</instanceable>
{code}
column93:
07/Dec/10 8:34 AM;rstoya05-aop;The "javax.faces.ViewState" hidden request parameter is used in JSF to detect a postback even in a non-portlet environment. In Web Flow we put the flow execution key rather than using it to store any view state.

You can try a custom FlowHandlerAdapter that saves this key to survive a redirect between the action and the render requests to see if that is all that's needed. Currently Web Flow does that for the "execution" key parameter. See these two classes:

org.springframework.webflow.mvc.portlet.FlowHandlerAdapter
org.springframework.webflow.context.portlet.DefaultFlowUrlHandler
column94: 15/Nov/11 8:28 AM;bacsik;Indeed with a custom FlowHandlerAdapter and companion Servletfilter (adapted DoubleClickFilter in liferay) we can make history-back work as smooth as in servlet environments.

column1: Inconsistent Behaviour When Disabling Back Button
column42:
I would like to disable back button support by Spring Web Flow. To do this I have configured my Flow Executor as follows:

Code:

    <webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor">
        <webflow:flow-execution-repository max-executions="1" max-execution-snapshots="0"/>
    </webflow:flow-executor>

In the middle of a multi-step flow, if the back button is presses a FlowExecutionRestorationFailureException is thrown. This is fine and as expected.

However, if flow A ends with a flowRedirect to flow B, the user can press the back button and gets redirected to a new instance of flow A. I would have expected the same FlowExecutionRestorationFailureException.
column91:
06/Dec/10 6:22 AM;rstoya05-aop;In the first case you have a flow execution that has not ended. Trying to access a snapshot that doesn't exist results in FlowExecutionRestorationFailureException. In the second case flow A has ended. Trying to access the flow execution results in NoSuchFlowExecutionException. 

The FlowHandlerAdapter provides default handling for NoSuchFlowExecutionException by redirecting to the start of the flow. There is no default handling for  FlowExecutionRestorationFailureException. You can change both of these defaults assuming they don't work for you by overriding FlowHandlerAdapter.defaultHandleException(..).

column1: Reference documentation needs to be updated to reflect support for correct versions of JSF and Portlet API
column42:
See the discussion for details - here is teh last comment :-

Quote:
Originally Posted by ajain  
Does this mean that JSF 2.0 is supported but in Portlet environemnt only JSF 1.2 supported when integrated with Portlet?
=>Indeed JSF 2 and 1.2 are supported but JSF 2 is not supported in combination with Portlets. We could update the documentation to be more explicit about that.

Quote:
Originally Posted by ajain  
Although, section 2.4 said Portlet API 2.0 is supported, section 14.1 says only JSR 168 is supported. Does the statement above mean, certain 286 isn't fully supported.

I will be doing my own testing, but wanted to make sure that Portlet API 2.0 and JSF 2.0 integration is supported to use Spring Webflow.
This section needs to be updated. Would you mind opening a ticket in JIRA for that? 

=>Portlet API 2.0 is now a required dependency. Hence claiming JSR-168 support is arguably confusing. On the other hand changing that to JSR-286 isn't quite the answer either. Again see this issue not only for work that needs to be done in Web Flow but also highlighting the fact JSF Ajax components need to issue Portlet resource requests.

column1: Regression in showing global messages only
org.springframework.faces.webflow.context.portlet.PortletFacesContextImpl should implement setCurrentPhaseId rather than delegate it.
column42: Using JSF 2 in a portlet environment causes an infinite recursion on setCurrentPhaseId because the PortletFacesContextImpl just delegates it to the FacesContext which in turns delegates it to an "real" implementation. Because PortletFacesContextImpl is the "real" implementation this will start a recurions that will never end. I think that PortletFacesContextImpl should implement setCurrentPhaseId and not delegate it further.

column1: HandlerInterceptor.postHandle() and FlowExecutionListener.sessionEnding() are now called after the view is already rendered
column42:
After upgrading from Spring Webflow 1.0.7 to 2.1.1, HandlerIntercepter.postHandle() and FlowExecutionListener.sessionEnding() are no longer called before the view is rendered. The ModelAndView parameter to postHandle() is always null for that reason. The DispatcherServlet is no longer handling the rendering of the view, which makes the postHandle event of little use.

The real problem is that there is no equivalent replacement FlowExecutionListener event that is triggered after flow execution and action states have finished but before the view is rendered to allow for modifying attributes accessible by the JSP.

For view states, the FlowExecutionListener.viewRendering() event is a very close replacement (with the small caveat that render actions are called between the event and rendering). This would work well enough but it is not called before rendering an end state view, only for view states.

In an attempt at fixing this locally, I added the viewRendering and viewRendered calls to org.springframework.webflow.action.ViewFactoryActionAdapter to expand the scope of those events to include before and after rendering end state views as well. The source code for this is attached.

column1: javax.faces.ViewState hidden field resolves to Spring WebFlow state id instead of outer faces state
column42:
I don´t think that webflow should generate the javax.faces.ViewState id if it is participating in an already ongoing faces request. I´m getting an error on postback when the outer faces request is trying to restore state with the webflow viewstate id.

Regards,
Hampus
column91:
28/Sep/10 9:35 AM;rstoya05-aop;When you use Web Flow component tree state is not stored in the session but in view scope. This is why Web Flow manages the ViewState hidden field. 

As an additional comment, the scenario for Web Flow "participating in an already ongoing faces request" is not very clear to me given that Web Flow itself drives the complete JSF lifecycle. Trying to fit that in an ongoing faces request has implications on more than just setting the ViewState hidden field.
column92: 28/Sep/10 11:18 AM;hampe98;So if the portal makes a faces request when it´s aggregating the portlets I cannot use webflow?
column93:
28/Sep/10 2:04 PM;rstoya05-aop;Yes and I don't think this is specific to Web Flow. It has more to do with integrating JSF with Portal technology. Web Flow is merely driving the JSF lifecycle and the JSF lifecycle wasn't built with the idea of being nested within another JSF lifecycle.

This idea can be seen quite clearly in the Portlet Bridge for JSF. Here is a quote from JSR-329:

"For each portlet whose behavior is implemented using the Faces technology, the portlet activates and executes its own instance of the bridge by using the APIs defined in this specification.  The bridge provides the intermediate that translates between portlet and JSF semantics. The portlet container and the Faces engine are loosely coupled through the portlet bridge - neither the portlet container, nor the Faces engine, is aware of the other."

And also:

"For each request directed through the portlet bridge, the Faces environment is initialized, the Faces lifecycle is executed, and the targeted Faces page/view is processed/rendered."

In other words, the Faces engine should not have to know that it's running in a portal and each portlet executes its own lifecycle and that is independent of the lifecycle of other portlets.

column1: FlowFacesContext.newInstance should take into account that the incoming request could be a faces request and put away the original FacesContext so that it could be restored upon FlowFacesContext.release
column91:
28/Sep/10 9:23 AM;rstoya05-aop;The fact that Facelets is used to aggregate portlets on a page seems like an implementation detail of the portal itself, one that shouldn't be propagated to individual JSF portlets. Have you considered raising this as an issue with the portal itself?

If you have no other recourse, I suggest installing a FlowExecutionListener that saves and restores the FacesContext of the portal (. It is a simple solution and seems more for this situation. See FlowFacesContextLifecycleListener for an example.
column92: 28/Sep/10 11:26 AM;hampe98;Why shouldn´t it be propagated to the individual portlets? I want the benefits of facelets all the way from the portal layer (with classpath templating) down to the portlets. I suppose that most portals use jsp´s as their aggregation layer but they miss out on a lot of stuff that facelets offer. You don´t think that facelets and JSF will become a way for portals to do aggregation?
column93:
28/Sep/10 2:08 PM;rstoya05-aop;My reply would be the same as here:
https://jira.springsource.org/browse/SWF-1401?focusedCommentId=58576&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_58576

I'd be curious if you've seen any examples of this Portal working with any JSF portlets (specifically not using Web Flow).
column94: 28/Sep/10 11:20 PM;hampe98;It´s not really a portal if compared to liferay or other enterprise portals. It´s more of a simple dynamic aggregation engine that we wrote. We want to keep it in facelets but you think we should be ok if we don´t propagate the faces request down to the individual portlets?

column1: PortletExternalContextImpl should mimic the behavior of the jsfportletbridge implementation
column42:
PortletExternalContextImpl.java should do as the jsfportletbridge (bridge previously used with webflow) does and just return the url in encodeActionURL (and does not call the portlet response for encoding).

The action urls are most often just plain strings such as "next" and the Open Portal Portlet Container (2.1.2) does not allow non absolute URLs or relative URIs in PortletResponse.encodeUrl

Regards,
Hampus

column1: expression in view attribute of <end-state>, are not working
column42:
In the web-flow schema it is stated:
{quote}
The name of a view to render as a final flow response. Is often not specified when the caller handles this flow outcome and cares for the response. When specified, the value can be a flow-relative path to a view template:

priceForm.jsp

It can also be an evaluatable expression:

${flowScope.myViewExpression}

The externalRedirect: prefix may be used to request a redirect to an external location, typically to interface with an external system or controller. External redirect query parameters may be specified using ${expressions} that evaluate against the request context. The supported formats for an encoded externalRedirect expression are:

externalRedirect:
externalRedirect:contextRelative:
externalRedirect:serverRelative:
externalRedirect:

For example:

externalRedirect:/hotels/index
externalRedirect:http://someOtherSystem?orderId=${order.id}

The flowRedirect: prefix may be used to redirect to another flow:

flowRedirect:myOtherFlow?someData=${flowScope.data }

For exotic usages, you may plug in a custom ViewFactory bean you define:

${myCustomViewFactory}


When this attribute is not specified, no final response will be issued. In this case, the caller is expected to handle this flow outcome. 
{quote}

the following code 
{code}
	<view-state id="enterEntityQuestionData">
        <transition on="cancel" to="canceled">
            <evaluate expression="'/home.xhtml'" result="flowScope.finalView" />
        </transition>
        <transition on="add" to="createEntityQuestion">
            
        </transition>
        
	</view-state>
{code}

and then
{code}
<end-state id="canceled" view="#{flowScope.finalView}"/>
{code}

simply does not work

while constructions like view="externalRedirect:#{......}" will work.

column95: 25/Oct/10 8:11 AM;rstoya05-aop;The change was made as part of work done to integrate the Spring 3 type conversion into Spring Web Flow (see [SWF-1234] for more details). Let me know if this resolves the issue. Note that named converters as shown in the original comment above (converter="userTypeConverter") are not supported in Spring's type conversion. They're still supported in Web Flow (through Web Flow's type conversion system) but are effectively deprecated. The idea is Spring's type conversion system, which makes use of generics should be able to figure out what converter is needed for a given a source and target type pair.

column1: Wrong binding properties inside a subflow call
column42:
I have a form that performs a save and update operations, using nested properties, e.g. 'person.opcionSino.id' in a input form element, when I call this flow it performs the operation normally and each attribute is correctly mapped into the nested properties. The problem arises when I call this flow from another flow (subflow) when the subflow performs an action, the nested properties are bad mapped, thought I can see in the attributes map that the value comes with the right value, but in the pojo it changes the value incorrectly!!!

Main Flow:
{code:xml}
	<view-state id="usuarioList" view="/jsf/seguridad/usuarioList.xhtml">
		<on-render>
			<set name="viewScope.eliminar" value="true" type="boolean" />
			<set name="viewScope.eliminarFlowBundle" value="'botonera.eliminar.title'" />
		
			<evaluate expression="usuarioListActionFlow.list()" />
		</on-render>
		<transition on="editItem" to="editItem" />
	</view-state>
	
	<subflow-state id="editItem" subflow="usuario">
		<input name="id" value="requestParameters.id" />

		<transition on="cancelarFlow" to="usuarioList" />
	</subflow-state>
</flow>
{code}

The usuario flow:
{code:xml}	
	<var name="usuarioModel" class="com.gvt.proactive.hibernate.model.Usuario" />
	
	<input name="id" type="long" />

	<decision-state id="createOrEdit">
		<if test="id == null" then="usuarioInput" else="edit" />
	</decision-state>

	<action-state id="edit">
		<evaluate expression="daoManager.getObject(usuarioFormBean.getClass(),id)"
			result="usuarioModel" />
		
		<transition to="usuarioInput" />
	</action-state>
	
	<view-state id="usuarioInput" view="/jsf/seguridad/usuarioForm.xhtml">
		<on-render>
			<set name="viewScope.salvar" value="true" type="boolean" />
			<set name="viewScope.salvarFlowBundle" value="'botonera.salvar.title'" />
			
			<evaluate expression="usuarioModel.fillPOJO()" />
		</on-render>
		<transition on="salvar">
			<evaluate expression="usuarioActionFlow.save(usuarioModel,messageContext)" />
			<render fragments="usuarioForm" />
		</transition>
	</view-state>
	
	<on-end>
		<evaluate expression="externalContext.sessionMap.remove('usuarioActionFlow')"/>
	</on-end>
</flow>
{code}

Form of this flow (short):here we can see the nested properties defined on inputValue eg. 'usuarioModel.organizacion.id'
{code:xml}
<gvt:selectOneMenu inputId="organizacionSelectId" bundleLabel="#{bundle['usuario.organizacion.id']}"
	inputValue="#{usuarioModel.organizacion.id}" items="#{organizacionItems}" itemLabel="razonOrganizacion"
	itemValue="id" required="true" toolTip="toolTip.usuario.organizacion.id" />
<gvt:selectOneRadio inputId="opcionSinoByEsActivaSelectId" bundleLabel="#{bundle['usuario.opcionSinoByEsActiva.id']}"
	inputValue="#{usuarioModel.opcionSinoByEsActiva.id}" items="#{opcionSinoItems}"
	itemLabel="nombreOpcionSino" itemValue="id" required="true" toolTip="toolTip.usuario.esCuentaActiva" />
{code}
When it's called from a main flow, the nested properties has incorrect mapped values in the model, thought, in the request map it's correct, the problem is when binding to the model!!, Remember, when this flow is called directly (not in subflow), the nested properties are correctly mapped and have the values that user choosed!!!

column91: 02/Sep/10 2:33 AM;rstoya05-aop;This exception is not surprising. As indicated in the blog post (http://blog.springsource.com/2010/08/05/spring-web-flow-2-2-0-m1-released) partial state saving is not yet supported for Apache MyFaces. It needs to be disabled through the "javax.faces.PARTIAL_STATE_SAVING" context parameter.
column92:
02/Sep/10 1:14 PM;james2010;I already disabled the partial state saving when I tested the code. Here is the configuration in my web.xml.

	<context-param>
		<param-name>javax.faces.PARTIAL_STATE_SAVING_METHOD</param-name>
		<param-value>false</param-value>
	</context-param>

column1: servletRelative redirects don't work with default-servlet-handler
column42:
When using the default-servlet-handler element from Spring 3.0.4 and later (and thus mapping the DispatcherServlet to the default servlet), servletRelative redirects on an end state do not work as expected.  

For example, if I have an end state in the "rewards/newReward" flow defined like so:
	<end-state id="rewardConfirmed" view="externalRedirect:servletRelative:/rewards/1" />

This will *not* redirect to /rewards/1 as expected.  Instead, it redirects to /rewards/newReward/rewards/1.

It's worth  noting that as a workaround, a contextRelative redirect works fine.
column91:
25/Aug/10 10:59 AM;rstoya05-aop;When the DispatcherServlet is mapped with the default mapping "/", the current request's servlet path is the full path after the context path (i.e. "/rewards/newReward"). Since the FlowHandlerAdapter.sendServletRelativeRedirect() method always appends the servlet path to the URL in this case we end up with the full path of the current request + the path for the redirect URL. So we end up with a wrong URL.

Incidentally this behavior is observed also when using extension mappings (*.do, *.html). In those cases the servlet path is also the full path after the context path so you end up with: "/rewards/newReward.do/rewards/1.do".

I would argue that this is not a bug when the "servletRelative" prefix is used since the FlowHandlerAdapter is correctly following the instruction. 

However, sendServletRelativeRedirect() is also the default method used for external redirects when no prefix is used. That means if using the default mapping "/" then "externalRedirect:/rewards/1" won't work. It would have to be "externalRedirect:contextRelative:/rewards/1" to avoid adding the servlet path.

1. Since there is no easy way to know how the DispatcherServlet is mapped, one option would be to make the FlowHandlerAdapter configurable with regards to whether it should add the servlet path or not. This would be similar to UrlBasedViewResolver.setRedirectContextRelative(boolean). 

2. Alternatively the FlowHandlerAdapter.sendServletRelativeRedirect() method could avoid adding the servlet path when request.getPathInfo() is null. That is the case for the default mapping and for the extension mapping. When using a prefix mapping on the other hand the path info is usually not null unless the URL contains the servlet prefix only, which is an unlikely URL to use for a flow.
column92: 26/Aug/10 12:17 PM;jeremyg484;I like the idea of option 2, but I'm not sure it can be guaranteed to work correctly across all Servlet containers.  We ran into a similar issue at one point when working on the default-servlet-handler, where we were attempting to map it automatically instead of requiring the additional XML config.  Relying on a null PathInfo worked on Tomcat, but I noticed that this behavior seems to be left quite open in the Servlet spec, so there's not necessarily a guarantee that it will work elsewhere.  If it can't be guaranteed to work portably, then option 1 would seem to be the way to go.
column93:
27/Aug/10 1:33 AM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks Jeremy. Looking at the servlet spec: 

"A string containing only the ’/’ character indicates the "default" servlet of the application. In this case the servlet path is the request URI minus the context path and the path info is null."

So path info is supposed to be null according to the spec. That said I came across this WebSphere container property "com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.enabledefaultservletrequestpathelements":

http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/rweb_custom_props.html

It allows turning off the above servlet spec behavior and it's set that way by default. 

I think it's fair to implement option 2, which would be transparent and in agreement with the servlet spec. We could also add option 1 as an override for container environments where it may be needed.
column94:
02/Sep/10 4:43 AM;rstoya05-aop;I've added the following in FlowHandlerAdapterTests:

1. testSwf1385DefaultServletExternalRedirect() - external redirect for with default servlet mapping where the servlet path contains the full URL after the context path and the path info is null.
Outcome => does not prepend the servlet path

2. testSwf1385DefaultServletExternalRedirectDeviation() - external redirect with default servlet mapping where the path info contains the full URL after the context path and the servlet path is empty.
Outcome => prepends the servlet path, which in this case it is empty and has no effect

3. testSwf1385DefaultServletExternalRedirectServletRelative() - external redirect with default servlet mapping where the "servletRelative:" prefix is used.
Outcome => prepends the servlet path (as instructed)

At this stage I have not added a FlowHandlerAdapter property to enforce context relative redirects. In case number 2 above the servlet path is empty so pre-pending it should not make a difference.

column1: Views are not inherited from parent flow
column42:
Let's say parent flow has following structure^
parent
    |
    |--parent-flow.xml
    |--parentView.xhtml

Inside parent-flow.xml there is following view-state:

<view-state id="parentState" view="parentView.xhtml"/>

Child flow looks like this:

<flow ...
		parent="parent">
...
	<view-state id="test">
		<transition on="bang" to="parentState"/>
	</view-state>
...
</flow>

The problem is when one hits 'bang' action of child flow parentView.xhtml view in parent flow can't been seen. The error is similar to:

'The requested resource (/spring/child?execution=e3s2) is not available.'
column91:
31/Aug/10 3:54 AM;denis_k;Workaround for the issue:
One can specify relative path in view attribute. The example from description works if you specify parent view like that:

 <view-state id="parentState" view="../parent/parentView.xhtml">
    </view-state>
column92:
09/Sep/10 1:46 AM;rstoya05-aop;In addition when relative paths aren't sufficient you can also use absolute paths. For example:

<view-state id="parentState" view="/WEB-INF/parent/parentView.xhtml" />

I am closing this issue as based on its summary it isn't really an issue. The view attribute information does get inherited but must be a valid relative or absolute path in order to be resolved correctly.

column1: Spring Faces throws NPE when writing flow state if JSF servlet is called instead of Spring Dispatcher Servlet

The following is from the server log, pinpointing the error.
