column1: FlowExecutionImpl: handleException ignores result of another handleException
column91:
24/Aug/10 1:44 AM;rstoya05-aop;Please confirm or correct my understanding of the scenario:  
1. exception A is raised but exception handling results in exception B
2. recursive exception handling for B succeeds and therefore handleException() returns normally
3. back in the top-level handleException() exception A is re-thrown because handled=false
column92: 24/Aug/10 9:44 AM;andriy.vyedyeneyev@gmx.at;correct. Step 3 should not rethrow exception A, because it's already handled
column93:
24/Aug/10 10:27 AM;rstoya05-aop;So given that exception B was handled, then no exception should be re-thrown at all. I agree with that.

Also from the original comment: "finally do not forget to re-throw latest not original exception if handling completely failed". If exception B is not handled then exception B will be re-thrown so this should work. Or did you mean something else?
column95: 24/Aug/10 10:08 PM;rstoya05-aop;Yes that makes sense. I will create some unit tests and experiment this fix.
column96:
31/Aug/10 12:24 PM;rstoya05-aop;I've added a couple of test cases:
1. FlowExecutionImplTests.testExceptionHandledByNestedExceptionHandler() - demonstrates this issue
2. FlowExecutionImplTests.testExceptionHandledAvoidEndlessRecursion() - causes endless recursion

The fix for #1 is very similar to the one proposed. 
The endless recursion is handled through a simple test preventing more than 5 levels of recursion.
column97:
31/Aug/10 3:08 PM;andriy.vyedyeneyev@gmx.at;5 levels of recursion sounds for me a bit limited, i will explain my use case. 

1. Inside of flow execution(which is subflow) happens event, this event can't be processed by active flow (no transitions in state, no global transitions), so it should be routed to outer flow, 
2. in outer flow event will be fired again to check if there is a handler, if no handler defined (no global transition)  then  1.) else 3.)
3. handle event and continue

so if we have 5 as maximal recursion level, this algorithm will be limited to only 5 subflows. 

actually i think that probability of exception handler deadlock (the only point why we need 5 as limitation imo) is equal to probability of event ha  
ndler deadlock, and spring web flow as far as i know has no limits on recursive handle events. Both cases are error cases and should be handled in same way.

my proposition let recursion be without limits, or try to detect cycles (may be overkill)
column98:
01/Sep/10 2:26 AM;rstoya05-aop;You make a good point that this should be left to the application. Indeed even if we stop "infinite" recursion throwing a FlowExecutionException at that point is arguably not any better than the StackOverflowException that would occur otherwise.

I wonder though if the above scenario does apply to the exception handling recursion check though? If a NoMatchingTransitionException is raised in a subflow, then the flow execution attempts to find a matching exception handler. If there is no match, the exception is re-thrown (and bubbles up outside of web flow). If there is a match the exception handler is invoked. A second level of recursion will only occur if the exception handler itself fails and another matching exception handler is found for the new exception.
column99: 02/Sep/10 2:28 AM;andriy.vyedyeneyev@gmx.at; Exactly, subflow will find exception handler, and during handling, which includes transition to end state and reactivation of event in outer flow, can happen exception.
column100: 02/Sep/10 3:08 AM;rstoya05-aop;Okay, I've backed out the test case and the check for endless recursion in handleException.

column1: Flow Grandparent Inheritance
column42:
Hello there,

We have an environment with WebFlow 2.0.9, and a possible issue with Flow Inheritance.  I searched existing bugs and did not find anything on this topic.

The basic scenario is that we have navigation for the whole system and then for each area, and we want two generations of State Level Inheritance.  With the configuration (below), the transitions from the grandparents mainViewState do not resolve from a child state like areaOneTabOne.

There may be an alternate approach like using global-transitions and subflow-state definitions, but it seemed to us that two generations of State Level Inheritance or maybe CSV Multiple Inheritance like the Flow Level would be intuitive and nice.  The workaround of including all transitions system wide in the mainViewState works but is not very elegant.

Could you let us know if this is possible, or might be supported in the future?

Thanks,

Matt

---

<!-- grandparent -->
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">
	
	<view-state id="mainViewState" view="main.xhtml">
		<transition on="areaOne" to="areaOne" />
		<transition on="areaTwo" to="areaTwo" />
	</view-state>
	
	<view-state id="areaOne" view="flowRedirect:areaOne"/>
	<view-state id="areaTwo" view="flowRedirect:areaTwo"/>
		
</flow>

<!-- parent -->
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd"
	parent="grandparent">
		
		<view-state id="areaOneMain" parent="grandparent#mainViewState"> 
	 		<transition on="areaOneTabOne" to="areaOneTabOne" />
			<transition on="areaOneTabTwo" to="areaOneTabTwo" />
	 	</view-state>
	 	
		<view-state id="areaOneTabOne" view="flowRedirect:areaOneTabOne"/>
		<view-state id="areaOneTabTwo" view="flowRedirect:areaOneTabTwo"/>

</flow>

<!-- child -->
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow" 
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow 
						http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd"
	parent="grandparent, parent">
	
	<view-state id="areaOneTabOne" view="tabOne.xhtml"  parent="parent#areaOneMain" />
	
</flow>
column91:
27/Jul/10 7:09 PM;rstoya05-aop;Web Flow was designed with scenarios of controlled navigation in mind - a sequence of screens you have to go through. One level of inheritance as well as multiple inheritance are typically enough to handle situations where several flows have some differences.

It sounds like what you're defining is global site navigation. This is a slightly different scenario, one that will likely have a better solution in Web Flow 3. Multi-level inheritance though pushes towards being more complex, hence not the preferred solution.

Defining global navigation is common in JSF applications. You can try any of the techniques available today (that you already know about) - top level flow with subflows, global transitions, multiple inheritance. You can divide global transitions or shared states across more fine-grained files since multiple inheritance is possible.

column1: IllegalArgumentException in ConvertingPropertyEditorAdapter due to invalid BeanWrapper expression
column42:
Given this code:

public class Survey {
    private Map<Question, Response> responses = new HashMap<Question,Response>();
    ...
}

public class QuestionConverter implements Converter<Integer, Question> {
    ...
}

<form:input path="responses[1].value" />

During rendering, the expression "responses[1].value" is processed correctly by Spring EL, which converts the integer 1 to a Question, then does a look up in the responses map, and then converts the "value" field to a String. At this point this should be all that is needed. However, the following exception occurs:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The field type is required
	at org.springframework.util.Assert.notNull(Assert.java:112)
	at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.ConvertingPropertyEditorAdapter.<init>(ConvertingPropertyEditorAdapter.java:48)
	at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.findSpringConvertingPropertyEditor(BindingModel.java:273)
	at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.findEditor(BindingModel.java:183)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.support.BindStatus.<init>(BindStatus.java:125)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.tags.form.AbstractDataBoundFormElementTag.getBindStatus(AbstractDataBoundFormElementTag.java:174)

Spring MVC's BindStatus tries to find a PropertyEditor but the above expression cannot be processed by the BeanWrapperImpl because it fails to recognize that 1 needs to be converted to a Question. 

It would be safe if we didn't create a ProperytEditor when the BeanWrapperImpl fails as Spring EL has already formatted the value correctly.

27/Aug/10 11:40 AM;rstoya05-aop;I've checked in a new test case in:
spring-webflow/src/test/java/org/springframework/webflow/mvc/view/DefaultBindingModelTests.java

However I am no longer able to reproduce the issue (I'm pretty sure I was able to before?!)

In BindingModel, line 229 there is a check for whether the value is a String after the expression is evaluated. Since SpEL converts to a String as part of the expression evaluation, the lines within the if condition on line 229 should never be reached in this case.

Travis, would you mind taking a look at the unit test (in the 2.2 branch) and see if you find something I'm missing?

svn co https://src.springframework.org/svn/spring-webflow/branches/spring-webflow-2.2-maintenance
cd spring-webflow-2.2-maintenance/build-spring-webflow
ant
open Eclipse and import projects

Thanks!

spring-webflow/src/test/java/org/springframework/webflow/mvc/view/BindingModelSwf1370Tests 

I'm still having trouble demonstrating the issue through a test case. The above test runs fine.

If we assume that Spring EL does format the value to a String as part of evaluating the expression - this is indicated both in my comment above and in the forum thread, then the BindingModel.getFormattedValue() method should return directly without any further processing.

column1: SecurityFlowExecutionListener compatibility with Security 3
column42:
Hello there,

We have an environment with WebFlow 2.0.9, Security 3.0.1, and Spring core 3.0.0 versions.  I had to come up with a workaround to configure the SecurityFlowExecutionListener.

It seems Security 3 has refactored into different packages and is not reverse compatible with code written against Security 2 like the WebFlow 2.0.9 SecurityFlowExecutionListener.  I pulled the code (from spring-webflow-2.0.9.CI-380) and recompiled into a different class called SecurityThreeFlowExecutionListener (attached) in my own project.  I then configured this in the context and everything works great:

	<webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor">
		<webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
			<webflow:listener ref="securityFlowExecutionListener" />
		</webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
	</webflow:flow-executor>
	
	<!-- Installs a listener to apply Spring Security authorities -->
	<!-- This uses a temporary bridge between Flow 2 and Security 3 -->
	<!-- <bean id="securityFlowExecutionListener" class="org.springframework.webflow.security.SecurityFlowExecutionListener" /> -->
	<bean id="securityFlowExecutionListener" class="com.mattscompany.security.SecurityThreeFlowExecutionListener" /> 

The main change was to import from the new Security 3 packages, but I also commented out a ConfigAttributeDefinition reference from the decide method that I could not find in Security 3 which has not impacted me.

I looked through to see if this was already addressed in Flow 3 but did not find anything.

Thanks,

Matt
column91: 22/Jul/10 2:25 AM;rstoya05-aop;This has been addressed in the 2.1 branch (see [SWF-1182]). The latest production release is 2.1.1 and it's built on Spring 3.0.3 and Spring Security 3.0.2.
column92:
22/Jul/10 6:42 AM;matt;Sounds like I should upgrade to flow 2.1.1 and try that out.

Is flow 2.1 backwards compatible with security 2?
column93:
22/Jul/10 6:49 AM;rstoya05-aop;Yes, please upgrade to 2.1.1 if you need to use Spring 3 and Spring Security 3. Have a look through the 2.1.1 documentation. There is a short section on "what's new" that's worth reading.

Due to the package changes in Spring Security you cannot use Spring Security 2 with Web Flow 2.1.1.

column1: GenericConversionService for String.class causes duplicate converters
column91:
08/Jul/10 7:20 AM;rstoya05-aop;Interesting use case.

The Spring 3 conversion service does type conversion purely based on a source and target type pair. The StringTrimmerPropertyEditor however converts between String and String and that doesn't seem like enough information to decide whether to invoke getAsText or setAsText in a given situation. Even though you've found a way to make it work for your use case I suspect that's always going to result in the invocation of setAsText. Do you rely on the getAsText method as well in your solution? 

If you only need the setAsText functionality then I can suggest creating a simple (one-way) Converter that wraps the StringTrimmerPropertyEditor and invokes the setAsText method. The GenericConversionService will then register only one Converter.
column92:
08/Jul/10 7:41 PM;adam_jh;I agree, the conversion system between String and String hides whether to call getAsText or setAsText, but I guess what is trying to be achieved in such cases (where the source and target are the same) isn't a conversion between types but a processing step so perhaps propertyeditors shouldn't even be used/wrapped at all because in my mind they were there to convert and process, whereas spring only wants a conversion now. Also, I wouldn't want this logic to transfer to other non-mvc areas of spring so I don't really want to hack it into a ConversionService.

Trouble is, where can I put such processing? In old spring mvc I was able to post-process custom binding (onBind) and clobber together fields which existed only in the web page to one that existed in the dom (eg date fields separated by 3 combo boxes of day, month, year got translated into one date field). In new mvc or webflow I haven't seen a suitable place and also for this particular 'global' web scenario of trimming and nulling text I don't see any easy point of entry.

Incidentally, I don't need the getAsText since the web page renders nulls as "" for the fields - which is lucky.

I think spring mvc/webflow needs to add the ability to hook in bind post-processors into DataBinder?
column93: 08/Jul/10 7:55 PM;adam_jh;It appears others would want the same functionality too - and those who used a conversion id will also need a solution. See top 4 posts of http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=59042&page=2
column94:
08/Jul/10 10:43 PM;rstoya05-aop;Yes, I think you're correct in saying this is more of a post-processing task than type conversion. One person in the forum thread said he thought it was a good idea to separate those out into a separate layer. 

There is a ticket for adding the equivalent of onBind in Spring 3.1 [SPR-6437]. As far as I know Web Flow does not provide a similar hook although there are places where you may be able to add such logic (around AbstractMvcView). 

I am afraid I will have to close this issue based on the original description as I see nothing further we can do. The GenericConversionService appropriately registers a reverse converter when it sees a TwoWayConverter.
column95:
09/Jul/10 12:15 AM;adam_jh;Yes, it is more of problem of merging different philosophies than a bug. Thanks for the pointer to 6437, though I do believe this custom binding functionality should be made available too in webflow. Once its in spring mvc, more people will ask of its equivalence in webflow. If I have problems in the meantime with String converters I will look at AbstractMvcView.

Thanks
column96: 09/Jul/10 2:13 AM;rstoya05-aop;Keep an eye on Web Flow 3, which adds Java based flows with a programming model that is similar to Spring MVC annotated controllers.

column93: 01/Jul/10 7:43 PM;rstoya05-aop;It looks like the same issue - during rendering while resolving a bean in an EL expression. The FlowFacesContext does have a method with ExceptionHandler in its signature so I bet your view has expressions that reference facesContext. Could you verify that? Alternatively put a breakpoint on BeanELResolver.java:179 and see what bean it's trying to resolve.
column94:
04/Jul/10 8:44 PM;sandro.roeder@googlemail.com;Hi Rossen,
you are right it was the problem. there was a reference in a view to a facesContext.
In this case it was really stupid:
 <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="#{facesContext.externalContext.requestContextPath}/css/vip.css"/>

just the change to this resolved the problem: <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="#{externalContext.contextPath}/css/vip.css"/>

Thanks very much for your help.
column95: 04/Jul/10 8:48 PM;rstoya05-aop;This issue is being tracked as [SWF-1263].

column1: Removing <script> tags from a partial response causes issues when using RichFaces data tables
column91: 15/Jul/10 5:13 AM;rstoya05-aop;Updated summary to reflect more accurately the issue (was 'RichFaces integration when working with Datatables').
column92:
15/Jul/10 5:20 AM;rstoya05-aop;Updated Spring.RemotingHandler to remove scripts but not script tags entirely from partial responses. This will be inserted in place of the actual script tags in the response:

<script> // Original script removed to avoid re-execution </script>

column1: Improve logging around partial re-rendering to help in debugging
column42: Would be good to see which part of the component tree re-rendered on a view if fragments was set.  In general, we should look at improving logging in JavaScript and Faces modules where there are common user errors.

column1: ResourceServlet and sf:commandLink - add option to exclude dojo.js
column42: Allow an option so Spring does not add the dojo.js. This will allow Spring Faces to integrate easier with projects using existing DOJO libraries. In our case we are using Dojo 1.3 and Spring 2.5.6 uses Dojo 1.0. We have made a number of custom JSF/Ajax components using Dojo and after using Spring (and configuring the Resource Servlet in web.xml), our Dojo components stop working. Part of this is also due to the fact that there is no way to tell the Resource servlet to use mapping other than /resources/.  See to forum for more information.
column43: Windows 2000 Server, IBM Websphere 6.1, IBM JDK 6, Dojo 1.3.1

column1: Remove differences in application layer for the MVC and Faces versions of the booking samples
column42:
There are minor differences in the application layer code between the MVC and Faces versions of the booking samples.

In detail, the SearchCriteria differs (setPage(int) versus nextPage(), resetPage(), previousPage()) and the Service differs (MVC has cancelBooking(long) versus cancelBooking(Booking)).

column1: Perform a "redirect on pause" after a component POST event.
column42:
Using complex JSF components which use POST request for updating their state (e.g. Tomahawk tabbed pane) Spring Webflow does not perform a redirect on flow refresh, so the view is in a not-reloadable state (you get the browser warning on reposting data). The component postback is treated as a view refresh (ViewState.refresh() -> viewSelector.makeRefreshSelection()) and SWF won't perform a redirect even if alwaysRedirectOnPause is set to true.
alwaysRedirectOnPause only triggers the redirect for ViewStates if they are reached by a transition, but I cannot define transitions for component POSTs.
column91: 24/Jul/07 9:09 PM;klr8;I guess the components are posting without firing an action outcome.
column92:
30/Jul/07 3:26 AM;dpasek;Yes, the components are not triggering a action event / outcome. They just update their state (eg. sorting) and rerender the current view. I don't want to use a SWF transition for this.

Here's a small example with a quick (and dirty) patch for the FlowPhaseListener (see faces-config.xml).
Using the SWF FlowPhaseListener a tab change will create a not reloadable view.
My RedirectFlowPhaseListener performs a redirect (with saving component state before) on a postback. For avoiding endless looping an additional request param is added so the redirect is only performed once.
SWF should try something like this for full Post-Redirect-Get-Support with JSF.

column1: Add a ResourceELResolver that can be used outside of Web Flow
column42: There is currently no mechanism for resolving messages from a ResourceBundle through the ELResolver chain if the current request is not a Web Flow request.  We should add something similar to the FlowResourceELResolver that does not depend on Web Flow for resolution of the current Locale.

column1: Error message for popups when "render" tag has been ommited
column42:
When using popups with Spring Faces, it happened that I forgot the "render" tag. 

Instead of writing this:

<view-state id="reviewBooking" popup="true" view="reviewBooking.xhtml">
		<on-entry>
			<render fragments="bookingDetails" />
		</on-entry>
		<transition on="confirm" to="bookingConfirmed" />
	</view-state>

I had written this:
<view-state id="reviewBooking" popup="true" view="reviewBooking.xhtml">
		<transition on="confirm" to="bookingConfirmed" />
	</view-state>

In that case, all I've got is an empty popup with no specific error message (see attached screenshot). It would provide a more friendly user experience if there was a specific user message or an exception stack trace instead. I am sure a significant number of people have run into that issue before :).
column91: 27/Aug/10 3:02 AM;rstoya05-aop;This appears to be a duplicate of [SWF-1317]

column1: Support EL-Expression in Spring Faces UI-component ClientTextValidator "regExp"-attribute
column91:
15/Jun/10 12:18 PM;odoepner;Hello,

Apparently it would be quite easy to fix this in the DojoWidget class in org.springframework.faces.ui where getInvalidMessage() and getPromptMessage() already support EL expressions.

Currently, the only workaround seems to be to build a modified spring-faces.jar. Of course that is not a good solution.

Are there any reasons for not implementing EL expression support for these attributes?

What is the correct process for submitting a patch?

Thanks
Oliver
column92:
15/Jun/10 12:21 PM;odoepner;In my previous comment I said "EL expression support for these attributes" because the "required" attribute seems to have the same limitation.

It would be really nice if both of these could support EL expressions because it would allow model-driven vaildation constraints (rather than hardcoding the attributes in the views).

Thanks
Oliver
column93: 15/Jun/10 10:31 PM;fanoaky;Yes, it would be really helpful if this could be fixed
column94: 15/Jun/10 10:31 PM;hamish;Yes, it would be really helpful if this could be fixed otherwise it will using a different javascript library...

column1: Implement the sort functionality in booking-faces sample in a degradable manner
column42:
The sort links in the header of the data table displaying the search results in the booking-faces sample do not work without JavaScript enabled, due to an inherent limitation of using <f:param>.

An alternate approach should be demonstrated that combines <h:outputLink> with <sf:ajaxEvent> to degrade gracefully.

column1: JSF Centric Integration
column42:
In SWF 1.0.5 it was straight forward to invoke a flow from a JSF UICommand.  Currrently, in SWF 2.0.2 it requires a workaround using an action listener as discussed in the forum discussion referenced below.

Further, on completion of the flow, returning to the JSF context requires an external redirect.

See Forum Discussion http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=56318
column91:
08/Sep/10 2:55 PM;rstoya05-aop;In version 1.x SWF hooked into the JSF lifecycle. For example the FlowNavigationHandler resumed or launched flow executions as necessary or otherwise delegated to the standard NavigationHandler. This gave an opportunity to detect JSF actions of the form "flowId:myFlow".

In version 2.x SWF drives the JSF lifecycle rather than hooking into it and doesn't get involved in requests that weren't sent to it. Consequently there is no need for a NavigationHandler.

Instead of SWF providing a NavigationHandler (which conceptually it doesn't need otherwise) I would argue an application could resolve this fairly easily by creating a JSF NavigationHandler that detects actions prefixed with "flowId:" and redirects like the code sample shown in the forum discussion.

column1: For investigation: Problems with global transitions and session timeouts
column42:
To be investigated:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=39932

column1: Improve documentation for Spring Faces for different environments such as Websphere
column42:
See http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=58134

In general, any special requirements for various environments should be noted in the reference documentation.,
column91:
09/Sep/08 1:36 AM;paulnewport;I can confirm that the instructions for setting up Spring Faces in Websphere 6.1 as mentioned in the link to the forum are correct. A web app configured to work in WAS 6.1 will also work in Tomcat with no problem, the only real issues for WAS are to have the context param set as so:

<context-param>
  <param-name>com.ibm.ws.jsf.LOAD_FACES_CONFIG_AT_STARTUP</param-name> 
  <param-value>false</param-value> 
</context-param>

and to make sure the unified EL jars are in WEB-INF/lib with the correct class loading policies set (PARENT LAST) for both the WAR and the EAR it has to be deployed in.

column1: Handling an event without transitioning on re-renders the command that signaled the event by default
column42: This is inconsistent with the way plain JSP views work with tiles, where the entire view is re-rendered if no fragments are specified.  I admit I find re-rendering the entire view more natural, but perhaps there is a reason we only re-render the component. If there a reason, it would be good to document this, along with the general way ajax re-rendering works in a JSF environment.

column1: Work with the MyFaces and JSF RI teams to make FacesServlet an optional deployment artifact for JSF usage.
column42: We've successfully fully integrated JSF into a Spring MVC DispatcherServlet front controller environment.  In this case, the FacesServlet is no longer required, but must be deployed as a "dummy servlet" just so the JSF implementations can bootstrap.  We should work closely with the MyFaces team, JSF RI team, and JSF 2.0 expert group to reduce this requirement.

column1: Enhanced ability to signal SWF events in JSF
column42: Currently the only way to signal an event to SWF from JSF is through JSF's action mechanism.  Spring Faces should add the ability to signal an SWF  event programmatically so that it may be done from other components that do not necessarily implement ActionSource.  For example, it would be useful to signal an SWF event from within an Apache Trinidad RowSelectionListener.

column1: Provide support for resolving messages from a MessageSource in a JSF view.
column42: It could be quite useful to be able to resolve messages in a MessageSource from EL expressions in a JSF view.  Simple support for this could be added through a JSF VariableResolver (or ELResolver for JSF 1.2).  Providing a nice way to handle parameters for the message would require a little more thought, as it would be nice to have a better alternative to JSF's use of the <f:param> tag for this purpose.  Such support may require a custom JSF tag in order to provide maximum benefit and ease-of-use.
column91: 12/Jul/10 11:37 PM;rstoya05-aop;Support for resolving messages was added in Web Flow 2.0.0.RELEASE. The FlowResourceELResolver enables access to the MessageSource of the active flow through the keyword "resourceBundle" (e.g. ${resourceBundle['someKey']}.

Maybe even the existing DelegatingVariableResolver could handle this, and ignore the Groovy options if Groovy was not on the classpath?

Rgds
Agim

column1: Maintaining JSF state beyond view scope
column42:
The state of the JSF component tree persists as long as the user is in the same view-state. There are times though when the JSF state needs to be maintained even after exiting that view-state, and restored when entering the same view-state at a later point.

Most commonly, there is a form that can be filled with a value selected from another screen. The user transitions to a view-state that allows to search and select a value and then transitions back to the originating view-state. The user needs to see the screen exactly the way it was before going to the value selection screen (i.e. on the same tab, the same page on a paginated data iteration component, etc).

This requirement seems so common (and necessary) that it would be nice if spring-faces provided a built-in way to achieve this.

The implementation is quite simple from the framework's point of view. The JSF state can be saved in flow scope when leaving the view-state and restored back when entering the view-state. The most appropriate implementation is with a FlowExecutionListener. I don't think the memory requirement is an issue, if this feature is used wisely, because the state is only stored temporarily and only when needed.

Attached is the implementation I've written and used with success in several large industrial projects.

================================
            Usage
================================

Attach the org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfStateManagingFlowExecutionListener in the webflow configuration.

  <webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor" flow-registry="flowRegistry">
      <webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
          <webflow:listener ref="jsfStateManagingListener" />
      </webflow:flow-execution-listeners>
  </webflow:flow-executor>

  <bean id="jsfStateManagingListener" class="org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfStateManagingFlowExecutionListener" />

In the flow definition, whenever you have a transition from a view-state that needs to save the JSF state so that it's restored the next time you enter the view-state, just add the saveViewState attribute to the transition. For example

  <view-state id="viewState1" view="myView">
      <transition on="x" to="y">
          <attribute name="saveViewState"/>
      </transition>
      ...
  </view-state>

column1: <sf:ajaxEvent> and checkbox-onclick-event does not work
column42:
This problem is discussed in detail in Springforum at http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?p=192814#post192814 --- I have a problem with spring faces ajax integration. I would like to use the -Tag to submit my current form to render a page-fragment (a menu) based on the supplied form arguments. In this special case the form consists of a single checkbox and the menu should be re-rendered if the onclick event occurs. My code looks like: Code: In my flow-definition i have defined a global transistion "updateMenu" for this case, which should re-render the page-fragmemt "menuForm:menuFragment": Code: My Menu-Fragment looks something like: Code:
Only Hardware
The good news are that this code works. But not as i had expected. There is a strange behaviour that i can't explain: What I expect: The checkbox is unchecked. The user clicks on the checkbox and starts the ajax-request, which results in the "OnlyHardware"-Text in the Menu. The checkbox remains checked. What I got: The checkbox is unchecked. The user clicks on the checkbox and starts the ajax-request, which results in the "OnlyHardware"-Text in the Menu. The checkbox remains NOT checked. Why?? In the forum i posted a dirty workaround, that worked for ie7 and firefox 3 but not in ie 6.
column91:
23/Jul/08 6:30 AM;pepe;I have debugged the javascript-code and found out the problematic code-snippet in Spring-Dojo.js, where i commented out the line containing the instruction: 

dojo.stopEvent(event);

in the "submit"-function of "Spring.AjaxEventDecoration"-declaration.

After that hotfix the described problem disappeared.

While this "stopEvent" instruction makes sense in scenarios where you are using links (sf:commandLink) or buttons (sf:commandButton) it is a failure to use this for checkboxes because the default browser behaviour gets neglected. i think this is equal to returning false in an inline-javascript-onclick-attribute.

So my bugfix-suggestion is to check the type of the used component:

<a> = stopEvents
<input type="button" ... > = stopEvents
<input type="checkbox" ... > = DONT stopEvents
<input type="radio" ... > = DONT stopEvents

and I would also suggest that the default behaviour is, that events are NOT stopped.

column1: JSF 1.2 a label ValueExpression not correctly output if a converter (and probably validator) message is created
column42: If a converter creates a FacesMessage on a component that uses a ValueExpression on the label the label is not correctly output.  A common technique is to delay evaluation of the Summary and Detail messages until the render phase when things like the message bundle will be available, but because of the way the FlowFacesContext handles messages, it will try to retrieve the Summary and Detail message right away, which will cause the ValueExpression to return an empty string when evaluated.  The problem can be reproduced using the booking-faces example.  I will attach the necessary files.  enterBookingDetails.xhtml and faces-config.xml were both changed and a new messages.properties file, to be placed into the resources directory.

column1: Double-Transition problem on WebSphere Portal 6.1
column42:
There is an "double transition" issue running webflow 2 in the described configuration. While processing an action request the transiton is handled correctly. But the same transition is performed a second time within the following render request. This seems to be a bug within the faces integration. 

I will provide a sample eclipse project that bases on the sample application. The Spring and SWF jars are not included.
If you click on the button "search hotels" in the slightly modified "swf-booking-portlet-faces" sample application running on IBM WebSphere Portal 6.1 the transition "search" will be executed twice. One time in the action phase/action request and a second time in the render phase/render request (see the attached stacktrace).

The JSF-Action-Outcome seems to be stored during the action request in the request attributes with the key "org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfView.EVENT_KEY" and is used by SWF to execute this transition. This data is still present during the render request and SWF will try to execute this transition again. This will most likely fail, because the flow is already in another state where this transition is not defined.

Workaround: remove this attribute from the request attributes at the end of the action request processing in your own DispatcherPortlet.

column1: After a4j:commandLink execution and save w/validation failure subsequent calls to "save" flow won't engage
column42:
Per this thread in the forum (http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=55479), I have made several attempts to get this working but suspect this might be a bug with the RichFaces integration.  I can provide a sample application that reproduces the issue.  Basically the scenario is the user creates a new request and adds affects products to the request.  Each add will fire an a4j:commandLink and update the table accordingly.  This information is held in memory until the request is submitted.  When the user attempts to submit the request, the request will be validated.  In the case where there is a validation failure, the message will show to correct the validation error.  Once corrected, the user will attempt to submit again and the "save" event in the flow will not be called.  Instead it rerenders the current page.

The issue is why won't the "save" event in the flow be called again after subsequent clicks on the save button defining that action.  In JSF Phase 5, I see from the logs no call to the save event but instead it starts rendering right away:

column1: Trinidad ADF Components not right URL
<sf:commandLink /> and <sf:commandButton />: "disabled" attribute not working
column42:
In the tag <sf:commandLink/>, the "disabled" attribute is not working. When disabled is set to "true", the link is still enabled.
It seems that the problem also happens with <sf:commandButton />.
See here for more details: http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=73561
This might be easy to fix. This tag corresponds to the class org.springframework.faces.ui.ProgressiveUICommand. 
Inside of it, there is a method called getDisabled(). I believe this is not correct, disabled is a Boolean so the corresponding method should be called isDisabled.
This tag is very close to the one that comes with JSF's reference implementation. This one is called <h:commandLink/>. The tag corresponding to this class is called javax.faces.component.html.HtmlCommandButton. 
Inside this class, the corresponding method is indeed called isDisabled().

However onclick still contained a Spring.RemotingHandler call. On the other hand commandLink was also rendered with disabled="disabled" but the anchor tag doesn't even have such an attribute. 

I made changes to render a commandLink consistent with the JavaDoc for the standard commandLink tag:

"If the value of the disabled attribute is true, render a span element. Render all the passthru attributes and the target attribute as pass-through attributes on the span, even though the target attribute will have no effect on a span. Render the current value of the component as the content of the span. Return."

I've also ensured that no JavaScript code is rendered on behalf of a commandLink or commandButton that is disabled.

column1: issue when having a pop-up on top of another one
column42:
Our application would need to have a pop-up on top of another one.

To keep things simple, I have built an example based on the booking-faces application.

I have the following xml code:

<view-state id="changeSearchCriteria" view="enterSearchCriteria.xhtml" popup="true">
		<on-entry>
			<render fragments="hotelSearchFragment" />
		</on-entry>
		<transition on="search" to="reviewHotels">
			<evaluate expression="searchCriteria.resetPage()"/>
		</transition>
		<transition on="popTransition" to="popState"/>
	</view-state>
	
	<view-state id="popState" view="enterSearchCriteria.xhtml" popup="true">
		<on-entry>
			<render fragments="hotelSearchFragment" />
		</on-entry>
		<transition on="search" to="reviewHotels">
			<evaluate expression="searchCriteria.resetPage()"/>
		</transition>
	</view-state>

column1: datePattern attribute not honored in Spring JS decorator for Dojo DateTextBox
column42:
Specifying a date pattern in a Spring JS decorator for Dojo DateTextBox is not honored:

<script type="text/javascript">Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.ElementDecoration({elementId : "birthDaySpringJS", widgetType : "dijit.form.DateTextBox", widgetAttrs : {datePattern : "dd/MM/yyyy"}})); </script>

Essentially Dojo seems to select a default localized format when using the date widget (for US locale this is M/dd/yyyy) and does not a accept (manually typed) input like 15/06/2009.

Doing the same using Dojo directly works fine:

 <input type="text" name="birthDayDojo" constraints="{datePattern:'dd/MM/yyyy'}" value="" dojoType="dijit.form.DateTextBox" />

This emits the correct date format when using the Dojo date widget.
column91:
17/Jun/09 10:16 AM;sschmidt;Had a quick chat with Jeremy and he suggested this:

<script type="text/javascript">Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.ElementDecoration({elementId : "birthDaySpringJS", widgetType : "dijit.form.DateTextBox", widgetAttrs : {constraints : {datePattern:'dd/MM/yyyy'}}})); </script>

This works fine!
column93:
06/Oct/10 4:32 AM;rstoya05-aop;1. dijit.form.DateTextBox uses locales for the display of a date.
"Routines in the dojo.date.locale package are used against the setting of djConfig.locale or the locale of the user's browser to determine the appropriate behavior." (http://docs.dojocampus.org/dijit/form/DateTextBox)

2. dijit.form.DateTextBox uses a fixed pattern to communicate the server side:
"DateTextBox uses ISO8601/RFC3339 format yyyy-MM-dd to specify dates when communicating outside the Javascript realm. This format is both neutral to cultural formatting conventions as well as to time zones."

As pointed out already (1) can be customized by passing "constraints : { datePattern : '...' }". Unfortunately that only takes care of #1. Unfortunately there is no way to customize #2 without overriding the parts of dijit.form.DateTextBox. This is why we have datePattern in widgetAttrs. It causes Spring.ElementDecoration to parse and serialize the server-side date according to the specified pattern.

This is why as Krzysztof pointed out using widgetAttrs : { datePattern : '...', constrains : { datePattern : '...' } ) works but is less then ideal because the date pattern is specified twice. 

There is a suggested solution on http://docs.dojocampus.org/dijit/form/DateTextBox under the section "Alternate Date Format to/from a Server", which sets the initial value to "", provides an onChange handler that formats the date each time it changes, and also invokes the same handler initially. A quick test shows that doesn't work.

Instead Spring.ElementDecoration can automatically add the constraints property when a datePattern is specified.
column94:
06/Oct/10 5:30 AM;rstoya05-aop;Fixed by adding a constraints property in addition to parsing the value and and serializing it according to the datePattern in widgetAttrs. 

I've also filed this issue in the Dojo tracker:
http://bugs.dojotoolkit.org/ticket/11835

column1: ResourceSerlvet  cannot be mapped to a servlet path without prefix
column42:
Suppose the ResourceServlet would be used to load resource files from anywhere in the application, without using a servlet prefix. E.g.: if there is no file in /context-root/scripts/my.js, it should load it from the classpath.
In such case, one would want to map the servlet using this kind of mapping:
<servlet-mapping>
    <servlet-name>resourceServlet</servlet-name>
    <url-pattern>*.gif</url-pattern>
    <url-pattern>*.ico</url-pattern>
    <url-pattern>*.jpeg</url-pattern>
    <url-pattern>*.jpg</url-pattern>
    <url-pattern>*.js</url-pattern>
    <url-pattern>*.png</url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

Since the ResourceServlet is using the getPathInfo() method, there has to be a servlet prefix; getPathInfo() will return null in this kind of configuration.

Can a default path be used when the getPathInfo() returns null? E.g.:
if (rawResourcePath == null) {
    rawResourcePath = request.getRequestURI().substring(request.getContextPath().length());
}

The only way to work around this problem, is by wrapping the request that returns a non-null path. (See the attached .java files.)

Best regards,
Wannes Simons.

column1: sf:commandLink does not work when iterated by facelets ui:repeat
column42: The error occured when we tried to use a sf:commandLink in Web Flow to open up a viewstate as a popup. Apparently something goes wrong that does not trigger the state transition. The sf:commandLink was nested inside a  facelet ui:repeat element.

column1: Form elements do not get properly decorated when the 'widgetAttrs' property is omitted from the decoration
column42: When decorating a text input with a dijit.form.TimeTextBox on a page with multiple TimeTextBox decorations, the first field is decorated fine if the 'widgetAttrs' property is omitted from the decoration, but subsequent TimeTextBoxes do not get decorated properly if their decorations are missing a 'widgetAttrs' property.  The subsequent decorations will use the 'name' attribute of the first decorated input as the 'name' attribute for their own elements.  The proof is in the attached test case HTML file.
column91: 08/Jul/09 12:57 PM;rstoya05-aop;I think the issue is Spring.AbstractElementDecoration, which declares widgetAttrs as an object literal and that ends up being inherited and incorrectly re-used in all ElementDecorations that don't declare their own widgetAttrs.
column92:
19/May/10 11:14 PM;triqui;I can confirm this too. I just stumbled upon this with multiple FilteringSelect elements reusing attributes from the first widget created. I debugged it and Rossen is right, widgetAttributes are shared by all ElementDecorations in the same page. As already mentioned an easy workaround would be to add widgetAttrs: { } to every ElementDecoration.
Maybe that could be added to the docs till a fix is applied.

column1: Dojo.parse + ajax response
Spring.ElementDecoration takes the wrong element name when submitting a form
column42:
If you decorate two (or more) elements with the same widgetType (dijit.form.FilteringSelect), you will get the same element name when you submit the form (m1=1&m1= for the following sample).

	<form method="POST" action="test.html" acceptCharset="UTF-8">
		<select  id="m1" name="m1">
			<option value="1">test1</option>	
		</select>
		<select id="m2" name="m2">	
			<option value="2">test2</option>	
		</select>
		<input type="submit" />
	</form>
	<script type="text/javascript">
		Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.ElementDecoration({
			elementId: "m1",
			widgetType: "dijit.form.FilteringSelect"}));
		Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.ElementDecoration({
			elementId: "m2",
			widgetType: "dijit.form.FilteringSelect"}));
	</script>

column1: validateAllOnClick applies to entire page instead of just target form
column42:
When using validateAllOnClick, the validation is applied to the entire page, instead of just the enclosing form. This makes it impossible to consistently use the Spring Faces validation on a page with two forms. For example: 

<h:form id="one">
    <sf:clientTextValidator required="true">
        <h:inputText id="searchOne" required="true" />
    </sf:clientTextValidator> 
    <sf:validateAllOnClick>
        <sf:commandLink id="searchCommandOne" action="searchOneAction" />
    </sf:validateAllOnClick>
</h:form>
<h:form id="two">
    <sf:clientTextValidator required="true">
        <h:inputText id="searchTwo" required="true" />
    </sf:clientTextValidator> 
    <sf:validateAllOnClick>
        <sf:commandLink id="searchCommandTwo" action="searchTwoAction" />
    </sf:validateAllOnClick>
</h:form>

If the user wants to use form two, he will not be able to submit without entering text into searchOne, even though that field is clearly not relevant to form two. 

It looks like for the Spring.validateAll function in Spring.js, it's checking all validate decorations for the page, instead of restricting them to those for the form.
column91: 25/May/10 3:30 AM;jryder;We are using Spring Web Flow 2.0.8 in a portal environment and this is an issue for us as well.  In some cases we have one form per portlet and are dipslaying more than one instance of that portlet on a page.  In other cases we have instances of several different portlets (that each contain unrelated forms) on a single page.  In either case, ValidateAllDecoration does not work for us when multiple forms are present.  We really need a way to validate only a specific form.  As indicated by Stevi, this has been mentioned by others on the forum (http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=73594).  A patch is proposed in SJS-53 (which looks like a duplicate of this issue).

column1: Split out JSF 2 specific methods from FlowFacesContext for backwards compatibility with JSF 1.2
column42: While it is generally possible to  use FlowFacesContext in JSF 1.2 because JSF 2 methods (and types) are never called, if the faces context is used in EL expressions in a JSF view, then the introspection causes all declared methods to load their input and output types causing ClassCastException.

column1: AjaxTilesView does not handle cascaded attributes properly for dynamically generated Tiles definitions.
column42:
When rendering with a dynamically generated Tiles definition, cascade attributes are not available in the AttributeContext and hence cannot be used with the <tiles:insert-attribute> tag on a JSP page.

The problem was originally reported by by Mandus Elfving in comments under [SWF-1053] ~ 24/Jun/2010. The comments include a detailed description and tests to demonstrate the issue.
column91: 11/Jul/10 10:41 AM;rstoya05-aop;Closing this issue. It is no longer needed after [SWF-1053] was re-opened.

column1: Incorrect distribution of methods between FlowApplication and Jsf2FlowApplication
column42: Some JSF 1.2 specific methods were erroneously added to Jsf2FlowApplication instead of FlowApplication. This causes backwards compatibility issues with Apache MyFaces 1.2 where some of these methods throw UnsupportedOperationException.

column1: OpenEntityManagerInViewInterceptor don't work when using on-entry action of a transition and lazy loading properties with Hibernate.
column42:
When using spring web flow with OpenEntityManagerInViewInterceptor, the LazyInitializationException is fixed when retrieving entities within transition using <on-render> action, but when using <on-entry> action, the exception still is there.

I could verify that the OpenEntityManagerInViewInterceptor works because we stopped having the LazyInitializationException that we were having on many pages, but as I mentioned above, it keep happening when using <on-entry> action. 
When we change the type of action from <on-entry> to <on-render>, the exception disappears. 

Trying to debug the problem, we found that when putting a breakpoint on the getter of the lazy fetched property and inspecting it (using the IDE tools from Spring Source Tool Suite), the property is filled accordingly and the exception does not occur. If we only put a breakpoint on this getter but we do not inspect the value, the exception still is there. 

I'm attaching two logs (trace) from the same request causing the error, one using <on-entry> action with the exception at the end; and one using <on-render> action which completes successfully. 

Contact if further information/test/help is needed.
column91: 26/Jun/10 9:17 AM;ezequiel;Tested on version 2.1.0.RELEASE with jsf 2, and the problem is still happening.
column92: 26/Jun/10 9:24 AM;kdonald;That is expected because a redirect happens between entry and render.
column93:
27/Jun/10 2:45 PM;ezequiel;First of all, thank a lot for the response.

So, as I understand (please correct me if I'm wrong); when a <view-state> is entered (maybe because of an action being activated on a browser event, as is being done on my scenario):

1)First, the request that changed to the new <view-state> arrives at the server, where the interceptor (OEMIVI) attaches a EntityManager to the entire processing of this request;
2)Then, I suppose that the <on-entry> actions of the new <view-state> are executed (as part of the processing of the request of point 1, so the EM should be there I think),
3)After this, a redirect (the one you mentioned?) is sent to the browser to signal that the resource that has been asked for has moved, and the browser issues a get for the new resource-url;
4)Finally, a new request is processed, and the actions of <on-render> of the new <view-state> are executed, as part of the get request done by the browser (at this point, an EM should already have been attached to the thread by the OEMIVI interceptor).

So, on both actions, <on-entry> and <on-render>, the interceptor should have attached an EM to the thread that is processing the request, even if those actions are processed on different requests, letting lazy-properties be initialized and loaded correctly using this EM.

Shouldn't the detached entities that had lazy-loaded properties get reattached to this EM when trying to access the lazy-loaded properties, or at least this lazy-loaded properties be filled using this EM?
Is this an issue of the OEMIVI or the JPA implementation (hibernate in my case) rather than a SWF issue?

I'll try some more test to see if the behavior between request is happening on other scenarios (maybe with flowScope entity-variables, whose lazy-loaded properties are accessed in a different request that the one that loaded the entity-variable).
As I understood the OEMIVI should provide an EM to those entities that where detached (maybe because the transaction that loaded them finished), and whose lazy-loaded properties are accessed/read after that.

Finally; sorry for my not so good/quite bad English. 
If I can be of any assistance in resolving this possible issue please let me know.
column94:
15/Jul/10 4:56 AM;ezequiel;Doing more tests, I found that between transition of a view-state the exception occurs when trying to access a lazy-loaded property of an entity retrieved from the base on another transition.
May be I misunderstood something; is this behavior the correct one when using OpenEntityManagerInViewInterceptor??, shouldn't entities associated to the viewScope/flowScope get reattached to a session/entitymananger (the one associated to the thread by the OEMINI) even on different request to the server, and not only on the same request that loaded the entity.
Is this correct/expected behavior?
column95:
17/Jul/10 9:18 AM;ezequiel;Not a Bug, it is just the expected behavior of OEMIVI.
I misunderstood the concept of this interceptor. 
This issue can be safety discarded.

column1: Spring web flow looses the extension ( as configured in the servlet mapping ) whenever redirects a request on session timeout.
column42:
We have a system configured to map the following pattern "*.swf" to be handled by Spring Web Flow servelt, this is, whenever the application gets a request like "whatever.swf" request, Spring Web Flow services it.

Whenever the HttpSession expires, and the user executes a request to the server, Spring Web Flow realizes that the session has expired and tries to redirect the user ( 302 ) to a URL that is composed in the excepcion handling code.

The problem arises at the mentioned URL composition, Spring Web Flow is not aware of the mapping and composes an URL that includes the name of the action requested without any execution parameter ( at that moment the execution context is already gone ), but also lacks of the extension configured in the servlet mapping.

The effect is that if there is no "/*" mapping in the application's web.xml the user get a 404.
column91:
18/Jun/10 12:29 AM;rstoya05-aop;I think what you are looking for is this:
https://src.springframework.org/svn/spring-webflow/branches/spring-webflow-2.1-maintenance/spring-webflow/src/main/java/org/springframework/webflow/context/servlet/FilenameFlowUrlHandler.java

An alternative FlowUrlHandler implementation that can be set on the FlowHandlerAdapter. It was added in Spring Web Flow 2.0.5 so upgrading to 2.0.9 or 2.1.0 would probably resolve the issue.
column92:
20/Jun/10 7:47 PM;argaldo;Indeed it is what I was looking for. Great!

I thought it was a bug as we were constrained to SWF 2.0.2 and it seams, as you say, that there were no support for this kind of behaviour at that time.

Thank you very much for your prompt reply. You can consider this issue solved.

column43: Using: Spring Web Flow 2.1.0.RC1 + JSF 2 (PR2) + Hibernate + tc server from spring source tool suite
column91:
14/Jun/10 1:46 AM;rstoya05-aop;I was able to reproduce the issue with the booking-faces sample by switching to OGNL as follows:

<faces:flow-builder-services id="facesFlowBuilderServices" development="true" expression-parser="parser" />
<bean id="parser" class="org.springframework.webflow.expression.WebFlowOgnlExpressionParser"/>

The explanation is that with the above configuration the WebFlowOgnlExpressionParser gets set up with a DefaultConversionService (OgnlExpressionParser, line 37) by default, so unless a different instance of a ConversionService gets passed to it (e.g. FacesConversionService) then OGNL expressions requiring type conversion fail to find custom converters.

The issue goes away when this configuration is used instead:

<faces:flow-builder-services id="facesFlowBuilderServices" development="true" conversion-service="conversionService" expression-parser="parser" />
<bean id="conversionService" class="org.springframework.faces.model.converter.FacesConversionService"/>
<bean id="parser" class="org.springframework.webflow.expression.WebFlowOgnlExpressionParser">
	<property name="conversionService" ref="conversionService"/>
</bean>

Based on that I think there is no issue to fix but I can improve the sample code in the documentation to emphasize the importance of setting up WebFlowOgnlExpressionParser with the conversion service that contains all the custom converters.

I tested it on version 2.1.0.RELEASE, and work perfect.

column1: MessageContextErrors ResolveMessageCodes
column42:
In the MessageContextErrors.rejectValue(...) method the default message is passed into resolveMessageCodes(...) incorrectly.

The current method call is as follows:

resolveMessageCodes(errorCode, defaultMessage, field, fieldType)

The correct method call is as follows:

resolveMessageCodes(errorCode, objectName, field, fieldType)
column91: 01/Dec/10 4:08 AM;rstoya05-aop;Scheduling for 2.3.0 as this affects JSR-303 validation via LocalValidatorFactoryBean that ends up calling MessageContextErrors.

column1: Default conversion service cannot convert unmodifyableSet to List
column42:
This test shows that the default behaviour of spring when converting to lists
is not always as expected.

When converting a UnmodifiableSet (aquired by Collections.unmodifiableSet)
to java.util.List it returns a List with the Set as the only element.

Expected return value is a list that contains all elements from the set.

column1: Incorrect PhaseListener execution order
column42:
JSF 1.1 and 1.2 spec say in the chapter '11.3 PhaseListeners' that "When the lifecycle phase exits, due
to an exception or normal termination, the afterPhase() listeners must be called in
reverse order from the beforePhase() listeners in the following manner."

In Spring Faces, the PhaseListeners beforePhase() and afterPhase() methods are invoked in the same order, not complying the spec.
See org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfUtils notifyBeforeListeners() and notifyAfterListeners() methods.

column42:

	at javax.faces.component.UIForm.processDecodes(UIForm.java:216)

Along with this change the dependency on com.springsource.com.sun.facelets should also be removed and the Facelets implementation in jsf-impl used instead.
column91:
02/Jun/10 7:02 AM;rstoya05-aop;Various updates have been made to ensure compatibility with Mojarra and Apache MyFaces versions 2 and 1.2. 

The com.sun.facelets dependency has been removed from all samples including booking-faces and jsf-booking (but not booking-portlet-faces). The same samples are also configured to use the 2.0 version of the faces-config XML namespace. The jsf-booking sample was updated to take advantage of JSF 2 features resulting in a smaller faces-config.xml.

Please, note that partial state saving is not currently supported and must be disabled through the "javax.faces.PARTIAL_STATE_SAVING" servlet context parameter.

column1: Binding list into checkboxes will reset to null if you add grid's paging functionality
column42:
I created a grid with checkbox column that binds to List<String> (list).

><form:checkbox path="selectedItemLinkIdList" value="${item.linkId}" />

if the case that, all data are displayed in the grid, all checked items are binded upon submit.
but after I add paging functionality to the grid... the previously checked items were not bonded.

scenario:
1) display 1-10 records of 100 (Page1)
2) put check to 10 records
3) click Next Page (confirmed that the 1-10 checked items were bonded into list)
4) display 11-20 records of 100 (Page2)
5) click Previous Page (confirmed that the 1-10 checked items were disappeared list)
6) display 1-10 records of 100 (Page) but the previously checked items were not checked

problem:
upon Next Page, it tries to lookup again the checked items of the current displayed data then do the remove/add into list.

maybe this is the correct behavior but is there a way to support it also...?

column1: AjaxTilesView fails to render multiple fragments
column42:
We decided to use Spring 3 and Spring Web Flow 2.1.0.M1 to get around Bug SWF-1053 on Tomcat 6.

AjaxTilesView only renders the *first* fragment when multiple fragments are requested. In 2.0.9 rendering of multiple fragments worked properly.

Our configuration:
{code:xml}
<bean id="tilesViewResolver" class="org.springframework.js.ajax.AjaxUrlBasedViewResolver">
		<property name="order" value="2" />
		<property name="viewClass"
			value="org.springframework.js.ajax.tiles2.AjaxTilesView" />
</bean>
{code}

I noticed in 2.0.9 version of *AjaxTilesView* the line
{{response.flushBuffer();}} was present in {{renderMergedOutputModel}}

In 2.1.0.M1 this line is commented out.
When I remove the comment the view works again. We've tested with IE6 and Firefox 3.6.3

After some debugging with Firebug I think that I've found the problem.
Without the {{response.flushBuffer();}} the server send a {{Content-length}} header with the length of the *first* fragment only. Obviously the browser stops reading the request after the content length has been reached.
With {{response.flushBuffer();}}  the response doesn't contain a  {{Content-length}} at all and all fragments get rendered by the browser.
column91:
10/May/10 8:51 PM;rstoya05-aop;Linking in related issues for more background information:
https://jira.springsource.org/browse/SWF-1078?focusedCommentId=53602&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_53602
column92: 11/May/10 2:52 AM;rstoya05-aop;Tiles does either a forward or an include when rendering. This is done conditionally depending on whether the response has been committed. When multiple fragments need to be rendered, the individual JSP fragments need to be included, not forwarded to. I've added back the code that commits the response by flushing the response buffer. This will be done conditionally only when multiple fragments are being rendered.

column1: Registering implementation of Mapper in classes extending AbstractMvcView is not trivial
column42:
AbstractMvcView performs binding by instantiating a DefaultMapper, instead of some provided mapper class. 
When subclassing ServletMvcView to provide a custom mapper, the bind method cannot be overridden easily as it private.
Methods called by bind method reference DefaultMapper instead of the Mapper interface.
MvcViewFactoryCreator does not provide a hook for supplying a custom ViewFactory class.
Thus, to change from DefaultMapper the default MvcView, viewFactory, and viewFactoryCreator classes must be subclassed.
column91: 04/May/10 8:55 AM;cduplichien;Sorry, I appear to have effectively created a duplicate of SWF-1218.
column92:
17/May/10 1:04 AM;rstoya05-aop;Clark, the bind() method passes a DefaultMapper to subordinate methods (addModelBindings and addDefaultMappings) in order to add one or more instances of DefaultMapping. The Mapper interface on the other hand has a map method only. It does not specify how the mapping is to be done between the source and the target and is not aware for example that it can be done by through Mapping instances. 

Does your Mapper implementation not rely on Mapping instances at all? If so then it sounds like you wouldn't need the subordinate methods (addModelBindings and addDefaultMappings) either.

There is a ticket scheduled for 2.1.0.M2 to make AbstractMvcView.bind() protected. Have a look at [SWF-1218] and comment here. 

Thanks
column93: 17/May/10 7:30 PM;rstoya05-aop;I believe the changes for [SWF-1218] addressed this issue as well. Please comment if you think that's not the case.

column1: <form:select> binding to object not functioning
column42:
When setting up a model with a target object (MyObject) and attempting to bind a list of <form:select> items, where the backing objects are Map<Key,MyObject>, the binding operation does not automatically bind the selected MyObject from the map to the model. Creating a type converter simply uses the object the type converter emits to bind to the model. 

SWF 1.x used to allow the binding to happen automatically when binding a <form:select> tag to a model.

Since the objects in the select binding are complex, a type converter does not provide the necessary solution because type converters only have access to the single 'String' when converting from HTML->Object. There doesn't seem to be a way to have a reference to the backing Map<> object to the select box to pick the proper value.

The binding could happen on an <evaluate/> within the flow but this seems like a workaround.

I should be able to throw a List of objects into the <form:select> and, assuming the types are assignable, automatically pick the item off the list and bind it to the model.
column91:
29/Mar/10 12:23 AM;jonnio;Here is my analysis to date.

Using SWF 2.8 and MVC 3.0.1.RELEASE:

1. The AbstractMvcView can ONLY bind request parameters to model objects as Strings OR objects created from a String. it cannot bind objects from scope to the model because the bind method only passes the requestParameterMap to the mapper.map. Line 405 is:

		return mapper.map(requestParameters, model);
and should probably be
		return mapper.map(flowScopes(), model);

Yes, there is a 'converter' mechanism but since the converters are stateless and do not receive 'scope' in the binding process, there is no way to convert from 'string' to 'complete object'. I would have to serialize my object out as base64 or something. Seriously?

2. There needs to be some level of searching through the scope with the bound EL expression and then fall back to the type converter. I think this is because the framework won't know what the binding state is? Maybe in the exposure of the binding model, some indicator can be added that tells the expression engine where or even IF to look using EL.

3. The spring <form:select, <form:options tags do not work well enough to make this happen anyway. I end up writing jstl like:
    <form:select path="myObject">
        <c:forEach items="${testValues}" var="val" varStatus="stat">
            <option value="testValues[${stat.index}]" label="${testValues[stat.index].name}"
                    selected="${val eq targetValue }"/>
        </c:forEach>
    </form:select>

because the option writer only writes the actual 'key' value as the parameter name. In reality, you need a syntax like myObjectMap[keyvalue], etc so the expression engine has something to go with. Just writing the 'key' and 'value' means that the mapping engine will get the key with no variable scope. This means the system will always give a type mismatch because it won't find an object with a name of 'key' and will therefore attempt to bind the 'string' parameter value.

I think the spring option tags should write object[key], object[index] when writing from maps and collections. There should be a new flag on the writer to trigger this behavior? I do think this is backwards compatible so maybe it is not an issue.

4. Another way to solve this might be to enhance the binding so I can have a 'stateful' twowayconverter that somehow sources the mapping from the core list. This means I have to do a lot more work to setup the binding rather than just using the view layer to do the work.

5. Ironically, this used to work in the older versions of spring. It is not clear to me why this functionality was rolled back.
column92: 29/Mar/10 12:48 AM;kdonald;Web Flow 1's FormAction.bind/bindAndValidate methods only ever bound request parameters as well, so I'm having a hard time following how this worked "out of the box" in the previous version.  All form-based binding in both MVC and Web Flow has always been based on binding incoming request parameter strings to model properties, using property editors/type converters as the mechanism to convert from String to Object.
column93:
29/Mar/10 2:22 AM;jonnio;Maybe i am mistaken then. It was a while ago but I do know that we could get map binding to work with just jstl manipulation. We could also inject the propertyeditor with a list of items to bind.

Do you have any workround suggestions?
column94: 20/Apr/10 5:10 AM;jonnio;Sok Keith, I have some good ideas how to at least configure the binder to at least check if binding to/from a map using a request parameter based key might work. This would mesh nicely with the existing tag library binding mechanisms and also allow the binding to happen directly from the model. I will post a patch and see what you guys think.
column96: 12/May/10 11:04 PM;jonnio;So, how do you do #2? The converters are supposed to be 'singleton' instances. How would the engine know how to bind a specific set of request parameters for my session to the converter? There is no session adapter mechanism to bind the converter to a scoped object for lookup. Suggestions?
column97:
13/May/10 12:30 AM;rstoya05-aop;
I was hoping #1 would work for your case. It's simple and almost identical to your description (a field of type int instead of MyObject and an extra getter).

To your question.. the converters are indeed singletons and singletons can be injected with other objects of a more short-lived scope with the help of an AOP scoped proxy. The configuration look like this:

<bean id="converter" class="MyConverter">
    <property name="someProperty" ref="scopedSpringBean" />
</bean>

<bean id="scopedSpringBean" class="MyScopedObject" scope="flow">
    <aop:scoped-proxy/>
</bean>

It can be done with annotations as well if you prefer that (@Component + @Scope with proxyMode attribute). In either case you'll need bean factory post processor to enable the custom "flow" scope:

<bean class="org.springframework.webflow.scope.ScopeRegistrar"/>

Keep in mind you can access "scopedSpringBean" within the flow definition in EL expressions but you will not find a flow-scoped object called "scopedSpringBean". The actual instance of MyScopedObject is in flow scope but under a slightly different name to avoid a name clash with flow variables of the same name.

column1: transitions on exceptions ignore history attribute
column42:
Transitions for handling exceptions (with on-exception attribute) ignore history attribute. 

TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler creates new Transition with TargetStateResolver (in TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler line 110 ). However it doesn't populate attribute map of this new Transition , so history attribute is ignored when transition is executed.
column91:
08/Mar/14 6:44 AM;telmo.costa@gmail.com;I also bumped at this problem. I need to discard history in an on-exception transition, but effectively the handler does not copy the history attribute value to the transition attributes map it builds.

It seems like an easy patch, but I noticed this issue is unresolved for 4 years now. Is there a reason not to resolve it?

I don't think it is possible to use a modified handler to replace the original and reuse the transitions definition, as the original handler is directly instanciated in the code. I will have to get around with a specific custom handler, but it would really nice to use the original support.

Thanks in advance.

column1: JpaFlowExecutionListener does not close db-connections when lazy loading is used
column42:
We are using JPA and flow managed persistence with spring web flow. On pages that use entities which have properties that are lazily-loaded, with each call of the page one db connection is aquired and not released.
This quickly leads to db-blocking because connections are not released. 
If we change the properties to eager loading everything works fine.

Looking at the code of JpaFlowExecutionListener and HibernateFlowExecutionListener we see that the later one does disconnect the hibernate session on each call of "paused" while the JpaFlowExecutionListener does not do that.
column91:
07/Apr/10 1:37 AM;rstoya05-aop;Please provide more information on how to reproduce this issue including dependencies (JPA provider, JDBC driver, connection pool)  and relevant code including JPA mappings and queries. 

I'm unable to re-create it by using the Spring Travel sample application as a sandbox, using Apache DBCP, and configuring lazy loading from Booking to Hotel and User.

With regards to the differences between the Hibernate and the JPA FlowExecutionListeners, JPA does not provide a configurable connection release mode and providers should always eagerly release JDBC connections.
column92: 07/Apr/10 8:05 AM;cgs;Which version of Spring? The symptoms sound similar to SPR-6895.
column93: 12/Apr/10 5:08 AM;rstoya05-aop;Moving to 2.1 to allow more time for feedback and to retest with Spring 3.0.x.
column94: 12/May/10 5:22 AM;rstoya05-aop;This issue appears to match the description of [SPR-6895], which was fixed in Spring 3.0.2 (thanks Christopher for pointing that out). Having failed to reproduce it and without any further information on how to do so, I am closing it with the assumption that it's fixed.

column1: Hitting escape or close on a popup causes webflow to become out of sync
column42:
When a view state is rendered as a AJAX popup the DOJO dialog can be cancelled by clicking on the small X or by hitting the escape key.  The cancel operation replaces the flow execution key (although not visually in the browser URL) so webflow becomes out of sync and will handle the next button click as if the state is still on the popup.

This behaviour can be demonstrated on the travel reference application by clicking "change search" on the results page then hitting escape.

I guess there are a number of ways that this could be fixed:

- Disable the cancel for the dialog so you have to execute a form post
- Somehow trigger a webflow transition on the cancel
- Fixup the flow execution key if onCancel occurs so that it matches the key visible on the URL
column91:
27/Aug/10 3:13 AM;rstoya05-aop;Phil, I'm not able to reproduce this. I guess I'm not quite sure what you mean by "The cancel operation replaces the flow execution key (although not visually in the browser URL)".

Let's say on the results page all links are e1s2. Press "change search", the resulting modal dialog has a form with e1s3. Close the dialog (hit x or escape) and you're back to the page where all links are e1s2. This is okay because the view state associated with e1s2 is still there and any links/buttons can still submit. What am I missing? 

I'm using 2.2 but I don't think that matters.

Perhaps it was an issue specific to 2.0.8.

The reference application running here http://richweb.springframework.org/swf-booking-faces/spring/main looks like it may have the bug but without access to the logs it is hard to tell.  If you click “Change Search” then on the (X) then click on “View Hotel” the first click does nothing (I think this is where the error will be logged).  Click again and it works.

I think this one can just be closed.

Cheers,
Phil.

column1: Redirect after POST not occuring with transition from view-state to end-state
column42:
It is not possible have redirect after POST in Spring Webflow 1.0.6 when transitioning from a view-state to an end-state (unless the end state uses an external redirect).

Here is the Tomcat access log for a straight run through the 'birthdate' sample. Note the last request, is a POST which gets a 200 response code. This was a submission to resume the "enterCardInformation" view-state, resulting in a chain of transitions leading to the "displayAge" end-state.

127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/flowAction.do?_flowId=birthdate HTTP/1.1" 302 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/flowAction.do?_flowExecutionKey=_c1B3BCC9E-2BBB-4F25-4813-351A8A8A472C_k842A97B1-E31E-DC5D-E506-30D7F33C2F3C HTTP/1.1" 200 1281
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/style.css HTTP/1.1" 304 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/images/spring-logo.jpg HTTP/1.1" 304 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/images/webflow-logo.jpg HTTP/1.1" 304 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:41:55 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/images/submit.gif HTTP/1.1" 304 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:42:12 +0000] "POST /swf-birthdate/flowAction.do HTTP/1.1" 302 -
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:42:12 +0000] "GET /swf-birthdate/flowAction.do?_flowExecutionKey=_c1B3BCC9E-2BBB-4F25-4813-351A8A8A472C_k354BDCFC-C248-30CA-1581-00A8B09BF443 HTTP/1.1" 200 1522
127.0.0.1 - - [18/Jan/2010:14:42:19 +0000] "POST /swf-birthdate/flowAction.do HTTP/1.1" 200 780

What I think ought to happen is either:

a/ redirect behaviour on entry to end-state should follow same rules as on entry to view-state (i.e. depend on setting of alwaysRedirectOnPause).

OR

b/ it should at least be possible to use a 'redirect:' flag on the view attribute of an end-state to force a redirect on entry to the end-state.

1) Make LocalAttributeMap#createTargetMap() methods offer up Hashtables rather than HashMaps, since Hashtable's writeObject() method is marked synchronized

2) Arrange for LocalAttributeMap#writeObject() to obtain its 'attributes' field's lock before serializing.

3) ??

column1: attribute 'image' of commandButton is not rendered
column42:
sf:commandButton has an image attribute that is supposed to generate a tag of the form. I would expect that this tag:

 <sf:commandbutton id="button" action="some_transition" processIds="*" image="image.gif"/>

should generate this html code:

 <input id="button" type="image" src="image.gif"/>

However, the result displays a button instead of the image, and the html is as follows:

 <input id="button" type="submit" onclick="Spring.remoting.submitForm(....)" />
