column91:
13/Feb/10 9:08 AM;viy;Just an opinion (cause some time ago I also developed a some kind of ToStringifier).

ToStringCreator is a simple but powerful Spring solution for generating toString() representation for any Java obj which doesn't have pretty-printing implemented toString(). But it seems that ToStringCreator doesn't track cycles in objects graph.
This means that having cycled object graph (A->B->C->A: means instance A references instance B which in turn references instance C and so on) then any attempt to pretty-print any of A, B, C via ToStringCreator will cause similar StackOverflowError.

In your stacktrace above we see such a cycle:
org.springframework.webflow.core.collection.LocalAttributeMap -> org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImpl -> org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowSessionImpl -> org.springframework.webflow.core.collection.LocalAttributeMap
(of course I mean that instances of the correspondent classes have a cycle not the classes)

Solutions:
1. ToStringCreator should track the cycles. But tracking the cycles will overweight the simple and lightweight ToStringCreator.
2. All src code which uses ToStringCreator should never pass object involved in cycled objects graph to ToStringCreator for pretty-printing.
(Because the 2-nd one couldn't be guaranteed because codebase of src relying on Spring is a big enough then the only 1-st option may really fix a problem)

Workaround for you:
Just turn off logging level for 'org.springframework' back. I don't see any other solution for the moment.

HTH

column1: POMs of Spring Web Flow 2 artifacts at maven central repo wrongfuly contain references to external repositories
column42: POMs like [spring-binding-2.0.8.RELEASE.pom|http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/springframework/webflow/spring-binding/2.0.8.RELEASE/spring-binding-2.0.8.RELEASE.pom] and [spring-webflow-2.0.8.RELEASE.pom|http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/springframework/webflow/spring-webflow/2.0.8.RELEASE/spring-webflow-2.0.8.RELEASE.pom] contain references to external (non maven central) repositories, so they do not adhere to the rules for deploying artifacts to maven central repository (see "FAQ and common mistakes" in official ["Guide to uploading artifacts to the Central Repository"|http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-central-repository-upload.html]).

column1: Wrong error message when binding
column42:
When binding fails there is lookup only for the most matching version of error message, not for all.
User can not change localization of the message (if this is not the most matching one)

Let's say I have a value of type "BigDecimal". Messages subsystem should look for these keys inside messageSource:
item.item.novaHodnota.potencialniZdroj.hodnotyVlastnosti[2].hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch
item.item.novaHodnota.potencialniZdroj.hodnotyVlastnosti.hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch
item.novaHodnota.potencialniZdroj.hodnotyVlastnosti[2].hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch
item.novaHodnota.potencialniZdroj.hodnotyVlastnosti.hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch
hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch
java.math.BigDecimal.typeMismatch
typeMismatch"

But it alny looks for "item.item.novaHodnota.potencialniZdroj.hodnotyVlastnosti[2].hodnotaCislo.typeMismatch" (and return this as it's default message.

This is major problem when mapping Lists (as in my example), because user can not add messages for all indexes (there can be thousands of these)

column1: MyFaces bugs causes FacesMessage serialization failure in a clustered environment
column42:
One of changes in webflow 2.07 causes the message context to be stored across redirects, unfortunately a current MyFaces bug (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MYFACES-1347) causes serialization failure when running in a clustered environment.

Since the MyFaces issue has been opened since 2006 here is a work around patch that could be applied to webflow.

As this is a MyFaces issue you might not want to apply the patch but I will post it here anyway in case anyone else hits the same issue.

column1: sf:commandLinks do not work with IE in certain configurations
column42:
Due to an Internet Explorer defect/feature, if the site you are on is set as a Trusted Site and Active Scripting is disabled for the Internet zone, then sf:commandLinks do not appear to work (i.e. if you click on them then the URL bar changes to have a # appended to it but you stay on the same screen)

This is most likely due to the issue as documented @ http://support.microsoft.com/kb/948550
column43: Internet Explorer 6/7/8 where site you are on is set as a Trusted Site and Active Scripting is disabled for Internet zone.
column91: 21/Oct/09 10:37 AM;r2b2;Suggested patch (fixes issue for IE7). Still to be tested with other IE versions.
column92: 22/Oct/09 11:54 AM;r2b2;Have been thinking about this issue more and am wondering if it would be a good idea to have the sf:commandLink output be wrapped in a <span /> which would mean that other commandLinks wouldn't be clobbered by the innerHTML overwrite?

column1: FlowHandlerMapping.setFlowRegistry not implented as documented
column42: JavaDoc says: "Optional. If not set, this handler mapping will look in the containing application context for a bean with id flowRegistry." That's not true, you get an exception if you don't configure the flowRegistry explicitly. Should act as documented, defaulting is the sensible thing to do here. I would suggest do to the same for the FlowHandlerAdapter.setFlowExecutor, which is also required at the moment and could benefit from a default as well.

column1: ScopeRegistrar overrides the Spring request scope
column42:
ScopeRegistrar adds a "request" scope in the Spring scope system. Spring also defines a "request" scope (see WebApplicationContextUtils.registerWebApplicationScopes).

The problem is that it is impossible to use the two different scopes since Spring only allows one scope by name (the scopes are kept in a Map<String, Scope>).

I think that ScopeRegistrar should registers the "request" scope with a different name which does not conflict with the Spring "request" scope.

column1: Web Flow first wants to resolve the model before even checking if a databinding should be done at all
column42:
Filed on behalf of Agim Emruli, Agim.Emruli@springsource.com in regards to Support Issue #7504.

Web Flow has a small "bug" that it first wants to resolve the model before even checking if a data binding should be done at all.  There is no need to retrieve a model object if there is no data binding at all.

Attached is a patch that fixes the issue.

It would be great if this can be included into the standard web flow release.  If it cannot, then a customer specific release will need to be packaged to address the issue.

Thanks
column91: 10/Sep/09 7:12 AM;kdonald;We'll take a look at this and integrate into trunk promptly.  We can then discuss release roadmap.  Watch this space.  Thanks!
column92: 24/Sep/09 2:02 PM;kdonald;Fix applied.  We took a look at the suggested patch and decided to go with another approach to deal with this issue.  Rather than make changes to the ViewState event processing lifecycle, we applied a fix that simply returns a null model if the model expression fails to evaluate (instead of throwing the EvaluationException out).  The null model will cause no binding and validation logic to run, since there is no model to execute against.

When i replace the org.springframework.faces-2.0.8.RELEASE.jar with the org.springframework.faces-2.0.7.RELEASE.jar the APPLY_REQUEST_VALUES phase is invoked. The most parts of the application worked perfect. But some method references are changed. So that isn't a solution.

column1: Tomahawk panelTabbedPane/panelTab  serverSideTabSwitch="true" not working (client side switching does work)
column42:
The tomahawk tags panelTabbedPane/panelTab using serverSideTabSwitch="true" stopped responding in Webflow 2.0.7 and 2.0.8 (does work with 2.0.6).  

Using:

Spring Framework: 2.5.6
Myfaces: 1.2.6
Tomahawk: 1.1.8

Setting serverSideTabSwitch="false" (uses JS client side switching) is a workaround, but introduces a JS dependence.  Same issue also occurs when using RichFaces 3.3.0's tabPanel/tab tags (server side tab switching is unresponsive).  This probably eliminates tomahawk as the culprit.

Using

<context-param>
<param-name>facelets.BUILD_BEFORE_RESTORE</param-name>
<param-value>false</param-value>
</context-param>

as was done to "fix" SWF-1124 did not work.

column1: EL expression as transition criteria prevents suppression of validation or binding
column42:
Using EL expression that evaluates to true/false for transition criteria prevents the suppression of validation or binding through the use of attributes "validate=false" or "bind=false". The check on these attributes take place during processUserEvent, but this check simply matches eventId and transition.id using String.equals(). In the case of EL expression transition criteria, transition.id will never matches the eventId for any matching transition.

Not sure if it is by design, hence the documentation should mention such non-working combination, or this problem itself is an overlook. I am seeking feedback from dev team and plan accordingly.

PS: I can already come up with one reason not to execute the transition criteria during processUserEvent, simply to prevent repeated execution in case the EL makes any changes to values (once in processUserEvent, and once during actual lookup of transition in the flow execution). But then such EL is not so fitting for the purpose of matching criteria.

column1: Concurrent threads in flow causing sessionMap attribute to return null
column42:
Two concurrent threads executing the same flow action result in either externalContext.sessionMap.cart to return null or the returned value not being set in flowScope in one of the threads.

<on-start>
	<set name="flowScope.cart" value="externalContext.sessionMap.cart" type="cart.ShoppingCart"/>
</on-start>

02/Sep/09 7:54 PM;uttingj;Anyone explain this behaviour?

I decided to pass in the shopping cart to the top level flow using a flow handler which is fine in  a single threaded environment.
flow:

<input name="cart" type="cart.ShoppingCart" required="true" value="flowScope.cart"/>
<action-state id="decideOnActivityType">
	<evaluate expression="handsetActions.getActivityType(flowScope.cart.userSessionModel)"/>
	<transition on="contractHandset" to="decideOnStartState"/>
	<transition on="paygHandset" to="addPaygHandset"/>

public MutableAttributeMap createExecutionInputMap(HttpServletRequest request) {
        
        MutableAttributeMap map = null;
        
        HttpSession session = request.getSession();
        
        synchronized (session) {
        	ShoppingCart cart = (ShoppingCart) session.getAttribute("cart");
        	if(cart != null){
        		map = new LocalAttributeMap();
        		map.put("cart", cart);
        	}
        }

    }

column1: Apache Trinidad ajax requests (PPR) don't work.
column42:
In doResume method (ViewState.class), isAjaxRequest always returns false, SWF executes an incorrect redirect and PPR requests fail.

To solve this we need to create and configure a new AjaxHandler. This is not explained in the reference documentation.
column43:
Spring 2.5.6
Spring Web Flow 2.0.7.
MyFaces 1.2.3.
Apache Trinidad 1.2.11
column91:
04/Aug/09 9:19 AM;kdonald;Jeremy,
A note about AjaxHandler in the Web Flow docs would be helpful to the community.
column92:
05/Aug/09 10:18 AM;jeremyg484;The attached implementation is somewhat incomplete, though it is a good start.  It handles the detection of an Ajax request correctly, but still uses the Spring JavaScript-specific headers for handling a redirect.  The proper way to handle a redirect with Trinidad still needs to be determined before this could be included in Spring Faces.

That said, I have added a brief explanation of the AjaxHandler interface to the documentation as well as a note in the section on Trinidad linking to this issue.

column92:
22/Aug/09 6:53 AM;wwheeler;OK, I couldn't resist digging into this. :-)

ConfigurableApplicationContext.setId() method is new with Spring 3.0.0.M4. 

i did

$ mvn dependency:list | grep '3.0.0.M3'
[INFO]    org.springframework:org.springframework.asm:jar:3.0.0.M3:compile
[INFO]    org.springframework:org.springframework.context:jar:3.0.0.M3:compile
[INFO]    org.springframework:org.springframework.expression:jar:3.0.0.M3:compile

It turned out that one of my dependencies was a locally installed library that was built against 3.0.0.M3. I just reinstalled it and problem was solved.

So this isn't a bug. Just user error. ;-)

column1: Validator only runs if signature matches exact model object Class
column42:
when writing a Validator component, (matching the conventions of name), the signature of the method *must match exactly* the command object type.

Let's say my validation method is :
validateMyViewId(MyObject command, ValidationContext ctx) (...)

Then the validator will not run if command object is of type MyExtendedObject (extends MyObject)

This is a critical behaviour, in case the command object changes during the webflow, then validation won't be run anymore.

(The match is done in ValidationHelper class)
column91:
17/Jun/09 9:40 PM;cannyduck;The validation implementing method is also not found if the model object is a proxy. It that case the ValidationHelper should search in all implemented interfaces for a matching method.
If more than one method are found, all should be invoked.
column92: 18/Jun/09 12:38 AM;cannyduck;I attached a patch for the ValidationHelper that supports proxy and the inheritance handling. It would be great if Keith can review and integrate it into 2.0.8.
column93: 05/Aug/09 8:46 AM;jeremyg484;I have applied the patch and done some minor cleanup and added further unit tests.  Thanks for your contribution!
column94: 06/Aug/09 6:54 PM;cannyduck;Thanks for your commit Jeremy. Why do you removed the Proxy interface support? So that the ValidationHelper also searches for methods including one of the proxy interfaces.
column95:
21/Aug/09 8:28 AM;jacorob;Random comment in case someone stumbles across this due to their 2.0.7 validation failing after upgrading to 2.0.8 (like me). The change in 2.0.8 may break working 2.0.7 due to the undocumented automatic calling of a method named 'validate' on your Validator (regardless of whether or not the specific method validate${state} was found and invoked).

See issue http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-1170 for a more complete description.

column1: Validators can't be tested
column42:
It's not possible to test whether validation by convention would be executed during a transition.

Minor refactoring can cause Validators to not be executed anymore and there is no easy way to make this apparent. The mock classes for testing webflow never do any validation at all, so it's not possible to add this to unit tests. There is also no way to explicitly define a Validator in the flow definition which would at least show problems during runtime.

column1: Wrong ID assigned to the flow when the flows are registred using flow-location-pattern AND base-path
column42:
If we are trying to use a general pattern to register a set of flows in conjunction with the base-path attribute, SWF fails to assign the correct ID to the flow.

e.g. 

<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" flow-builder-services="flowBuilderServices" base-path="/WEB-INF/flows">
	<webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/*.xml" />
</webflow:flow-registry>

2009-06-15 15:44:10,221 DEBUG [org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl] - Registering flow definition 'ServletContext resource [/WEB-INF/flows/products/editProduct.xml]' under id 'products' >> 
2009-06-15 15:44:10,221 DEBUG [org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl] - Registering flow definition 'ServletContext resource [/WEB-INF/flows/truck.xml]' under id 'truck' >> 

removing the base-path, the issue is solved.

<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" flow-builder-services="flowBuilderServices">
	<webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/WEB-INF/flows/**/*.xml" />
</webflow:flow-registry>

2009-06-15 15:46:28,341 DEBUG [org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl] - Registering flow definition 'ServletContext resource [/WEB-INF/flows/products/editProduct.xml]' under id 'editProduct' >> 
2009-06-15 15:46:28,341 DEBUG [org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl] - Registering flow definition 'ServletContext resource [/WEB-INF/flows/truck.xml]' under id 'truck' >>
column43: Windows Vista x86, Eclipse 3.4.2 Ganymede, SWF 2.0.7, Spring Framework 2.5.6SEC01, Tomcat 6.0.20
column91: 14/Jun/09 11:55 PM;alexandru.ionita;Adding a tailing slash to the base-path attribute in not solving the problem.
column92: 15/Jun/09 12:21 AM;kdonald;What you're seeing is expected behavior that matches the algorithm described in the reference documentation and webflow-config schema.  With the base-path defined, flow ids are determined from the directory structure, with the expectation each directory is a flow directory where the directory name serves as the flow id.  This was done to make it easy to define globally unique flow ids from the path to the flow in the filesystem; for example, /hotels/booking/booking.xml and /car/booking/booking.xml would produce unique ids of "hotels/booking" and "car/booking" - if the id was only determined by the filename you'd have a collision.

The converter is getting applied going from String to List, but not from List back to String. But since my form also populates other fields of my domain object in addition the list of e-mails, and since I don't want this collection wrapper object in my real domain object that gets persisted, I need to create a special form backing object that contains my collection wrapper and other attributes, and then transfer from the form backer to my real domain object, and having parallel domain objects isn't good. column1: Endless Redirects happens when more then one request Parameter is present on redirect
column91: 05/Aug/09 9:40 AM;jeremyg484;I have improved this slightly in the case of JSF 1.2 by detecting the presence of the javax.faces.ViewState parameter.  Unfortunately, for JSF 1.1, we have to fall back to the other implementation as the name of the view state parameter is not guaranteed across implementations.  If you're stuck on JSF 1.1, you could always create a custom ViewFactoryCreator/ViewFactory/View impl that looks for an impl-specific parameter to detect a postback.

column1: Spring WebFlow throws IllegalArgumentException while binding map entries
column42:
If I'm not wrong, since 2.0.7 org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel implements org.springframework.validation.BindingResult. This affects behavior when binding properties of java.util.Map type.

BindStatus(RequestContext requestContext, String path, boolean htmlEscape) is instantiated for field of java.util.Map type. As far as I could trace relevant execution, Spring tries to determine type of map entries, and since map is empty type ends up to be null which is not acceptable as parameter to ConversionExecutorPropertyEditor(ConversionService conversionService, Class fieldType, String converterId) constructor called from BindingModel findEditor(String field, Class valueType) method.

column1: Conversations are not getting pushed to the top of the ConversationContainer list when requested
column42:
Here's the scenario:

1. I have a conversation with a series of links (conversation A), each link starts a new conversation.
2. I click a link and the new conversation starts.
3. I click the browser's back button.
4. The previous conversation (conversation A) is re-rendered.
5. I repeat steps 2 and 3 several times. Eventually conversation A is deleted because it is considered 'old'. The result is that SWF tries to start a new conversation when the back button is hit max-executions number of times.

Instead of this behaviour, SWF should push the current conversation to the top of the ConversationContainer's list so that it is not considered old.
column91: 30/Nov/09 12:04 AM;jonnio;Better yet, wrap the conversation and add a 'last accessed time' and expire the oldest one to be accessed.
column92:
07/Dec/09 1:25 AM;cduplichien;Here's what we've come up with as a local fix (still in testing):
1) Modify ConversationContainer to use a LinkedList instead of an ArrayList. New conversations go to the First, and when the maxConversations are exceeded, the Last is removed.
2) Add a "public void touch(ConversationId id)" method to the ConversationContainer, and expose it through the ConversationManager. This method simply moves the conversation with the given ConversationId to the First of the LinkedList, if the conversation exists.
3) Make a call to the touch method in your FlowExecutionRepository's getFlowExecution(FlowExecutionKey) method. The docs state "This should be called to resume a persistent flow execution.", so it appears the best place to place this call.

Now, any flow which is accessed to be resumed will have it's associated Conversation placed at the top of the ConversationContainer, preventing expiration.

column1: Rendering national characters to HTML don't work properly
column42:
Steps to reproduce:
Add any national characters to 'booking-faces' sample project. You can use these for instance 'рус'.
This is how resulting html look like "& # 1 0 5 6 ; & # 1 0 9 1 ; & # 1 0 8 9 ;" (without spaces) and should be just 3 characters in utf-8 encoding. These codes understood by browser and rendered correctly, but this leads to page growth in size in 3.5 times.
Same with 'booking-mvc' and CharacterEncodingFilter works fine.

column1: ValidationHelper should make use of Validator.supports method
column42:
invokeValidatorDefaultValidateMethod calls validate on Validator instances without checking if the validator actually supports the given model. 

The ambiguity in naming the model that led to this being an issue for me can (and probably should) be avoided but since the supports(clazz) method exists, it would be nice if it got used.

column1: required="true" on <binding> tag is ignored if there no corresping parameter in the request
column42:
Let's assume the following state definiton:

	<view-state id="shipmentAddress" view="shipmentAddress" model="orderModel">
		<binder>
			<binding property="order.customer.firstName"  required="true" />
			<binding property="order.customer.lastName"  required="true" />
		</binder>
		<transition on="continue" to="shipmentOptions"/>		
		<transition on="back" to="shop" bind="false"/>		
	</view-state>

Then if there is neither "order.customer.firstName" nor "order.customer.lastName" parameter in the HttpRequest then no validation is performed, which makes declarative validation useless, since we can't relay on date sent from the user (throughhtml form) to be correct.

column1: Unclosed Tags in Documentation
column42:
The following code for global-transitions is given in section 4.12 of the Spring Web Flow Reference:

<global-transitions>
    <transition on="login" to="login">
    <transition on="logout" to="logout">
</global-transitions>

The transition tags are not properly closed and should be 

    <transition on="login" to="login" />
    <transition on="logout" to="logout" />

column1: SelectionTrackingActionListener always sets current row selected
column42:
This line:
    ((SelectionAware) value).setCurrentRowSelected(true);
always sets the current row as selected for any ActionEvent involving a SelectionAware model.

In my experience, this makes it impossible to unselect a row in a datatable.  Even if I tie a checkbox column to the currentRowSelected property, clicking anywhere on the row (including the checkbox) sets it as selected=true.

In fact, I'd like to bypass this ActionListener all together and just have the checkboxes control row selection.

column1: Id handling of Spring AjaxViewRoot causes problems to RichFaces AjaxViewRoot
column42:
There is a serious problem when combining Spring-faces ajax components and Rich faces Ajax components.

This is most easily noticed since 2.0.7, when the jsf view state is saved as part of the flow history. To reproduce open a spring popup view-state using an sf:commandButton and cancel it by pressing Esc or X. After that, no rich-faces ajax requests will be able to work.

The reason seems to be the following: Spring's AjaxViewRoot effectively replaces in its constructor the ID of the underlying ViewRoot with a newly generated unique id appended by "_ajax". This ID remains in the state of the original ViewRoot even after Spring - AjaxViewRoot has finished its job. RichFaces - AjaxViewRoot relies on its ID to determine which part of the component tree to process. Therefore, since its ID has been replaced, the processing never happens on the whole ViewRoot as it should.

This is also easily reproduced by firing an sf:commandButton action that does not transition to another view. After that request is processed, subsequent rich-faces ajax requests will not work.

You may consider the small patch I am attaching. This should be ok unless you think there are deeper complications here.

Thanks and regards.
column91: 03/Aug/09 9:06 AM;jeremyg484;The patch seems like a reasonable alternative with no adverse side-effects, so I have gone ahead and committed it.  Thanks Nazaret!

column1: Lost events when more than one ActionEvent occured in JSF
column42:
Current implementation of FlowActionListener doesn't support more that one ActionEvent in JSF. One of such scenario:

<rich:simpleTogglePanel switchType="client" opened="false">
  <a4j:commandButton action="action"/>
</rich:simpleTogglePanel>

If you open the togglePanel and press the button - event in SWF is lost. Log fragment:

...
springframework.faces.webflow.FlowLifecycle - Processing application
...
>ActionEvent from button
springframework.faces.webflow.FlowActionListener - Invoking action javax.faces.component._MethodExpression
springframework.faces.webflow.FlowActionListener - Event 'action' detected
...
>SimpleToggleEvent from simpleTogglePanel
springframework.faces.webflow.FlowActionListener - No action event detected

As you can see, FlowActionListener is detected event of pressing the button, but lost this event after. Implementation of rich:simpleTogglePanel detects opening of the panel in request from button and rise SimpleToggleEvent (it can't do this before because of switchType="client").

As workaround you can use switchType="ajax" (then SimpleToggleEvent is rised in separate request cycle) but this is not always acceptable (for instance such request is cleared displayed messages from validation).
column91:
01/Sep/09 7:38 PM;manolito;This patch removes two lines from the FlowActionListener, that clear the currently registered eventId of the last ActionEvent.
Subsequent ActionEvents must not remove the last event outcome if they have no outcome (eventId) themselves.
Jeremy, could you please inspect this change for any unwanted side effects?
Thanks,
Manfred

        <dispatcher>FORWARD</dispatcher>
        <dispatcher>INCLUDE</dispatcher>

		<servlet-name>Spring MVC DispatcherServlet</servlet-name>
        <dispatcher>REQUEST</dispatcher>
		<dispatcher>FORWARD</dispatcher>
		<dispatcher>INCLUDE</dispatcher>

	</servlet-mapping>

column1: Flow execution URL returned from externalContext.getFlowExecutionUrl(String, String) is not encoded
Ajax refresh of a fragment causes whole page to be refeshed in IE7
column42:
Using Spring Web Flow/Ajax to refesh a single Tile....  works fine in Firefox, but in IE7 the whole page is refreshed - what happens is:

1) I click on the link.
2) The browser requests the fragment specified.
3) The server responds with just the content of the single associated tile.
4) The browser requests the whole page.

When using Firefox, step 4 does not happen - it replaces <div>s in my document with <div>s with matching ids from the response, which is exactly what I expect. IE7 is failing to replace the divs, and instead requests the entire page (it resends  the same request without the 'fragments' parameter.)

This problem is apparent in the swf-booking-mvc sample application for version 2.0.6. It was OK in version 2.0.5. (NB remember to clear out your IE cache when switching between the two, otherwise the javascript files get cached.)

One way to observe the problem is by using a proxy (such as Fiddler), so you can see what requests are being made.

column1: Jsf view state is maintained across redirects even if the view-state has been exited and re-entered
column42:
SWF 2.0.6 added support for maintaining the Jsf view state across redirects, in order to restore the view's correct state after transitions with no target (event handler). (see SWF-964). There seems to be an omission in that fix, since the JSF view state is now maintained even when the view-state is exited and then re-entered. This will happen, for example, after a transition which has the same view-state as target state.

As a workaround, the user may clear the viewRootHolder from the flash scope before the transition.

		<transition on="goToSameView" to="thisView">
			<set name="flashScope.flowViewRootHolder" value="null"></set>
		</transition>

column1: An exception transition fails to transition if the exception occurs before the first view state is entered.
column42:
I have a global transition for an exception and an action that throws an exception from on-entry of the first view state. A transition is actually attempted but results in a null pointer exception in AbstractFlowExecutionRepository.getConversation where the execution key is null. If on-entry is changed to on-render the problem does not occur.

I will attach a sample flow definition and server output.

column1: Execution key is not always incremented.
column42:
It's easy to reproduce with booking-mvc. Enter Book Hotel data, go to confirm (e1s2). Press Back and press Proceed again (e1s2). I should see e1s3.

A specific use case where this is an issue is where a page has links that open browser popup windows. Each browser popup ends up with the same execution key, which is initially fine but if you try to refresh the first browser popup you get the content of the second.
column92: 17/Apr/09 6:45 AM;kdonald;nextSnapshotId() now delegating to snapshot group, which by default always increases sequence.

column1: No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error
column42:
This can be reproduced with both the swf-booking-mvc and swf-booking-faces sample applications. Steps to reproduce:
1. Disable JavaScript
2. Start to book a hotel. Don't enter any data and press Proceed. This will render the same page with the validation errors. (No issue yet, as can be seen when you would use the back button; this will take you back to the previous step. However, don't do this just now)
3. Again, just press Proceed. The screen rerenders as expected with the same validation errors. However, try and press the back button now: you will now get a browser warning that it's about to rePOST our form data. Apparently the last 'Proceed' action did not result in a redirect after POST. 

AFAIK, this is a bug and a redirect should be sent from the server. If this is not the case, I would really like to know the rationale for this behavior and see it documented.
column91: 07/Apr/09 4:46 AM;jkuipers;Note that both empty form submits result in just a POST: I wasn't very clear on that in my description, as I originally misinterpreted the back-button behavior. There is no inconsistency there, it's just unexpected that a validation error results in no redirect but a direct response instead.
column92:
07/Apr/09 8:22 AM;kdonald;Hi all,
 
I am considering applying this patch to AbstractMvcView to resolve this issue, at least in a MVC environment in the 2.0.x line:
 
In processUserEvent we add:
 
                if (mappingResults != null && hasErrors(mappingResults)) {
                        requestContext.getFlashScope().put(ViewActionStateHolder.KEY,
                                        new ViewActionStateHolder(eventId, mappingResults));
                        ExternalContext context = requestContext.getExternalContext();
                        if (!context.isAjaxRequest()) {
                                Boolean redirectOnPause = requestContext.getAttributes().getBoolean("alwaysRedirectOnPause");
                                boolean redirectAllowed = redirectOnPause != null ? redirectOnPause.booleanValue() : false;
                                if (redirectAllowed) {
                                        requestContext.getExternalContext().requestFlowExecutionRedirect();
                                }
                        }
                }
 
This basically makes the behavior consistent with ViewState POST+REDIRECT_GET semantics: if bind/validation errors happen, redirect on pause is true, and it's not an ajax request, we'll redirect... else we won't.  So someone not wanting the redirect would just turn redirectOnPause to false (it's always false in a Portlet environment).  This is an existing setting so it would be extending it to apply to the case of bind/validation errors as well.  An existing 2.0.x app that has redirectonPause=true will notice redirects on validation failures now by default... this is a change but arguably one that leads to better user experience in the browser.  Are we ok with this in 2.0.x?
 
Keith
 
________________________________________
From: Keith Donald
Sent: Tuesday, April 07, 2009 2:38 PM
To: Keith Donald; Joris Kuipers; Rossen Stoyanchev; Jeremy Grelle
Subject: RE: [Fwd: [Spring-JIRA] Created: (SWF-1096) No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error]
 
So the Ajax MVC case seems trivial, just add a isAjaxRequest tester:
 
                if (mappingResults != null && mappingResults.hasErrorResults()) {
                        requestContext.getFlashScope().put(ViewActionStateHolder.KEY,
                                        new ViewActionStateHolder(eventId, mappingResults));
                        ExternalContext context = requestContext.getExternalContext();
                        if (!context.isAjaxRequest()) {
                                requestContext.getExternalContext().requestFlowExecutionRedirect();
                        }
                }
        }
 
JSF is more complicated, unfortunately. I see no obvious way inside processUserEvent to find out whether the user event resulted in bind/validation errors that require a redirect to be viewed... one idea is testing FacesContext.getMaximiumSeverity but that might be stretch.  You see,  processUserEvent is called on all flow execution resume operations, which includes postbacks (via form or link) as well as a browser refresh (GET).  For each of these calls, Spring Faces always executes the JSF postback lifecycle... just on a "refresh" request these postback phases do nothing.  This is problematic because if we naively request a redirect, we would do that for a refresh request as well and we'd end up in an infinite loop (a flow execution redirect by definition triggers a flow execution refresh).  Perhaps Jeremy can enlighten us.
 
Keith
 
________________________________________
From: Keith Donald
Sent: Tuesday, April 07, 2009 1:58 PM
To: Keith Donald; Joris Kuipers; Rossen Stoyanchev; Jeremy Grelle
Subject: RE: [Fwd: [Spring-JIRA] Created: (SWF-1096) No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error]
 
Adding Jeremy to this thread.  Jeremy please advise if you see any issues on the Ajax/JSF side.
Keith
 
________________________________________
From: Keith Donald
Sent: Tuesday, April 07, 2009 1:56 PM
To: Keith Donald; Joris Kuipers; Rossen Stoyanchev
Cc: erwin@ervacon.com
Subject: RE: [Fwd: [Spring-JIRA] Created: (SWF-1096) No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error]
 
Alright I just did a basic addition to AbstractMvcView.processUserEvent:
 
                if (mappingResults != null && mappingResults.hasErrorResults()) {
                        requestContext.getFlashScope().put(ViewActionStateHolder.KEY,
                                        new ViewActionStateHolder(eventId, mappingResults));
                        requestContext.getExternalContext().requestFlowExecutionRedirect();
                }
 
... the last line requests the redirect... so it worked... in Firefox no browser warning, when I went back I saw my data and no errors.  A nice usability improvement.
 
Good in theory but not quite as simple as it sounds
- What if user event raised in a Ajax request
- What about JSF environment
- What about Portal
 
Keith
 
________________________________________
From: Keith Donald
Sent: Tuesday, April 07, 2009 1:31 PM
To: Joris Kuipers; Rossen Stoyanchev
Subject: RE: [Fwd: [Spring-JIRA] Created: (SWF-1096) No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error]
 
Alright, its good you raised this issue as I'm actually in this related area working on 2.0.7 ViewState flash scope management issues.
 
I have a proposed solution
- With the revised 2.0.7 ViewState.resume logic (1) , it's now possible for the View that processes the user event to record response complete if it desires; for example, to request a execution redirect if the view fails validation.  In that case, no flow event is expected to be raised and the view itself has control over the response issued.
 
I can make a "redirectOnErrors" flag configurable on MvcViewFactoryCreator that turns on this behavior.  Not sure I can change it the default to be true though in a point release.  Need to think on that.
 
Keith
 
(1) https://fisheye.springsource.org/browse/spring-webflow/branches/spring-webflow-2.0-maintenance/spring-webflow/src/main/java/org/springframework/webflow/engine/ViewState.java?r=2364
 
________________________________________
From: Joris Kuipers
Sent: Tuesday, April 07, 2009 11:28 AM
To: Keith Donald; Rossen Stoyanchev
Subject: RE: [Fwd: [Spring-JIRA] Created: (SWF-1096) No redirect after POST occurs after server-side validation error]
 
Ah, of course you're right there! I assumed there was a redirect because FireFox didn't warn me about a re-POST when I hit the back button, but after the first POST the back-button results in a GET of course, not in the same POST again... Sorry about that, should have thought of that myself.
 
That still leaves the general question of whether a redirect would be appropriate, or if it should be a configurable option at least, but as far as the reported inconsistent behavior that was simply my mistake. I'll update the JIRA issue accordingly.
 
Joris

column97:
19/Oct/10 11:02 AM;maksim;Hi,
It looks like this issue is happening again in 2.2.0 release. It works fine with 2.1.1 release.
column98:
19/Oct/10 1:09 PM;rstoya05-aop;This feature led to complications with the implementation for partial state saving (SWF-1365) due to the assumption on the part of JSF 2 that the lifecycle occurs within a single request. This is JSF related but more generally it can be argued that not re-directing after a server-side validation error is not incorrect. In this case the form submission hasn't completed unlike the case of the successful POST where we want to split the processing of the form submit from the GET for the next page. Also use of Ajax when submitting a forum, something rather common, further mitigates this issue.

The feature wasn't removed entirely but it is not enabled by default. There is a redirectInSameState flag in ViewState but it is not currently exposed through any flow definition level configuration.
column99:
19/Oct/10 3:57 PM;maksim;Hi Rossen, 

Thank you for a quick and informative response. Is it possible to expose the redirectInSameState flag in the next release of webflow?

Maksim
column100: 21/Oct/10 8:10 AM;rstoya05-aop;It would be possible. We'd have to think how to handle the fact this flag would cause issues in a JSF 2 environment.

column1: Merge process causes duplicate entries in parent transitions.
column43:
flow1:
 state: list
  transition: show
    actions: 3 actions

flow2: inherited from flow1
 state: perform
  transition: blabla

flow3: -- inherited from flow2
 state: list -- inherited from flow1:list
  transition: show -- inherited from flow1:list:show
    actions: 3 actions
column91:
06/Apr/09 6:30 AM;maksar;The same with merging lists. You should make a new list instead of using same.

Another side-effect: for example, the same TransitionModel object instances can exist in different flows (after merging flows). If after that any other merge process will be occured (which touches TransitionModel instance) list of transition actions in parent flow can be changed.
column93:
07/Apr/09 10:47 AM;maksar;Sorry, my mistake in environment conditions. 

I've attached new test with flow definitions.

Here is the idea how I've fixed the defect. It was done by assigning a "deep copy" of merged Model to the child merging object. In this case all Model-s in child tree will be different instances from target Model tree. Deep copy must be assignes not only when merging collections, but also when merging Model-s.
column94:
08/Apr/09 12:46 AM;kdonald;I reviewed your project and the merge algorithm is actually executing as designed - 9 is correct, not 6.  This is because actions are not mergeable, and your flow is extending flow1 and flow2, where flow2 also extends flow1.  With the current design, flow1 will be merged with flow3, then flow2 will be merged with flow3.  Because flow2 extends from flow1 as well, the 'list' state gets merged into flow3 twice--once from flow3 directly extending from flow1, and again from the fact flow3 extends flow2 which extends flow1.  This then applies the merge algorithm to flow3's list state twice, which then causes 6 additional actions to be added, giving a total number of 9.

If you believe you have a solution that employs a better approach for this scenario, feel free to attach a patch and we'll review it.
column97: 08/Apr/09 3:08 AM;kdonald;BTW, if you agree with this approach, we could use some help implementing these 21 createCopy methods on each of the models!  We're also fighting a few more fires in other JIRA open for 2.0.7 so any assistance you can provide here in terms of a patch would be very helpful and help the fix get done faster.
column98: 08/Apr/09 4:25 AM;maksar;Ok, I'll provide a patch in a day or two. The solution must be 1.4 compilant, right?
column99: 08/Apr/09 4:28 AM;kdonald;Yes, must be 1.4 compliant.  We'll standby for your patch.  Thanks.

09/Apr/09 12:19 AM;maksar;Hi,

I've attached a patch. Should be applied to the SVNROOT/springframework/spring-webflow/trunk/spring-webflow folder.
column101: 14/Apr/09 7:44 AM;kdonald;Patched applied.  Much appreciated.  Would you mind doing a quick review and test in your environment to ensure the patch took care of all issues?

column1: AjaxTilesView composite definition traversal algorithm ignores AttributeType
column42:
When looking for a fragment of a composite view to render, the AjaxTilesView traverses nested definitions on the composite.  Unfortunately, it is also treating template and string attributes as definition ids, which can cause the wrong definition to render when the name of the attribute is the same as another, unrelated definition.

The algorithm in AjaxTilesView should only consider definition attributes...

This is a potential security risk as it could allow a client to render unrelated composites outside control of server, so I'm marking it critical for 2.0.7.
column91: 03/Apr/09 8:49 AM;jeremyg484;AjaxTilesView now checks the AttributeType of the Attribute before adding it to the map of potentially renderable fragments.  This is still not fool-proof as AttributeType will be null if a particular Attribute has not previously been rendered, thus we have no choice but to add that attribute to the map.  In general it is recommended that the user be careful and still try to avoid values for an attribute of type "string" that could potentially collide with definition names.
column92:
06/Apr/09 1:33 AM;kdonald;Reopened:
- Needs unit tests
- Why are we treating AttributeType.TEMPLATE as a nested definition?
- Pretty sure the first call to super.renderMergedOutputModel should follow with a return statement

column1: WebFlowMessageCodesResolver creates leading '.' in the messageCodes
column42: The function WebFlowMessageCodesResolver.resolveMessageCodes creates leading '.' in the messageCodes. So the MessageBuilder can not find the messages in message.properties e.g. "model.date.typMismatch=Typo in date field".

column1: viewScope variable is not getting destroyed
column42: An evaluation result (java.util.List) in\s stored in a viewScope variable. When leaving the view (backward or forward) the viewScope variable is not getting destroyed. By return to the current view the result set is simply added to the previous result set.
column43: Windows XP Professional Version 2002 SP2, Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_11-b03), Eclipse PlatformVersion: 3.4.2 Build id: M20090211-1700, Apache Tomcat Version 6.0.14, Spring framework version 2.5.5, SPRING WEB FLOW 2.0.6
column91: 31/Mar/09 5:09 AM;kdonald;Can you be more specific on the sequence of steps that is causing the unexpected behavior? If you go back in your browser and then forward to your view, the flow execution key on the view you returned to will still match the state on the server and view-scope will be in-tact as is.  If however you go back and them raise an event on the previous page that transitons to the view again, a new view-scope will be allocated.  More information would be helpful.

column97: 31/Mar/09 5:42 PM;kdonald;I had a look at your code on the forum and I suspect your results List is shared among all threads, as from what I can tell your formBackingObject is an application scoped singleton.  That would explain the duplicates -- you keep adding to this shared list and exporting it to view-scope.

column1: Trying to deserialize the flow execution from the uploaded file
column42:
(Forum posts 54466 and 62542)
Uploading a file using Commons FileUpload as provided with Spring 2.5.6 with Webflow 2.0.6. Strictly per Spring Reference chapter 13.8 (http://static.springframework.org/spring/docs/2.5.x/reference/mvc.html#mvc-multipart), I am utilizing the third option when uploading the file, i.e. "The third (and final) option is where one binds directly to a MultipartFile property declared on the (form backing) object's class. In this case one does not need to register any custom PropertyEditor  because there is no type conversion to be performed.".

Here is my multipart resolver:

  <!-- Multipart (file upload) resolver for Commons FileUpload. -->
  <bean id="portletMultipartResolver" class="org.springframework.web.portlet.multipart.CommonsPortletMultipartResolver">
    <!-- one of the properties available; the maximum file size in bytes -->
    <property name="maxUploadSize" value="10485760"/>
  </bean>

The file uploads fine, however, then I get:

org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.snapshot.SnapshotUnmarshalException: IOException thrown deserializing the flow execution stored in this snapshot -- this should not happen!
...
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /usr/WebSphere/AppServer/temp/jadws211/WebSphere_Portal/Vendor_Com_nce_Portal_PA_1_0_77A/vcportlet.war/upload_346f083a_120338c0f30_3217_00000006.tmp (A file or directory in the path name does not exist.)

Somehow, the webflow is attempted to be deserialized from the uploaded file, as seen above!? The uploaded file was previously deleted with transferTo(.) method.

Why has the webflow tried to be deserialized from the uploaded file?
column43: Spring 2.5.6 (Portlet), Webflow 2.0.6, Commons FileUpload, running on WebSphere Portal Server 5.1
column91: 23/Mar/09 4:43 AM;kdonald;If you are binding to a flow-scoped bean that flow-scoped bean will be serialized when the flow pauses, then deserialized when the flow is restored.  Can the Multipart object be serialized and deserialized successfully?  You might consider converting the multipart to a byte[] during the binding process using a converter.
column92: 23/Mar/09 5:39 AM;mindjoy;My flow-scoped model bean is serializable and the Multipart object used is CommonsMultipartFile which is serializable as well, therefore, it should be serialized and deserialized successfully. The point is that suggested way of uploading a file from the Reference Manual (chapter 13.8) as cited in my previous posting is not working. Are you suggesting that I should abandon the technique of uploading with Multipart object and not use its transferTo(.) method? If so, why is it suggested in the Reference Manual? Or I am missing something important here? I like this technique since the upload works perfectly and exactly the way I want it (I can copy the uploaded file to the specific location on the server).
column93: 23/Mar/09 6:14 AM;kdonald;I'm simply suggesting that serialization and subsequent deserialization of the Multipart object may be causing this problem.  You might try writing a unit test that tries to serialize and deserialize this object to see if you can reproduce it locally.
column94:
07/Oct/09 3:29 AM;barrypitman;I'm getting the same error, also using the third approach. I turned the logging level to debug on  org.springframework.web.multipart.commons, and noticed this happening:

First, after uploading the file, it is saved:
DEBUG (CommonsFileUploadSupport.java:258) - Found multipart file [file] of size 32768 bytes with original filename [test.xls], stored at [C:\Temp\filename.tmp]

Then, the DispatcherServlet deletes it by calling this: multipartResolver.cleanupMultipart((MultipartHttpServletRequest) request);  giving this log message:
DEBUG (CommonsFileUploadSupport.java:278) - Cleaning up multipart file [file] with original filename [test.xls], stored at [C:\Temp\filename.tmp]

Finally, when SWF tries to deserialize the flow, it throws the error because the file isn't there anymore:
SnapshotUnmarshalException: IOException thrown deserializing the flow execution stored in this snapshot -- this should not happen!
Caused by:
FileNotFoundException: C:\Temp\filename.tmp (The system cannot find the file specified)

I'm using SWF 2.0.8.RELEASE. Getting the same error in jetty & tomcat. Java 1.6.0_07. I've shortened the filename here for brevity, but it was identical in each case.

If I bind using a ByteArrayMultipartFileEditor, and converting to a byte[] it works fine, but I'd prefer to be able to bind to a MultipartFile directly.
column96: 08/Oct/09 8:48 PM;barrypitman;I see that this issue has already been discussed here: http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=54466 where several other workarounds were suggested. Still it does seem like a bug, though certainly not a major one.

You did not see this because this exception happening on view-state render in combination with your general exception handler was throwing your flow into an infinite loop.  In general, I'd be wary of such general exception handling logic inside your flow.  In any case, this appears to be a compatibility issue with Tiles 2.1
column101: 19/Mar/09 9:02 AM;kdonald;I went ahead & created the JIRA at http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-1078
column102: 19/Mar/09 9:04 AM;kdonald;Closing as this issue is because we don't yet support Tiles 2.1.  Track/contribute SWF-1078 for 2.1 support.
column103: 19/Mar/09 9:27 AM;kdonald;Just to reiterate on this one; We will not be able to add support for Tiles 2.1 in Web Flow 2.0.x; this will need to be introduced in the next major release of SWF, and the foundational TilesConfigurer support added in Spring 3.  We would happily integrate contributions in this area to expedite getting the Tiles 2.1 support in Spring Framework and Spring JavaScript / Web Flow 3.  I'll also open a JIRA on Tiles 2.1 with the Spring Framework project and reference it from here and SWF-1078.  Feel free to submit patches to both tickets for any Tiles 2.1 integration code you wish to contribute back.
column104: 19/Mar/09 9:32 AM;kdonald;See http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SPR-5411 for Tiles 2.1 support in Spring 3

column1: org.springframework.js.resource.ResourceServlet - An attempt to access a protected resource at /dojo/resources/blank.html was disallowed.
column91:
19/Mar/09 7:05 AM;sandrews;The Spring JS ResourceSerlvet servers files directly from the classpath, because of this, only explicitly allowed types are served to client.  HTML files are not severed by default because they may be exist on the classpath, but not be intended for external clients.

You can add additional file types to serve by adding a init-param to the servlet definition in web.xml for 'allowedResourcePaths'.  The default value is equivalent to:

<init-param>
  <param-name>allowedResourcePaths</param-name>
  <param-value>/**/*.css,/**/*.gif,/**/*.ico,/**/*.jpeg,/**/*.jpg,/**/*.js,/**/*.png,META-INF/**/*.css,META-INF/**/*.gif,META-INF/**/*.ico,META-INF/**/*.jpeg,META-INF/**/*.jpg,META-INF/**/*.js,META-INF/**/*.png</param-value>
</init-param>

To serve HTML files located inside the version of Dojo packaged with Spring JS, you will want to append this pattern to the example above:
META-INF/dojo/**/*.html,META-INF/dijit/**/*.html
column92: 19/Mar/09 9:05 AM;kdonald;Use allowedResourcePaths

The issue is related to the http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-1017
In 2.0.6 there is returned original message (_LabeledFacesMessage), which is depends on presence of FacesContext when invoking getSummary() method, which is called by richfaces messages component when saving visual state...
column92: 18/Mar/09 8:11 AM;kdonald;One potential solution here, which isn't terribly elegant but should work, is to override the FlowFacesMessageAdapter writeObject routine to setup and teardown a FacesContext before delegating to its children.  I think someone needs to ask the question to the Rich Faces team why their custom FacesMessage class depends on a FacesContext, though. That doesn't make much sense to me.  Certainly the standard FacesMessage class has no such dependency.
column93:
18/Mar/09 8:14 AM;kdonald;This might be of interest: https://jira.jboss.org/jira/browse/RF-5830

Looks like RF 3.3.1 might have a fix for this problem...
column94:
18/Mar/09 10:31 AM;sergeyastakhov;The fix for RF-5830 didn't change anything - they just added two checks for nulls, Calls for getSummary()/getDetails() is stiil there.

The root of the problem - is specific message _LabeledFacesMessage, which is added by standart validation logic in MyFaces component implementation. This class is allow to use EL-expressions in summary/details, so it needs to access to the FacesContext for evaluation of result getSummary()/getDetails() methods.

The simpliest workaround - is using standart <h:messages> component instead. Default implementation from MyFaces didn't attempts to save/restore message list as view state, as do RichFaces component. RichFaces implementation save message list for supporting AJAX-validation ( https://jira.jboss.org/jira/browse/RF-4433 ).
column95:
18/Mar/09 10:17 PM;philw;The best fix that I can come up with is to replace _LabeledFacesMessage instances with vanilla FacesMessage instances when they are adapted.  This should make 1.0.6 behave much like 1.0.5 for these messages that need to access the FacesContext, but with the added advantage that they are still mutable.

The only downside of this that I can see is that the expression used to construct the message will only be evaluated once (when it is first added) and not multiple times.  I would not think that this would cause too many problems in reality.

Attached is a patch.
column96: 19/Mar/09 6:42 AM;kdonald;Patch applied.  Thanks Phil.  If you guys could confirm in the next 2.0.7 nightly build that the patch resolves your problem that'd be great.

column1: Spring.RemotingHandler handleResponse method should use a display:none span element
ManySelectionTrackingListDataModel and OneSelectionTrackingListDataModel don't track selections correctly when using a <rich:dataScroller> component
column42: Using an eagerly loaded DataModel (i.e., loading an entire list of results into memory at once and then scrolling through that list via subsequent requests) uncovers a bug in the setCurrentRowSelected implementations in ManySelectionTrackingListDataModel and OneSelectionTrackingListDataModel where the selections potentially get "lost" across requests.

column1: ViewState.resume should check externalcontext.isResponseComplete before rendering or requesting redirect
column42:
There are cases when a user action may want to handle the http response manually, for example write directly to the response or call methods such as externalContext.requestExternalRedirect(...)

I assume that the user should then call externalContext.recordResponseComplete() to notify the SWF engine that the response was handled.

In these cases the View state should take into account whether recordResponseComplete has been called so that it does not try to handle the response itself. Specifically the resume( ) method should do someting like:

if (!stateExited && context.getExternalContext( ).isResponseAllowed( ) && context.getExternalContext( ).isResponseComplete()) {
 ....
}

What is missing is the last check: context.getExternalContext( ).isResponseComplete( )

Also, I noticed that FlowHandlerAdapter executes the requested redirects without checking if response.isCommited(). Shouldn't this check be present as well, just in case?
column91: 12/Mar/09 4:08 AM;nkaza;If I am not mistaken similary functionality was provided in SWF 1 with the ability to define a null view (ViewSelection.NULL_VIEW)
column93: 31/Mar/09 10:38 PM;nkaza;There is still a slight problem, the flashScope is not cleared when the user handles the response and this causes problems to the next request. What is the correct approach? Should the user explicitly clear the flash scope or should the framework clear it somewhere? What about the messageContext? Should the messages be cleared as well? Because I see ViewState clears them explicitly after rendering. (I don't know exactly why since they are part of the flash scope). Thanks!
column94: 01/Apr/09 1:43 AM;kdonald;Framework should clear flash scope when pausing, arguably always, regardless of whether a ViewState view renders or not.  good catch. We'll look into this.
column95: 06/Apr/09 9:02 AM;kdonald;I have committed a fix to this in 2.0.x maintenance for 2.0.7.  Would you mind testing a nightly snapshot?
column96: 07/Apr/09 12:40 AM;nkaza;Ok, tested. Actually, in my use case the problem remains. I am doing the following: I am requesting an external redirect, which is loaded in a new browser window. When the user goes back to the previous window and tries to execute any other action, the flash scope has not been cleared and is causing problems to that request. I see that with the current fix, ViewState.clearFlashIfNotRedirecting( ) prevents the flash scope from being cleared when any kind of redirect is requested. Wouldn't it make more sense to clear flash "if not flow execution redirect requested". I think we could argue that flash scope is valid only across a flow execution redirect, so it should be cleared before flow definition and external redirects.
column97: 07/Apr/09 1:05 AM;kdonald;Good catch... You can watch for the commit using fisheye at https://fisheye.springsource.org/browse/spring-webflow
column98: 07/Apr/09 9:17 AM;kdonald;Fix committed. Is it resolved for your use case now?
column99: 07/Apr/09 7:51 PM;nkaza;Yes it is. Thanks!

column1: Validation helper not able to dal with scope prefixes for models
column42:
Validation helper happily includes scope prefixes (if they are used in the flow definition) of a flow's model attribute for resolving the corresponding validation bean and method.

E.g.

<view-state id="modifyCatalogueViewState" view="modifyCatalogue" model="viewScope.catalogue">

would cause the validation helper to search for a validation bean with id="viewScope.catalogueValidator"

The lookup process in the validation helper class should strip the scope from model names.

Workaround: either do not use a scope prefix in the viewState's model attribute or define the validator bean id as such that it includes the scope as prefix.
column91: 08/Mar/09 11:22 PM;rauar;Typo: s/dal/deal in issue title
column92:
23/Nov/10 6:49 AM;gdelprete;This bug also has an effect when using Formatters on model attribute.

If a model attribute is of a type which has a formatter defined for it (in my case I registered DateFormatter to handle Date objects), the conversion on form submit seems to work (you'll see DateFormatter.parse being called), but when going back to view, the Object->String conversion does not happen (DateFormatter.print is never called; in my case, on the web page the Date was printed in toString() format).

Note: this happens also not only on validation errors (eg. a typeMismatch) but also if the format on submit is correct and the view is just rendered again because no transition target state was specified (eg. a "search form + search result" page), so it can be easily seen, and the issue is not related to only Validation (at least the way I understand it - I'm rather new to the Spring world).

I've seen at least 3 forum thread where people could not get Printers to work, I think either the model attribute in view-state should be handled with EL (which might be useful nevertheless) or SWF code should strip the scope id, or the documentation should be updated to cleary specify that you must NOT use a scope id with the model name in the model attribute of view-state. 

I'm using Spring Web Flow 2.2.0.
column93: 25/Nov/10 2:37 AM;rstoya05-aop;You don't need to specify the scope when in the  model attribute. Can you confirm if this works <view-state ... model="foo"> (as opposed to <view-state ... model="viewScope.foo">)?

column1: FlowFacesContext didn't expose context messages with null source
column42:
In Faces context there is exist method getClientIdsWithMessages().
In your implementation (FlowFacesContext) you didn't return in this method null source id (IdentifiedMessageCriteria returns false for nulls).

JSF specification say nothing about nulls in return of this method, but several implementation of messages tag relies on this. For instance last versions of MyFaces <h:messages> and RichFaces <rich:messages> behaves that way. As result these implementations didn't show user messages with null source added to the MessageContext.

The workaround is easy - just allways specify some source id, but better solution would be allow to use null as source.
column91:
13/Mar/09 5:47 AM;jeremyg484;If a message with a null source is added, null will now be included in the values of the iterator, as according to the spec for getClientIdsWithMessages:
"If any messages have been queued that were not associated with any specific client identifier, a null value will be included in the iterated values"

column1: AjaxTilesView does not handle cascaded attributes properly
column42:
i have one cascaded attribute in my view:

<definition name="specifyPhone" extends="template">
		<put-attribute name="handsetTable" value="/WEB-INF/templates/handsets.ftl" cascade="true"/>
		<put-attribute name="body" value="/WEB-INF/templates/specifyPhone.ftl"/>
</definition>

template contains "body" attribute
body template contains "handsetTable" attribute

the first time i render the full page everything is ok

when i try to specify 'handsetTable' as render fragment, nothing gets rendered because of exception: javax.servlet.ServletException: No tiles attribute with a name of 'handsetTable' could be found for the current view: org.springframework.js.ajax.tiles2.AjaxTilesView: name 'specifyPhone'

when i try to specify 'body' as render fragment, body attribute gets rendered, but without handsetTable attribute. I can see the exception in the log: org.apache.tiles.jsp.taglib.NoSuchAttributeException: Attribute 'handsetTable' not found.
column91: 04/Mar/09 12:48 AM;rstoya05-aop;Web Flow  builds with Tiles 2.0.5. The cascading attributes were added in Tiles 2.1.0.
column92: 26/May/09 8:58 AM;alex_marshall;I can confirm this bug as well, and it's causing big problems for me.  Is there any time estimate on a fix for it ?
column93:
09/Jun/09 9:49 PM;triqui;Web Flow works perfectly with Tiles 2.1.0 and cascading attributes except for this issue. If you never ever use an ajax request, it's perfectly safe to use Tiles 2.1.0 so that you can benefit from the much easier configuration using cascaded attributes.
Higher versions of tiles have other issues though.
column94: 18/Apr/10 4:39 PM;rstoya05-aop;The AjaxTilesView now handles cascaded attributes. The booking-mvc sample has been changed to take advantage of anonymous nested definitions (as opposed to cascaded attributes) and a unit test has been added for a tiles definition with cascade=true.
column95:
23/Jun/10 7:28 PM;mel;This doesn't work as expected in 2.1. If I do as miceuz have done I still get an exception telling me "Attribute 'handsetTable' not found.". (or in my case body_content). When rendering attributes of a definition all cascaded attributes must be added to the AttributeContext so that they are available when rendering the attribute. I have solved it by adding the following code to AjaxTilesView (line 127):

...

container.startContext(request, response).inheritCascadedAttributes(compositeDefinition);

container.render(attributeToRender, request, response); // This is the original code for rendering the attribute

container.endContext(request, response);

...

This makes the cascaded attributes available when rendering the attribute. I don't know if this is sufficient or if we need to add anything more than the cascaded attributes to the AttributeContext, but it works for med with cascaded attributes at least.
column96:
23/Jun/10 8:54 PM;rstoya05-aop;Mandus, I've just had another look at this and I can't replicate the problem. 

Here is what I did. 

1. AjaxTilesViewTests has a method testRenderFragment_CascadedAttribute(), which shows a cascade attribute can be used as a fragment. Previously the AjaxTilesView was ignoring cascade attributes. See the first reported error in the original description above ("No tiles attribute ...") -- it comes from the AjaxTilesView (not Tiles).

2. To show that Tiles attributes work as described here (http://tiles.apache.org/framework/tutorial/advanced/nesting-extending.html) I modified src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/hotels/views.xml in the booking-mvc sample as follows:

{code}
<tiles-definitions>
	
	<definition name="hotels/search" extends="standardLayout">
		<put-attribute name="body" value="/WEB-INF/hotels/search.jsp"/>
		<put-attribute name="searchForm" value="/WEB-INF/hotels/searchForm.jsp" cascade="true" />
		<put-attribute name="bookingsTable" value="/WEB-INF/hotels/bookingsTable.jsp" cascade="true" />
	</definition>

	<definition name="hotels/*" extends="standardLayout">
		<put-attribute name="body" value="/WEB-INF/hotels/{1}.jsp" />
	</definition>

</tiles-definitions>
{code}

The sample runs fine and clicking on the "Change Search" link, which points to the "searchForm" fragment works fine too.
column97:
23/Jun/10 9:20 PM;mel;For me it doesn't work as expected with cascaded attributes. I have a general definition that looks as follows:

<definition name="general" template="/WEB-INF/jsp/templates/general.jsp">
        <put-attribute name="header" value="header">
            <definition template="/WEB-INF/jsp/tiles/header.jsp" preparer="headerPreparer" />
        </put-attribute>

        <put-attribute name="body" value="/WEB-INF/jsp/tiles/body.jsp" />

        <put-attribute name="menu" value="menu">
            <definition template="/WEB-INF/jsp/tiles/menu.jsp" preparer="menuPreparer" />
        </put-attribute>

        <put-attribute name="footer" value="/WEB-INF/jsp/tiles/footer.jsp" />
    </definition>

In my application the definitions are generated dynamically from the view name supplied in the controller. The generated definitions inherit from the general definition and gets a cascaded template attribute named 'body_content' which is used in the body template for the body of the page. When I try to load a page and specify that it should only return the body fragment everything goes fine until it tries to render the body attribute and run the code for the <tiles:insert-attribute name="body_content" /> tag. Since the cascaded body_content attribute is not present in the AttributeContext it cannot insert the attribute and the exception is thrown.

You can compare this to rendering definitions if you take a look at the render method for definitions (line 610) in BasicTilesContainer. There you can see that they inherit the cascaded attributes (and other relevant stuff) before rendering, and that is what we are missing (we only need to inherit the cascaded attributes though).
column98:
23/Jun/10 9:46 PM;rstoya05-aop;I see. The scenario is with use of dynamic attributes (what is called "Runtime Composition" in the Tiles docs). 

I would appreciate your help in demonstrating the issue. Would it be difficult for you to add a method to AjaxTileViewTests.java (https://src.springframework.org/svn/spring-webflow/branches/spring-webflow-2.1-maintenance/spring-js/src/test/java/org/springframework/js/ajax/tiles2/AjaxTilesViewTests.java) that demonstrates your use case more concretely?

Also I think this merits creating a new issue. The original description of this issue as it was described, without the use of dynamic attributes, has been resolved. 

By the way I did try your suggested fix and it broke another test. Will have to take a closer look now that the scenario is more clear.
column101:
24/Jun/10 7:19 PM;rstoya05-aop;Thanks for submitting the tests.

I understand your point about this being nothing more than cascade attributes as documented in Tiles. However, I do think there is sufficient nuance to merit the creation of a separate issue. It will be easier for others to read the new description and understand if the issue relates to them rather than sifting through the much longer history here. The new issue will be scheduled for a maintenance release and properly linked back to here. 

Update: the new issue is [SWF-1262].

column1: TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler hides log message
column42:
So basically 

first define a 

<bean id="flowExceptionHandler" class="org.springframework.webflow.engine.support.TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler"/>

next define an action-state

<action-state id="errorAction">
    <evaluate expression="errorService.populateSystemError"/>
    <transition on-exception="com.system.error.SystemError" to="someerror.state"/>  
</action-state>

now check you log file and see no error being logged.

column1: Messages restored from flash scope (DefaultMessageContext) are not in the same order of source messages
column42:
During the Apply Request Values, Process Validations, Update Model Values, and Invoke
Application phases of the request processing lifecycle, messages can be queued via the FacesContext.
The JSF 1.2 Spec (Section 6.1.5) requires that messages are returned in the order in which they were added.

SWF does not meet this requirement.

After a flow execution the messages contained in MessageContext are stored within flash scope.
The implementation of DefaultMessageContext is not preserving the order of source messages. It uses a simple HashMap when creating the serializable messages in createMessagesMemento().

As a result the restored messages from flash scope are disordered in the following flow execution.
column91: 10/Mar/09 10:59 PM;werlitz;patch attached for DefaultMessageContext
column92: 12/Mar/09 2:06 AM;kdonald;Patch applied; thanks

column1: There's no obvious way to create a custom FlowHandlerAdapter for the FlowController
column42:
We're encountering a problem where WebFlow redirects to non-SSL addresses when using an SSL front end/proxy.  Basically, the incoming request is SSL, it gets captured by the load balancer and turned into a non-SSL request to the web server.  When WebFlow does a redirect, because the incoming request is non-SSL, it tries to redirect to a non-SSL address.  The solution is to look for a header injected by the proxy to indicate the original request was SSL.  This would be easily enough done with a modification to the FlowHandlerAdapter.sendRedirect method.  Because most of the fields in FlowHandlerAdapter are private, however, we couldn't simply extend and override the sendRedirect method in a custom FlowHandlerAdapter.  Trying to create a separate FlowHandlerAdapter, however, also did not work, because, even though the FlowController has a setFlowHandlerAdapter method, it takes as an argument not an interface, but rather the concrete class FlowHandlerAdapter.

This seems like an error in the API for FlowController.  Though in theory you have the ability to create a custom FlowHandlerAdapter, since there's no easy way to extend the class, and since it is a concrete class rather than an interface reference, it appears to be impossible to use this feature easily.

For now, we may have to resort to forking the WebFlow source code and directly modifying the FlowHandlerAdapter class ourselves, which seems to be an exceptionally kludgy approach.
column91: 06/Feb/09 7:01 AM;kdonald;In general, we recommend direct use of FlowHandlerAdapter and FlowHandlerMapping over use of FlowController for 2.0.5 and >.  FlowHandlerAdapter definitely needs to be improved to allow for extension in this case.  I scheduled it for 2.0.6, which is due out by the end of February.
column92: 06/Feb/09 7:38 AM;syntheticzero;Great.  I think if the sendRedirect method and the instance variables it references were protected instead of private, it would at least allow us to extend and patch the server for this one case.  It might be a good idea to think through some of the other functionality of the adapter that people might want to override/extend and make those protected at the same time.
column93: 09/Mar/09 4:14 PM;kdonald;Made FlowHandlerAdapter#sendRedirect protected and exposed access to its instance variables.  Improved documentation around subclass hooks in FlowHandlerAdapter.

column1: Select dropdowns don't maintain selected state in IE when rendered into a modal dialog from an Ajax response
column42:
Due to one of IE's many lovely quirks in the way it handles select dropdowns, rendering a select as part of an Ajax response into a modal dialog results in the dropdown not maintaining the set selected option for any selection beyond the first entry.

"You can actually reproduce this using the swf-booking-faces application.  Go to the Hotel Search page in IE and change the default page size from 5 to 10.  Do a search and then hit the Change Search Criteria link so the modal dialog comes up.  It doesn't have the changed selection in the drop down - it's set back to 5.  Do it in Firefox, and it works."
column91: 06/Feb/09 3:18 AM;jeremyg484;The problem occurs because when passing a NodeList to Dojo's dijit.Dialog.setContent(), Dojo actually clones the nodes in the NodeList before inserting them.  This is where IE loses the selection state.  Changed approach to just insert the response HTML text instead of the transformed NodeList.

column1: FilenameFlowUrlHandler does not implement createFlowDefinitionUrl
column42:
FilenameFlowUrlHandler, which was introduced in 2.0.4, extracts the flow id from an http request. However, it fails to construct the correct URL given the flow id. I think this should be implemented by overriding createFlowDefinitionUrl.

Test case:
1) configure a flow executor repository with max-executions="1"
2) Start a flow "X". 
3) Now start another flow "Y" by navigating to the URL of the "Y" flow. 
4) Press back on the browser. If the createFlowDefinitionUrl method works correctly then the system should take you to the beginning of a new flow "X".
