column93: 05/Aug/09 5:50 AM;jeremyg484;I've incorporated the patch along with minor cleanup and some additional unit tests.  Indeed, we should consider in the future whether having both PathInfo and ServletPath empty should actually be an error case, but since DefaultUrlHandler has the same behavior I've left it alone for now.  Thanks for the patch, Nazaret!

column1: Transitioning from a flow found in parent flow registry to a subflow found in a child flow registry doesn't work
column42:
A modified version of booking-portlet-faces sample application has been used to test this scenario.
/WEB-INF/config/application-config.xml file contains a parent flow registry that has as its only flow location - main.xml
/WEB-INF/config/hotelbooking-portlet-config.xml contains a child flow registry, which has as its parent the parent from application-config.xml; its flow locations are view.xml and booking.xml

When the application is tested, after a hotel is chosen from the list and "Booking" is clicked an exception is thrown:
NoSuchFlowDefinitionException: No flow definition 'booking' found

Debugging the Web Flow code it seems that even if FlowExecutionImplFactory is aware of all the DefaultFlowRegistries (the parent and the child one) and is able to get the flow definition from the parent registry, when trying to build the "main" flow the subflow is not found.
My gut reaction would be that the search space, when resolving flow definitions, should include the complete path from the leaf to the root of the flow definition registry hierarchy.

I think the way it behaves now is the intended behavior, but this will somewhat limit the possibilities of structuring the flow definitions in a web app: moving all the common flows to a higher level (war app level in this case) and the specific flows (sub-flows in this case) to portlet-specific level.
column43: Spring 2.5.6, Web Flow 2.0.5, Pluto 1.1.6 portlet container
column91:
12/Mar/09 2:24 AM;kdonald;Flows in a child registry can reference flows in parent registry, but not vice versa.  This is how it was designed, and it allows a flow in a child context like a Portlet to reuse flows defined in a parent context like the root application context. I'm not sure I understand the usecase for allowing a flow in a parent registry to register a flow in a child registry.  Can you elaborate?

I don't expect we'll make any changes in 2.0.x here; I need more information on use case we can't support well to warrant any changes in future releases to the registry system design.

column1: 'valid' property of input components gets lost before JSF render phase in portlet
column42:
The request cycle of a portlet usually constists of an seperate ActionRequest and RenderRequest.
Spring Faces does bridge these two independant Requests. Specific to the portlet environment the ViewRoot of the JSF component tree is saved at the end of the ActionRequest and restored before JSF enters the render response phase. This way the component tree itself and its state is correcly preserved for rendering. The ViewRoot gets restored in JsfViewFactory.getView(). In this method JsfViewFactory.processTree() also gets called and resets the 'valid' property of EditableValueHolder componets to 'true'. 

This might be correct before JSF processes the ActionRequest but is NOT correct before JSF enters the render response phase within the RenderRequest. 

The state information of the 'valid' property is lost and components whose rendering depend on that property (set to 'false' in the ActionRequest because of an validation error) display incorrectly.
column43: IBM WebSphere Portal 6.1, Sun JSF 1.2, Sun JSF PortletBridge, Facelets
column91: 12/Mar/09 4:43 AM;werlitz;attached a patch with a possible solution
column92: 13/Mar/09 2:54 AM;jeremyg484;Updated the JsfViewFactory to only reset the valid flag during the RESTORE_VIEW phase.

column1: '<transition on-exception' for AccessDeniedException handling does not work
column42:
SWF will throw one of Spring Security's AccessDeniedException instances when a <secured> element applies to a state, transition or flow. It would be desirable that this AccessDeniedException is presented to the <transition on-exception> mechanism. However, the "on-exception" facility does not catch a <secured> element exception but instead throws 
the exception and Spring Security's ExceptionTranslationFilter will handle it. The handling of the exception by Spring Security's filter is undesired because the more advanced state-aware concepts such as "to=.." do not apply (ExceptionTranslationFilter can only redirect to a URL, not an SWF transition).

What would be nice is a way the '<secured' tag and the '<transition on-exception' tag both reside within the view-state:

<view-state id="enterBookingDetails" model="booking">
        <secured attributes="ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
        <transition on-exception="org.springframework.security.AccessDeniedException" to="noAccess" />
</view-state>

Alternatively, a global-transition would be feasible as well:
    <global-transitions>
        <transition on-exception="org.springframework.security.AccessDeniedException" to="noAccess" />
    </global-transitions>

but that gives me a weird exception:

org.springframework.webflow.execution.FlowExecutionException: Exception 
thrown in state 'null' of flow 'hotels/booking'

    at org.springframework.security.util.FilterChainProxy$VirtualFilterChain.doFilter(FilterChainProxy.java:378)
    at org.springframework.security.intercept.web.FilterSecurityInterceptor.invoke(FilterSecurityInterceptor.java:109)
[...]

The modified booking-flow.xml is attached. It just needs to be dropped into the standard booking-mvc sample in order to replicate the problem.
column91:
18/Jan/09 2:50 PM;sschmidt;A little playing around shows that there is a solution the JSF version:

When subclassing the SecurityFlowExecutionListener

public class MySecurityListener extends SecurityFlowExecutionListener {

    public void stateEntering(RequestContext context, StateDefinition state) throws EnterStateVetoException {}

    public void stateEntered(RequestContext context, StateDefinition previousState, StateDefinition newState) {
        SecurityRule rule = (SecurityRule) newState.getAttributes().get(SecurityRule.SECURITY_ATTRIBUTE_NAME);
if (rule != null) decide(rule, newState);
    }
}

and registering that listener in the webflow config, the <transition on-exception="org.springframework.security.AccessDeniedException" to="noAccess" /> works when registered in the view-state.

column95:
12/Mar/09 6:00 AM;kdonald;The crux of this issue is when SecurityFlowExecutionListener.stateEntering is called to perform the state-level security check, the state being checked is not yet the "current state".  Therefore if the AccessDeniedException is thrown, the exception handlers for that state are not applied--rather, the handlers for the current state are applied (or just global flow handlers if the current state is null).  Moving the check to stateEntered is not an option because that has the potential to bypass state entry  logic (when the security constraint fails) while executing state exit logic (when transitioning to the target state of the exception handler) which is not symmetric and will lead to the problems Stefan experienced when he tried this.

I also verified adding a global transition that does the AccessDeniedException handling for a state-level security constraint does work, which is expected, since global exception handlers get associated with the flow and do not require any state to be set to be resolved.  I think that's the best we can do in 2.0.x.  It doesn't make sense for a state exception handler to be applied if the state has not yet been entered yet, and once a state has entered its too late to prevent it from executing its behavior, because it will be potentially exited as well.
column96: 12/Mar/09 6:02 AM;kdonald;Marked WONT FIX as we anticipate no changes made in 2.0.x on this.  Use flow-level exception handlers to handle state-level security constraint violations.  We should consider wrapping the AccessDeniedException in a EnterStateVetoException if information about the vetoed state is needed to handle the access denied event.  I'll open a separate improvement JIRA for this.

column1: FlowFacesContext does not return the same FacesMessages instances
column42: I am currently using a phase listener to fix up faces messages before they are displayed (a method described here http://www.oracle.com/technology/pub/articles/masterj2ee/j2ee_wk7.html).  Unfortunately FlowFacesContext creates a new FacesMessage adapted from spring messages on each call to FacesContext.getMessages().  This means that any set method called on the message is lost.

column95:
03/Jul/08 1:56 AM;philw;Jeremy,

Attached is an updated patch that can be applied to the current trunk.  I have moved all FlowFacesContext code relating to messaging into a new delegate class.  

The main change that I have made is to created a new FlowFacesMessageAdapter class.  This class converts a FacesMessage to a spring Message and replaces the builder pattern that was used previously.  Because the Message is now an adapter the original FacesMessage that was added can be retained and returned from the toFacesMessage helper method. 

There is also an update to the test case to ensure the fix works.

Could this change be considered for the 2.0.3 release?

Cheers,
Phil.

column99:
15/Jul/08 6:41 AM;jeremyg484;Phil,

Are you using JSF 1.2?  I just ask because in JSF 1.2 you can improve the messages in this way without the PhaseListener.  For example, the JSF 1.2 standard message for the long range validation is:

{2}: Validation Error: Specified attribute is not between the expected values of {0} and {1}. 

You can specify a label attribute on the component and that label will get inserted for {2}.

For example:
<h:inputText label="A Long Input" id="foo" value="#{bar}"/>

- Jeremy

column1: popup="true" results in NoMatchingTransitionException
column42:
Adding popup="true" to a view state doesn't work if the transition results from a form submit on a JSP page. This issue can be demonstrated with the swf-booking-mvc sample:

<view-state id="reviewBooking" model="booking" popup="true">
<on-entry>
<render fragments="body"/>
</on-entry>
...
</view-state>

The cause for the issue is in the Spring.RemotingHandler. This is the exact scenario:
  1) user presses Proceed button to submit
  2) RemotingHandler.submitForm() appends parameters (e.g. fragments="bookingForm", _eventId_proceed="_eventId_proceed")
  3) server responds with redirect URL
  4) RemotingHandler.renderURLToModalDialog() appends the same parameters again
  5) server responds with NoMatchingTransition exception because it tried to process _eventId_proceed again

Commenting out the first line of RemotingHandler.renderURLToModalDialog() fixes the issue. I see no good reason for propagating the parameters from the submit to the subsequent redirect request.I verified with swf-booking-mvc and swf-booking-faces.
column91: 13/Jan/09 2:09 AM;jeremyg484;Accidental duplicate of SWF-1013

  3) server responds with redirect URL

Commenting out the first line of RemotingHandler.renderURLToModalDialog() fixes the issue. I see no good reason for propagating the parameters from the submit to the subsequent redirect request.I verified with swf-booking-mvc and swf-booking-faces.

column1: Fields on sequent pages with identical ids are populated with wrong values
column42:
If fields on sequent pages (e.g. "A" and "B") have identical ids (e.g. "name"), the fields on page "B" are populated with the values from page "A". 
See: http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=63733&highlight=Strange+binding+issue 

It seems that the bug has been introduced with the fix for SWF-953.

Relevant classes:
AbstractMvcView
AbstractMvcViewFactory

column1: export flowExecutionContext in AbstractMvcView
column42:
Please export the flowExecutionContext variable in AbstractMvcView.
This allows it to be used as a special EL variable conform the documentation and makes it consistent with the way JSF handles it.

I have not checked this problem since SWF2.0.2, but I could not find another fix for this in the jira, so I guess it's still relevant.
Please, also check http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=56326

Kind regards,
Andy.

column1: Performing a commit against a persistenceContext on sessionEnded prevents capturing a commit failure
column42: On the FlowExecutionListener.sessionEnded callback, the flow has already terminated.  If a commit occurs here and fails because of a version check on an optimistic lock, there is no way for the ending flow to capture this and ask the user to start over and try again.  The common optimistic lock failure case should be implemented and the commit logic possibly moved to sessionEnding which runs before ending--allowing the flow to handle failures.
column91: 12/Mar/09 9:52 AM;kdonald;sessionEnding now does the commit

column1: Problem with the pop up
column42:
Hi All,

I am facing issue rendering pop up with webflow 2.0.5

On the submission of a popup with a Validation Error (say empty mandatory field ), the Parent page is getting replaced with the pop up contents i.e  On any kind of validation error in pop up, if the control is again redirected to the same pop up, then the pop up is rendered as a full page and not as a pop up. Somehow the pop up state is getting lost. Strangely the error messages appears fine.

We also tried using 
	<transition on-exception = "java.lang.Exception" to="finish">
but of no help.

Please note that every thing works as expected if a form is used instead of a pop-up. 

Below is the jsp action button which triggers the subflow event.

input value="Upload List" id="uploadList" type="button"
name="_eventId_upload" onclick="Spring.remoting.submitForm('uploadList', this.form.name, {ajaxSource:'temp'});"

Here is the main webflow

<view-state id="emailRecipients" view="admin/email/recipients"
model="model">
<transition on="upload" to="upload" validate="false" />
<transition on="generate" to="generateList" validate="false" />
</view-state>

Below is the subflow for even upload from the above flow

<view-state id="uploadList" popup="true" model="fileObject" view="admin/email/uploadList">
<transition on="upload"></transition>
<transition on="validate" to="errorReport">
<evaluate expression="service.getEmail(fileObject.fileConten t, email, flowScope.uploadXlsEvent)"
result="conversationScope.recipients"/>
</transition>
<transition on="cancel" to="finish" bind="false"></transition>
</view-state>

<action-state id="errorReport">
<evaluate expression="service.isValidEmail(flowScope.uploadX lsEvent)" />
<transition on="no" to="errorMessage">
<evaluate expression="service.getErrorReportForEmailRecipien ts(flowScope.uploadXlsEvent)"
result ="flowScope.errorMessages"/>
</transition>
<transition on="yes" to="finish" />
</action-state>


<view-state id="errorMessage" popup="true" view="admin/email/uploadListErrorReport">
<transition on="continue" to="finish" bind="false"/>
<transition on="cancel" to="uploadList" bind="false"></transition>
</view-state>

<end-state id="finish"></end-state>

When initially the jsp upload button is clicked, the subflow is called which goes to view state uploadList of subflow and since pop up is true it renders it as a pop up.
But if you notice, in the viewstate errorMessage of subflow, the control is again directed back to uploadList view state on cancel transition. But this time the same viewstate is executed but the view is not comming as a pop up but instead is full size page.

The only difference i see here is that the first one is submitted from a submit button and hence is working.
Second one is another transition for the same view which is a pop up, but doesnt work.

Am i missing something here?? Do i need to do more?? Spring webflow reference document just talks about popup ="true" attribute and nothing else.

Any Idea/Suggestion would be of great help!
column91: 06/Aug/09 5:44 AM;jeremyg484;The replacement of the popup could be for one of two possible reasons: 1) You are submitting the form with a non-Ajax style submit or 2) You are submitting via Ajax but rendering back the content for an entire page instead of just the content for the form contained in the popup.  In order to display the error content in the popup, you must submit the popup's form via an Ajax submit, and in the case of an error render back only the HTML fragment containing the form.

I have the exact same problem.

<view-state id="editObjectA"  >
... 

<transition on="moreInfos" to="editObjectAMoreInfos"/>

</view-state>

and then from editObjectAMoreInfos.xhtml (moreInfosFragment is the whole page in fact)
<sf:commandButton id="saveButton" value="Validate" processIds="*" action="okTest" />
// okTest sends me back to the initial page.

I have found that I must use the sf tag.  a4j won't work since the following code doesn't get executed :

I would guess that I am only missing a detail here but can't see it for now.

column93:
22/Dec/09 11:46 PM;berkum;
Since I know that eventually some people will "google" their way to this thread.

I was able to make the popup work as expected but not without any difficulty.  Here are some steps to follow : 
(note here we are talking about a popup with validation inside it.  Otherwise, there is no problem)

1 - use a sf:commandLink or a sf:commandButton to navigate your way to the popup.  a4j: and h: equivalents won't work (weel, did not manage to make it work).  It will simply display the popup content as a whole page.

	<sf:commandButton id="moreInfosButton" value="Popup..." action="popup" /> 

2- In your transition, mention the render fragment.  Otherwise, the page will appear as there is a popup on the surface but you won't see the popup.

 	<transition on="popup" to="popupPage" >
		  <render fragments="popupFragment" />  
	</transition>  

In my case, popupFragment is the id of the top level panel (rich:panel) containing the popup content.


3- Your popup action (OK, SUBMIT, SAVE, ...) has to use again a sf:commandButton or sf:commandLink.  Here is the most important part.  You need to specify the processIds attributes and it has to point to the top level
fragment (popupFragment) or a component inside it if you do not wish to refresh the whole popup.  If you don't define this attribute you will
find yourself with the popup not above the original page but above the popup content itself in a page.  And the validation errors will appear in the background, not in the popup.

I wish the popup functionality would be more "intelligent", that is whenever we are transiting from a popup and find errors, we don't have
to define the zone to be refreshed, the framework would simply know it.  Maybe that should be an improvement to the framework.

column1: StringToEnum throws IllegalArgumentException for enum-based properties of model
column42:
Out-of-the-box binding fails with an IllegalArgumentException on form postback when attempting to bind to a model object (defined in the view) that contains enum-based properties.

StringToEnum registers the java.lang.Enum class as the target. However, in the toObject method, the attempt to find the appropriate backing constant using Enum.valueOf fails because the underlying target does not reference the constants defined by the user's enum class and, worse, the subsequent test for enumType.isEnum() fails for the java.lang.Enum class.

I believe that StringToEnum needs to allow the user-defined enum class to be registered as the target class, and that PropertyEditorRegistrySupport.getCustomEditor should support registering the requiredType using this mechanism for this to truly work out-of-the-box.

In the meantime, the only workaround for this appears to be to define a custom String-to-Enum converter and explicitly register each and every class that needs to use it.
column43: SpringSource dm Server v1.0, WebFlow 2.0.5.RELEASE, Spring Framework 2.5.6.A, Tiles 2.0.5, JSP 2.1, JRE 1.6.07

column92:
12/Feb/09 5:11 AM;kdonald;Steve,
What EL system are you using for binding back here? The default JBOSS EL, OGNL, or Spring's bean wrapper?
column93:
12/Feb/09 7:04 AM;skippy;Keith,

I'm using the JBoss EL; the SWF docs imply that only the JBoss and OGNL EL variants are available, and that the Spring EL won't be along until 3.0+. Does the EL make a difference?
column94:
12/Feb/09 7:48 AM;kdonald;This is resolved now.

The StringToEnum Converter was interfering with BeanWrapper's own default enum facility.  Unfortunately, the generic StringToEnum converter cannot be used in this context as a PropertyEditor because the concrete enum targetClass to use is not known at the time the PropertyEditor adapter is registered.  The simplest fix is to simply NOT register a String->Enum converter when working with a BeanWrapperExpression, instead relying on BeanWrapper's own native enum conversion capabilities.
column95:
12/Feb/09 7:54 AM;kdonald;Steve,

I am unable to reproduce this against JBoss EL or OGNL against the 2.0.x maintenance branch.  I was able to reproduce this when Spring's own BeanWrapper has been configured when using a custom MvcViewFactoryCreator with the "useSpringBeanBinding" flag set to true.  This is sometimes done to take advantage of BeanWrapper's ability to convert between Strings and objects in generic collections e.g. List<RegisteredType>.  Are you doing this?  OGNL and JBOSS EL do not support such special generic type conversion.
column96:
12/Feb/09 8:14 AM;skippy;Keith,

I'm somewhat surprised that you couldn't reproduce this; I'm not doing anything particularly out-of-the-ordinary here - my setup follows pretty much the setup described in Sections 9 and 10 of the docs: I have an org.jboss.el.ExpressionFactoryImpl bean as the expressionFactory, an org.springframework.webflow.expression.el.WebFlowELExpressionParser as the expressionParser and an org.springframework.webflow.mvc.builder.MvcViewFactoryCreator as the view-factory-creator, although this latter IS registered with the "useSpringBeanBinding" property set to "true". I can't remeber why I needed to do this now, although it would be fair to say that I have numerous instances of generic lists being displayed (but not bound).

Did I just screw up?
column97:
12/Feb/09 8:32 AM;kdonald;Right, if you set "useSpringBeanBinding" to true that turns on the BeanWrapperExpressionParser for view->model data binding INSTEAD OF using the default ExpressionParser (in your case, JBOSS EL).  There is definitely a bug related to String->Enum binding with the BeanWrapperExpressionParser, which I just fixed. This should be the only issue.

You probably turned on "useSpringBeanBinding" because you wanted to take advantage of Spring's ability to convert objects of generic collections e.g. a String[] -> List<RegistrantType>.  You may have also done this to use the exact same EL notation used in Spring MVC-based views (there are some subtle differences between BeanWrapper syntax and Unified EL/OGNL)
column98:
12/Feb/09 7:51 PM;skippy;Keith,

You are, of course, absolutely right. By removing both the custom enum converters AND the useSpringBeanBinding property, the app still works using 2.0.5.RELEASE (which implies that I'm not using it to bind to generic collections after all). Still, with the fix you've made here, it should now work regardless of the useSpringBeanBinding setting. Many thanks.

column91: 12/Mar/09 6:46 AM;kdonald;Does your flow enter a view-state after it handles the exception? That is the expected way to pause the flow, and key assignment happens when a ViewState is entered.  If you enter a custom state type you'll be expected to do similar ViewState logic yourself.
column92: 12/Mar/09 8:59 AM;kdonald;Improved javadoc around FlowExecutionHandler implementation.
column93:
12/Mar/09 10:36 PM;triqui;Well, they key of this issue is that it happens when a exception is thrown BEFORE any viewstate has been entered (ie on flow start, when creating variables, on first viewstate start)

I'm not completely sure after such a long time, but if I remember correctly this also happens with flow transitions on-exception.

The question is that if the exception is thrown BEFORE a viewstate is entered, then the FlowExecutionImpl has the following values:
started=true
flowSessions.size()=0
key=null
So,
The flow has started (hasStarted() is true) is not active (isActive() is false), and hence it has ended (hasEnded() is true) before it started.
The resulting state of the flow is that it was not fully started (started is true but key is null and flowSessions is empty) and it was paused, but when it tries to resume it throws the above exception or an IllegalStateException (from getActiveSession()).

That's why I switched from transitions on-exception to exception-handler, that way I can add this in my handler:
   public boolean canHandle(FlowExecutionException ex) {
      return ex.getStateId() != null && canHandleWithState(ex);
   }

But that completely kills the goal of sending the flow to a custom state when an exception is thrown.
Only if it is thrown BEFORE a viewstate has been entered but still.

Maybe your changes to javadocs explain a solution to this, but I don't know where to check it, how can I have a look at the modified javadocs?
column95:
13/Mar/09 1:18 AM;kdonald;/**
 * A strategy for handling an exception that occurs at runtime during the execution of a flow definition.
 * 
 * Note: special care should be taken when implementing custom flow execution exception handlers. Exception handlers are
 * like Transitions in that they direct flow control when exceptions occur. They are more complex than Actions, which
 * can only execute behaviors and return results that drive flow control. For this reason, if implemented incorrectly, a
 * FlowExecutionHandler can leave a flow execution in an invalid state, which can render the flow execution unusable or
 * its future use undefined. For example, if an exception thrown at flow startup gets routed to an exception handler,
 * the handler must take responsibility for ensuring the flow execution returns control to the caller in a consistent
 * state. Concretely, this means the exception handler must transition the flow to its start state. The handler should
 * not simply return leaving the flow with no current state set.
 * 
 * Note: Because flow execution handlers are more difficult to implement correctly, consider catching exceptions in your
 * web flow action code and returning result events that drive standard transitions. Alternatively, consider use of the
 * existing {@link TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler} which illustrates the proper way to implement an
 * exception handler.
 * 
 * @author Keith Donald
 */
public interface FlowExecutionExceptionHandler {

	/**
	 * Can this handler handle the given exception?
	 * @param exception the exception that occurred
	 * @return true if yes, false if no
	 */
	public boolean canHandle(FlowExecutionException exception);

	/**
	 * Handle the exception in the context of the current request. An implementation is expected to transition the flow
	 * to a state using {@link RequestControlContext#execute(Transition)}.
	 * @param exception the exception that occurred
	 * @param context the execution control context for this request
	 */
	public void handle(FlowExecutionException exception, RequestControlContext context);
}

Don't know about custom listeners from other users or other spring listeners yet to be implemented.

	at java.util.LinkedList.getLast(Unknown Source)

	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImpl.execute(FlowExecutionImpl.java:377)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.RequestControlContextImpl.execute(RequestControlContextImpl.java:201)

column97:
13/Mar/09 3:00 AM;kdonald;Triqui,

I appreciate your help researching and debugging issue.

I have just committed some changes that should resolve the issue.  Specifically, getActiveSession/getCurrentState and co will return NULL if the root session has not been created yet because the flow is still starting.  Those methods should only throw exceptions now when the flow is NOT_STARTED or has ENDED.  I have introduced a FlowExecutionStatus enum that we use to track statuses more clearly internally now.  This has been committed in trunk.  Is it possible you can run your tests against these fixes and report back?  We're close to releasing 2.0.6 so if you have the opportunity to try it out today that'd be great.

Thanks

FlowDefinitionResourceFactory.getFlowId does not remove the classpath scheme if the resource implements ContextResource
column42:
In order to solve some other business requirements, I have created a custom Resource implementation that is returned when using "classpath*:" type resource patterns.  (It's essentially a UrlResource that implements ContextResource).  However, when FlowDefinitionResourceFactory attempts to calculate the flow id, it removes the classpath scheme from the beginning of the base path for every instance (where base path is used) except for if the resource implements ContextResource.  Looking at the code, I don't see any reason to skip it in this case, as in the common cases, invoking removeClasspathScheme will have no effect, while not artificially limiting any resource type that implements ContextResource.  

I am attaching a patch that does this.
column91: 16/Dec/08 8:17 AM;sandrews;Applied patch.  Thanks for the contribution.

column1: Spring Web Flow validation conventions don't match superclasses/interfaces in method parameter
column42:
Not sure if this is a bug or an implementation choice, but whichever, its making it hard for me to use Spring Web Flow :-)

Spring Web Flow's convention options only allow for exact matching, i.e. UsernamePasswordCredentialsImpl instead of the more generic interface UsernamePasswordCredentials or the superclass Object.  This makes it near impossible for it to automatically find generic validation methods without manual intervention.

Can this be changed to allow for less stringent matching?  A specific use case for this is someone who uses the Javalid framework.  They can have one generic validator that can handle any domain class that uses the Javalid annotations.  Unfortunately, because of the matching of the convention the validator itself can't be generic enough to be useful since you still need to customize the method signature per domain class.
column91: 16/Dec/08 1:15 AM;kdonald;In 2.0.5 your Validator can implement org.springframework.validation.Validator and it will be invoked through the generic validate(Object, Errors) method.  You'd need to alias your generic validator bean with correct names for your model objects e.g. accountValidator, orderValidator for Web Flow to find it, but that should work.   See the ValidationHelper class in binding.validation for the exact algorithm.
column92: 16/Dec/08 1:27 AM;sbattaglia;I'll try this out and let you know. I guess I didn't ask well enough on the forum because the answer I had received that if I didn't want to follow the convention then I would need to manually call the method.  I'll check this out now and leave a comment if it matches my needs.  Thanks! (wish you had seen my question on the forum ;-))
column93: 16/Dec/08 1:31 AM;sbattaglia;Okay just tried it and that worked. Thanks.  I'll link to this from the forum in case anyone else has a similar problem and searches.

column1: Maven Central artifact ids match SpringSource Enterprise Bundle Repository artifact ids which can lead to dependency resolution conflicts
column42:
In a existing "non osgi" project, if I asked for spring-core version=2.5.6 I'd end up with one version of Spring Framework core .jar in my local repo.  In a new OSGI project, if I asked for org.springframework.core version=2.5.6 I'd end up with another version of Spring Framework core in my local repo [the OSGi version, with all OSGI-enabled dependencies].  But that'd be ok, because those two versions and their transient dependencies are indexed under different artifact ids and don't interfere with one another.

On the other hand, if I my first project asked for org.springframework.core version=2.5.6 and resolved that in Maven Central, my new OSGi project would try and use that artifact directly it would end up with transitive dependencies that are not OSGI compliant--because they were resolved against Maven Central.  That's the issue Thomas pointed out - and this issue effects all web flow artifacts in Maven Central.

2.0.6 should publish under different artifact ids in central to prevent this conflict from arising.
column91: 15/Dec/08 7:13 AM;kdonald;See how Spring Integration dealt with this: http://jira.springframework.org/browse/INT-245

column1: Flow Id not properly calculated when using "classpath*:" style resources in base-path
column42:
I am attempting to define flows in the following manner:

    <webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath*:/project">
      <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/webflow.xml"/>
    </webflow:flow-registry>

I have a webflow.xml in a jar file at the path:

project/proof/create/webflow.xml

Ideally, the flowId would be "proof/create".

When I do this, the flowId ends up being the full url (including the system file path, the jar url protocol, etc). If I change my flow-registry definition to:

    <webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath:/project">
      <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/proof/create/webflow.xml"/>
    </webflow:flow-registry>

it works fine. However, I lose a lot of flexibility this way (I intend to add many more flows, in multiple jar files).

It seems the culprit is in FlowDefinitionResourceFactory, in the "removeClasspathScheme" method. It strips "classpath:" from the front of the basePath, but doesn't look for "classpath*:". If I strip the "classpath*:" from the front of the basePath (with a debugger), it works as expected.
column91:
15/Dec/08 12:49 AM;sandrews;You can still use flow location patterns with a classpath: base path.  Is there some reason that this does not suit your needs?

For example:
<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath:/project"> 
    <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/webflow.xml"/> 
</webflow:flow-registry>

The Spring Travel sample applications use this style to locate the flow definitions and default the flow identifiers.
column92: 15/Dec/08 1:10 AM;deraj123;My understanding of spring resource patterns is that without the classpath*: each location pattern will only map to one file.  I would prefer for the patterns to map to multiple files.

with this:

    <webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath:/project">
      <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/proof/edit/webflow.xml"/>
      <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/proof/review/webflow.xml"/>
    </webflow:flow-registry> 

webflow successfully loads two webflow definitions - "proof/edit" and "proof/review". 

with this:

<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath:/project">
    <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/webflow.xml"/>
</webflow:flow-registry> 

webflow loads exactly zero webflow definitions - with the same libraries provided.

As an aside, using:

<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" base-path="classpath*:/project">
    <webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/webflow.xml"/>
</webflow:flow-registry> 

loads both webflow definitions successfully, but the id's are:

"file:/home/jbunting/pathToJar/jarfile.jar!/project/proof/edit"
and
"file:/home/jbunting/pathToJar/jarfile.jar!/project/proof/review"

(obviously, replace pathToJar and jarfile with the actual directory and file names, but they're long, and I thought they would confuse the issue)

column1: Binding to properties of objects in a collection of dynamic size fails with IndexOutOfBoundsException
column42:
Binding to properties of objects in a dynamically sized collection (e.g. AutoPopulatingList, LazyList, GrowthList, etc.) fail with webflow and jboss-el.  It looks like org.jboss.el.ValueExpressionImpl.setValue() gets invoked for any additional items but the invocation results in an IndexOutOfBoundsException.

Our web form allows questions to be added or removed client-side using JavaScript. Each question has a couple of properties that we want to bind to.

For example, an input for question 3 (at index 2) would look like this:
<input name="command.questions[2].title" type="text"/>

In this example "command" is our root binding object, which contains a list of "questions", each of which have a "title" property. We have addressed this with Spring MVC by using a LazyList (commons class, same as AutoPopulatingList) or by using a GrowingList (commons class). These override get/set methods on the List interface to automatically create questions as needed by the binding code.

However, the EL binding code used by webflow doesn't simply call "get" or "set" on the list, but instead it calls size() and throws an exception if the size isn't large enough. (this is down in ListELResolver) In the previous example, since on the first binding, the questions list would be empty, the EL binding code calls size() which returns 0. Since we're trying to bind to a question at index 2, the binding code throws a PropertyNotFoundException.

A workaround is to pre-populate the list of questions, but since the client-side DHTML can add or remove those, it's impossible to know how many will be needed for binding (hence our use of Lazy/GrowingList). Perhaps we could hack something together that passes the total number to the server in a hidden field, etc. but I'm not even sure how to hook into the web code prior to binding to do this. (is there a hook into the binding before the EL binding code runs? i.e. the ability to add objects into the collection before webflow tries to bind to the command object)

I should also mention that binding to a collection of simple properties works fine. For example if my binding was just to "command.questions[3]" you could use a GrowthList. In this case the binding code calls questions.set( 3, "value") and the growth list automatically grows the size of the list to support this. However, "command.questions[3].title" does not work.
column91: 12/Dec/08 6:00 AM;jhaile;Original forum post related to this issue is here: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=64698

column1: File extension left off when generating flow definition URLs for requests mapped using a servlet-mapping of *.extension (like *.htm)
column42: This is a bug in DefaultFlowUrlHandler; in the case of a servlet mapping like *.htm, the servlet path is populated and the path info is null.  The method that extracts the flow id from the servlet path correctly strips the file extension.  However, the method that generates a new flow url to perform a flow redirect does not append the extension back.  This means the servlet would never be mapped when the redirect is sent.

column1: BeanWrapperExpressionParser does not respect target valueType when applying PropertyEditor->Converter adapter logic
column42: This can result in generic converters failing because they don't have the targetClass context to perform a suitable conversion.  This issue was detected when the StringToEnum converter failed when use in conjunction with the BeanWrapperExpressionParser.  The conversion executors adapted as property editors need to be configured with a suitable targetClass context to resolve this issue.
column91:
12/Feb/09 8:04 AM;kdonald;Fixed by simply not overridding BeanWrapper's own enum conversion facility.

There is no way we can resolve the targetClass to convert to before calling setProperty a deterministic way; it's ultimately up to the BeanWrapper to do that during its setProperty attempt.  Given the current system, the best we can do is pre-register all String->Object Converters before calling setProperty and ensure we don't interfere with BeanWrapper's default facilities.  This limits the use of generic converters that can convert an entire class hierarchy in conjunction with a BeanWrapper Expression Parser.

Web Flow 3.0 its alignment with Spring 3.0's EL is expected to deal with this issue directly.

column1: MVC form:checkbox and form:checkboxes tags do not apply registered Converters for their item values

a. checkbox binding to List<Capabilities>, selectable from availableCapabilities.
b. registered StringToCapability converter which renders capabilitiy's name as a string
c. even though converter is registered, the value for a checkbox element is the value of Capability.toString(), which is not correct

The bug seems to be in the fact that MVCViews' BindingModel does not implement BindingResult and specifically the findEditor method used by BindStatus.

column1: Multiple JSF validators duplicate messages
Custom converters do not get applied correctly with collection elements (array/lists)
column42:
Reproducible test case:
- Register a custom converter...e.g. StringToBundle
- Use it for a list binding... each to support a list of checkboxes binding to a List<Bundle> property on a model.
- That will fail, saying it will not know how to converter from String to List.  It should be able to recognize it can apply the custom converter to each list element.
Current workaround is to fallback to default converter for string->type, which limits to per-type specification of conversion logic instead of per-field.
Also, for introspection of generic metadata to work properly you must enable "useSpringBeanBinding" when setting up the mvc view system (MvcViewFactoryCreator) as bean wrapper is the only EL-like system that supports this at present.

column1: subflow inheritance not working
column42:
I have one parent flow and 2 subflows in it.

All the subflows need to serve some global menu click actions, so I put those common menuclick actions in the common-flow definition as global transitions to go the common endstates that all the subflows are supposed to serve.

Code:

<flow abstract="true"...>
<!-- these will serve the global menuActions -->
   <global-transitions>
      <transition on="menu1ClickAction" to="menu1ClickAction-EndState" />
      <transition on="menu2ClickAction" to="menu2ClickAction-EndState" />
  </global-transitions>

<!--this common-subflow will serve to receive the above common end states-->
   <subflow-state id="common-subflow" >
         <transition on="menu1ClickAction-EndState" to="subflow1" />
         <transition on="menu2ClickAction-EndState" to="subflow2" />
   </subflow-state>

</flow>

the main flow is inheriting from the common-flow definition
and its subflows are inheriting from the common-subflow

Code:

<flow parent="common-flow" ...>
  <view-state ... />

  <subflow id=''subflow1" parent="common-flow#common-subflow"/>
  <subflow id=''subflow2" parent="common-flow#common-subflow"/>
  <subflow id=''subflow3" parent="common-flow#common-subflow"/>
</flow>

I was assuming that when I am in subflow2 and the menu1ClickAction happens, I should get forwarded to the subflow1 in this case, but I get a nullpointer exception in
Code:

org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.model.FlowModelFlowBuilder.parseSubflowExpression(FlowModelFlowBuilder.java:713)

because this function is called by FlowModelBuilder.parseAndAddSubflowState() function which passes it
state.getSubflow() parameter which for common-subflow state is NULL - I understand that since I have not provided the value for subflow attribute in the common-subflow element but shouldn't the child get this value after the merge algorithm is applied on the parent and the child.

Is it a bug or something that I am missing ? ( I have SWF 2.0.5 jars.)
column91:
10/Dec/08 8:09 AM;kdonald;Everything seems to be OK here.  The problem is you're linking a abstract subflow-state definition with id "common-flow' into your child flow and your flow fails to compile as a result.  I suggest you break out your parent flow into two flows, one you inherit from directly and the other you link from.  See:

parent

<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd"
	abstract="true">

	<global-transitions>
		<transition on="menu1ClickAction" to="menu1ClickAction-EndState" />
		<transition on="menu2ClickAction" to="menu2ClickAction-EndState" />
	</global-transitions>

</flow>

parent2

<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd"
	abstract="true">

	<subflow-state id="common-subflow">
		<transition on="menu1ClickAction-EndState" to="subflow1" />
		<transition on="menu2ClickAction-EndState" to="subflow2" />
	</subflow-state>

</flow>

child

<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd"
	parent="parent">

        ...

	<subflow-state id="subflow1" parent="parent2#common-subflow" subflow="child"/>
	<subflow-state id="subflow2" parent="parent2#common-subflow" subflow="child"/>
	<subflow-state id="subflow3" parent="parent2#common-subflow" subflow="child"/>

</flow>

This way no "common-flow" subflow-state ever gets linked into your child--you simply use the parent#common-subflow to populate your subflow1-3 states with common info.

column1: Message code resolving in Web Flow seems broken
column42:
I have the Portlet application based on SWF and MVC. 
I have the form displaying the order, which have table for displaying order items. In each row there is an editable field "Quantity" so that use can edit the number of items ordered. 
The 'order' model object contains 'orderItems' list with items; so the input fields in the table are binded to this expression:
first row:      order.orderItems[0].quantity
second row: order.orderItems[1].quantity
etc.
Quantity is a number. If user enters the non-number string, the binding error is raised and message is displayed: "typeMismatch on order.orderItems[0].quantity". This is obviously too obscure for user, so I want to replace it with some nice message. Here begins the problem.

1. I searched across SWF user manual, find no word about replacing the messages. I believe that standard procedure is used, i.e. in messages.properties file I specify the messages, but what are the keys (codes) to use? No idea. It is not documented at all. I search also across forums, but also no hint found.
2. We use Spring MVC, so perhaps something in Spring Framework manual. I found only the section on binding referring to DefaultMessageCodesResolver. According to the documentation of DefaultMessageCodesResolver, I should expect following codes to be used:
    *  1. try "typeMismatch.order.orderItems[0].quantity"
    * 2. try "typeMismatch.order.orderItems.quantity"
    * 3. try "typeMismatch.orderItems[0].quantity"
    * 4. try "typeMismatch.orderItems.quantity"
    * 5. try "typeMismatch.quantity"
    * 6. try "typeMismatch.int"
    * 7. try "typeMismatch" 
I tried all of them, and found out that only the last one ("typeMismatch" ) works. It's sad, because it is too general, not specific to this order object or this screen. 
So how should I specify the code for this situation?
3. After debugging the SWF code, I found that the method AbstractMvcView.createMessageResolver() is called and it creates two codes:
    * 1. "order.orderItems[0].quantity.typeMismatch"
    * 2. "typeMismatch" 
Again, first one makes no sense in case of list (I cannot list all possible indices in messages file: "order.orderItems[0].quantity.typeMismatch", "order.orderItems[1].quantity.typeMismatch", "order.orderItems[2].quantity.typeMismatch", ... - it makes no sense). The second one is too general (actually, I used it, because I had no choice).

So it looks like there is no simple way to specify message in such a case.

To sum it up:
1. The message codes used by SWF are not documented. One have to debug the code to find it. 
2. The mechanism of creating those codes is not documented too. Does it mean that SWF doesn't use the DefaultMessageCodesResolver? 
3. If SWF uses its own mechanism instead of DefaultMessageCodesResolver, then this mechanism is very poor, as you see: there is no way to specify messages for collections binding errors; also, there is no way of specifying messages for specific types (e.g. no code "typeMismatch.int").
4. DefaultMessageCodesResolver uses codes patterns "errorType + object" ("typeMismatch.x.x.x"). The SWF mechanism uses opposite: "object + errorType" ("x.x.x.typeMismatch"). This is misleading.
column91: 09/Mar/09 3:18 PM;kdonald;Made MessageCodesResolver strategy pluggable, allowing plugging in a DefaultMessageCodesResolver for consistency with Spring MVC.
column92: 23/Jun/10 6:30 PM;tcgtam;To Keith: Which version should I expect to include the fix to this problem, 2.0.6 or 3.0.0M1?

column1: SimpleELContext is not thread-safe
column42:
Class SimpleELContext extends javax.el.Context. 
Javadoc http://java.sun.com/products/jsp/2.1/docs/jsp-2_1-pfd2/javax/el/ELContext.html said :
"""" Because it stores state during expression evaluation, an ELContext object is not thread-safe """.

Instance of SimpleELContext is stored in ELDelegatingPropertyResolver and ELDelegatingVariableResolver, which are application singletons, so this instance of SimpleELContext is shared for all sessions.

This bug is very strange, because in single user development/testing everything works fine, but in production with more users, we got usually NullPointerException on bizzarre places in program like this :
>        String label = getItemLabel() != null ? getItemLabel().toString() : null;

Attachment contains a patch, which helps me.
column43: WebSphere 6.1 / Tomcat 5.5, JSF 1.1, MyFaces 1.1.6 / Tomahawk 1.1.8, RichFaces 3.1.6, SpringFramework 2.5.6
column91:
12/Mar/09 2:37 PM;phamlen;Just some testing results:

We had this problem on our application and were able to consistently reproduce it by having two users submit the same form of a complex page at the same time.  (Specifically, we could reproduce it 20 out of 20 times and had debugged it down to the SimpleELContext before we found this Jira bug.)

We then applied the patch to a fresh copy of 2.0.5.RELEASE source from svn and it eliminated the problem (and all other related problems.)  

It also had no noticeable impact on performance when we ran our load testing (we have a standard loadtest and there was no difference in the numbers.)

In addition, we actually tested this patch using both the SUN Mojarra RI implementation and MyFaces 1.2.6 and using two different EL engines (UEL and an Ognl EL variant.)  It worked on all variations.

-Peter Hamlen (phamlen _at_ mail.com)

column1: Wrong method specified in sample validation code for returning MessageContext from ValidationContext
MessageContextErrors ignores nestedPath in getFieldValue
column42:
Implementation of MessageContextErrors.getFieldValue causes error when a validator calls errors.getFieldValue (e.g. by calling ValidationUtils.rejectIfEmptyOrWhitespace) after calling errors.pushNestedPath. 

This applies to MessageContextErrors that are initialized with 
mappingResults = null
expressionParser = DefaultExpressionParserFactory.getExpressionParser()

The reason for the error seems to be that getFieldValue calls parseFieldExpression(field) ignoring the nestedPath.

Also, in spring-faces, the FlowActionListener initializes a MessageContextErrors with
mappingResults = null
expressionParser = null

and getFieldValue is therefore unavailable.

See forum thread: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=63958

column1: Evaluation with result mapping during subflow transition results in no transition

If I remove the <evaluate> from the transition, the transition occurs and the view renders correctly.  If I change the evaluate expression to not have a result, then the transition also occurs and the view renders correctly.

Here is the subflow-state snippet that fails to work:
    <subflow-state id="phoneBankingInitiativeFlow" subflow="phoneBankingInitiative">
        <input name="initiativeCommand"/>
        <transition on="cancel" to="selectInitiative"/>
        <transition on="initiativeCreated" to="selectInitiative">
            <evaluate expression="deploymentCommand.setInitiativeId(initiativeCommand.initiativeId)" result="deploymentCommand.initiativeId"/>
        </transition>

    <subflow-state id="phoneBankingInitiativeFlow" subflow="phoneBankingInitiative">

Any more information you can provide would be helpful.  I successfully tested with the following flow defs:

top.xml

<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">

	<var name="initiativeCommand" class="org.springframework.webflow.engine.model.builder.xml.swf966.TestBean"/>
	<var name="deploymentCommand" class="org.springframework.webflow.engine.model.builder.xml.swf966.TestBean"/>
	
    <subflow-state id="phoneBankingInitiativeFlow" subflow="sub">
        <input name="initiativeCommand"/>
        <transition on="cancel" to="selectInitiative"/>
        <transition on="initiativeCreated" to="selectInitiative">
            <evaluate expression="currentEvent.attributes.initiativeId" result="deploymentCommand.initiativeId"/>
        </transition>
    </subflow-state>
    
    <view-state id="selectInitiative" /> 
    
</flow>

sub

<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
	xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
	xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-2.0.xsd">

	<input name="initiativeCommand"/>
	
	<end-state id="initiativeCreated">
		<output name="initativeId" value="initiativeCommand.initiativeId"/>
	</end-state>
	
</flow>

column1: Render phase ignores facesContext.responseComplete
column42:
It seems that the render response phase of the JSF lifecycle is executed regardless of whether facesContext.responseComplete() has been called before.

Perhaps, JsfView can check for this condition and return without rendering if it is true. 
Also, just from a quick look into it, shouldn't externalContext.recordResponseComplete be set when facesContext.responseComplete() is called so that a redirect is also prevented?

See forum thread: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=63607

column1: The ViewActionStateHolder stays in flashScope after successfully transitioning to the next view
column42: In 2.0.5, a Web Flow / Spring MVC View's "action state" (holding the user event and data binding results) is stored in flash scope after event processing to support re-rendering binding error state, even after a redirect [which does not occur in a servlet environment by default but always occurs in a Portlet environment].  Currently, this state is lingering around in flashScope even when the view has no errors and the flow succesfully transitions to the next view.  While this does not cause side effects, it is incorrect behavior none-the-less.  The view action state should only be stored in flash scope when there are binding errors...

column1: Booking MVC Reference Application: Decorated RadioButton components do not bind "on" selected value
column42:
The "Smoking" field of the BookingDetails form does not bind the 'on' value correctly when decorated.  With JavaScript turned on, Dojo submits a value "on" when the field is selected.  The backing Boolean converter cannot convert this "on" text value to a Boolean result.  With JavaScript off, the default radio button field submits "true" which binds correctly.

This may be a regression since the upgrade to Dojo 1.2, since the decoration is configured to submit a 'true' value and it appears to be submitting 'on' anyway.

The right fix is most likely enhancing the StringToBoolean converter to be able to convert on/off as well as true/false.  We should also look to upgrade to the latest Dojo 1.2 maintenance release if this is in fact a Dojo bug.
column91: 15/Nov/08 9:02 AM;kdonald;Removing the explicit value = true widgetAttr on the decoration fixed the problem.
column92: 26/Nov/08 12:18 AM;kdonald;This appears to still be a problem in the latest Web Flow 2.x.  Jeremy, any ideas?  Is it a Dojo bug?
column93: 26/Nov/08 12:59 AM;sandrews;The ElementDecoration for smoking should use string values for 'true' and 'false' instead of boolean values for widgetAttrs.value.

column1: Not possible to use Errors object as an alternative to ValidationContext on model validation methods
column42: This is an inconsistency.  If support for Errors is provided on model Validator objects, it should also be provided on the actually form backing objects themselves.

column1: User entered values that cause binding failures not available in ValidationContext during model validation.
column42:
This is inconsistent with Spring MVC's Errors object, which makes the user-entered "field value" available.
This allows a Validator to validate against the user-entered value, and supports returning a single set of combined errors that report binding and validation failures.

<webflow:flow-location-pattern value="**/*.xml" />
</webflow:flow-registry>

WORKS

<webflow:flow-location-pattern value="/**/*.xml" />
</webflow:flow-registry>

DOES NOT WORK

</webflow:flow-registry>

column1: No change in execution parameter with recursive subflow
column42:
In our flow definition we use a recursive call of the same flow definition. So it can happen, that during flow execution the same view-state is reached several times but in different subflow calls. We implemented our system with version 2.0 M4 and now updated to release 2.0.4. With version 2.0 M4 the ids of the execution parameter (execution=e1s2) increased with every click on any button of any view. Even if the click ended in a recursive subflow call, which ended in the same view-id again. For us, this behaviour is the required behaviour in order to enable the use of the browser back-button.
With release 2.0.4 we now encountered a problem. Whenever a new subflow is started the execution parameter does not change. Thus, the browsers back button does no longer work correctly.

Thanks for your help!

Kind regards
Bernd Stadlhofer

column1: Multiple Fragments not rendering
column42:
Multiple fragments are not rendered when specified by a comma separated list.  Adding response.flushBuffer() to line 96 of AjaxTilesView.java seemed to fix the issue.  Comparing revisions it looks as though it was either intentionally or accidently removed in 2.0.4 because a call to request.getSession() was added in it's place.

Attached file is the patched version.
column91:
07/Nov/08 10:03 AM;nscavell;Also I noticed that if you define the fragments in the webflow definition as apposed to the javascript defintion, the webflow definition separated list either replaces all whitespace, or trims each fragment after the list is split.  When you define the fragments via JavaScript, the fragment can contain whitespace.  So doing something like params: {fragments: "fragment1, fragment2"} will result in an exception because there isn't a tile definition with the string value " fragment2" (notice the whitespace).  I would prob either replace all whitespace when String attrName = request.getParameter(FRAGMENTS_PARAM); is called or loop through the strings after StringUtils.commaDelimitedListToStringArray(attrName); is called and do a trim.

This issue I believe existed in previous versions of webflow, not sure.  I just find it important to treat the fragments with consistency, either if you define them in the webflow definition or JavaScript.

column1: Locating of flow definitions broken when base-path not being used
column43: WinXP SP2, WebSphere Application Server 6.1.0.17, JSF 1.2, Facelets
column91: 06/Nov/08 1:07 PM;nickr;Note that the SWF code excerpts above are back-to-front.
column92:
07/Nov/08 12:22 AM;kdonald;Nick. This was a tough call for us, and one I went back and forth on.   I would definitely prefer *not* to introduce such changes in point releases, but we felt that the existing behavior was not ideal .  We ultimately considered the previous 2.0.x behavior a bug / gap since it could simply not support nested flow paths, for example: /air/booking and /hotel/booking would simply both map to flow id 'booking' then, which obviously breaks down.

Separately, mapping flows to URLs manually resulted in too much redundancy in configuration.  We sought to address this in the 2.0.x scope from the outset--we introduced FlowHandlerAdapter in 2.0.0 with the goal to address this but unfortunately didn't complete the job until FlowHandlerMapping was introduced in 2.0.4 [which is now recommended as a superior alternative to the old FlowController].

We also considered going to 2.1 with this change, but in the end decided it was best to complete 2.0.x and classify this as "closing the last gap" in Web Flow 2.0.x.

We were expecting the production using nested URL paths to their flows to be fairly small at this point, versus the number invoking flows at top-level URLs e.g. /login, which would not be effected by this change.  We may have underestimated that.

How are you working around this issue?  More insight and suggestions from your side is appreciated.
column93: 10/Nov/08 12:47 AM;kdonald;Will document compatibility issue in 2.0.5 and note how to restore earlier 2.0.x behavior.
column94: 10/Nov/08 1:17 AM;kdonald;Considering adding "useFullRequestPathAsFlowId" property to DefaultFlowUrlHandler, with value=false when used with FlowController and value=true for FlowHandlerAdapter/FlowHandlerMapping.  Since it is expected most existing web flow applications use the FlowController, this will have the positive benefit of not breaking them.  Those using the handlermapping/adapter can set the flag to false explicitly if they need the old behavior.  Sound acceptable?

column1: flow-registry base-path in combination with flow-location-pattern not working in dm server environment
column42: Perhaps an issue with pattern matching for OsgiResources?
column91:
30/Oct/08 10:28 AM;sandrews;This issue boils down to UrlResources being returned from getResources(pattern) in a Spring DM environment.  A traditional web application returns ContextResource which provides easy access to the path information for the resource.  Currently, only ContextResources support the file path default flow id convention.

The file name default flow id convention is used instead.

We have two main options:
1. Support UrlResource for the file path convention
2. Document the limitation and work with the spring-dm team on a long term solution
column92: 31/Oct/08 2:44 AM;kdonald;Coordinated with Sam. This issue is being handled by dm server team.

column1: Incorrect redirect in new session
column42:
If a flow is mapped using a URL extension, and if someone uses a bookmarked link from an earlier flow instance, Spring WebFlow loses the extension on new flow creation, resulting in 404-not found. Here are the details:

Spring WebFlow automatically puts a flow execution key in URL, for example accessing /myapp/myflow.xyz will take you to: /myapp/myflow.xyz?execution=e1s1

If someone bookmarks this link, and later tries to use it directly (in a new browser session), WebFlow is supposed to redirect back to /myapp/myflow.xyz to start a new flow. However, it is redirecting to /myapp/myflow - note the missing ".xyz" suffix. Obviously, this results in 404-not found.

I am using the normal setup - myflow.xyz is mapped to flowController using SimpleUrlHandlerMapping, and *.xyz is mapped to Spring MVC dispatcher servlet. The flow is defined in myflow.xml, and is registered with flowRegistry.

The versions used are Spring WebFlow 2.0.3 and Spring 2.5. This bug occurs in all application servers and browsers I tested. As users frequently bookmark the links, at least the initial entry into a flow, this is a serious bug, with no work-around. 

Corresponding forum thread is at http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?p=209256 .

column94: 10/Nov/08 8:14 AM;kdonald;Unfortunately the fix you provided is not that simple--it will not work with a redirect to another flow definition.  It should be possible to detect the presence of a file extension in the request URI e.g. .htm and then guess that this needs to be appended to the flow id for the next request to be mapped properly.  It would be much cleaner if we could actually lookup the servlet mapping, but this is not supported by the servlet specification at present.

column1: ResourceServlet crash and add "Error 500" at the end of the streamed resource
column42:
The ResourceServlet uses the "in.available()" syntax which seems to fail when running IBM WebSphere 6's JRE.
This happens both with compressed (gzipped) content or not.

By replacing the code with a more traditionnal approach (using in.read() like "FileCopyUtils" does), it works fine !

My proposition of fix is:
----------------------------------- replace in 'doGet' method:
while (in.available() > 0) {
	int len = in.read(buffer);
	out.write(buffer, 0, len);
}
----------------------------------- by:
int bytesRead = -1;
while ((bytesRead = in.read(buffer)) != -1) {
	out.write(buffer, 0, bytesRead);
}

By the way, the exception is:
[10/20/08 13:49:59:905 CEST] 0000002a SystemOut     O 20/10/2008 13:49:59,905 DEBUG      [WebContainer : 0] com.fortis.rsa.spring.webflow.js.ResourceServlet - Enabling GZIP compression for the current response.
[10/20/08 13:49:59:905 CEST] 0000002a SystemErr     R java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
	at java.util.zip.DeflaterOutputStream.write(DeflaterOutputStream.java:128)
	at java.util.zip.GZIPOutputStream.write(GZIPOutputStream.java:93)
	at com.fortis.rsa.spring.webflow.js.ResourceServlet$GZIPResponseStream.write(ResourceServlet.java:352)

column1: AjaxTilesView fails for nested tiles-definition in case of an ajaxRequest
column42:
The AjaxTilesView does not resolve nested tiles-definition in case of an ajax request.

For the following tiles-definition the tiles "form" is not added to the flattenedAttributeMap and hence a partial rendering of the form-tiles is not possible.

<tiles-definitions>
    <definition name="index" template="/WEB-INF/jsp/index.jsp">
        <put-attribute name="form" value="simpleform" />
        <put-attribute name="result" value="/WEB-INF/jsp/result.jsp" />
    </definition>
   <definition name="simpleform" template="/WEB-INF/jsp/searchForm.jsp">
		<put-attribute name="errorform" value="error" />
	</definition>
	<definition name="base.error" template="/WEB-INF/jsp/base.error.jsp">
		<put-attribute name="formobject" value="errorFBO" />
	</definition>
	<definition name="error" extends="base.error">
		<put-attribute name="formobject" value="childErrorFBO" />
	</definition>
</tiles-definitions>

In the attached zip-file I provide a possible fix  - see line 123 in the AjaxTilesView-class. Here I add a nested definition to the result map.

Additionally I provide a junit-test for testing the changes. To make this work I had to change the signature of the flattenAttributeMap-method from private to protected.

-------------
files changed:
src/main/java/org/springframework/js/ajax/tiles2/AjaxTilesView
pom.xml

files added:
src/test/resources/tiles-views.xml
src/test/java/org/springframework/js/ajax/tiles2/AjaxTilesViewTest

20/Oct/08 12:10 AM;oehmiche;had to adapt the class AjaxTilesView again.

adding the attribute to the map instead of a template string.

column1: Enum mappings can fail if they override methods
ConversionExceptions thrown during EL type coersion are leaking out, which causes the data mapping process to halt
column42:
This bug effects the Unified EL expression parser implementation.
The result is ConversionExceptions are getting thrown out to the client and not caught by the data mapping system during data binding.
The bug is in the BindingELExpression class used by ELExpressionParser.

column1: AJAX commandLinks within <f:facet> do not work
column42:
This seems to be a known issue but I could not find an Issue here in Jira. 

A note in the booking-faces example in /WEB-INF/flows/main/reviewHotels.xhtml points to it:

<h:dataTable id="hotels" styleClass="summary" value="#{hotels}" var="h" rendered="#{hotels.rowCount > 0}">
        <h:column>
                <f:facet name="header">
                        <!-- @TODO - Ajax won't work here until JSF RI fixes bug in UIData.invokeOnComponent - scheduled for 1.2_09 -->
                        <sf:commandLink id="sortByNameLink" ajaxEnabled="true" action="sort" value="Name">
                                <f:param name="sortBy" value="name" />
                        </sf:commandLink>
                </f:facet>
                #{h.name}
        </h:column>
[...]

The above mentioned release is now available. Its changelogs in fact point to some fixes on invokeOnComponent.  
But wehen I tried to replace the jsf-api and jsf-ri jars that came with spring webflow 2.0.3, nothing changes. 
The AJAX call is answered with a single script tag which updates the form action, and that's all..

So what is the status of this?

Is the JSF-RI fix still not working / was it another issue that was fixed?

Are there additional webflow changes needed?
column91: 03/Oct/08 1:05 AM;jeremyg484;It sounds like you did not set processIds to an appropriate value.  By default, only the submitting component is processed.  (We will likely change this in the future to make processIds="*" the default.)
column92: 10/Nov/08 1:54 AM;jeremyg484;Samples were updated in 2.0.4 to use JSF RI 1.2.09, and the sorting commandLinks were updated to use Ajax.

column1: FlowResourceELResolver does not work outside of Web Flow environment
column42: Throws a NPE if the request context is null -- resolution using resourceBundle is not possible when a jsf view is rendered by spring mvc directly
column91:
05/Oct/08 3:39 AM;ttimbul;I second a fix, for the reason that it then becomes possible to reuse code fragments (facelets in particular) that reference 'resourceBundle'. Outside of Webflow this can be loaded with <f:loadBundle>, completely transparent to the (x)html template.

So a possible fix is to ignore if Webflow isn't active by doing a check for whether getRequestContext() returns null, rather than blindly returning the MessageContext, like so:

replace
           if(base == null [...]
with
           if(getRequestContext()!=null && base == null [...]

in all overridden ELResolver methods.

Or to the same effect:

if(getRequestContext()==null) {return [null/false/default return value];}
if(base == null [...]

column1: Merging Transitions doens't consider on-exceptions
column42:
Suppose we have a flow called FLOW_A containing a global transition like the following: 
    <global-transitions>
        <transition on="something" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="myHandler.doSomething()"/>
        </transition>  
    </global-transitions>

Suppose FLOW_A has a parent abstract flow FLOW_B also containing some global transitions containing on-exceptions like the following:
    <global-transitions>
        <transition on-exception="Exception1" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException1(rootCauseException)"/>
        </transition>
        <transition on-exception="Exception2" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException2(rootCauseException)"/>
        </transition>
    </global-transitions>

During the merge of both global transitions the result will be something like:
    <global-transitions>
        <transition on="something" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="myHandler.doSomething()"/>
        </transition>  
        <transition on-exception="Exception1" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException2(rootCauseException)"/>
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException1(rootCauseException)"/>
        </transition>
    </global-transitions>

instead of 

    <global-transitions>
        <transition on="something" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="myHandler.doSomething()"/>
        </transition>  
        <transition on-exception="Exception1" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException1(rootCauseException)"/>
        </transition>
        <transition on-exception="Exception2" to="somewhere">
            <evaluate expression="exceptionHandler.handleException2(rootCauseException)"/>
        </transition>
    </global-transitions>


This is because in the org.springframework.webflow.engine.model.TransitionModel.isMergeableWith(Model model) method only the "on" is considered and not "on-exception": 

    public boolean isMergeableWith(Model model) {
        if (!(model instanceof TransitionModel)) {
            return false;
        }
        TransitionModel transition = (TransitionModel) model;
        return ObjectUtils.nullSafeEquals(getOn(), transition.getOn());
    }

instead of 

    public boolean isMergeableWith(Model model) {
        if (!(model instanceof TransitionModel)) {
            return false;
        }
        TransitionModel transition = (TransitionModel) model;
        return ObjectUtils.nullSafeEquals(getOn(), transition.getOn())
                && ObjectUtils.nullSafeEquals(getOnException(), transition.getOnException());
    }
column91: 24/Oct/08 2:16 AM;sandrews;Both the 'on' and 'on-exception' values will be evaluated when determining if a transition is mergeable.

column1: Conversion fails for genric typed class
column42:
I have a Categrory class implementing a generic Entity<T extends Serializable>. The interface is defining a setId(T):void and a getId():T method. On the Category class I define T as being an Integer (giving setId(Integer):void and getId():Integer). On my view I have a form binding to the Category class.

On my development machine (Windows platform) my application works fine, but when I deploy on my Ubuntu server, conversion fails with the following stacktrace:

org.springframework.binding.convert.ConversionExecutorNotFoundException: No ConversionExecutor found for converting from sourceClass [java.io.Serializable] to target class [java.lang.String]
        at org.springframework.binding.convert.service.GenericConversionService.getConversionExecutor(GenericConversionService.java:162)
        at org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.support.FlowBuilderContextImpl$ParentConversionServiceProxy.getConversionExecutor(FlowBuilderContextImpl.java:132)
        at org.springframework.binding.convert.service.GenericConversionService.getConversionExecutor(GenericConversionService.java:160)
        at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getConverter(BindingModel.java:171)
        at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getFormattedValue(BindingModel.java:144)
        at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getFieldValue(BindingModel.java:128)
        at org.springframework.web.servlet.support.BindStatus.<init>(BindStatus.java:120)

When I remove the generic interface from the Category class, the ConversionService always finds the Integer as sourceClass, with the generic type, on Linux the service is resolving to Serializable.

EDIT: Also, atm I'm unable to test this on a Windows box, so I can not confirm nor deny whether 2.0.3 or the latest snapshot works under Windows.

EDIT2: I'll also mention that in my case the generic type is bound to Long instead of Int as is the case with the reporter of this issue.  Also, I'm fairly new to Spring, I'd like to know if there exists a release schedule/roadmap for Spring Webflow, where I could see when 2.0,4 is due?

My problem is the same except that I have a field that is a Long not an Integer. I have the error whenever there's a binding to the id field.

Stacktrace:
org.springframework.core.convert.ConverterNotFoundException: No converter found capable of converting from 'java.io.Serializable' to 'java.lang.String'
	at org.springframework.core.convert.support.GenericConversionService.convert(GenericConversionService.java:180)
	at org.springframework.expression.spel.support.StandardTypeConverter.convertValue(StandardTypeConverter.java:70)
	at org.springframework.expression.common.ExpressionUtils.convertTypedValue(ExpressionUtils.java:67)
	at org.springframework.expression.spel.standard.SpelExpression.getValue(SpelExpression.java:98)
	at org.springframework.binding.expression.spel.SpringELExpression.getValue(SpringELExpression.java:78)
	at org.springframework.webflow.mvc.view.BindingModel.getFormattedValue(BindingModel.java:228)

column100: 17/Dec/10 5:44 AM;rstoya05-aop;There were a few (possibly related) issues reported for type conversion in Spring 3.0.4 and 3.0.5 (SPR-7816, SPR-7766). Short of creating a test that invokes the GenericConversionService directly, I guess a simpler test would be to try with Spring 3.0.3, which was the last version reported not to have that problem.
column101:
23/Dec/10 7:09 AM;marenato;I tried a quick test with Spring 3.0.3 but it produce other conversion errors that seems related to Spring Security 3.0.3, i'll test it better for now I created a custom converter as a workaround.

If could be of any use: debugging I noticed that the different behavior between win an linux is originated in the class _org.springframework.expression.spel.support.ReflectivePropertyAccessor_, in the method _findGetterForProperty_ (called by canRead) by the instruction {{Method[] ms = clazz.getMethods();}}.
In Linux the array {{ms}} has at index 0 the method {{getId()}} with _java.lang.Long_ as return type and at index 1 the method {{getId()}} with _java.io.Serializable_ as return type, in win  vice versa at index 0 the method {{getId()}} with _java.io.Serializable_ as return type and at index 1 the method {{getId()}} with  _java.lang.Long_ as return type
column102: 23/Dec/10 8:38 AM;rstoya05-aop;It's worth pointing out the issue was originally created for Web Flow 2.0.x based on its own ConversionService. In Web Flow 2.1 we switched to using Spring's ConversionService internally. It might be worth trying to reproduce the issue outside of Web Flow in a unit test that creates a Spring ConversionService (Web Flow uses FormattingConversionServiceFactoryBean unless you specify your own instance) and then performs the conversion.

column1: ServletExternalContext.getFlowExecutionUrl(..) returns a server-relative URL, should be a context-relative one
column42: public class ServletExternalContext public String getFlowExecutionUrl(String flowId, String flowExecutionKey) { return flowUrlHandler.createFlowExecutionUrl(flowId, flowExecutionKey, request); } The JavaDoc at ExternalContext.getFlowExecutionUrl(..) says "Get a context-relative flow execution URL ...", but flowUrlHandler.createFlowExecutionUrl(..) returns a server-relative URL. MockExternalContext.getFlowExecutionUrl(..) does return a context-relative URL, as documented.
