column1: SWF-JSF: Lost values after call a subflow with immediate=true
column42:
Call a rootflow where the jsf page has some required fields and a button to call a subflow (maybe to choose some pictures or other data). 
The button has the attribute immediate="true" so that the user can input some required fileds, call the subflow and after it, the user should complete the input of required fields.
Because the immediate=true, the upate model phase of jsf was overjumped. If you retunr to the rootflow, the main jsf page get the data from the model and all the not updated date are lost.

See the example please.
column91: 27/Aug/08 4:41 PM;axelbecker;Rootflow with Subflow and Testbean.
column92: 19/Sep/08 2:50 AM;jeremyg484;This is the expected behavior of JSF.  You could get around it by turning off field-level required validation in the JSF controls and instead using Web Flow's model-level validation.

column1: swf-booking-faces example app: login page shows login link; layout depends on currentUser.name
column42:
The login page shows a login link - not very nice. Using that link can mess up the "flow"

I wonder especially about a good solution to this:
- Either have a separate layout for the login page - not very nice as most of the layout will probably be duplicated
- Or have a condition around that block not showing the login link within a login page - string condition on url? might be the simplest solution.

Another remark, something I missed within that example app: access-denied-page
so changing the required role to ROLE_SUPERVISOR will deny the users "jeremy" and "scott". So a inconvenient errror page is shown.
  I experimentally added a access-denied-page and changed the required role. So logging in as jeremy would get me that access denied page and than bring me back to /intro . BUT now I'm having a request.remoteUser=jeremy, but the page still shows me a login link instead of the expected "Welcome jeremy - logout". It seems to me, that currentUser.name used within the layout, to decide on whether to show a login link or the welcome msg and a logout link, is only defined within flows and not within simple pages like intro.xhtml . Using request.remoteUser within the layout solved me this one. I wonder if this is a correct fix?

column1: After JSF validation/conversion errors, state is not returned correctly
column42:
My page is showing both searchform and searchresults.

When a user inputs wrong data in the searchform, validation errors are shown correctly to the user (request 1). When he then corrects the error and resubmits, everything works fine (request 2). When he then chages any input field and submits, the search is done using the new values (request 3...n), but the page is rerendered with the values of request 2.

I was able to reproduce this on other pages (simple test pages, with 2 input fields) as well.

This issue might be related to issue 738.
column91: 14/Aug/08 12:33 AM;jeremyg484;Any chance you can attach the artifacts from your simple test pages?  It would greatly help in reproducing the issue.
column93: 09/Dec/08 5:23 AM;jeremyg484;Now ensuring the updated component state gets stored across the redirect for a recursive transition.

column1: Formatting service attribute not exposed in webflow:flow-builder-services
column42:
The documentation in the schema tells us "Registers custom implementations of services needed to build flow definitions. With this tag, you may 
 configure a custom ConversionService, FormatterFactory, ExpressionParser,"
 
but there is no FormatterFactory attribute.
column91:
14/Aug/08 12:34 AM;david@davidkarlsen.com;I see that the formatting stuff has been replaced with Converters: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=58172

The docs for the xsd should be updated accordingly.

column1: RichFaces a4j loadStyle doesn't get rendered
column42:
In my RichFaces application, I use the a4j:loadStyle tag, causing a <link> tag to be rendered for my stylesheet. After migrating my page to SWF 2.0, the link tag dissapears from the rendered HTML source.

After debugging I discovered that the org.ajax4jsf.application.AjaxViewHandler is responsible for rendering ViewResources (which are javascripts, stylesheets, etc.). However, this class is never invoked when serving an SWF page.
column91: 24/Aug/08 10:35 PM;mike;The problem was that the filter for ajax calls was not configured right. This issue can be closed, as it is a non-issue.

column92: 04/Aug/08 5:44 AM;kdonald;This is just a limit of windows file paths... they are limited to 255 characters... extracting from a directory much closer to the root of your filesystem should solve your problem. the only thing we can do here is better document this windows limitation.
column93:
12/Mar/12 2:20 PM;paulrivers;I wanted to say that I had the same problem. Here are my steps -

1. Downloaded .zip file to desktop, double clicked to open it, and tried to copy the folder out of the zip file. Partway through it gives me the error message:
"The system cannot find the file specified."

2. Moved the .zip file to the root of the d:\ drive, double clicked to open it, tried to copy it to the root of the d:\ drive - again, same "The system cannot find the file specified." message partway through copying it.

3. Downloaded WinZip. Opened it (from D:) with WinZip. Tried to extract the folder - messages similar to above about "unable to create a sensible filename" and the name of the default windows temp directory.

4. Finally got it to work when I changed WinZip settings to use a shorter path name for the temporary directory, and also unzipped it to D:.

5. Realized later that if I double click on it and open it with the "Extract all files" link on the left, that appears to work (using the default windows zip file thingy).

When I go to delete the file folder with the unzipped files from d:\, it says I can't put it in the recycle bin because some of the filenames are to long.

I wrote this partially so maybe the next person who had this problem would find a workaround.

But also - yeah, windows filename length restrictions suck. But a lot of us are stuck with that restriction. When the filenames are so long you can't even copy the files to the desktop - couldn't they be shortened? I mean do they really need to be as long as -
\projects\spring-webflow-samples\platform-spring-travel\org.springframework.samples.springtravel.hotel.search\src\main\java\org\springframework\samples\springtravel\hotel\search\impl

?

column1: on-exception transition does not work because ognl.MethodFailedException.getCause() returns null
column42:
When the original exception is thrown it is wraped with "ognl.MethodFailedException" and then with "ActionExecutionException". Then "TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler" tries to get the cause. In case of "ognl.MethodFailedException" should be used "getReason" method.

Also I found another trouble in "TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler.getTargetStateResolver". If some bad-styled "getCause" exception method will return "this", then we get stack overflow.

column1: FlowResourceFlowViewResolver.getViewInternal does not use the property
column42:
There is a property "defaultViewSuffix", but the method uses hard coded ".jsp" constant. So, if another suffix is used then the IllegalArgumentException is thrown in any case.

For example, we are using "jspx", so this view resolver does not work.
column91: 03/Aug/08 1:12 PM;kdonald;.jsp and .jspx internal views are supported in 2.0.3. Is the default support good enough for your needs?

column1: Typo in sentence in documentation
column42:
Section 11.4

"The faces:flow-builder-services tag also several other defaults appropriate for a JSF environment. "

I think there is a verb missing in the above sentence. Perhaps it should say something like:

"The faces:flow-builder-services tag also configures several other defaults appropriate for a JSF environment. "

column1: Transition back to the same view-state in the same request triggers a redirect
column42:
Currently transitioning to other states such as action-states to perfrom actions, then transitioning *back* to the original view-state triggers default redirect+after+post and snapshotting behavior.  In an ajax environment this leads to the server sending a redirect back to the same view, when generally a partial re-rendering of the same view is desired instead.  In non ajax environments, the redirect+after+post behavior s correct, however the additional snapshotting is not needed.

Handling for this case should be revised where:
- transitioning back to the originating view-state in the same request does NOT trigger a redirect response for an Ajax request.  Instead, the view should re-render in the same request: either the same view, or one or more fragments.
- transitioning back to the originating-view-state in the same request SHOULD result in a redirect+after+post for a non-ajax request.
- transitioning back to the originating view-state should NOT result in another flow execution key being assigned and a new snapshot being created. Rather, the current executing snapshot should simply be updated on pause.

column1: Spring Travel MVC Sample: Partial-refresh of messages div on booking form validation error causes erroneous Dojo Popup to appear with empty body in FF3
column42: Just noticed this today.  Seems to only happen in Firefox (I am using FF3).  Safari works fine. Also, the faces version works fine in Firefox.
column91: 14/Jul/08 5:18 AM;jeremyg484;The problem was two-fold.  First there were Javascript syntax errors in the bookingForm.jsp template.  Second, when the Javascript was being evaluated as part of the returned page from the Ajax request, control was passing to Spring.remoting.handleError and a popup was being displayed even though the server response itself was not an error.  Corrected the template, and also corrected Spring-Dojo.js to only display the error popup for actual error responses.

column1: Spring Security (PreAuthentication) setup fails with Spring webflow, works otherwise
column42:
I am using Spring 2.5, Spring Webflow 2.0.2 and Spring Security 2.0.1 versions
I think I have hit upon a bug involving preAuthentication+ spring Security+ Spring Webflow and its related to Spring Webflow since Spring Security+preAuthentication is working fine for non spring-webflow related pages.

I started with sample webapp from Spring web flow. Then added form-login based security using "tutorial" sample application from Spring Security.
It was all working fine. Then I changed my spring security setup to accommodate the requirement for preAuthentication (since we are using Tivoli Access Manager/Web Seal infrastructure for authentication and will continue to use Spring Security for authorization). After a lot of struggle, I have Spring Security working such that I can navigate from my unsecured home page to a secured (non SWF) page and I notice (from DEBUG log output) that Spring security filter chain is doing its job correctly.

But when I click on the other secured link on my home page that starts my (spring webflow based) web-flow, I get the error in the browser

Code:

Error 501: Method is not defined in RFC 2068 and is not supported by the Servlet API

Here's the exception trace, I get from Websphere 6.1.0.15 server -
Code:

[09/07/08 16:16:46:046 EDT] 00000027 WebApp        E   [Servlet Error]-[Spring MVC Dispatcher Servlet]: com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.webapp.WebAppErrorReport: Method  is not defined in RFC 2068 and is not supported by the Servlet API 
	at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.webapp.WebAppDispatcherContext.sendError(WebAppDispatcherContext.java:538)
	at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.srt.SRTServletResponse.sendError(SRTServletResponse.java:968)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponseWrapper.sendError(HttpServletResponseWrapper.java:152)
	at org.springframework.security.context.HttpSessionContextIntegrationFilter$OnRedirectUpdateSessionResponseWrapper.sendError(HttpSessionContextIntegrationFilter.java:498)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:788)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:856)
	at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.servlet.ServletWrapper.service(ServletWrapper.java:1068)
	at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.servlet.ServletWrapper.service(ServletWrapper.java:1009)
	at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.filter.WebAppFilterChain.doFilter(WebAppFilterChain.java:145)
	at org.springframework.security.util.FilterChainProxy$VirtualFilterChain.doFilter(FilterChainProxy.java:359)

So before , it was like
CASE-1:
Spring Security (form-login) + spring Webflow --> working fine for secured (both SWF and non-SWF) pages.

my securityContext.xml from CASE_1 is :
Code:

<global-method-security secured-annotations="enabled">
	</global-method-security>

	<http>
		<intercept-url pattern="/login.jsp*" filters="none" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/secure/extreme/**"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/secure/**"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/faces/policysearch*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/spring/*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
		<form-login login-page="/login.jsp" />
		<logout />
	</http>
<authentication-provider user-service-ref="userDetailsService">


			<user-service>
			<user name="super" password="super"
			authorities="ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
			<user name="scott" password="scott" authorities="ROLE_USER" />
			<user name="mark" password="mark" authorities="ROLE_USER"
			disabled="true" />
			<user name="base" password="base" authorities="ROLE_BASE" />
			</user-service>

	</authentication-provider>

CASE-2:
Now, after I changed my authentication setup from form-login to preauthentication --> only my non-SWF, secured pages can be visited.
And I get the above mentioned error when I try to visit the SWF controlled web pages.
my (current, non-working) securityContext.xml from CASE_2 is :
Code:

	<global-method-security secured-annotations="enabled">
	</global-method-security>

	<http
		entry-point-ref="preAuthenticatedProcessingFilterEntryPoint">
		<intercept-url pattern="/secure/extreme/*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/secure/*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/faces/policysearch*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
		<intercept-url pattern="/spring/*"
			access="ROLE_SUPERVISOR,ROLE_USER" />
	</http>


	<beans:bean id="preAuthenticatedProcessingFilterEntryPoint"

	<beans:bean id="preAuthenticatedProcessingFilter"

		<custom-filter position="PRE_AUTH_FILTER" />
		<beans:property name="principalRequestHeader" value="iv-user" />
		<beans:property name="credentialsRequestHeader"
			value="iv-password" />
		<beans:property name="authenticationManager"
			ref="authenticationManager" />
	</beans:bean>

	<authentication-manager alias="authenticationManager" />

	<beans:bean id="preauthAuthProvider"
		class="org.springframework.security.providers.preauth.PreAuthenticatedAuthenticationProvider">
		<custom-authentication-provider />
		<beans:property name="preAuthenticatedUserDetailsService">
			<beans:bean id="userDetailsServiceWrapper"
				class="org.springframework.security.userdetails.UserDetailsByNameServiceWrapper">
				<beans:property name="userDetailsService"
					ref="userDetailsService" />
			</beans:bean>
		</beans:property>
	</beans:bean>

	<beans:bean id="userDetailsService"
		class="org.springframework.security.userdetails.memory.InMemoryDaoImpl">
		<beans:property name="userProperties">
			<beans:bean
				class="org.springframework.beans.factory.config.PropertiesFactoryBean">
				<beans:property name="location"
					value="/WEB-INF/users.properties" />
			</beans:bean>
		</beans:property>
	</beans:bean>

I even turned on the DEBUG output for org.springframework.webflow, org.springframework.js, org.springframework.binding, org.springframework.faces packages but no additional output was spit out in the log file, I just got the same exception trace as mentioned above.

At this time, I would even appreciate any tips to further debug this situation as to how I could get more detailed errors from SWF or Spring security in this case,

column1: FlowResourceFlowViewResolver hardcoded to ".jsp"
column42:
FlowResourceFlowViewResolver has got ".jsp" hardcoded (line 83).

This is not a very nice move. JSP Documents (.jspx) would like to get a JstlView just as much as JSP Pages do.

column1: Sample JSF/SWF + Portlet does not function and does not use JSR-301 compliant bridge
column42:
The sample booking-portlet-faces application is not deployable in Pluto or in Liferay.  This integration was marked fixed here: http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-183 but it does not appear functional   

Shouldn't a JSR-301 compliant bridge be used instead of a proprietory bridge also?
column91:
15/Jul/08 6:02 AM;sandrews;The booking-portlet-faces sample application does not provided a JSR-301 bridge, although one is required.  This app has been tested against Pluto 1.1 with the JSR-301 RI.  The portlet bridge must be provided manually, as it is not final and is not available in our repository.

This is documented at http://static.springframework.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.0.x/reference/html/ch12s06.html#portlet-issues-jsf
column92:
15/Jul/08 6:29 AM;sandrews;Requested JSR-301 RI be added to the repository.
https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/BRITS-109

column1: null value setted to model if conversion imposible
column42:
By default in transition bind="true". In case of using FormAction my setters called 2 times:
1. Web flow automatic binding. That set null in collection field because can't convert values (collection values type is domain object).
2. FormAction set correct values.

BUT on next step Web Flow binding set same filed to null. It's should'nt did that.
Sample:
....
    <view-state id="choiseYMeasurement" view="choiseYMeasurement" model="reportSettings">
        <on-render>
            <evaluate expression="myAction.setupForm"/>
            <evaluate expression="measurementViewBuilder.getTreeOfMeasurements(reportSettings.multitudeYClass)"
                      result="viewScope.mainY"/>
        </on-render>
        <transition on="back" to="choiseFixture"/>
        <transition on="next" to="choiseXMeasurement" >

<!-- binding sets the null hear -->

            <evaluate expression="myAction.bindAndValidate"/>
        </transition>
        <transition on="cancel" to="cancel" bind="false"/>
    </view-state>

    <view-state id="choiseXMeasurement" view="choiseXMeasurement" model="reportSettings">
        <on-render>
            <evaluate expression="measurementViewBuilder.getTreeOfMeasurements(reportSettings.multitudeXClass)"
                      result="viewScope.mainX"/>
            <evaluate expression="reportSettings.getTypeMultitudeX()" result="viewScope.typeMultitudeX"/>
        </on-render>
        <transition on="back" to="choiseYMeasurement"/>

<!-- binding sets the null hear -->

        <transition on="next" to="bookingConfirmed"/>
        <transition on="cancel" to="cancel" bind="false"/>
    </view-state>
....

column1: Wildcard support for flow location of flows within registry (Related to http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-562)
column42:
If we use explicit location of 1 flow, it can resolve the flow, 
however in case we use the wild card mechanism (/WEB-INF/flows/**/*flow.xml) it fails to resolve it.

We came to the same conclusion for the 3 release versions of webflow (2.0.2, 2.0.1, 2.0.0)

We invoked the flow using this url http://localhost:8081/my-contextroot/spring/testflow

FYI some config files.

(webflow-config.xml)
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
       xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
       xmlns:webflow="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow-config"
       xmlns:faces="http://www.springframework.org/schema/faces"
       xsi:schemaLocation="
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.5.xsd
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow-config
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow-config/spring-webflow-config-2.0.xsd
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/faces
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/faces/spring-faces-2.0.xsd">	

	<!-- Launches new flow executions and resumes existing executions. -->
	<webflow:flow-executor id="flowExecutor" flow-registry="flowRegistry">
       	<webflow:flow-execution-attributes> 
            <webflow:always-redirect-on-pause value="true"/> 
        </webflow:flow-execution-attributes>
	</webflow:flow-executor>

	<!-- Creates the registry of flow definitions for this application -->
	<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" flow-builder-services="facesFlowBuilderServices">
<!--		<webflow:flow-location path="/WEB-INF/flows/testflow.xml" />-->
		<webflow:flow-location path="/WEB-INF/flows/**/*flow.xml" />
	</webflow:flow-registry>
	
	<!-- Configures the Spring Web Flow JSF integration -->
	<faces:flow-builder-services id="facesFlowBuilderServices"/>
</beans>

(webmvc-config.xml)
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
       xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
       xsi:schemaLocation="
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
           http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.5.xsd">

	<!-- Maps request URIs to controllers -->			
	<bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.handler.SimpleUrlHandlerMapping">
		<property name="mappings">
			<value>
				/testflow=flowController
			</value>
		</property>
		<property name="defaultHandler">
			<!-- Selects view names to render based on the request URI: e.g. /main selects "main" -->	
			<bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.UrlFilenameViewController" />
		</property>
	</bean>

	<!-- Handles requests mapped to the Spring Web Flow system -->
	<bean id="flowController" class="org.springframework.webflow.mvc.servlet.FlowController">
		<property name="flowExecutor" ref="flowExecutor"/>
	</bean>

	<!-- Maps logical view names to Facelet templates (e.g. 'search' to '/WEB-INF/search.xhtml' -->
	<bean id="faceletsViewResolver" class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.UrlBasedViewResolver">
		<property name="viewClass" value="org.springframework.faces.mvc.JsfView"/>
		<property name="prefix" value="/WEB-INF/flows/" />
		<property name="suffix" value=".jspx" />
	</bean>
		
</beans>


(web-application-config.xml)
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"

	<!-- Scans for application @Components to deploy -->

	<!-- Imports the configurations of the different infrastructure systems of the application -->
	<import resource="webmvc-config.xml" />
	<import resource="webflow-config.xml" />

</beans>

	</servlet>
	
	
	<servlet-mapping>

	<servlet-mapping>

	<!--

	-->

	-->
<!--	<servlet-mapping>-->

<!--	</servlet-mapping>-->
	

	<welcome-file-list>

	</welcome-file-list>

</web-app>

column1: Spring Faces creates XHTML-incompatible JavaScript scripts
column42:
Spring Faces creates JavaScript-blocks that are not compatible with XHTMl standards and cause validation errors:

For example the following JSF taglet:

<sf:commandLink styleClass="cmd" id="showDetailData" value="#{d.firstName} #{d.lastName}" action="select"/>

creates (among other things) the following JavaScript block:

<script>Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.CommandLinkDecoration({elementId : 'users:data:24:showDetailData', linkHtml : users_data_24_showDetailData_link}));</script>

This is wrong for several reasons: (a) No type for the script is defined (required by XHTML), (b) The content of the script block is not correctly uncommented in browsers not supporting JavaScript.

The correct block looks like this (type added and correct commenting for all types and versions of browsers added):

<script type="text/javascript"><!--//--><![CDATA[//><!--
Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.CommandLinkDecoration({elementId : 'users:data:1:showDetailData', linkHtml : users_data_1_showDetailData_link}));
//--><!]]> </script>

Much more verbose but according to our knowledge the only correct way to do it (we will propose a much less verbose style more up to date with current state of the art JavaScript programming later on once we get through the current bugs ;-).

Since we right now are busy with a project for the German public sector, this poses a critical problem for us, since XHTML conformance is required by binding software architecture agreements specified by the German government (SAGA 4.x). Without this conformance it will not be possible to have the system approved by the German government.

column91:
28/Jul/08 9:15 PM;klamborn;Not sure if you are aware of the following attribute on a weblogic server:

Archived Real Path Enabled - Global property to determine the behavior of getRealPath() for archived web applications. When this property set to "true", getRealPath() will return the canonical path of the resource files.

By setting this property on the server and restarting the server, the error above will no longer occur.

column1: Application errors are hidden when they occur during an Ajax request
column42: Currently if an uncaught exception occurs during an Ajax request, the Spring.remoting.handleError method simply logs the status code to the console.  This is especially confusing at development time as the developer will not see the full stack trace as they would on a normal request.
column91: 02/Jul/08 6:35 AM;jeremyg484;By default, Spring.remoting.handleError will now display the full error page in a Dojo popup.  This can be turned off by setting Spring.debug=false in a script block.

column1: ResourceServlet returns wrong 404 page
column42: The ResourceServlet returns the server default error page even when custom 404 page defined.
column91: 02/Jul/08 12:49 AM;sandrews;Switched response.setStatus to response.sendError

column1: Transition on-exception not handled with ognl
column42:
Transition on-exception is not handled when using Ognl as Expression Language .
When ognl.MethodFailedException is thrown, the cause of the exception is returned by method "getReason()" (instead of "getCause()"); therefore the method "TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler. getTargetStateResolver(..)" should check also "ognl.MethodFailedException.getReason()", in order to catch the exception.
column91: 30/Jun/08 8:13 PM;chrysimo;A possible fix
column92: 31/Oct/08 10:36 AM;sandrews;EvaluationException is thrown when an exception occurs from an OGNL expression.  The EvaluationException will now wrap the 'reason' for the exception instead of the exception itself.

column1: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.springframework.orm.jpa.SharedEntityManagerCreator
column91: 18/Sep/08 1:53 AM;jeremyg484;You should not be trying to serialize a repository or service.  They should be marked transient in your managed bean.  In order for the transient dependencies to be properly restored in the PipelinePage bean, you can instead define it as a flow variable using the <var> tag in your flow definition and use @Autowire.

However, when we take a look at the booking-faces example, all layers are serializable. :-(

I'm not sure what's the best attitude that you SWF-guys would suggest, but even taken a look at the appfuse generated code (swf, primefaces) no transient modifier is used. What's the current best approach according to you guys?

The problem seems to be connected with the Quipukit-DataTable component in the view and the way how an execution-snapshot is serialized. I have tested different versions of the Quipukit component library (1.5, 1.4.3) with SWF 2.0.2 on Tomcat 5.5.26 (Sun JDK 1.5) and IBM WebSphere 6.1 always getting the same NPE. The sample application includes Quipukit 1.5, SWF 2.0.2, Spring 2.5.4 for Tomcat.

If you replace the SWF 2.0.2 libraries with version 2.0.1 everything works correctly and the NPE does not occur. Thus I suppose there no problem with the Quipukit component library and the bug was introduced with a change in the snapshot (de)serialization from SWF 2.0.1 to 2.0.2.
column43: Tomcat 5.5.26 on Sun JDK 1.5, Quipukit 1.5 or 1.4.3, JSF 1.2, Facelets, Spring 2.5.4
column91: 13/Aug/08 9:54 PM;werlitz;I don't know what was changed internally but version 2.0.3 seems to fix this issue.

column1: Conversion services not used during binding when integrating with Spring MVC
column42:
Conversion services are not called during binding when using MvcViewFactoryCreator to integrate with Spring MVC. I'm not sure if this is a bug, or it is deliberate behaviour that might need better documentation somewhere.


For example, with the following configuration:

	<webflow:flow-builder-services id="flowBuilderServices"
		view-factory-creator="mvcViewFactoryCreator"
		conversion-service="conversionService" />
	<bean id="conversionService" class="example.example.CustomConversionService"></bean>		
	<bean id="mvcViewFactoryCreator" class="org.springframework.webflow.mvc.builder.MvcViewFactoryCreator">
		<property name="viewResolvers" ref="tilesViewResolver"/>
	</bean>
	<bean id="tilesViewResolver" class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.UrlBasedViewResolver">
		<property name="viewClass" value="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.tiles2.TilesView"/>
	</bean>


I would have expected that my conversion service in bean conversionService is used when binding, but it is not. And there actually seem to be two reasons why the conversion service is not used. 

One reason is that AbstractMvcView.bind() creates a new DefaultMapper instance to do the mapping, but does not call setConversionService() on the DefaultMapper instance. This means that DefaultMapper.conversionService will always be null; it does not have access to a conversion service.

However even if DefaultMapper did have a conversion service available to it, I am not convinced that the individual mappings (DefaultMapping objects) would use the conversion service. When DefaultMapping.map() is called, it first checks whether DefaultMapping.typeConverter is null -- if null it uses the conversion service, if not null it uses typeConverter. As far as I can tell typeConverter will never be null though, and if so the conversion service will never be used. DefaultMapping.typeConverter is set by AbstractMvcView.addDefaultMapping() for every mapping, and the value it sets it to is a FormatterBackedMappingConversionExecutor instance backed by a DefaultFormatterRegistry instance that seems to created, well, by default.

It could that that the intention is that we use formatters instead of conversion services. If so, that should be documented.
column91:
06/Aug/08 6:15 PM;palich;I've had the same problem with Spring Web Flow 2.0.3 with a very similar configuration. The effect is that the conversion service is only used for rendering a view, but not for binding afterwards.

My first approach was to use the property "useSpringBeanBinding" of the bean "mvcViewFactoryCreator" (new in 2.0.3). This was good for conversion, but then more complex expressions didn't work (e.g. for array access). This is due to the fact that Spring's own DataBinder is used then.

The solution is to not use the "useSpringBeanBinding" property, but define your own "expressionParser" as a bean and set the property "conversionService" to the same ConversionService used in the "flowBuilderServices" bean. Here comes the relevant part of the webflow-config.xml:

<webflow:flow-builder-services id="flowBuilderServices"
	view-factory-creator="mvcViewFactoryCreator" 
	conversion-service="conversionService"
	expression-parser="expressionParser" />
								   
<bean id="expressionParser" class="org.springframework.webflow.expression.WebFlowOgnlExpressionParser">
	<property name="conversionService" ref="conversionService" />
</bean>

		<property name="productDescriptionDao" ref="productDescriptionDao"/>
	</bean>

My facelets page has a reference to bean 'pipeline' that refers a manager which refers a DAO that refers a Hibernate SessionFactory.
First rebndering of the page goes ok. But when I resubmit the page the reference to the sessionFactory gets lost (this.getHibernateTemplate == null) on the level of the DAO.
What is wrong here? What did I misconfigure ?

Thanks in advance !
.
column92:
07/Aug/08 6:25 AM;tom_soete;The flow scope variables get serialized (in order to support 'Web
Continuations').

In your case, the flow scope variables contain your Manager objects,
which contain your Dao objects, which contain a HibernateTemplate,
which contains the SessionFactory.

Before displaying the page for the first time, the flow scope (and for
completeness: also the flash scope) variables get serialized and saved
in the FlowExecutionRepository.
At that moment, your sessionFactory is lost, because the state is not
serialized (it's transient, see SessionFactoryImpl.java ...).



Try to put the variables in the Conversation scope, and you won't have
this problem, as the conversation scope variables are not serialized
between requests.
HOWEVER, this is not the solution to your problem!

You should rethink about the role of SWF in the context of your
application. It plays the role of 'Application Controller'
(http://martinfowler.com/eaaCatalog/applicationController.html).


Put the calls to your Manager objects in the flows:

<view-state id="pipeline">
<transition on="editPipeline" to="editPipeline">
  <evaluate expression="productLineManager.saveOrUpdate(pipeline)"></evaluate>
</transition>
<transition on="exit" to="finish" />
</view-state>

...so your "pipeline" flow variable does not have to refer to the
productLineManager anymore.

I recommend you to have a look at the "booking-faces" sample in the
SWF distribution.

(This will probably solve your issue [SWF-775] as well)

column1: java.lang.IllegalStateException: No Scope registered for scope 'flow'
column42:
Hello,

I try to replace the standard JSF managed beans with oridinary Spring beans with scope 'flow'. Whenever I try to access such as bean, eg 'bbMenu':

<rich:menuItem value="Pipeline" submitMode="server" action="#{bbMenu.doPipeline}">

with bbMenu defined in my Spring config as

<bean id="bbMenu" class="com.mazda.poc.bb.Menu" scope="flow" />

I get the runtime error "No Scope registered for scope flow"

What am I missing or doing wrong. I attached web.xml and important Spring config files.

Kind regards
column91: 29/Jun/08 5:22 PM;cbonami;Definitions related to Spring Web Flow
column92: 29/Jun/08 5:23 PM;cbonami;The main flow file containing all flows in my app
column93:
29/Jun/08 7:54 PM;cbonami;I solved this by adding


<bean id="scopeRegistrar" class="org.springframework.webflow.scope.ScopeRegistrar" />

to my spring-config

column1: sf:commandLink fails on IE 6 when javascript disabled
column42:
When using the sf:commandLink component with javascript disabled the renderer falls back to the ProgressiveCommandButtonRenderer.  This renders <button> elements.

Unfortunately due to a feature of IE 6 button elements are all submitted, regardless of the button that was actually clicked.  (see http://www.kopz.org/public/documents/css/multiple_buttons_ie_workaround.html).  The means that if two links are on the page the action fired might be incorrect.

Could the ProgressiveCommandButtonRenderer be changed to render <input type="submit"> elements instead?
column91: 27/Jun/08 5:54 AM;philw;Attached Patch

column1: bind="false" on a global transition doesn't seem to have any effect
column42:
Despite bind="false" on a global "cancel" transition, the flow remains in the same view. When the transition is moved to the view state the cancel takes place.

This is an excerpt from the flow:

	<view-state id="edit" model="account">
		<transition on="next" to="beneficiaries"/>
	</view-state>

	<global-transitions>
		<transition on="cancel" to="endCancel" bind="false"/>
	</global-transitions>

This is used in conjunction with a facelets view.
column91: 24/Jul/08 4:05 PM;alaisi;This bug also affects jsp views. We currently can not use almost any global transitions due to this problem.

column1: spring-js uses java 1.5 method calls
column42:
The ResourceServlet uses Java 1.5 Method calls.

when running in Tomcat 5.5.26 with compat package and JDK 1.4,
i'll get: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: java.lang.String.contains(Ljava/lang/CharSequence;)Z

133:		if (gzipEnabled && StringUtils.hasText(acceptEncoding) && acceptEncoding.contains("gzip")
134:				&& compressedMimeTypes.contains(mimeType)) {

this stands against the release notes:
Web Flow 2 requires Java 1.4 or greater and runs on all major Java EE platforms including Tomcat, Jetty, Websphere, WebLogic, and JBoss.

column93:
13/Oct/08 8:41 AM;sandrews;An IllegalStateException will now be thrown when a redirect is requested for a RenderRequest/RenderResponse.

Improved the documentation regarding the issue and a work around for a redirect on end-state.  The work around is to override FlowHandler.handleExecutionOutcome this hook provides access to the RenderReponse object after the flow execution has ended.

This issue may be readdressed in the Web Flow 3.0 timeframe.

column1: ViewFactory beans cannot be plugged into views
column42:
The XSD for the webflow view-state, view attribute states:

"For exotic usages, you may plug in a custom ViewFactory bean you define: ${myCustomViewFactory}"

However, this does not seem to be supported.  The FlowModelFlowBuilder createViewFactory method does not check if the expression itself implements ViewFactory.

column1: Spring Webflow 2.0.2 decorator's uppercase attribute is not working
column42:
The uppercase attribute of sf:clientTextValidator is not working as documented.

e.g.

<sf:clientTextValidator uppercase="true">
<h:inputText id="middleInitial" value="#{users.contacts.middleInitial}" required="false" title="Middle Initial" />
</sf:clientTextValidator>

When the page gets rendered, the uppercase property is not copied into the created Dojo widget

Affected version: Spring web flow 2.0.2 RELEASE

column1: FacesMessage.SEVERITY_FATAL does not propagate through FlowFacesContext
FacesMessage.detail does not propagate through FlowFacesContext
column42:
Hello !

FacesMessage consists of summary and detail part of message. In FlowFacesContext.addMessage(String clientId, FacesMessage message), the detail value of FacesMessage is not read and saved to RequestContext.messageContext thus its value is thrown away.

One result of this is that validation messages are not displayed correctly when <h:messages showDetail="true"/> is on. Actually, detail holds and shows the value of summary (probably as a result of fallback somewhere in SWF). 

As a matter of fact, many jsf built-in validation and conversion error messages specify detail part of message and those could never be displayed as well.

This issue can be simulated on booking-faces, when <h:messages errorClass="errors" showDetail="true" showSummary="true" /> is used and invalid date is given as input to 'Check In Date' assuming that javascript is switched off in browser preferences to disable javascript validations (in IE it can be done on Security tab of Internet Options, attribute 'Active scripting'). I provide a diff with changes for quick simulation.

I think this is quite serious issue, because it blocks JSF feature that is quite common even in built-in jsf components.

Michal

Off topic: I think that integration of SWF with JSF as well as SWF itself is perfectly done in very clean and concise way. It was a pleasure to traverse through the sources. It shows that you took your time on SWF design. Good job, really!
column91:
15/Jun/08 8:23 PM;durdina;Diff for simulating the issue. 

Messages.properties from jsf is also included as a reference to actual message that should be displayed - see keys ending with _detail.

column1: Using the browser back button displays wrong data, if validation errors occurs
column42:
The steps to reproduce that:

1) Enter invalid data in view fields- > submit - > error messages are displayed, stay on the same view
2) Enter valid data view fields -> submit -> go to next view
3) Use the browser back button (the invalid data and error messages are displayed instead of the valid data)
    (using the back button on the view to go to the last state, shows the correct valid data)

flow definition snippet:

<view-state id="enterContractData" model="contract">
        <transition on="next" to="enterBankData" />
</view-state>
    
<view-state id="enterBankData" model="contract">
       <transition on="back" to="enterContractData" bind="false"/>
       <transition on="next" to="confirmData" />
</view-state>

column1: Can't place scoped-proxied beans into flow scope
column42:
If I create a bean in session scope, and try to assign it to a flow scope var, I get an error, because not all beans in flow scope are serializables. Problem is not only within session scope, as it happens the same with a custom scope. Seems more a problem dealing with CGLIB proxies.

Defined in AppContex.xml

	<bean id="sesionperson" class="org.springframework.webflow.samples.phonebook.Person" scope="session"
		p:firstName="Peter" p:lastName="Smith">
		<aop:scoped-proxy proxy-target-class="true"/>
	</bean>	

Defined in myFlow.xml

	<var name="flowperson" class="org.springframework.webflow.samples.phonebook.Person"/>
	<view-state id="inicio" model="idContainer">
		<on-render>
			<evaluate expression="sesionperson" result="flowperson" />
		</on-render>
	</view-state>

The bean implements Serializable

public class Person implements Serializable {
	....
}

The problem solves if I eliminate <aop:scoped-proxy proxy-target-class="true"/> from the bean definition. I suppose that the proxied bean does not implement Serializable.

THIS WORKS:

	<bean id="sesionperson" class="org.springframework.webflow.samples.phonebook.Person" scope="session"
		p:firstName="Peter" p:lastName="Smith">
	</bean>	

And the StackTrace

1. Add Spring bean:
<bean id="sessionBooking" class="org.springframework.webflow.samples.booking.Booking" scope="session">

3. Add set action in on-start:

4. Print the following in the JSP (prints "111"):
<spring:bind path="booking.hotel.price">${status.value}</spring:bind>

column1: FlowPhaseListener should save away JSF view state before issuing a flow execution redirect
column42: Currently, FlowPhaseListener will simpley do a requestDispatcher.sendRedirect() when a flow execution redirect is required, followed by a JSF responseComplete(). As a result the JSF view state is not saved before issuing the redirect and it is lost (i.e. no available on the subsequent GET request).
column91: 13/Jun/08 11:01 PM;klr8;Implemented.

column1: Enhance FlowPhaseListener to have it maintain FacesMessages accross client side redirects
column42: FacesMessages are stored inside the FacesContext which is tied to a request/thread. As a result, they are lost when using POST-REDIRECT-GET (alwaysRedirectOnPause). The FlowPhaseListener should be enhanced to temporarily store them away in flash scope.
column91: 13/Jun/08 10:59 PM;klr8;FlowPhaseListener now maintains FacesMessages accross a flow execution redirect by temporarily storing them in flash scope (SWF-745)

column92: 27/Jun/08 1:02 AM;jeremyg484;I would expect that you would have gotten a serialization error in the server logs?  Is this not the case?  Anything stored in the various extended scopes provided by Web Flow needs to be Serializable when using the default snapshot repository.  We will make sure this is clear in the docs.

column1: PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer within bean file imported into flow xml using 'bean-import' does not recognize classpath:
column42:
using     

<bean-import resource="my-flow-beans.xml"/>

within flow definition where my-flow-beans.xml contains 

    <bean class="org.springframework.beans.factory.config.PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer">
        <property name="placeholderPrefix" value="!{"/>
        <property name="location" value="classpath:my.properties"/>
    </bean>

results in resource not found exception '/WEB-INF/classes/classpath:my.properties'. Looks like the resource locator is not handling the classpath: syntax.
column91: 12/Jun/08 2:04 AM;jonnio;A workaround is to define the propertyplaceholderconfigurer somewhere else but that wouldn't be 'correct' for testing, etc.

column1: Form binding with numeric 'name' fails and causes binding error
column42:
I have found that when a form input value's name attribute is strictly numeric (doesn't start with a character), the binding fails. Normally, if an attribute is not found on the binding target, this is ignored. In this case, however, it causes the binding mechanism to fail.

I believe this type of binding error should be ignored.

column92:
11/Jun/08 6:59 PM;eric.feraud;Okey, I found the problem.

on-render I evaluate an expression, an place it in a requestScope.
I changed requestScope by viewScope and now it works fine.

column1: LabeledEnum Unusabled in Java 5+
column42: LabeledEnum is unusabled in Java 1.5+ because it extends Comparable without a null generic type. In Java 5 enums automatically implement Comparable of their own type thus causing it to be impossible to implement LabeledEnum. This is really fine with me but I think a Java 1.5+ version of this concept should exist as it seems silly to have to implement my own enum interface and conversion service for this type of functionality.
column43: Java 1.6, Windows XP SP3, Spring 2.5.4, Spring WebFlow 2.0.1

column92: 06/Jun/08 4:59 AM;joes.checkernet.com;I mean that I think having a Comparable enum for pre-Java 1.5 is great, however, I think you could easily support Java 1.5+ as well right out of the box. I'll attach what I did for my project.

column1: AbstractMvcView ignores ConversionService
column43: Java 1.6, Windows XP SP3, Spring 2.5.4, Spring WebFlow 2.0.1
column91:
05/Jun/08 7:05 AM;kdonald;Joe,

Yes, Formatters are specific object for formatting strings for display in a UI.  Converters are more generic, capable of converting from any type to any other type.  The systems are separate, but you can bridge between them (a Formatter can be used as a Converter, for example).  We need to make this easier to do in a future release.
column92: 06/Jun/08 5:05 AM;joes.checkernet.com;Here is an example of what I want to do, but it appears that the MVC implementation completely ignores my injected ConversionService
column93: 06/Jun/08 5:05 AM;joes.checkernet.com;I attached other files to a similar issue: http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-730
column94:
06/Jun/08 5:12 AM;joes.checkernet.com;My configuration looks something like:

...
<flow:flow-builder-services id="flowBuilderServices"
                                view-factory-creator="mvcViewFactoryCreator"
                                conversion-service="conversionService"
                                formatter-registry="formatterRegistry"
            />

    <bean id="formatterRegistry" class="com.mycompany.MyFormatterRegistry" />
    <bean id="conversionService" class="com.mycompany.MyConversionService" />
...

Perhaps AbstractMvcView is not where the ConversionService needs to be injected but it appears that when binding a form my ConversionService is never used.

example flow snippet:
...
    <view-state id="shippingMethod" view="checkout-shippingmethod" model="checkoutShippingMethodForm">
        <on-render>
            <evaluate expression="checkoutShippingMethodFormAction.getShippingPriceQuotes()" result="viewScope.shippingPriceQuotes" />
        </on-render>
        <transition on="back" to="addresses" bind="false" />
        <transition on="submit" to="reviewOrder" bind="true" />
    </view-state>
...
column95:
06/Jun/08 5:34 AM;kdonald;Joe,

I would recommend making your EnumFormatter public and then having a TextToEnum Converter that uses it under the covers. You have to register it twice, but at least you're not duplicating more than the registration code.

We should look in the future at auto-registering all formatters with the conversion service as well, for string->object conversions.  The thought; however, was that the two systems, while similiar, address slightly different concerns.  The Conversion system is more generic, while the Formatter system clearly focuses on data input formatting.

Can you elaborate on why you prefer the Conversion system to the Formatter system?  These two systems will be merging back into the core spring framework at some point, so we want to make sure we do everything to get them as solid as possible before then.
column96: 06/Jun/08 6:10 AM;joes.checkernet.com;The reason that I prefer the ConversionService in this case is that I can register all of my enums once via addConverter(new TextToEnum()); because I have the ability to know the targetClass during conversion. Am I doing something wrong or am I right that the ConversionService is completely ignored during binding? From my testing I haven't been able to invoke my conversion service and I believe I'm configuring it correctly.  Also strange, using Spring MVC and also in Spring WebFlow 1.x I believe that enums were bound using the name automatically.
column97: 06/Jun/08 6:52 AM;kdonald;You're not doing anything wrong.  The ConversionService used by Web Flow to internally convert from one type to another is not used for data binding of user form input.  The Formatter system cares for this concern in a more specific manner.  I see what you are saying--you want the ability to register a generic Enum converter/formatter and have it be applied for any Enum type.  It is true this is not easily possible with the Formatter system because the target type is lost.  We will consider this carefully.

column1: Unable to access FacesContext.getCurrentInstance() from transition expression
column42:
I have a transition event for a flow that triggers a method:

<view-state id="test">
		<transition on="someevent" to="someview">
			<evaluate expression="flowScope.someObject.someMethod()"/>
		</transition>
</view-state>


Within this method I am attempting to access the FacesContext object using FacesContext.getCurrentInstance().  Unfortunately this is returning null.

I have had a look to see if this is possible to fix but it does not seem easy.  The root cause seems to be that ViewState.resume calls the event directly and does not offer any easy hook points to create the faces context.

The viewFactory.getView, and view.processUserEvent() methods both create and release the faces context.  The event processing, however, is handled by context.handleEvent and there seems to be no way to allow the view or view factory to wrap this so that it creates and releases the faces context.

The only way that I can think to fix this is either:

* Change the view.getFlowEvent() method such that a corresponding view.releaseFlowEvent() method must be called.  Then in the JSF implementation create and release the flow context

* Change the context.handleEvent(event) to a view.handleEvent(context,event) method or a viewFactory.handleEvent(context,event).

My preference would be to add a handleEvent method to ViewFactory although I have not attempted this as the changes would affect some core webflow classes and does not seem particularly clean.  The problem might also occur on doEnter.


The only other suggestion as a hacky way to get around this is to surface a public method on org.springframework.faces.webflow.JsfView that allows a faces context to be created.  This way I could create a transition that uses the currentEvent object to get at the source, cast that to a JsfView and use that to create the context.

Any help would be appreciated.

So on my back transition I execute a flowScope.stateHolder.save() method.  It is this save method that needs access to the FacesContext to get to the viewRoot and to get the client ID of each component.

This system allows the user to fill out a form that will not pass validation and still go back without loosing values.

This might not be the best way to do this but I am trying to migrate a webflow 1 application so I have a lot of legacy code.  Previously I could get to FacesContext on my transition methods.

Any alternative suggestions?

column1: Component bindings not executed for components in Facets
column42: The JsfViewFactory processComponentBinding method does not iterate over facets when recursing.  This means that any components within a facet will not be rebound.

column1: Multiple checkboxes to Collection mapping
column42:
Using Spring's <form:checkboxes> tag to present multiple checkboxes for the user to choose values of a collection attribute of the model (e.g. Set<T>) WebFlow only offers the first selected value for mapping, and requests it to be mapped as a collection (Set, List, etc). The subsequent values are discarded silently.
Expected behavior would be convert every individual value to type T and set the attribute as the collection (e.g. Set<T>)
Spring MVC works this way.

Reference: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?p=183366
column91:
09/Jun/08 12:01 AM;kdonald;Related to several other issues reported on the forum:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=55478
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=55511
column92: 09/Jun/08 12:04 AM;kdonald;This is the highest priority issue open at the moment.
column93:
09/Jul/08 10:23 PM;kdonald;This issue should be resolved now for Spring 2.0.3.  Can you watching this issue try out a nightly build and confirm it is resolved for your environment? Nightly builds are available here: http://static.springframework.org/downloads/nightly/snapshot-download.php?project=SWF

A few things to note:
- The "format" and "convert" type-conversion systems have been unified under the "convert" api.
- The Converter API has changed a bit in this unification process.  See the example converters in the .converters package for an example.
- Ognl and Unified EL-based expression parsers should now have all the binding features of Spring MVC EXCEPT the ability to perform type conversion on elements of generic collections.  If you need this feature, you need to explicitly configure an MvcViewFactoryCreator instance in your webflow-config and set the "useSpringBeanBinding" flag to true.  That will configure an ExpressionParser backed by a BeanWrapper (the same system used by Spring MVC) for view->model binding (OGNL or Unified ELwould be used everywhere else, since BeanWrapper only supports property binding and is not a full-blown EL system).

Thanks for your patience on this issue.  Looking forward to your feedback.
column94:
10/Jul/08 2:42 AM;foolman;Hello,

It might be that I'm not doing something right, however it seems now that custom converters are not propagated to the EL parser. Therefore I can not test easily if the problem is resolved.
I've did the following: created some converters between string and my custom classes. Subclassed DefaultConversionService to include my converters too. Then I defined a bean with my subclass, and set up this bean as conversion-service in the flow-builder-services. 
When it comes to binding i get an exception:
org.springframework.binding.convert.ConversionExecutorNotFoundException: No ConversionExecutor found for converting from sourceClass 'java.lang.String' to target class 'hu.intellicom.tehflow.data.Ugyfel'

Debugging shows that my class is consulted during flow construction, however while binding the ELExpression class uses the GenericConversionService which definitely can not execute this conversion.
Is it that I am doing something wrong?
column95:
12/Jul/08 3:46 PM;kdonald;Gabor,

You will need to configure a WebflowElExpressionParser instance in your Spring application context with your custom ConversionService, then wire that instance into the flow system by using the expression-parser attribute of the flow-registry element.  Please let us know if this resolves your problem.

Yes, the default EL-based ExpressionParser uses a DefaultConversionService instance.
column96:
14/Jul/08 2:19 AM;foolman;Hello,
I've created a small sample application, and found the following:
For multiple checkboxes as representation of a List<T>, the webflow does not call the converter for the list elements, instead it calls the setter with List<String>, no matter what <T> is. (And java let's the setter being called with this even when T != String :( which is a serious problem with type-safety.)
This causes serious problems when used in connection with hibernate, as automatic setters throw exceptions for incorrect type.
column97:
14/Jul/08 2:30 AM;kdonald;Gabor,

Yes, but please see my original comment about how you can get type conversion of generic collection elements.  Only Spring's BeanWrapper supports this currently--OGNL and the JBoss EL do not.

Thanks, it turned out the first snapshot I've got (534) didn't contained the mentioned option yet. Upon upgrading to 540 I think I've hit this one: http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SWF-773 as I get EvaluationException on every non-standard Java type argument. 
At the current moment I can not think any workaround to set a conversion between String and <T> where <T> is of an user defined class. (I've set up a custom conversion service to the flow-builder-services, and even defined a WebBindingInitializer to see if it helps.)
column101: 15/Jul/08 4:40 AM;kdonald;Configuring a custom conversion-service that registers your custom Converters should do the trick.  This ConversionService should be hooked into the BeanWrapperExpressionParser that gets configured when the "useSpringBeanBinding" flag is turned on.  Can you turn on your Java debugger and confirm this? Line 147 of MvcViewFactoryCreator would be a good place to set a breakpoint.
column102:
15/Jul/08 5:50 AM;foolman;Unfortunately that's not the case. It's an instance of GenericConversionService.
If I'm right it is because FlowModelBuilderContextImpl's createConversionService method explicitly creates an instance and sets it up as the conversionService, and it get's propagated to FlowModelBuilder's local contest which propagates it to the ViewFactoryCreator.
By the current setup there is no chance of overriding this behaviour, i think.
column103:
15/Jul/08 8:42 AM;kdonald;Gabor,

It is a GenericConversionService, however, if you look at that object's "parent" property, and continue navigating in your debugger to the this$0->flowBuilderServices->conversionService property, you should see your custom service implementation.  This implementation is configured as the root parent ConversionService, and all converters registered there should still apply.  It just happens that Web Flow itself installs some specific converters of its own when setting up the flow builder system.  I would check and make sure your ConversionService and custom Converters are setup and registered/implemented properly.  You might also want to post that EvaluationException stack trace so we can get some more information. As far as I can tell, there isn't a problem in the code.
column104:
15/Jul/08 8:54 AM;kdonald;Well, the minute I suggest it isn't a problem with our code...

The GenericConversionService.getConversionExecutors(Class sourceClass) method is not considering converters registered in its parent--this is why those from String converters are never getting registered with the BeanWrapper as PropertyEditors.  This is definitely a bug.

We'll fix this shortly.
column105:
17/Jul/08 7:14 AM;kdonald;Gabor,

This should be fixed in SVN now -- Sourceforge was offline yesterday so that's why there has been a delay. Can you try out the latest code?
column106:

Yes, in the SVN version the conversion works fine, thanks for the fix. However I've noticed that transitions have bind="false" as default. This is going to be the new behaviour? 
 It can be defined as a best practice to explicitly specify in the definition whether to bind or not, although right now it means some definition revising for me :).

column1: Faces does not set components to valid on restore
column42:
I believe that during the restore stage of a JSF lifecycle all UIInput components should be set back to a valid state.  Looking at MyFaces 1.1.5 the org.apache.myfaces.lifecycle.RestoreViewExecutor class seems to do this using RestoreStateUtils.recursivelyHandleComponentReferencesAndSetValid.

I have a JSF component to highlight validation failures with a CSS style, this component uses the isValid() component method and now show failures even when a user has corrected them when.  This shows up when they navigate back to a screen.
column91: 29/May/08 1:44 AM;philw;Attached is a patch
column92: 29/May/08 10:49 PM;philw;Updated patch to include fix for SWF-723
column93: 05/Jun/08 3:04 AM;jeremyg484;Interesting.  I don't see any evidence of the RI doing this, and there is no mention in the spec of the state facilities needing to explicitly reset this flag.  It seems to me that as this is a part of a component's internal state, it should be up to the component as to whether the flag is reset or not.  Unfortunately, it looks like the base UIInput implementations just save and restore the state without any sort of reset.  Seems like a reasonable thing to do, and I can't see how doing it would have any adverse effect, so I'm willing to go with it.

column1: <sf:ajaxEvent> for <h:selectOneRadio> worked in RC1 but stopped working in 2.0.1
column42:
I have defined the following in my JSF page:
HTML Code:

            <sf:ajaxEvent id="changeDriverAjax" action="changeDriver" event="onchange">
              <h:selectOneRadio id="Driver_currentRowIndex" 
                                value="#{driverDataModel.rowIndex}">
                <f:selectItems value="#{drivers}"/>
              </h:selectOneRadio>
            </sf:ajaxEvent>

The radio's value is the index of the Data Model, i.e. 0, 1, 2 etc.
This used to work in RC1 but stopped working in 2.0.1. 

I tried to debug, and this is the difference that I found:

RC1:
Spring.advisors.push(new Spring.RemoteEventAdvisor({event:'onchange', targetId: 'mainForm:Driver_currentRowIndex', sourceId : 'mainForm:changeDriverAjax', formId : 'mainForm', processIds : 'mainForm:changeDriverAjax'}));

2.0.1:
Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.AjaxEventDecoration({event:'onchange', elementId: 'mainForm:Driver_currentRowIndex', formId : 'mainForm', params: {processIds : 'mainForm:changeDriverAjax', ajaxSource : 'mainForm:changeDriverAjax'} }));

If sourceId is empty, the underlying remoting handler that calls Dojo uses elementId. This is where the code path between RC1 and 2.0.1 starts to differ. In RC1, dojo.byId() tries to look for the <sf:ajaxEvent> (which doesn't exist in the DOM), whereas in 2.0.1, it tries to look for 'main: Driver_currentRowIndex' (which in the DOM is a <table> hosting the radio buttons).

Because of this difference, when I inspect the HTTP Post in Firebug, the value submitted for the radio button is:

RC1:
mainForm:Driver_currentRowIndex	0

2.0.1:
mainForm:Driver_currentRowIndex	mainForm:Driver_currentRowIndex

The second one eventually fails when the radio button tries to update my Data Model index.
column91: 04/Jun/08 7:23 AM;jeremyg484;Modified AjaxEventInterceptorRenderer to render the AjaxEvent component's id as the sourceId so that decoration of radio buttons and select boxes still results in their values being properly submitted with the form.

column1: booking-faces security-config.xml configuration is not correct
column42:
The problem is referenced somewhat in this thread:

http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=54311

But basically I think the configuration file is not valid with spring security 2.X.  The reference documentation for Spring Web Flow correctly describes the proper configuration but somehow the sample does not follow it.

The file to change is:

https://springframework.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/springframework/spring-webflow/trunk/spring-webflow-samples/booking-faces/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/config/security-config.xml

I think the correct content is:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:security="http://www.springframework.org/schema/security"
    xsi:schemaLocation="
    http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
    http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.5.xsd
    http://www.springframework.org/schema/security
    http://www.springframework.org/schema/security/spring-security-2.0.1.xsd">
    
    <!-- Configure Spring Security -->
    <security:http auto-config="true"  >
        
        <!-- Restrict URLs based on role -->
        <security:intercept-url pattern="/spring/login*" access="ROLE_ANONYMOUS" />
        <security:intercept-url pattern="/spring/logoutSuccess*" access="ROLE_ANONYMOUS" />
        <security:intercept-url pattern="/spring/logout*" access="ROLE_USER" />
        
        <!-- Override default login and logout pages -->
        <security:form-login
            default-target-url="/spring/main"
            authentication-failure-url="/spring/login?login_error=1"
            login-page="/spring/login"
            login-processing-url="/spring/loginProcess"
            always-use-default-target="false"/>

        <security:logout logout-url="/spring/logout" logout-success-url="/spring/logoutSuccess" />
    </security:http>

    <!--
        Define local authentication provider, a real app would use an external provider (JDBC, LDAP, CAS, etc)
        
        usernames/passwords are:
        keith/melbourne
        erwin/leuven
        jeremy/atlanta
        scott/rochester
    -->
    <security:authentication-provider>
        <security:password-encoder hash="md5" />
        <security:user-service>
            <security:user name="keith" password="417c7382b16c395bc25b5da1398cf076" authorities="ROLE_USER, ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
            <security:user name="erwin" password="12430911a8af075c6f41c6976af22b09" authorities="ROLE_USER, ROLE_SUPERVISOR" />
            <security:user name="jeremy" password="57c6cbff0d421449be820763f03139eb" authorities="ROLE_USER" />
            <security:user name="scott" password="942f2339bf50796de535a384f0d1af3e" authorities="ROLE_USER" />
        </security:user-service>
    </security:authentication-provider>
    
</beans>

column1: Clarify the purpose of the jsf-booking example
column42:
The web.xml for the jsf-booking sample does not include configuration for spring-js. Also the webflow modules are not included in the war built by ant; notwithstanding the fact that the xhtml files do refer to the sf:xxx tags. 

To fix this, the following should be added to web.xml (and the ivy file updated).

 	<!-- Serves static resource content from .jar files such as spring-faces.jar -->
	<servlet>
		<servlet-name>Resources Servlet</servlet-name>
		<servlet-class>org.springframework.js.resource.ResourceServlet</servlet-class>
		<load-on-startup>0</load-on-startup>
	</servlet>
		
	<!-- Map all /resources requests to the Resource Servlet for handling -->
	<servlet-mapping>
		<servlet-name>Resources Servlet</servlet-name>
		<url-pattern>/resources/*</url-pattern>
	</servlet-mapping>
	

Also: note that the following comment inside web.xml
	<!-- Just here so the JSF implementation can initialize, *not* used at runtime -->
is not applicable for the jsf-booking sample, because the faces servlet *is* used at runtime.
column91: 27/May/08 1:01 AM;kdonald;The purpose of jsf-booking is not to show Spring Faces, but to show the traditional, basic JSF + Spring integration approach.  We need to clarify this so folks understand the purpose of this sample.
column92: 05/Jun/08 8:41 AM;jeremyg484;Added an additional README.txt file to the jsf-booking sample to make its purpose clear.

column1: Please provide more information on JUnit testing in WebFlow docs
Upgrade Guide includes inaccurate example code for Flow Request URL Handler
column42:
The example provided for using a Flow Request URL Handler incorrectly shows a flowExecutor being passed in as a constructor-arg:
http://static.springframework.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.0.x/reference/html/ch14s03.html#upgrade-guide-java-url-handler

According the CHANGELOG for 2.0.0, this behaviour was changed as follows:
"  - Removing the FlowController and FlowHandlerAdapter constructors that accepted a FlowExecutor argument in favor of a default constructor with a flowExecutor property.  
    This was done for simplicity reasons for their typical use as Spring beans.
    Please note this change requires a minor update to pre 2.0.0 Web Flow + MVC configurations."

Therefore the documentation should be upgraded to reflect this.

column1: AbstractMvcView Not Backwards Compatible With Java 1.4
Redirect resonse code should be configurable (302 or 303)
column42:
Spring Web Flow seems to issue a 302 code for redirects. I'm assuming that this is because, as pointed out in the HTTP spec, most user agent are broken (or were at the time of the spec definition) and will follow a 302 redirect code with a GET as opposed to the specification's definition for a 302 that would imply the same method is used after the redirect. The spec states that a 303 should be used to get the user agent to follow with a GET. 

We are seeing the 'broken' behavior with our voice application when running on the Nuance voice browser (3.1 SP2) in that it follows the 302 redirect with the desired (by SWF), but not-to-spec GET. Another voice browser (Voxeo's Prophecy platform) does follow the spec to the letter and correctly re-POSTs, but this breaks our SWF app.

Who should 'fix' this? I would say that this should be configurable if the user agent's behaviour is well known and under the developer's control (as in our case), and HttpServletResponse.SC_SEE_OTHER should be a possible redirect code. If this is already possible, my search through the current issues didn't reveal it, and I'd appreciate a pointer in the right direction.
column91: 13/May/08 2:52 PM;kdonald;Made configurable with FlowController/FlowHandlerAdapter.setHttp10Compatible(boolean); set to false to force 303.  Consistent with Spring MVC RedirectView.

column1: Global messages displayed with <h:messages/> cannot be found in flow-local messages.properties
column42: When a global message (i.e. not field-specific) is added from a validator, the error code must be in a properties file referenced form a MessageSource. If the code is in a flow-local messages.properties it is not found. The Spring Faces validator components on the contrary do find error codes in flow-local messages.properties. This is inconsistent from a developer's point because both messages are displayed from a facelet view that belongs to a specific flow.
column91: 11/May/08 9:05 AM;kdonald;This should work, as the validator will use a Errors backed by the FlowExecution's MessageContext, which should be backed by the Flow Definition's MessageSource (definition.getApplicationContext()), which should be built from messages.properties in the flow's working directory.

column1: Failure in Regular Expression to find the <script> tags
column42:
The regularExpression in the scriptPattern variable (line 237) of the handleResponse method doesn't match if the script tag takes multiple lines.

For example the following tag won't be found by the pattern:
<script
    type="text/javascript">
        Spring.addDecoration(new Spring.ElementDecoration({
            elementId : "street",
            widgetType : "dijit.form.ValidationTextBox",
            widgetAttrs : { promptMessage : "Insert the name of your street." }}));
</script>

The pattern should be something like this: (?:<script(.|[\n\r])*?>)((\n|\r|.)*?)(?:<\script>)

column1: When loading ApplicationContext resources, use resource.getInputStream() instead of resource.getFile()
column42:
Since you are never guaranteed that an application is deployed in an exploded form, depending on Resource#getFile() will not always semantically make sense. Thus, you should instead use InputStreamSource#getInputStream() whenever possible.

If you need further input, please contact me directly.

Thanks,

  Sam

column1: Wrong OSGi Headers for Spring Core Imports
column42:
The OSGi Headers for "Import-Package" require the spring core packages with version 2.5.4.A but the Spring Core exports them as 2.5.4.

Here is a sample of one of the headers
           org.springframework.core.io.support;version="[2.5.4.A,3.0)"

I Suppose this is a BUG. I can't get the Webflow and associated "Binding" and "JS" bundles go to RESOLVED state in the OSGi.
column91: 27/May/08 1:46 AM;kdonald;2.5.4.A is the correct version

column1: Inherited flow's Global Transition not recognised when returning from a sub-flow.
column42:
Transition not found (which is present in abstract flow) when returning from a sub-flow.

http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?p=179051#post179051

Workaround is to add following line to handle the transition

<transition on="*" to="${currentEvent}"/>

column1: NumberFormatException not getting caught
column42:
This is against 2.0.0-RELEASE

With the new model auto binding/validation, as it is right now, it is impossible to handle a String->Number typeMismatch, as the NumberFormatException is never handled, bypassing any binding handling you might have. I have temporarily fixed this by creating a wrapping formatterregistry which catches the NumberFormatException and rethrows as an InvalidFormatException. 

The correct solution would be to actually catch NumberFormatException and rethrowing it as an InvalidFormatException.

column1: AjaxTilesView does not resolve deeply nested tiles attributes for rendering as fragments if the containing view has not previously been rendered.
column42: If a particular view has not been previously rendered by a standard JSP request, nested Tiles attributes (i.e., those in a nested definition that is filling in the attribute of a parent definition) will not have been initialized as expected when they are requested for rendering via Ajax.
column91: 30/Apr/08 6:22 AM;jeremyg484;Now properly initializing nested attributes by trying to load them as a Definition before trying to render.  Also added better logging for error situations.

column1: FileNotFoundException while using Weblogic10 and SWF classpath flow-location-pattern
column42:
Hello,
We are using Spring2.5.3+SWF2.0RC1 under jdk5/weblogic 10.
WE are defing our flows as follow:
<webflow:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" flow-builder-services="flowBuilderServices" >	
		<webflow:flow-location-pattern value="classpath:modules/**/flows/*.xml"/>
</webflow:flow-registry>

Our xml file flows are packaged under WEB-INF/classes. Using Tomcat application runs perfectly.
Using weblogic 10, war file is splitted in several jars at deployement time in a working folder.
org.springframework.util.ResourceUtils.getFile(URI, String) then compares computed URI protocol-> zip but expects a file protocol.
This leads to a FileNotFoundException.

Clearly, we think this is a Spring issue more or less related in SPR-994, but coming from a different use case.
Thanks to have a look.
column91:
28/Apr/08 12:16 AM;bferrenq;Hello,
Spring already handle this use case. 
Issue is that org.springframework.webflow.engine.model.builder.xml.XmlFlowModelBuilder.init() uses org.springframework.core.io.ClassPathResource.getFile() instead of  getFileForLastModifiedCheck().
column92:
30/Apr/08 9:56 AM;tjstavenger;I'm working on a project that is experiencing the same problem. Spring Web Flow knows enough to find the flows by the wildcard approach ferrenq shows, but then once it gets to line 112 of the XmlFlowModelBuilder.init() method in the 2.0.0.RELEASED code it fails with the same FileNotFoundException. 

I'm using Java 5 and WebLogic 9.2 MP1. The exception error message states we could deploy using an exploded archive, but that unfortunately is not an option for me.

After looking at the ClassPathResource.getFileForLastModifiedCheck() method, I too would agree that using this method instead of getFile() would correct the problem.

Is there a workaround that we could use until a fix is implemented in a current release? (beyond deploying with an exploded archive)
column95: 02/May/08 5:31 AM;kdonald;Fixed this for 2.0.1. Can you try out the next nightly build? Cheers
column96:
05/May/08 11:11 PM;bferrenq;Hello,
Issue fixed and tested under spring-webflow-2.0.0.CI-461.
Thanks!

column1: NoSuchConversationException in safari browser when deployed on Tomcat 5.5.x on a Linux machine
column42:
Our application has a view state with in a flow that is not a endstate, and from this state if the user clicks browser back and tries to fire any other events we are getting NoSuchConversationException on Safari 3.1 on Windows and MAC only when the application is deployed on Tomcat 5.5.x on Linux environment( RedHat and Debian as mentioned above)

We do not get this error when we deploy on Tomcat 5.5.x on Windows XP.  Below is the snippet of our flow.

<view-state id="displayDiseases" view="displayDiseases">
<transition on="go" to="executeCRCSearch">
<action bean="searchFlowAction" method="bind"/>
</transition>
<transition on="diseaseSelect" to="diseaseSelect"/>
</view-state>

<action-state id="executeCRCSearch">
<action bean="searchFlowAction" method="searchProtocol"/>
<transition on="success" to="checkEligibilty"/>
<transition on="allDisorders" to="displayDiseases"/>
<transition on="diseaseNotAssocitedToProtocol" to="diseaseFail"/>
</action-state> 

<view-state id="diseaseFail" view="diseaseFail">
<transition on="back" to="displayDiseases"/>
</view-state>

The start state is displayDiseases and after executeCRCSearch state the transition goes to view state is displayDiseases.  When we click browser back button then try to do executeCRCSearch we get the following exception.

We are currently using spring 2.5.2 and spring webflow 1.0.4 versions.


STACK TRACE ISorg.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.NoSuchFlowExecuti
