column1: Trinidad partial rendering not working correctly when used with Spring Faces
column42:
Trinidad's partial rendering features don't seem to be working correctly in combination with Spring Faces.  A JavaScript error similar to the following is being raised in the browser when the response is returned:

["Invalid PPR response. The response-headers were:\nServer: Apache-Coyote/1.1\nPragma: no-cache\nExpires:..."]DebugCommon1_2_7.... (line 16422)
["Error ", TypeError: responseDocument has no properties message=responseDocument has no properties, " delivering XML request status changed to ", function()]DebugCommon1_2_7.... (line 16422

I was able to reproduce this in a simple Trinidad test project.
column91:
05/May/08 12:19 AM;jeremyg484;Here is what I have found so far:

The error in question seems to be raised by Trinidad's client-side JavaScript for handling the updating of the page with the partial response, and is generally triggered by the ContentType of the response not being set to "text/xml".  I was able to reproduce this using .jspx templates.  These templates render as "text/xml" by default, causing the browsers not to render the page correctly on an initial non-ajax render.  To get them to render correctly on a normal request, a ContentType jsp directive needs to be added that sets the ContentType to "text/html".  The problem is that this ContentType is then still used when rendering the partial response.  I would imagine Trinidad is trying to explicitly set the ContentType to "text/xml", but the JSP "text/html" ContentType is overriding it, thus causing the error.
column92: 12/May/08 5:56 AM;jeremyg484;It turns out the source of the problem is that Trinidad is setting up a custom HttpServletResponse wrapper on the JSF ExternalContext during an Ajax request.  This wrapper essentially blocks any calls to setContentType on the response (so that the JSP rendering will not reset the ContentType to "text/html" after Trinidad has already set it up to be "text/xml").  Spring Faces was not managing this custom response correctly, so it was getting thrown away before render time.  FlowFacesContext now correctly preserves a custom response object during the course of a request, and this fixes the higher-level problem with Trinidad.

column1: deadlock in RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.getFlowDefinition when building flows with subflows
column42:
Two threads are loading flows from separate incoming web requests.  Thread 1 is loading Flow A which has a Subflow B.  Thread 2 is loading Flow B which has Subflow A.  The FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.getFlowDefinition(String id) method does this:

return getFlowDefinitionHolder(id).getFlowDefinition();

The FlowDefinitionHolder interface is implemented with RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder (whose use is hardcoded in XmlFlowRegistrar).  The RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.getFlowDefinition() method is synchronized.  In this example, Thread 1 will own the monitor on Flow A's RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder and Thread 2 will own the monitor on Flow B's RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder .  All subsequent requests to load either Flow A or Flow B will also wait behind this deadlock.

Here is a stack trace of a deadlock in SWF 1.0.3, but the same issue can be found in 1.0.5 with different line numbers:

org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.getFlowDefinition(FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.java:128)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.DefaultFlowServiceLocator.getSubflow(DefaultFlowServiceLocator.java:79)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.LocalFlowServiceLocator.getSubflow(LocalFlowServiceLocator.java:120)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.parseSubflow(XmlFlowBuilder.java:684)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.parseAndAddSubflowState(XmlFlowBuilder.java:609)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.parseAndAddStateDefinitions(XmlFlowBuilder.java:570)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.buildStates(XmlFlowBuilder.java:354)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.FlowAssembler.directAssembly(FlowAssembler.java:149)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.FlowAssembler.assembleFlow(FlowAssembler.java:131)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.assembleFlow(RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.java:173)
      org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.getFlowDefinition(RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.java:93)
      org.springframework.webflow.definition.registry.FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.getFlowDefinition(FlowDefinitionRegistryImpl.java:128)
      org.springframework.webflow.executor.FlowExecutorImpl.launch(FlowExecutorImpl.java:204)
column91: 27/May/08 1:53 AM;kdonald;For testing with Web Flow 2

column1: security-config.xml in booking-mvc does not validate against spring-security-2.0.xsd
column42:
In booking-mvc, security-config.xml line 19 should be

<security:form-login login-page="/spring/login" login-processing-url="/spring/login-process" default-target-url="/spring/flows/main" authentication-failure-url="/spring/login?login_error=1" />

instead of

<security:form-login login-page="/spring/login" login-url="/spring/login-process" default-target-url="/spring/flows/main" authentication-failure-url="/spring/login?login_error=1" />

Otherwise the file does not validate against spring-security-2.0.xsd and the app does not start up.

Here's a link to the forum thread: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=51199

In addition, it will look for certain JSF component Id's to re-render by convention if validation fails during an Ajax request.  It will look for a "messages" component, and a component with an id that matches the model expression (i.e., a form with a "booking" id would get re-rendered if model="booking" is set on the view-state) and automatically re-render them if found.

column1: implementations of ConversationLock.lock should throw exception after configurable timeout period
column42:
Using SWF 1.0.5 in a JSR 168 portlet on WebSphere.  This also looks to be an issue with 2.0M4 code, so I'm reporting it against that too.  The FlowExecutorImpl locks a conversation upon resume() or refresh() in 1.0.5 and resumeExecution() in 2.0 M4.  The ConversationLock is implemented by JdkConcurrentConversationLock in JDK 1.5+ and UtilConcurrentConversationLock in JDK 1.4.  In both cases, it uses the lock variant that waits infinitely unless interrupted.  

For UtilConcurrentConversationLock, it would be better to do ReentrantLock.attempt(long msecs) instead of ReentrantLock.acquire(); and in JdkConcurrentConversationLock it would be better to do ReentrantLock.tryLock(long time, TimeUnit unit).  Then have a reasonable default wait time, e.g. 30 seconds, and allow that to be customized.  If time period elapses without acquiring the lock, propagate an exception out of SWF to fail the request.

The use case for this is that a flow becomes hung inside an action execution due to a deadlock or something.  The user sees their browser waiting, so tries to submit the request again and again and again.  What would have been one hung thread (not Spring's fault) is now 1 + N, aggravating the problem and opening the door to exhausting the web container thread pool.
column91: 31/Mar/08 6:34 AM;kdonald;Made timeoutSeconds configurable in 2.0 RC1.

column1: DefaultExpressionFactoryUtils should not automatically set the javax.el.ExpressionFactory system property

column1: org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.impl.DefaultFlowExecutionRepository not extensible/appropriately pluggable
column42:
There is no method to support customizing/replacing the org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.continuation.FlowExecutionContinuationFactory used during the construction of a org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.impl.DefaultFlowExecutionRepository inside the constructor. This will force anyone wishing to replace/override/ehance the default org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.continuation.SerializedFlowExecutionContinuationFactory to duplicate/re-implement functionality in org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.impl.DefaultFlowExecutionRepository

- Sean

column1: DefaultExpressionFactoryUtils breaks backward compatiblity to JDK 1.4
column42:
The Method createExpressionFactory() in org.springframework.binding.expression.el.DefaultExpressionFactoryUtils tries to throw an IllegalStateException with arguments of type String and Throwable. 

The Class IllegalStateException in JDK doesn't allow for an throwable in it's constructor. This feature is first introduced in JDK1.5
column91: 13/Mar/08 8:28 AM;jeremyg484;Updated DefaultExpressionFactoryUtils to use the 1.4 version of IllegalStateException.

column1: org.springframework.faces.webflow.FlowVariableResolver not working with JDK1.4
column42:
The FlowVariableResolver is automatically configured by the faces jar (spring-faces-2.0-m4.jar, /META-INF/faces-config.xml). 

In it's static initializer it tries to create an instance of SpringBeanWebFlowELResolver which inherits from 
org.springframework.beans.factory.access.el.SpringBeanELResolver, but SpringBeanELResolver is not compatible with JDK1.4. 

In turn it might simply be an oversight to make SpringBeanELResolver JDK1.4 compatible (should be fairly easy to replace StringBuilder)?
column91: 13/Mar/08 9:48 AM;jeremyg484;Instead of depending on the 1.5 compiled SpringBeanELResolver, added a SpringBeanWebFlowVariableResolver to be automatically configured in the faces-config.xml of spring-faces.jar.

column1: Exception handling in FlowExecutionImpl and HibernateFlowExecutionListener
column42:
I'm using SWF 2.0M3 with persistence context configured for Hibernate.
When commiting the changes I got an org.hibernate.StaleObjectStateException as expected, because I modified the same object in two separate flows.

The first problem is, that this exception is absorbed in the exception wrapping code for an inactive flow in FlowExecutionImpl.

The second problem is, that the HibernateFlowExecutionListener tries to unbind the session from an inactive flow in exceptionThrown(), which causes a new exception.
In the end the hibernate session is still bound.

See my post:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=49127

column1: root messageSource not available in MessageSourceAware implementation in a flow
column42: messageSource configured in a root app context configuration is not available in webflow ActionForm objects, also implementing MessageSourceAware. To get the messageSource in the ActionForm objects, you must configure it directly in the flow definition file.
column91: 20/May/08 9:46 PM;sslavic;If there will be any more bug fix releases of SWF version 1, please apply this fix.

column1: PhaseListener registered before Restore-View, PhaseListener caching FacesContext
column42:
There are two problems with the existing Phase-Listener integration:

1) it is partially registered before restore-view - with many bridges (see also my comments on SWF-183), the callback will not be executed if a render-request is executed
2) the phase-listener caches the Faces-Context between the execution of the lifecycle and rendering the response - this is not allowed; as in a portlet-environment, the rendering might be executed by a different thread than the life-cycle, and the Faces-Context will not be available any more

regards,

Martin

column1: Make OGNL expression usage compatible with Web Flow 1.0 by default in Web Flow 2.0
column42:
Nearly all existing SWF users use Ognl as their expression language implementation, and Ognl is the default expression parser implementation.  As a result, the same Ognl usage semantics should continue to be the default in Web Flow 2.0.

Optionally, users can choose to use a Ognl EP with normalized UEL-like templating syntax, if they are familiar with UEL but have to run on Java 1.4.
column91:
06/Mar/08 8:31 AM;kdonald;OGNL usage will be refined to be simpler and normalized with EL usage in 2.0-version flows.
We will support 100% SWF 1.x OGNL usage compatibility for 1.0 version flow definitions.  This is being addressed in another ticket.

column1: Add support for running Web Flow version 1.x flows on the 2.x engine, providing a smooth migration to 2.x for existing 1.x users.
column42:
This means
- Adding spring-webflow-1.0-config.xsd and spring-webflow-1.0.xsd to the spring-webflow-2.0.jar
- Fully supporting the spring-webflow 1.x syntax in version 2.x, so users 1.x flows can run unchanged on the 2.x engine.
- Adding 1.0 config namespace handlers / parsers

1.x flows should then run on 2.x with no change necessary in most cases.  Only 1.x flows that install custom API elements such as view-state or end-state view-selectors will require definite migration effort.
column91: 04/Apr/08 3:53 AM;kdonald;Being addressed by 513

column1: Simplify EL expression parsing abstraction API, provide normalized OGNL and EL support with backwards compatability for SWF 1.0 OGNL usage.
column42: Based on customer feedback the spring-binding EL abstraction API could be simpler.  In addition, compatibility with OGNL expression usage in 1.0 was broken in 2.0 M2 and needs to be restored.

column1: Form actions updated incorrectly on Ajax response
column42: The actions of existing HTML forms are updated to reflect the correct flow execution URL as part of Ajax response handling, but the algorithm is overly eager in that it simply updates all form elements on the page.  This is undesirable for example if trying to display a new view state in a modal dialog.  If the existing form element is updated to point to the same flow execution snapshot as the new form in the dialog, closing the dialog and attempting to process actions on the original form will fail because the flow execution is restored in an incorrect state.
column91: 24/Jan/08 1:52 AM;jeremyg484;The server-side and client-side Ajax processing components have been corrected to only update the action URL of existing form elements if they are contained in the JSF component tree of the rendered response.

column1: Form action URL is updated in correctly on an AJAX request
column42: The first attempt at updating form action URL's with the new flow execution URL as a result of processing an AJAX request is too optimistic.  It assumes that all forms on a page always correspond to the same flow execution instance, but this is incorrect.  For example, when one form is rendered in initial page rendering, and then the ajax request renders a new form into an inline popup control, the two forms should have distinct form action URL's because they represent the flow in two different states.
column91: 14/Jan/08 6:45 AM;jeremyg484;The form action URL will now only be updated for forms that are children of the JSF View that is rendered during the course of the AJAX request.

column1: Wrong _flowExecutionKey in externalRedirect view when using PortletFlowController
column42:
My flow jumps to external system using externalRedirect in regular view state. Then it returns back using _flowExecutionKey automatically attached to external redirect URL and continues. Everything works well when I'm using MVC FlowController. Unfortunatelly my flow is running in portlet. When I'm trying to go back using attached _flowExecutionKey my flow executes the previous state. It calls transition that has been executed just before view state with externalRedirect. I have used the same flow to test both MVC and portlet solutions. The second one differs. I get the 'old' _flowExecutionKey (for previous state) in the external redirect and my external application can't go back to contunue the flow. It's going to run external redirect again. 

I have looked for the sources and compared resonse generation in both cases (MVC and portlets). A have also compared methods generating different types of responses (ApplicationView, FlowDefinitionRedirect, FlowExecutionRedirect, handleExternalRedirect) in both cases to make sure. 

In my opinion the bug is in PortletFlowController in handleActionRequestInternal(...) method. There is an anonymous ResponseInstructionHandler subclass Most of its methods uses responseInstruction.getFlowExecutionKey() to produce response except one handleExternalRedirect method that uses local variable flowExecutionKey. This variable contains key that refers to state that has been just executed. A new _flowExecutionKey should be given using responseInstruction as it is in the other methods. 

When I have changed this line to

String url = argumentHandler.createExternalUrl(redirect, responseInstruction.getFlowExecutionKey(), context); 

everything works well.
column91: 05/Sep/08 6:30 AM;klr8;This was indeed a bug. Fixed as suggested.

column1: swf-booking-mvc search form doesn't work in SWF 2.0 M3
column42:
The swf-booking-mvc demo bundled with SWF 2.0 M3 has a search form in the page that does not work. There is not a form action declared in the JSP:

<form:form modelAttribute="searchCriteria">

Thus, the form action is rendered by the JSP tag as:

<form id="searchCriteria" method="post" action="/swf-booking-mvc/flow/main/main.jsp">

The action that's rendered is incorrect. If the action is manually changed (through DOM manipulation) to the URL of the displayed page:

http://localhost:8160/swf-booking-mvc/spring/executions/main/{workflow_id)

... then submitting the form works fine. This is reproducible with the SWF 2.0 M3 distro. I didn't try regression testing, but can if desired.

This also seems to be a problem with Jetty: http://weblogs.java.net/blog/johnsmart/archive/2007/07/spring_mvc_tile.html

Reported in SpringWeb as I think this is not a webflow specific problem: http://jira.springframework.org/browse/SPR-4407

I am using spring 2.5.1

Gareth

column1: infinite loop possible in FlowExecutionImpl.handleException when application code throws exceptions
column91:
27/Nov/07 6:23 PM;agim;Hello, 

i think the current behavior is useful and shouldn't be changed. 
The ExceptionHandler has a canHandle method, there you have the possibility to return false if you can't handle the exception. 

The actual implementation has been added in SWF 1.0.4 (or maybe 1.0.3), and allows you to handle exceptions 
which happens while handling the exception itself. If you implement the canHandle method properly, then you will 
not run into any issue with that.

Best regards
agim
column92:
28/Nov/07 6:42 AM;chwu;Hi Agim,

Thanks for your reply. 

Could you tell me where that canHanlde method is defined? I got the 2.0M1 code and I did not find it in org.springframework.webflow.engine. FlowExecutionExceptionHandler or org.springframework.webflow.engine.support. TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler.

Could you tell me how the current implementation is useful? Maybe there is a way to achieve the intended "usefulness" and at the same time avoid the potential infinite recursive calls?
column93:
01/Dec/07 11:56 PM;agim;Hi, 

<qoute>
Could you tell me where that canHanlde method is defined? I got the 2.0M1 code and I did not find it in org.springframework.webflow.engine. FlowExecutionExceptionHandler or org.springframework.webflow.engine.support. TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler. 
</qoute>

http://static.springframework.org/spring-webflow/docs/2.0.x/api/org/springframework/webflow/engine/FlowExecutionExceptionHandler.html#canHandle(org.springframework.webflow.execution.FlowExecutionException)

<qoute>
Could you tell me how the current implementation is useful? Maybe there is a way to achieve the intended "usefulness" and at the same time avoid the potential infinite recursive calls?
</qoute>

In short, the canHandle Method must be implemented that it returns false for all exception that will be thrown if the exceptionhandler is called again. 

I.e. you have your Exception MyCustomFlowExecutionListenerException that is thrown from your handler (every time the handler is called), in this case you must return false inside the canHandle Method to avoid a infinite loop through your exception handlers.

regards
agim
column94:
03/Dec/07 1:51 AM;chwu;Hi Agim,

I downloaded the night build to see how FlowExecutionExceptionHandler.canHandle is implemented. That interface is implemented by org.springframework.webflow.engine.support.TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler and it just check if getTargetStateResolver(e) != null. This means I'd need to have my own custom TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler class to override it. 

TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler is used in org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.parseTransitionExecutingExceptionHandler. That method is PRIVATE. I'd like to override this for all the transitions since it could happen that some code could throw 1) runtime exceptions such as DB connection errors continuously as long as the code could not get a connection, or 2) application exceptions such as some validation logic that would fail by the given form data from the user.

It'd be very difficult for me to have a custom XmlFlowBuilder so that I can use my custom TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler and I believe XmlFlowBuilder and TransitionExecutingFlowExecutionExceptionHandler probably are not intended to be over ridden.

All this comes back to the question I had in the beginning: what exactly you guys want to achieve with that infinite loop? Maybe there are ways to achieve the same goal while avoid using an infinite loop?

I think a potential infinite loop should be avoided directly because we never know when it occurs and when it occurs it WILL bring down the program, which I believe is not a good thing in production environments.

Thanks,

ChienHsing
column95:
06/Feb/08 7:49 AM;johnmcase;You don't need custom exception handling to run into this problem.  I created a flow with a global transition on-exception="java.lang.Throwable" that should transition to an error page.  If I have a view state with exit-actions, and one of those actions throws an exception then I end up in this loop because webflow always tries to execute the exit-actions before transitioning out of the view-state.  I have tested this in both 1.0.4 and 1.0.5

I have a small project that demonstrates the issue that I can attach if needed, otherwise the following flow definition should be enough:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<flow xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
      xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
      xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow
                          http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-1.0.xsd">

    <start-state idref="page1"/>
    
    <view-state id="page1" view="page1">
    	<transition on="next" to="page2" />

    	<exit-actions>
    		<action bean="throwExceptionAction" />
    	</exit-actions>
    </view-state>   
    
    <end-state id="page2" view="page2" />
    
    <end-state id="error" view="error" />
    
    <global-transitions>
    	<transition on-exception="java.lang.Throwable" to="error" />
    </global-transitions>
    
    <import resource="testbug-flow-beans.xml"/>
    
</flow>

Below is the stack trace from one of the iterations in the loop which clearly shows the loop at FlowExecutionImpl.java:313  (version 1.0.5)

[#|2008-02-06T15:41:19.903-0600|INFO|sun-appserver9.1|javax.enterprise.system.stream.out|_ThreadID=16;_ThreadName=httpSSLWorkerThread-8080-0;|2008-02-06 15:41:19,903 DEBUG [org.springframework.webflow.engine.support.TransitionExecutingStateExceptionHandler] - Handling state exception org.springframework.webflow.engine.ActionExecutionException: Exception thrown executing [AnnotatedAction@11ffcc2 targetAction = my.pkg.webflow.ThrowExceptionAction@10b5037, attributes = map[[empty]]] in state 'page1' of flow 'testbug-flow' -- action execution attributes were 'map[[empty]]'; nested exception is java.lang.Exception: Test Exception
org.springframework.webflow.engine.ActionExecutionException: Exception thrown executing [AnnotatedAction@11ffcc2 targetAction = my.pkg.webflow.ThrowExceptionAction@10b5037, attributes = map[[empty]]] in state 'page1' of flow 'testbug-flow' -- action execution attributes were 'map[[empty]]'; nested exception is java.lang.Exception: Test Exception
Caused by: 
java.lang.Exception: Test Exception
	at my.pkg.webflow.ThrowExceptionAction.execute(ThrowExceptionAction.java:16)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.AnnotatedAction.execute(AnnotatedAction.java:146)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.ActionExecutor.execute(ActionExecutor.java:59)

column1: conversation not invalidated when flow terminates through a refresh
column42:
My understanding from the documentation is that when any one flow execution terminates, the entire conversation is terminated, when using the continuation repository.

As a strategy to prohibit using the back button to go back to certain pages, an attempt to go back will cause an exception to be thrown.  In the flow-def there is a <transition on-exception> which transitions to an <end-state>.   Following the log messages, the flow execution is terminated but the conversation is not terminated.

I believe the cause of this is that the FlowExecutorImpl.refresh method handles the re-entry into the snapshot, and refresh does not contain conversation invalidation logic.  The logic to handle conversation invalidation is in the FlowExecutorImpl.resume method.
column91:
14/Jan/08 4:47 AM;kdonald;I'm a little confused here.

If you go back and try to resume a ended flow execution, yes, you will get an exception.  However, such an exception will not be able to be handled by the flow execution since it has ended: it can only be handled by the calling environment, usually your MVC web framework.

You should never attempt to end a flow execution on refresh - refresh should never change the state of the flow.

column1: Resources Flow does not set cache headers properly to allow for resource caching
column42:
We should enable performance caching in accordance with Yahoo performance guidelines.
We should consider enhancing the ExternalContext response abstraction to allow for easily setting cache control headers.

column1: Add Hibernate Session disconnect callback on pause after view rendering
column42:
This is needed for proper returning of the connection to the pool.  This was not possible previously because SWF was not in control of the view rendering process.  Now that it is, this improvement is easily achievable.

Info from Juergen on this:
"The need to call disconnect really depends on the configured Hibernate connection release mode.  We might have a problem with our LocalSessionFactoryBean defaults there,since by default we only release it on closing the Session. This is fine for HibernateTransactionManager's purposes, but not so great for the Session-per-conversation pattern.

From that perspective, sandard Hibernate actually disconnects automatically, but in particular with typical Spring usage, we need to assume that the Session may still be connected (in "on_close"
release mode).

So to be on the safe side for any release mode, we should still call "session.disconnect()" once a conversation pauses. In case of auto-disconnection, this will simply have no effect, but in "on_close" mode
it will explicitly return the JDBC Connection to the pool.

Reconnecting should never be an issue, though. This will always be automatic, happening on demand (when the Session is actually accessed)."
column91: 15/Nov/07 6:43 AM;kdonald;Added session.disconnect() call on pause for flows that manage hibernate persistence contexts

column1: Restore JSF 1.1 compatability for Web Flow 2.0
column42: Spring Web Flow 2.0 M2 introduced a dependency on JSF 1.2.  We should investigate the amount of work required to support JSF 1.1 in Spring Faces, and also the demand for JSF 1.1 from our community.  Please vote on this issue if you require JSF 1.1 beyond March 2008.
column91: 26/Nov/07 6:10 AM;jeremyg484;JSF 1.1 compatability has been restored for the core JSF integration in Spring Faces.  Note that JSF 1.1 users on JDK versions prior to 1.5 will need to continue using OGNL for expression support in their XML flow definitions.  Some value-added features of Spring Faces (such as the built-in Ajax components) will still require JSF 1.2, but the majority of Spring Faces functionality should remain available to JSF 1.1 users.

column1: Forms in Session
column42:
Hi,

Our application is a web and intranet application using Sping - ibatis running on a WAS61 server. Our application is used for creating online accounts and user will be navigating through pages and after filling all the information he will be requested to submit the appl., before submittion application will prefill all his session data to a PDF(iText tool) and then submit the account. 

In the above arch., we have all forms in session and Actions class scope as session, the issue we are facing is during pdf prefilling, values across sessions are printing in the pdf, but when db values looks proper. Db works as expected, only the session values are jumbled. 

We have an ApplicationContext.xml with action type as "org.springframework.web.struts.DelegatingActionProxy" scope="session" parameter="dispatch".

column1: Website 2.0 schema contains 1.0 file contents (different from what is in JAR)
column42:
The 2.0 schema on the website (http://www.springframework.org/schema/.....) contains what appears to be the 1.0 schema contents.  (I haven't done a detailed comparison).  It definitely is different from the schema that's packaged in the 2.0-m2 JAR.  (JAR has "flow-executor", website has "executor").

By the way, what's up with all the "flow" prefixes in the element names?  Isn't that what we have XML namespaces for?
column91:
02/Nov/07 1:06 PM;kdonald;The recommended local namespace prefix for the spring-webflow-config.xml schema is now simply "swf".  This is shown in the m2 sample applications booking-jsf and booking-mvc. So you end up with descriptive tags like <swf:flow-executor/>, <swf:flow-registry/>, etc...

Here is a relavent snippet showing this usage style from the samples:

	<swf:flow-executor id="flowExecutor" flow-registry="flowRegistry">
		<swf:flow-execution-listeners>
			<swf:listener ref="jpaFlowExecutionListener" criteria="*"/>
		</swf:flow-execution-listeners>
	</swf:flow-executor>
	
	<swf:flow-registry id="flowRegistry" flow-builder-services="flowBuilderServices">
		<swf:flow-location path="flow/main/main.xml" />
		<swf:flow-location path="flow/booking/booking.xml" />
		<swf:flow-builder class="org.springframework.faces.ui.resource.ResourcesFlowBuilder" />
	</swf:flow-registry>

Since the local namespace prefix is arbitrary, it was thought that leaving off the flow would result in undescriptive "executor" and "registry" tags. 

The M2 xsd has not yet been uploaded to springframework.org.  Once uploaded, I'll resolve this issue.

column93:
13/Jun/08 11:15 PM;klr8;I'm not going to fix this for 1.0.6, not sure we should even fix it.

It works with a null return value from the invoked method because ResultObjectBasedEventFactory explicitly handles nulls. If you have a 'blank' string, it will simply create an Event with that String as event identifier calling the constructor. This triggers the exception since an event needs a non-blank identifier, as the exception clearly states.

What would an event with a blank identifier mean???
column94:
28/Jul/08 2:54 AM;hemalcshah;Erwin, Keith,

I am facing this issue in Wefblow 2.0.2, I have clone this JIRA issue for Webflow 2.0( SWF-728) but as discussion is happening here, I am posting my comments here.

I have a business service (process()) which could return empty string.
In few scenarios, my requirement is just to transition to next state after calling evaluate action ie I am using wildcard card "*" in transition.
In other scenarios, I use it in decision state where if resultant event is error then process to error state else process to other state. Here as well if resultant event is empty string than I just want to proceed to next state without any exception.

I have many business services which could return empty string. If empty string is not allowed as result of evaluate action than it means that I cannot use my existing business services directly "as it is". Either I have to write wrapper to that service call or refactor that service.

If I was writing new services than this won't be a pain but as I am migrating from existing proprietary workflow solution(XML + Java)  to a Webflow, I intended to re-use same Java services. Hence, refactoring those service is a pain.

Can we have behavior of  "empty string" event something similar to null event ?

If this requirement is very specifc to my use-case than other workaround to this issue I could think of is injecting Custom ResultEventFactorySelector.
But I was not able to figure out how achieve that in  webflow 2.0.2.  I saw EvaluateAction has an API setResultEventFactorySelector() but I am not sure how to configure it thorugh Spring bean definition.

Any input is highly appreciated.
column95: 29/Aug/08 3:59 PM;klr8;As indicated earlier, I'm not going to fix this in 1.0.6 since in 1.0.6 this is really intended behavior instead of a bug (hence the explicit test in the Event constructor).

column1: FormAction.doValidate() isn't called when there is no validator configured
column42:
FormAction.doValidate() isn't called when there is no validator configured.

This is no problem for the default implementation of FormAction.doValidate(), which would only invoke configured validators.

In the case of a custom doValidate() implementation (which is encouraged in the JavaDoc of validate()) it is very likely that you won't configure a Validator object. Neverless, you'd like your custom validation to be executed.

In other words, not bindAndValidate() should decide wether to call any Validators (strip "if (getValidator() != null"), but the default implementation of doValidate(). I can provide a patch if you'd like.

column1: Session binding conversation containers cannot be used in a cluster
column42:
See http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=41950

Original issue report:
--
Prior to version 1.0.4 I was able to have the functionality where if i had to restart tomcat for any reason users would be able to pick up right where they left off in a flow when tomcat came back up. This was because I am persisting my httpsessions on restart.  Since I have upgraded to SWF 1.0.4 When i restart tomcat my session are persisted as normal however I get a NoSuchConversationException.

Could this be the reason:

New in 1.0.4 you now use the session key "webflow.conversation.container." + new RandomGuid().toString(); to store the conversationContainer in the httpsession

However when tomcat restarts and we try to resume our webflow, since that RandomGuid() has now generated a different key it can no longer reference the ConversationContainer in the session since it used the old random key that was generated before tomcat restarted.

So my conversationcontainer is still in the session, but the sessionBindingConversationManager has no way to find it since the random key assigned as they session key has now changed.

Can anyone shine some light on this?
--

This was introduced in 1.0.4.  We should allow the key of a conversation container to be specified manually to allow unique containers per session without this random guid problem.
column91: 15/Aug/07 4:09 AM;kdonald;Caused by 304.
column92: 15/Aug/07 4:23 AM;kdonald;Made SessionBindingConversationManager's "sessionKey" property configurable. By default it is"webflow.conversationContainer", but it can be overridden on a per-conversation manager basis.  This allows unique session keys to support mulitple conversation containers in the same application, working safely in a cluster with standard session replication.

column1: Reloading classes of objects stored in a flow execution scope results in exception
column91:
23/Jul/07 6:32 PM;klr8;The problem is that the object in the serialized continuation snapshot still refers to the old class, before it was updated. We have seen this issue before and I'm not sure there is much we can do about it.

Objects in conversation scope should not suffer from this since they are not inside the continuation snapshot -- i.e. they are not serialized out.

A simple work around is to restart your browser: this will make sure you get a new session, and avoids hitting the old, 'corrupt' snapshots.
column92: 23/Jul/07 7:51 PM;graemerocher;As I mentioned in the post, a workaround from my perspective would be to be able to invalidate all serialized flows stored in the repository. This is the fix I need to get this working without browser/server restarts
column93: 24/Jul/07 9:06 PM;klr8;Do you think a 'clear' call via JMX would be sufficient? SWF-90 is asking for something like that.
column94: 25/Jul/07 12:27 AM;graemerocher;So you want users to clear flows via some JMX management console? No I need a programmatic way to do it.
column95: 12/Sep/07 11:55 AM;bosmon;The particular root exception class seems "highly recognisable", and it would seem reasonably straightforward to diagnose this situation by walking the "cause" stack and invalidate just the *particular* continuation snapshot that is involved. I'm interested though in how you are managing to reload the class without reloading the entire webapp - do you have Spring held at some higher ClassLoader level?

column1: firefox executes an another method
column42:
In a root flow there is called a method "loadAlberi"

<start-state idref="loadAlberi" />
	
	<action-state id="loadAlberi">
		<action bean="editAlberiAction" method="loadAlberi" />
		<transition to="basicFields"/>
	</action-state>

A subflow calls an another method "load" from another bean
                <transition on="edit" to="gLocation">
		<action bean="gLocationAction" method="loadGLocation" />
	</transition>

It works right in browsers Opera and IE. But Firefox calls the method "loadAlberi" instead of "loadGLocation", although it has no reason.
Btw. we use global-transitions but it should have no influence

column1: Fix several Web Flow reference manual typos
column42:
On Page 68 of the Reference manual

There are lots of sentences that are hard to parse but this section was too much.

5.6.2 Configuring the Web Flow system
"The artifacts defined faces-config.xml use Spring to locate the Web Flow system."
looks like an "in the" was omitted
The artifacts defined in the faces-config.xml use Spring to locate the Web Flow system.

Same section next paragraph. I am not sure what it was supposed to say but my guess is as follows.
"In this example inside webflow-config.xml resides the configuration of the Web Flow system the JSF artifacts
will delegate to."
Might be possible to parse it it said,
"In this example, the configuration of the JSF artifacts, to which the Web Flow system will delegate, resides inside webflow-config.xml."

I hope that this is what was intended. 


Here are a few commas ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
Please distribute them throughout the manual.
Look for sentences and phrases that start with "if", If", "in" and "In". Other places are short of commas but this would be a start.
English is a bitch of a language without proper punctuation. We just string words and phrases together and use punctuation to help guide the reader. Leave out the punctuation and it is anyone's guess as to what goes with what.

Keep up the good work.

column1: End-states do not allow convenient <transition on-exception> usage
column42:
You can install exception handlers using the exception-handler tag, but transition on-exception is not supported by the XSD.  This is not quite accurate because an exception thrown within an end-state should be capable of being handled by an local exception handler.

Workaround is to install the exception handler at the flow level as a global transition.

column1: HibernateSessionPerConversationListener does not play nicely with Spring's HibernateTransactionManager
column42:
The root explanation for this issue is from http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=39523.

It appears that The HibernateTransactionManager is closing the transaction opened by the listener even when the transaction is specified with Propagation.REQUIRED semantics.
column91:
07/Jun/07 1:37 AM;nebhale;The HibernateSessionPerConversationListener did not bind the transaction properly so that the HibernateTransactionManager would detect it.  Therefore, the HTM tried to manage the transactions itself causing this issue.  The listener now binds both the session and transaction properly and the HTM behavior works correctly.

Revision 7370

column1: CONVERSATION_CONTAINER_KEY should be unique per FlowExecutor
column42:
Background: If you configure a FlowExecutor within a single web app using a FlowExecutorFactoryBean, a SessionBindingConversationManager will be instantiated by default as your ConversationManager. This SessionBindingConversationManager will then store a ConversationContainer in the HTTP session under the key "webflow.conversation.container". In addition, you can configure the maxConversations to 1 if you like. This works as expected as long as you only configure only one such FlowExecutor.

Unintuitive behavior: if you configure multiple, unique FlowExecutors within a single web app using FlowExecutorFactoryBean as described above with maxConversations=1, you will then notice that both FlowExecutors ultimately use the same session key and thus conflict with each other. For example, if you start one flow for FlowExecutor #1 and start another flow which is handled by FlowExecutor #2, the execution of the 2nd flow will destroy the execution of the 1st flow.

The issue lies in the interpretation of the semantics of maxConversations. As it is currently implemented (i.e., with a single, global session key), the maxConversations takes effect for all configured FlowExecutors within a single web app.

I believe that this is unintuitive and actually not the desired behavior. If I configure two completely separate FlowExecutors with different flow repositories within a single web app, I expect that the configuration of one of them will not conflict with the configuration of the other.



See also:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=38156
column91: 30/Apr/07 11:34 PM;klr8;Each SessionBindingConversationManager now uses a unique key to store it's conversation container in the session (SWF-304).

column1: SWF-JSF: Unhandled flow execution exceptions result in improper flow execution lock management
column42:
A deadlock situation can occur when UNHANDLED flow execution exceptions occur during JSF navigation handling. In addition, I've been able to reproduce other undesireable behavior in other points where unhandled exceptions can be thrown.

Specifically the issues I noted are:

Case 1:
- Flow launched by a command link component
- Flow startup or starting view-state render action throws unhandled exception 
Result:
The jsf view that invoked the command redisplays the current view (non-swf) but conversation is left locked and unreferenceable from that point. 

Case 2:
- Flow launched by direct browser link (no component tree previously exists)
- Flow startup action throws unhandled exception
Result:
- JSF faces servlet tries render a view with the same name as the servlet path [which is arbitrary as far as SWF is concerned]

Case 3:
- Flow refreshed by browser click or redirect
- View state render action throws unhandled exception
Result:
The previous view is redisplayed and the tracked flow execution is lost making it impossible to postback. If post back with the key did occur, deadlock would result as the conversation was left locked after the unhandled exception was thrown.

Case 4:
- Flow event processed (as part of navigation handling)
- Transition action throws a unhandled exception
Result:
- Results in the unhandled exception propagating all the way to the servlet container. Going back in the browser and signaling the event again triggers deadlock as the conversation was left locked.

The bottom line is with 1.0.3 and in a JSF environment only unhandled flow execution exceptions are going to present locking problems. If all exceptions are handled by the flow execution, there should be no problems.

column1: typo "5.6.4. Launching a flow execution - normal HTML anchor"
column42: typo in reference "5.6.4. Launching a flow execution - normal HTML anchor" Go flowId -> _flowId

column1: SWF-JSF: Flow execution refresh operations incorrectly cause a new flow execution key to be generated
column42:
A new flow execution key is being incorrectly generated on each flow execution "refresh" operation (triggerable by a flow execution redirect, a browser refresh button click, and possibly even a partial page refresh if the FlowPhaseListener was involved). With a continuation-based repository (the default), this leads to a new continuation snapshot being taken and added. This causes the ContinuationNotFoundException once the number of refresh operations exceeded the maximum number of continuations allowed per conversation (30).

Easily reproducedy by setting max-continuations to "1" and doing a single browser refresh click immediately after launching a flow.

The fix means the same key should used throughout any number of refreshes of the same view, which is the correct behavior. A new key is only assigned after processing a navigation event, which allows a new snapshot to be taken to support going back to the previous view. This revised logic in FlowPhaseListener would be consistent with the logic in FlowExecutorImpl, which is used by the other environments Spring Web Flow runs in.

column1: SWF-JSF: JSF command buttons with action="flowId:XXX" don't work when invoked from within flow execution
column42:
Consider a button like this:

<h:commandButton value="#{labels.theLabel}" action="flowId:search-flow"/>

Pressing the button works only if we're not engaged in any flow. However if the page containing the button is a part of a webflow (i.e. configured as a view-state) the button does not work, the exception is below:
org.springframework.webflow.engine.NoMatchingTransitionException: No transition found on occurence of event 'flowId:search-flow' in state 'List' of flow 'quote-main-flow' -- valid transitional criteria are array<TransitionCriteria>[[eventId = 'refresh'], [eventId = 'new'], [eventId = 'select']] -- likely programmer error, check the set of TransitionCriteria for this state
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.TransitionableState.getRequiredTransition(TransitionableState.java:82)
	at org.springframework.webflow.engine.TransitionableState.onEvent(TransitionableState.java:112)

It seems that SWF 1.0.2 introduced FlowExecutionKeyStateHolder which restores flow execution earlier than it was in SWF 1.0.1. The result is that when request comes to FlowNavigationHandler the flow execution in SWF 1.0.2 is already restored and therefore the routine tries to feed the event 'flowId:search-flow' to that execution instead of launching new flow as it was in SWF 1.0.1.

Shortly, SWF 1.0.2 broke backwards compatibility for buttons like action="flowId:search-flow" that operate within another flow execution.

column91:
07/Apr/07 11:49 AM;kdonald;This is an expected exception as the flow has ended after you process your order and cannot be resumed.  Else you would commit your order twice.

If your flows don't enter end-states, they never end and can always be resumed on supported view-state events.  If your flow has ended or expired, you must catch this exception and restart the flow.  There is an enhancement request in 1.1 to build this exception capability in out of the box.

column1: Limitations using JSF UI components in end-state views
column42: It is not possible to bind values from managed beans to JSF UI components for a view that is assigned to an end-state. At least, this known limitation should be documented. However, the sellitem-jsf example shows that it is possible to access the values via the plain $ style jsp binding. According to http://forum.springframework.org/showpost.php?p=112174&postcount=61 it should be possible to create a solution by adding a special case to DelegatingFlowVariableResolver.
column91: 07/Apr/07 7:52 AM;kdonald;Added support for resolving end-state flow attributes in the request map in DelegatingFlowVariableResolver.

column1: Restoring the FlowExecution after RESTORE_VIEW phase in JSF causes some value binding expressions to fail.
column42: In order to remove the burden of needing to manually track and post back the flowExecutionKey from JSF developers, a new approach of storing the flowExecutionKey in the UIViewRoot's attributeMap was implemented.  Since the attributeMap gets repopulated during the RESTORE_VIEW phase of the JSF lifecycle, the restoration of the FlowExecution was moved to after the RESTORE_VIEW phase.  This causes any value bindings that need a reference to the FlowExecution to fail when they are evaluated during the RESTORE_VIEW phase.  Using the binding attribute of a component to bind the component instance to a bean stored within SWF's scopes will cause such a failure.
column91:
05/Apr/07 9:59 AM;jeremyg484;
The proposed solution is as follows:

1. Create a very simple JSF component with no rendering output that extends UIComponent and mainly is just interested in implementing the StateHolder interface.  

- The SaveState method of the component will be responsible for getting the proper value to store for the flowExecutionKey and saving it via the usual component mechanisms.
- The RestoreState method of the component will be responsible for restoring the FlowExecution from the restored flowExecutionKey.

2. Instead of setting the flowExecutionKey as an attribute on UIViewRoot, dynamically insert this component as the first child of UIViewRoot. That way its state will still be saved properly, and since the FlowExecution will be restored at the same time as the rest of the component tree, it should be available for resolution in any binding expressions that may follow.
column92: 05/Apr/07 11:06 AM;jeremyg484;Providing an implementation of the proposed solution.
column93: 06/Apr/07 1:26 AM;kdonald;Patch applied for 1.0.2

DelegatingFlowVariableResolver patch attached.

column1: FlowExecutorImpl's resume() and refresh() methods should throw a FlowException for an empty flowExecutionKey
column42:
FlowExecturoImpl's resume() and refresh() methods both call executionRepository.parseFlowExecutionKey(flowExecutionKey), which throws an IllegalArgumentException if the supplied encodedKey is empty (i.e., Assert.hasText(encodedKey, "The string encoded flow execution key is required")).

This behavior does not comply with the FlowExecutor's API, which states that resume() and refresh() should throw a FlowException.

Alternatively, AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository's parseFlowExecutionKey(String encodedKey) method should throw a FlowExecutionRepositoryException instead of the IllegalArgumentException.

In either case, the goal is to have SWF throw SWF specific exceptions instead of allowing an IllegalArgumentException to trickle all the way up the execution stack.

The impetus for this JIRA issue is that I am updating the SpringWebFlowExceptionResolver (see SWF-158), and it is not reasonable to register an IllegalArgumentException as a "supported SWF exception".

To reproduce this bug, configure a continuation backed flow using a RequestPathFlowExecutorArgumentHandler (configured with a defaultFlowId) as the argument handler in the FlowController, and omit the key from the URL. For example, with a web application context mapped to the ROOT and a FlowController mapped to "registration", accessing the following URL will throw an IllegalArgumentException:

http://localhost:8080/registration/k/
column91: 01/Apr/07 5:26 AM;klr8;AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository.parseFlowExecutionKey() now throws an BadlyFormattedFlowExecutionKeyException when asked to parse an empty flow execution key. As a result FlowExecutorImpl.resume/refresh now also adhere to their signature.

column1: JSF Problem : not filled in required fields cause fields to be emptied if page is whithin a flow
column42:
I have a page with several fields and some of them are required (required attribute is set to true). If this page is not invlolved in a flow, and if I don't fill in one of the required fields, after submitting, I get back to my page and all the fields I previously filled in are still there. I can correct the missing fields. So it's OK.

Same sample within a flow (I mean a flow is already started when I get to this page): if I don't fill all of the required fields or if I fill in a field which doesn't meet its validator, all of the fields are emptied after getting back to the page (because of validation problem).
column91: 23/Mar/07 2:30 AM;klr8;Another JSF related issue.
column92: 01/Apr/07 2:28 PM;kdonald;Cannot reproduce in 1.0.2 SVN head
column93:
08/May/07 6:41 PM;djeanprost;Found the problem I guess.

The problem was due to the flow definition. I used the.jsf extension instead of .xhtml (I use facelets).

Not working :
<start-state idref="enterPriceAndItemCount"/>

		<view-state id="enterPriceAndItemCount"
			view="/pages/test.jsf">
			<transition on="coucou" to="enterCategory"></transition>
		</view-state>
...
</start-state>

working :
<start-state idref="enterPriceAndItemCount"/>

		<view-state id="enterPriceAndItemCount"
			view="/pages/test.xhtml">
			<transition on="coucou" to="enterCategory"></transition>
		</view-state>
...
</start-state>

Judging from my problem, I think that there may be a bug somewhere, because, if there is no validation error in the submitted form, the forward is done correctly, ie, the next page is found. If there is a validation error, we get back to the correct page, but with no data in the page, as if we were hitting it for the first time.

If this is an expected behaviour, I think it's weird, please add a huge comment in the documentation. By the way, a clearer explanation on how the matching of the view and the real url is done would be interesting.

I hope this explanation will help bug fixer or readers.

Regards
dom

column1: Url encoding problems with ClientContinuationFlowExecutionRepository
column42:
See forum:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=36225
column91:
24/Mar/07 8:27 AM;klr8;This is indeed a bug. Check the "URL Applications" section in the following Wikipedia article for more info:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64encoded
column92:
25/Mar/07 2:06 AM;klr8;Resolved this issue by switching to the public domain Base64 encoder from:
http://iharder.net/base64

That encoder supports 'url safe' encoding, which is not supported by commons-codec. As a result the commons-codec dependency has been removed.

I drastically simplefied the code from http://iharder.net/base64 and enhanced the url safe encoding by using the '.' as a padding character instead of '=', as also done by the Bouncy Castle Base64 encoder (http://www.bouncycastle.org/java.html). As a results be url safe Base64 encoded strings now no longer contain any characters subject to URL encoding.

column1: InvocationTargetException when second Exception is thrown
column42:
Reported on the forums:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=35874
column91:
09/Mar/07 5:35 PM;klr8;This is indeed a problem.
When a FlowExecutionException occurs, FlowExecutionImpl.handleException() tries to handle it by first trying the state exception handlers and then the flow exception handlers. So far so good.
However, FlowExecutionImpl.handleException doesn't support the situation where handling the exception throws another FlowExecutionException (like in the example on the forum).
This seems like a reasonable implementation technique so FlowExecutionImpl.handleException() should be improved to deal with it.
column92:
17/Mar/07 12:41 AM;klr8;FlowExecutionImpl.handleException() now also tries to handle FlowExecutionExceptions that occur during exception handling (SWF-261).
Also added a unit test to verify correct behavior.

column1: nested inline flow state ids are not scoped
column42:
When using inline flows the states seem to exist at the same level as the main flow states. This means that an id cannot be reused in an inline subflow.

The example I have encountered is that my end states are generally called "end.finsih".  However, when using an inline flow I can not have the end state of the inline called that as it conflicts with the "end.finish" state in my main flow.  I would have expected inline flows to behave in a similar fashion to subflows defined in seperate files.  I would have expected the ids to be scoped to the subflow.

The exception raised is:        "There are multiple occurrences of ID value 'end.finsih'"

We should revisit other options (does XSD offer any?) and also consider the tooling that is maturing for 1.1.

column1: SessionBindingConversationManager does not update ConversationContainer in HTTP session every time.
column42:
The SessionBindingConversationManager does not update the ConversationContainer in the HttpSession every time (for every request). This can give problems in a clustered environment since the servlet engine will not detect any changes in the HttpSession contents and as a result will not push the updated session out to the cluster.

We should also revise the ConversationManager and Conversation interfaces to make sure the have all the hooks required. E.g. how do you know that a client (the FlowExecutionRepo) is done with the ConversationManager, e.g. to commit transaction? Does the unlock() method signal this or do we need another hook?

As a proof of concept we should probably build a DB backed ConversationManager.

The general impression I have is that SWF and clustering is an unknown quantity at the moment...makes me nervous!

Thanks,

column1: Flow redirection parameter incorrectly mapped in a portlet environment
column42:
've run into an issue similar to SWF-153

The problem is that while exposing parameters to a render request (in PortletFlowController, line 221 in 1.0) with response.setRenderParameters(redirect.getExecution Input()); a map passed to response.setRenderParameters has kays beeing strings and values also beeing string.
Unfortunatelly, response.setRenderParameters expect a map of keys beeing strings and values beeing ARRAYS of strings.

So, after trying to pass a redirect parameter a portlet container will fail (in case of pluto it is a IllegalArgumentException).

I've created a simple flow with which we can test the issue described:

Code:

<start-state idref="page1"/>

<view-state id="page1" view="/test/page1.jsp" >
		<transition on="next" to="testAend"/>
</view-state>
	
<view-state id="testAend" view="flowRedirect:testB?paramName=testValue" />

column1: XmlFlowBuilder cannot handle prefixes namespaces
column42:
If the flow definition does not use a default namespace for the Web Flow XSD but a prefixed namespace, XmlFlowBuilder cannot parse the flow definition. The following flow shows an example:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<swf:flow xmlns:swf="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow"
   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
   xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow http://www.springframework.org/schema/webflow/spring-webflow-1.0.xsd">

   <swf:start-state idref="loginView" />

   <swf:view-state id="loginView" view="Login">
      <swf:entry-actions>
         <swf:action bean="loginFormAction" method="setupForm" />
      </swf:entry-actions>
      <swf:transition on="Ok" to="loginAction">
         <swf:action bean="loginFormAction" method="bindAndValidate" />
      </swf:transition>
      <swf:transition on="Cancel" to="cancel" />
   </swf:view-state>

   <swf:action-state id="loginAction">
      <swf:bean-action bean="loginService" method="login">
         <swf:method-arguments>
            <swf:argument expression="requestScope.loginData"/>
         </swf:method-arguments>
         <swf:method-result name="user" scope="flow"/>
      </swf:bean-action>
      <swf:transition on="success" to="finish" />
   </swf:action-state>

   <swf:end-state id="cancel" />
   <swf:end-state id="finish">

</swf:flow>

If this flow is executed the following exception is thrown:

java.lang.IllegalStateException: This is not the 'flow' element
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.parseFlow(XmlFlowBuilder.java:445)
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.xml.XmlFlowBuilder.init(XmlFlowBuilder.java:329)
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.FlowAssembler.assembleFlow(FlowAssembler.java:122)
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.assembleFlow(RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.java:158)
	org.springframework.webflow.engine.builder.RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.getFlowDefinition(RefreshableFlowDefinitionHolder.java:89)

	org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.AbstractController.handleRequest(AbstractController.java:153)

column1: initBind called when expected not being called.
column42: According to the javadocs of the initBinder method in FormAction initBinder is only getting called when a new DataBinder is created ie. on bind and not on setupForm. However it is being called when setupForm is initialy called. We needed a PropertyEditor only registered when binding and not when rendering the view. Our workaround is to check in the initBinder method if it is a POST or GET request, when a POST is detected we are adding the PropertyEditor else we ignore it. Relevant docs: * Note that registration of custom property editors should be done in * {@link #registerPropertyEditors(PropertyEditorRegistry)}, not here! This * method will only be called when a new data binder is created, e.g. when * {@link #bind(RequestContext) data binding} needs to be done. In other cases, * e.g. {@link #setupForm(RequestContext) form setup}, it will not be * called since no data binder is required. I just wonder is this the correct behavior of is it just a mistake in the javadocs?
column43: Spring 2.0.1, Spring Web Flow 1.0, Acegi 1.0.3, jdk 1.5.07, Windows, Tomcat
column91:
20/Dec/06 12:31 AM;klr8;This is actually normal behaviour.

When setupForm is initially called, it needs to create a data binder to correctly setup an Errors instance. This ofcourse also involves registering property editors with the data binder. If setupForm (or any other method of the FormAction, except resetForm) detects an existing Errors instance, it will not create a data binder but just re-registers the property editors with the existing Errors instance. So the part of the JavaDoc that says "This method will only be called when a new data binder is created" is acurate.

The JavaDocs for initBinder were indeed a bit confusing, so I clarified that.

column1: BaseFlowServiceLocator does not allow overriding of default web flow converters
column42:
The BaseFlowServiceLocator.createConversionService method makes the user supplied conversion service the parent of a generic conversion service containing the standard web flow converters. As a result it's impossible to override these standard web flow converters by setting a conversion service on the BaseFlowServiceLocator with the custom converter registered.

The user supplied conversion service should take precedence over the default.
column91: 07/Dec/06 9:38 AM;klr8;Added BaseFlowServiceLocatorTests to trigger the issue.
column92:
21/Dec/06 12:53 AM;klr8;I have fixed this by introducing a new CompositeConversionService in the binding project. This maintains an order chain of conversion services. The user supplied conversion service takes presedence over the default web flow conversion service.

The user supplied ConversionService instance is not modified in any way (e.g. by setting its parent).

column1: uncorrect behaviour of FlowListenerAdapter on JSF environment
column42:
Adding a Listener to the flowExecutionFactory have two different behaviours if the SWF is integrated with JSF or not. In the second case (with JSF) the methods are executed only during entering the first state and no further (even though the flowin' of the states executes normally). 

The configuration used to test this behavour adopts a ClientContinuationFlowExecutionRepository, a  FlowExecutionImplFactory, a StaticFlowExecutionListenerLoader and a dummy listener inheriting from the FlowExecutionListenerAdapter.

It's important to remark that this bug have the side effect of making impossible the use of the OpenSessionInFlowListener Patch (with consequent problems of LazyLoading if also Hibernate is used)

column92:
01/Dec/06 5:01 AM;klr8;Could be related to incorrect (or no) use of a FlowExecutionStateRestorer by the FlowFaseListener.

Erwin
column93: 31/Mar/07 11:00 PM;kdonald;Fixed in 1.0.2

column1: FlowExecutorFactoryBean configures ClientContinuationFlowExecutionRepository with SessionBindingConversationManager by default
column42:
By default, the FlowExecutorFactoryBean will configure the ClientContinuationFlowExecutionRepository with a SessionBindingConversationManager. As a result even the ClientContinuationFlowExecutionRepository requires a HTTP session, creating one if non is found.

See also: 
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=32023

Erwin
column91:
29/Nov/06 10:30 PM;klr8;I've fixed this. There is now also a unit test that verifies correct behaviour.
One side effect is a very minor backwards compatibility issue:
The conversationManager argument of the createExecutionRepository hook method in the FlowExecutorFactoryBean is now possibly null. Review your implementation if you were verriding
 this method!

column1: alwaysRedirectOnPause ignored in JSF
column42:
FlowFacesUtils always creates its own FlowExecutionImplFactory if it can't find one with a secret name in the ApplicationContext.  It is created with the default constructor so it doesn't get any execution-attributes.  FlowFacesUtils doesn't really look hard enough because there is a FlowExecutorImpl in the context and this has its own FlowExecutionImplFactory with the attributes configured in flow:execution-attributes.  In the non-JSF world I think this is what is used to create a FlowExecution, but in JSF the work is done by the PhaseListener.

A quick fix would be to look a bit harder for the FlowExecutionImplFactory  and use the one that is buried in the FlowExecutorImpl.  It might be better to somehow make the PhaseListener use the same logic / factory as the non-JSF case.
column91:
30/Nov/06 12:25 AM;david_syer;Actually it's a bit more complicated than I thought at first, but I think I found a workaround.  FlowFacesUtils is also very eager to create its own FlowExecutionRepository if one does not exist in the app context.  This is trickier to add manually, but it can be done.

Thus we can force alwysRedirectOnPause by adding these two beans:

	<bean id="flowExecutionFactory" class="org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImplFactory">
		<property name="executionAttributesMap">
			<map value-type="java.lang.Boolean">
				<entry key="alwaysRedirectOnPause" value="true"/>
			</map>
		</property>
	</bean>
	
	<bean id="flowExecutionRepository" class="org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.support.SimpleFlowExecutionRepository">
		<constructor-arg>
			<bean
				class="org.springframework.webflow.engine.impl.FlowExecutionImplStateRestorer">
				<constructor-arg>
					<ref bean="flowDefinitionLocator"/>
				</constructor-arg>
				<property name="executionAttributesMap">
					<map value-type="java.lang.Boolean">
						<entry key="alwaysRedirectOnPause" value="true"/>
					</map>
				</property>
			</bean>
		</constructor-arg>
		<constructor-arg>
			<bean class="org.springframework.webflow.conversation.impl.SessionBindingConversationManager"/>
		</constructor-arg>
	</bean>

It probably should be easier to get this working, since it does by default if we are not in JSF.
column92:
06/Dec/06 3:01 AM;david_syer;Uploaded a patch (SWF-215.zip) that moves all the flow execution logic out of FlowPhaseListener and FlowNavigationHandler into an expanded FlowFacesUtils, and then uses the existing flow executor to locate the required resources.

It works better than the original - redirects are OK, as are continuations, which is a major improvement.  And the config is the same as for normal MVC (i.e. just use <flow:executor/>.

But the FlowExecutor interface is not used at all.  That isn't easy to achieve because the JSF lifecycle is going to need access to the flow, and the ExternalContextHolder pops up all over the place.  FlowExecutorImpl tends to assume that no-one else needs an ExternalContextHolder, so it nulls it out when it's finished with it.
column93: 07/Dec/06 6:58 PM;david_syer;First patch didn't compile (sorry).  Try again...
column94: 28/Feb/07 5:58 AM;kdonald;Made JSF config consistent with Spring MVC / Struts

column1: Ivy file lists junit as a default dependency
column42: Ivy file lists junit as a global dependency. Assume this isn't intended. Is listed as an optional dependency in /readme.txt. Expect it should be under the test configuration only.
column91: 17/Nov/06 10:46 PM;klr8;Not sure this is incorrect. It's a default configuration dependency because of the unit testing support SWF offers in the org.springframework.webflow.test package.
column92: 18/Nov/06 2:44 AM;klr8;After some more thought I don't think this should be changed. Testing is one of the things that SWF should support in the 'default' usage scenario, e.g. the global configuration. So it makes sense to leave it as a global dependency.
column93:
20/Nov/06 1:49 AM;klr8;More ideas:
The problem is basically that if we leave junit.jar as a global depedency, a project that uses SWF and maps its default config to the SWF default config ("default->default") will get junit.jar as one of its default dependencies which will likely be included in for instance the generated war file.

Options:

1) Just remove junit as a global dependency. This is simple but is theoretically not perfect. Will affect very little people in practice since most have junit as a test dependency anyway.

2) Remove junit as a global dependency and add a new "testSupport" configuration that extends global and adds junit as dependency.

3) Exclude junit when expressing the dependency on SWF in the ivy.xml:
<dependency org="org.springframework" name="spring-webflow" rev="1.0">
  <exclude org="junit"/>
</dependency>

Erwin
column94: 20/Dec/06 1:59 AM;klr8;I've added a 'testing' configuration that extends the global configuration and includes junit as a dependency. Projects using SWF can map their 'test' configuration to our 'testing' configuration.

column1: FlowExecutionContinuationGroup.add does not correctly handle updating of a continuation with the same key
column42:
If you call the FlowExecutionContinuationGroup.add method multiple times with the same continuationId, the internal continuations and continuationIds data structures will get out of sync.

This situation will occur with flow refreshes since the FlowExecutorImpl does not generate a new key for a refresh, so it will effectively call the add method with a key that is already in the continuation group.
column91: 05/Nov/06 10:44 PM;klr8;Fixed FlowExecutionContinuationGroup.add().

column1: Binding: locale not correctly handled in NumberFormatter
column42:
See failing unit test NumberFormatterTests for an example.

The binding.format package is not correctly handling the locale in all cases. E.g for BigDecimal, it uses the default locale for parsing, even though e.g. the BigDecimal constructor takes non-locale dependent decimal representations.

To be investigated...
column91:
21/Oct/06 5:04 AM;robvarga;I might be wrong, but the unit test method testParseBigDecimalInGermany in org.springframework.binding.format.support.NumberFormatterTests seems to be wrong.

The error is in line 37:

		assertEquals(new BigDecimal("123.45"), formatter.parseValue("123.45", BigDecimal.class));

The parseValue gets "123.45" as a number and it is supposed to be a German-locale number formatter. However, the decimal separator in German locale is a comma. So correctly the line should be (mind the comma in the first parameter of parseValue):

		assertEquals(new BigDecimal("123.45"), formatter.parseValue("123,45", BigDecimal.class));

Best regards,

Robert
column92:
21/Oct/06 5:08 AM;robvarga;Oh, sorry, that was the point of the unit test to rule out  locale dependency.

Best regards,

Robert
column93: 25/Oct/06 1:59 AM;klr8;I considered the same thing. So this issue basically asks: should the parsing be local independent or local dependent? The reason I got thinking about this was because the BigDecimal constructor parses its input string in a local independent fashion.
column94:
25/Oct/06 3:25 PM;robvarga;Hi Erwin,

if you would allow an outsider's comment:

As far as I saw, you have locale dependency everywhere in those formatters due to the localeContext in the AbstractFormatterFactory.

Also, the parseValue for BigDecimal is working in a locale-dependent manner, because when you have a default locale, the current code goes through a conversion to double in a locale dependent manner in NumberUtils.parseValue(3), and then back to String locale independently. Although, it would be better to write a custom converter to this, because the conversion to double loses precision if there is a locale, and it does not if you don't have a locale.

So I would say, it is rather uniform, it is better to accept it as locale-dependent, and if you want locale-independent behaviour, set a LocaleContext explicitly into your formatter factory.

Best regards,

Robert
column95: 25/Oct/06 11:04 PM;kdonald;moved for investigation in core spring, since swf's binding delegates to number utils.
column96:
25/Oct/06 11:07 PM;kdonald;See also related number utils concern:
http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=30733
column97:
26/Oct/06 5:01 AM;juergen.hoeller;Can we please summarize the current state of the discussion here :-)

There seem to be two main issues, as far as I see:
* locale-dependent number parsing - I'm not quite sure what we can do differently here...
* long-to-float conversion - that seems to be a general issue with the core Java number representation...

So at present, I don't see anything we can do about this in Spring. Any concrete suggestions?

Juergen
column98:
26/Oct/06 5:34 AM;robvarga;Hi Juergen,

A somewhat related issue, but does not strictly belong here:

The 3-parameter version of the NumberUtils.parseValue() method which takes a number format essentially does the following when converting a String to BigDecimal (assuming there is a decimal point character of the locale in the string):

  Double number = Double.valueOf(string);
  return new BigDecimal(number.toString());

This is locale-dependent, which is not important currently. But it also loses information, because the Double has limited precision. 

The 2-parameter version, on the other hand, does not lose information so, because it does new BigDecimal(string).

What I suggest is a custom locale-dependent parser (IMHO locale dependency is a good thing in this case, because for all other classes it is also locale-dependent), which does a conversion of the decimal digit character, drops group separators (if any), and possibly translates any other formatting (e.g. resolves scientific notation and translates that to scale), effectively dropping the locale dependency from the original string, and passes that converted string to the BigDecimal constructor, which expects a string formatted exactly as mentioned here. The point is, not to do a conversion to double in the entire process.

Best regards,

Robert
column99:
27/Oct/06 4:17 AM;juergen.hoeller;I suggest moving this issue back to the Web Flow project, since it is about the NumberFormatter in the binding package having to call the non-locale dependent "NumberUtils.parseNumber(String, Class)" call instead of passing in a NumberFormat for the system Locale there (as per my discussion with Erwin yesterday). Keith - any objections?

As for parsing a String into a BigDecimal without going through a NumberFormat (and its conversion to a double) - that's not a bad idea, but could be a bit tricky in the details (if it's supposed to work for any localized number format). Still, would be worth a separate enhancement request for the Spring core project itself.

Juergen
column100:
26/Dec/06 11:19 PM;klr8;As Juergen mentions, the precision loss in NumberUtils is a Spring core issue/RFE.

After some more thought, I'm following Robert's reasoning here: all of the formatters produced by the SimpleFormatterFactory are Locale aware. It's seem reasonabel and consistent that Number parsing and formatting is also handled in a Locale sensitive manner.

I've updated the NumberFormatterTests to reflect this.

Note that if you want to use a particular Locale during formatting/parsing, you just have to register a TextToNumber converter with the ConversionService that uses a FormatterFactory with the correct Locale installed. Such a ConversionService can be injected into the XmlFlowRegistryFactoryBean.

column93:
27/Mar/07 12:47 AM;nmoyere;For me, there is a bug in the JSF integration that does not retrieve correctly the FlowRepository from the FlowExecutor.

We have the same problem with the following configuration:
	<flow:executor id="flowExecutor" registry-ref="flowDefinitionLocator" repository-type="continuation" />
	
	<flow:registry id="flowDefinitionLocator">
		<flow:location path="/WEB-INF/flows/flow*.xml" />
	</flow:registry>

After a look with the debugger we found that SWF is using a SimpleFlowExecutionRepository by default and it is impossible to change it even if you specify another one explicitly.

We fix it with the patch contained in the attached file. We changed FlowFacesUtil.java to retrieve the FlowRepository from the FlowExecutor.
