column1: Usage of InheritableThreadLocal invites ClassLoader reference leaks
column42:
An almost identical issue was recently fixed by Juergen for Spring core 2.0.1 / 1.2.9: SPR-2258

Usage of InheritableThreadLocal in ExternalContextHolder is the same thing. Instead of duplicating the reasons why you should (almost) never use InheritableThreadLocal in a J2EE environment, I'll just point you to SPR-2258.

I'm not asking to unconditionally remove this, just make it configurable with a safe default.
column91: 27/Oct/06 6:32 PM;klr8;This indeed needs to be scheduled for resolution ASAP. Probably 1.0.1. A solution similar to that implemented by Juergen in core Spring is probably the way to go: make the ThreadLocal variant used configurable at the level of the FlowExecutor.
column92: 31/Oct/06 12:55 AM;klr8;I've looked at this a little bit and maybe we should just drop the ExternalContextHolder entirely. For the moment it's only used by the SessionBindingConversationManager to get access to the ExternalContext. Arguably we should pass the ExternalContext into the ConversationManager.
column93:
06/Nov/06 2:37 AM;klr8;After some more pondering on the issue, I think we should just switch to a normal ThreadLocal. That has 3 benefits:
1) Simple
2) No API impact
3) The flexibility of a ThreadLocal remains (if some internal CoversationManager implementation artifact needs the ExternalContext, it can get access to it without the ExternalContext needing to be passed around everywhere)

The need of an InheritableThreadLocal seems like a very exotic case, so I prefer we just keep it simple and go with ThreadLocal. If some ConversationManager implementation needs to expose the ExternalContext to threads it is spawning it can still do so by either just passing the object in or using it's own InheritableThreadLocal holder.
column94: 10/Nov/06 6:21 AM;klr8;ExternalContextHolder now just uses a ThreadLocal instead of an InheritableThreadLocal.

column1: Should FlowExecutorImpl.refresh put the execution back into the repo?
column42:
Hinted at in post http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=30064
What if a render action, executed on refresh, manipulates e.g. flow scope. That change should remain for the span of flow scope since the semantics of the scope types should be fixed.

Currently FlowExecutorImpl.refresh is not calling executionRepository.putFlowExecution(), which should probably happen to make sure any modifications done to the FlowExecution during the refresh are saved.

Alternatively we should just disallow the change: refresh is supposed to be idempotent, so it should not have any impact on the flow execution at all. So maybe the FlowExecutionImpl.refresh should just setup a read-only RequestControlContext...Makes sense I guess.

Erwin
column91:
10/Oct/06 6:11 AM;ande;I would not like to see the flowExecution saved at the end of a refresh. The current behavior is consistent in that you will receive the same view on each refresh, which is expected from current redirect->refresh metaphor. Allowing side effects in render actions could potentially lead to unexpected results that would be hard to diagnose.

A read-only implementation of RequestContext would be cool, but might be a large change this near to 1.0, with the current interface returning MutableAttributeMap for the various scopes. That might lead to something like an UnmodifiableMutableAttributeMap implementation? Probably not, but it did cross my mind.
column92:
11/Oct/06 6:00 AM;klr8;After some discussion we decided to have the FlowExecutorImpl put the FlowExecution in the flow execution repository after the refresh. However, it will reuse the same key, so no new key will be generated.

This ofcourse opens the door to non-idemponent-refreshes. It's the responsability of the developer to make sure that does not happen.

Note that render actions are allowed to have some side effects, e.g. installing property editors in the flash scope. So those side effects of a technical nature are okay.

column1: FlowPhaseListener does not lock flow execution
column42:
I am having a problem with end states and the way that FlowPhaseListener handles them.  When entering an end state, the end() method in AbstractConversationManager's ConversationProxy is called to attempt to unlock the current FlowExecutionLock.  This fails because there is never any lock acquired on the flow execution, which makes the ReentrantLock code in concurrent throw an Error about illegal lock usage.  Looking at the code, it appears that FlowPhaseListener does not have the exact same functionality that the FlowExecutorImpl for Struts/Spring MVC does (it does not perform any locking/unlocking).  As a result, when my code enters an end state, a stack trace (illegal lock usage) occurs and my application cannot proceed.

I am providing a patch that has addressed this issue.
column43: Spring 2.0-rc4, Spring Web Flow nightly 1.0-rc4-20060925031940, IBM JDK 1.4.2 (WebSphere), concurrent 1.3.4 (for locking in 1.4), JSF
column91: 05/Oct/06 10:32 PM;klr8;This should be fixed in RC4. LocalConversationManager and it's ConversationProxy no longer exist. SessionBindingConversationManager does not do an unlock when a conversation ends.
column92:
06/Oct/06 3:40 AM;agoldstein;I've updated to the latest (final) version of RC4, but still have a problem when doing an externalRedirect.  I think the FlowPhaseListener is trying to save the execution twice - once in prepareResponse() as part of "before" RENDER_RESPONSE, and a second time as part of "after" RENDER_RESPONSE.  If an end state is the selected state in the flow, I believe the conversation no longer exists at the time the second execution of saveFlowExecution() occurs.  I added some code (which exists in the patch I uploaded) that marks the flow execution as "clean" after it has been saved, and that appeared to take care of things for me.  I'm not certain that it's 100% correct in fitting in with the Web Flow lifecycle/needs, however.  Please refer to the stack trace below.

Also, the flowExecutionKey shouldn't be part of the URL for an externalRedirect, should it?

If you would like me to create separate JIRAs for these issues, I'll be more than happy to.

[stack trace - occurred after reaching an end state with an externalRedirect]

12:30:09,252 ERROR [PhaseListenerManager] Exception in PhaseListener RENDER_RESPONSE(6) afterPhase
org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.NoSuchFlowExecutionException: No flow execution could be found with key '_c2F429484-7F27-D75D-C4C6-2F049AE41C1C_kC5ECDF30-A488-12B2-521C-BE67A7EF15F4' -- perhaps this executing flow has ended or expired? This could happen if your users are relying on browser history (typically via the back button) that references ended flows.; nested exception is org.springframework.webflow.conversation.NoSuchConversationException: No conversation could be found with id '2F429484-7F27-D75D-C4C6-2F049AE41C1C' -- perhaps this conversation has ended?
Caused by:
org.springframework.webflow.conversation.NoSuchConversationException: No conversation could be found with id '2F429484-7F27-D75D-C4C6-2F049AE41C1C' -- perhaps this conversation has ended?
        at org.springframework.webflow.conversation.impl.SessionBindingConversationManager$ConversationContainer.getConversation(SessionBindingConversationManager.java:179)
        at org.springframework.webflow.conversation.impl.SessionBindingConversationManager.getConversation(SessionBindingConversationManager.java:85)
        at org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.support.AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository.getConversation(AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository.java:208)
        at org.springframework.webflow.execution.repository.support.AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository.removeFlowExecution(AbstractConversationFlowExecutionRepository.java:113)
        at org.springframework.webflow.executor.jsf.FlowPhaseListener.saveFlowExecution(FlowPhaseListener.java:298)
        at org.springframework.webflow.executor.jsf.FlowPhaseListener.afterPhase(FlowPhaseListener.java:139)
column93:
16/Oct/06 8:23 AM;agoldstein;Sorry for the delay in providing an updated patch - hectic weekend.

The patch works for me when testing external redirects.  I pass null as the flowExecutionKey when creating the external redirect, as it appears this parameter should not be needed by the external URL.

As far as end states go, adding the markClean() method to FlowExecutionHolder and the call of it in FlowPhaseListener#saveFlowExecution() avoids the problem of trying to save a flow execution that has already been removed from the repository (because of the end state functionality) in FlowPhaseListener#afterPhase().  I'm not sure if this is sufficient/100% correct because I'm not completely familiar with when a flow execution must be saved, so please feel free to modify as necessary.

column1: FlowExecutionImplStateRestorer does not restore inline flows correctly
column42:
There is a bug in the FlowExecutionImplStateRestorer.restoreState() method:

It's using an inner helper class FlowSessionFlowDefinitionLocator to lookup the FlowDefinition objects for all the FlowSessions in the restored flow execution. This process is non-trivial because of the inline flow stuff, 
which are 'containing flow local'.  This restoration will fail if top-level root flow A spawns top-level subflow B which spawns 
inline subflow B-0. I don't see how the FlowDefinition of B-0 will be found by the FlowSessionFlowDefinitionLocator...

column1: AbstractFlowRegistryFactoryBean populates registry more than once
column42:
I'm not 100% sure what the behavior should be, but it seems to me that a flow registry produced by an AbstractFlowRegistryFactoryBean should only be populated one time, upon initialization.  As it is in 1.0 RC3, every time getObject() is called on the factory bean, doPopulate(getFlowRegistry()) is called.  If there are multiple references to the flow registry within a Spring application context (as there often are), then the registry will get populated multiple times.

I have subclassed AbstractFlowRegistryFactoryBean and only want the doPopulate() method to get called one time.

If a populate-on-initialization is the correct behavior, then to fix it, you just need to change the getObject() to simply return the flow registry and add a call to doPopulate() in the afterPropertiesSet() method.  I'll attach a patch that does this.
column91: 11/Sep/06 10:21 AM;kweiner;A patch to org.springframework.webflow.registry.AbstractFlowRegistryFactoryBean that calls doPopulate() only once upon initialization.
column92: 12/Sep/06 1:33 AM;kdonald;Patch applied, thanks.

1. What are the dependancies of Spring Web Flow 1.0-rc3 with Spring Framework 1.2.8 ?
2. Are there .pom files for this ?
3. Could these be uploaded to the Maven2 repository with a different version number (e.g. 1.0-rc3-1.2) ?

Thanks, Condor

column1: Error in the dtd file for decision-state (spring-webflow-1.0.dtd)
column42:
Hi,

The attributes "then" and "else" of the "if" element in the decision-state are of type IDREF (instead od CDATA).
Indeed, according to the documentation in the dtd, these attributes can be expressions evaluated at runtime against the request context (e.g. then="${flowScope.previousViewState}").

Matthieu
column91: 09/Sep/06 8:25 AM;kdonald;Corrected in 1.0 RC4; dynamic target state resolver expressions have been removed in 1.0 RC4 in favor of use of decision states.

column1: BeanInvokingActionFactory cannot correctly treat scope mechanism of Spring 2.0
column42:
Spring 2.0 supports new scope mechanism.
WebApplicationContexts support request and session scopes.
However, BeanInvokingActionFactory.createBeanInvokingAction
treat request-scoped bean as flow-scoped bean.
column91: 12/Sep/06 6:41 AM;kdonald;This automagic and 2.0 incompatible behavior has been removed in 1.0 RC4.

column1: Subflow input-mapper requirement causes a catch 22 for flows used both as sub and stand-alone flows
column42:
Discussed at http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=25784

Essentially, for a parent flow to pass flow scope values into a subflow, that subflow MUST declare an input-mapper in it's flow definition. This is new functionality introduced in RC2 I believe.

Once you introduce an input-mapper into the flow definition, that flow can no longer be used as a stand-alone flow. The reason being that the input-mapper required parameter is null.

column1: CLONE -ViewId resolution problem when using facelets in FlowPhaseListener
column42:
Hi,

On a reload of the same page, the FlowPhaseListener uses method isDifferent(ViewString viewId, UIViewRoot viewRoot) to check if we are on the same page. 
In case of facelets usage, that method receives a viewId of the form "/mypage.xhtml" (both for the viewId param and in the viewRoot param). Then the method will check "/mypages" against "/mypages.xhtml" and therefore return true. This forces the creation of a new UIViewRoot tree.

Thanks in advance,
column43: myfaces 1.1.3, spring webflow 1.0 rc2, tomahawk 1.1.3, facelets 1.1.6
column91: 22/Jun/06 12:07 AM;svetsch;I just tested with 1.0-rc3-20060620091739 and the problem seems to be the same. It seems that webflow does not support viewId with extensions (.xhtml in my case) since the method isDifferent(...) try to remove the extension from the UIViewRoot viewId parameter but not to the String viewId parameter.
column92:
26/Jun/06 9:01 PM;svetsch;It's working now with 1.0-rc3. Yan can close the issue !
Thank you,

column1: ViewId resolution problem when using facelets in FlowPhaseListener
column42:
Hi,

On a reload of the same page, the FlowPhaseListener uses method isDifferent(ViewString viewId, UIViewRoot viewRoot) to check if we are on the same page. 
In case of facelets usage, that method receives a viewId of the form "/mypage.xhtml" (both for the viewId param and in the viewRoot param). Then the method will check "/mypages" against "/mypages.xhtml" and therefore return true. This forces the creation of a new UIViewRoot tree.

Thanks in advance,

column1: Dependencies in maven pom contain wrong scope
column42:
SWF rc2 is uploaded to the maven repo, which is great. However allmost all dependencies are declared with scope "compile" so all of these dependencies are included when I build a war file.

My suggestion is: replace the dependencies on all of the spring components by 1 on spring-2.0m5 with scope "provided". The clover dep should be scoped "test". 

According to the SWF wiki the only real dependency of SWF are on spring-binding and ognl. These can be kept in scope "compile". The rest can be scoped "provided".

Saves us from excluding a whole bunch of jars in our poms.
column91: 25/Jun/06 2:09 PM;nebhale;I'll admit to being a bit of a maven novice, but I'm not sure why you'd want those jars to be listed as provided.  My interpretation of the 'provided' scope (http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html) is for something like spec jars.  So for example the servlet-api that would be found in tomcat.  I'm reasonably sure that all of the dependencies that I listed as compile are actually required for compilation, so that's why they are listed that way.  I'll update the mistake of clover on the tests, but can you give me some background on why provided?
column92:
27/Jun/06 5:06 AM;carlos;Ben is right, provided should only for things included in the application server, not many more than the servlet-api.

What probably should be added is <optional>true</optional> to those dependencies that have a lot of chances not to be required. There's a thin line between what should be optional and not, it comes down to a common sense and configuration simplification.
For instance if you can use spring-mvc, jsf or struts, the three should be optional as there are not many chances of using all at the same time
column93:
28/Jun/06 3:07 AM;nebhale;The scopes weren't completely right but I've updated them now.  However, we did not make everything provided, but rather made a lot of stuff optional.  At this time, we're going to upload the poms that way but you can expect in the future some changes to the structure of the projects to better take advantage of Maven's features.

http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MAVENUPLOAD-961

column1: tomahawk should be handled as a separate module in ivy repository
column42: Tomahawk is handled as an artifact in the myfaces module. However, Tomahawk is released as a separate package with its own versioning, so should be treated as a separate module instead. In fact, according to the apache website, tomahawk can be used with other JSF implementations.

column1: DispatchMethodInvoker methodCache should match leniently
column42: This is arguably an enhancement request rather than a bug, but I feel it is exceedingly rare for any reflection-based method lookup to actually want to locate only methods matching the exact class specified per the behavior of java.lang.Class.getMethod.  The easiest way I see to fix this is to use spring-binding's ClassMethodKey object to create the Method in the cache.

column1: JSF view rendering problem on view refresh due to data validation errors
column42:
After upgrading from SWF ea to rc1, if a form has one or more validation errors, all the information entered on that form is lost (ie it reverts to the previous state before the form was submitted).

What this means is that if there is a single validation error on the page all the data entered on that page is lost.

I traced the SWF RC1/MyFaces source code through and it seems that the org.springframework.webflow.executor.jsf.FlowPhaseListener.prepareApplicationView() is always making a call to javax.faces.application.ViewHandler.createView() (implemented by org.apache.myfaces.application.jsp.JspViewHandlerImpl) and sets it in the FacesContext. What createView() does is create a new empty viewRoot, (losing any information submitted in the last request) so when MyFaces renders the view, it refreshes the components from the model, not from the previous request. This logic happens as part of the FlowPhaseListener.beforePhase() when the PhaseEvent's phaseId is PhaseId.RENDER_RESPONSE.

What SWF-ea does (in PlowPhaseListener.prepareView()) is just update the FlowExecutionKey in the FlowExecutionHolder and in the FacesContext.externalContext.requestMap, so when MyFaces renders the view, it still has access to the previous request's components and their state.

Not sure what the appropriate fix is (I haven't delved too much further into the high-level logic of those components), but at the end of the FlowPhaseListener.beforePhase() method, the FacesContext.viewRoot should still have a handle to the viewRoot that was created as part of the form submission.  What I have done for a local fix is to check to see if there are messages in the FacesContext, and if so, leave the existing viewRoot in the FacesContext.
column91: 01/Jun/06 2:21 AM;kdonald;Fixed 1.0 RC2.

column1: PortletFlowController throws NullPointerException on browser refresh or with continuations
column42:
Apologies but I don't have time to fix this at the moment.  Besides which, I feell it's a bigger problem than I can just fix on my own...

The following is based on the way WebSphere Portal works, but it is my understanding that all JSR 168 compliant portlet containers should work in the same way.  I'd be interested if someone could demonstrate the following behaviour in other containers.

The JSR 168 spec describes portlet lifecycle with two states: a render state and an action state.  A portlet starts in its render state eg when a page that portlet is on is requested.  This corresponds to a call to that portlet's doDispatch method.  The doDispatch method for all portlets on the requested page is executed each time that page is requested. 

If we send an action request to one of the portlets on the page ie by posting a form, or clicking on an action URL, that portlet enters its action state.  This corresponds to a call to that portlet's  processAction method.  Only that portlet enters its action state and only its processAction method is executed.  However, once its action state is complete, the render state of all portlets on the current page is entered, and each portlet's doDispatch method is executed.

Most importantly, if you trigger the browser's back or refresh functionality, the page being refreshed or returned to is requested again, triggering the doDispatch method for each portlet on that page, but the processAction method is not re-executed for any of these portlets.

If we have a look at the PortletFlowController class, it has a handleRenderRequestInternal method and a handleActionRequestInternal method - these correspond to the aforementioned render and action states, respectively.  

The handleRenderRequestInternal first checks if a conversation exists: if it doesn't, eg if this is the first view state in the flow, the flow executor is called to launch a new flow, and its response instruction is used to create the first view; if it does, the response instruction from the last action state is retrieved (and then removed) from the session and used to transition to the next view state.

The handleActionRequestInternal performs whatever processing is defined in the flow and then stores its response instruction on the session for the subsequent view state.

The problem here is that if you trigger the browser's back or refresh functionality, the handleRenderRequestInternal method is re-executed for each portlet on the page without a preceding handleActionRequestInternal method, so the session is empty, which means responseInstruction is null, and so a NullPointerException is thrown when the toModelAndView method calls response.isApplicationView().

Further, consider using continuations.  The flow executor which handles continuations is called within the handleActionRequestInternal method, but if you use the browser's back button to access a portal page, only the handleRenderRequestInternal method is executed for the portlets on that page, and the result is a NullPointerException again.

I propose leaving the response instruction on the session after it is retrieved during the render state.  Further, I think that continuation handling needs to be moved to the handleRenderRequestInternal method.
column91:
02/Jun/06 5:58 AM;kdonald;Added support for "refreshing" flow execution on render request when no cached response instruction is in the session.  This should sufficiently support browser refresh capability.

Joe, I'm a little unclear why continuations would be advantageous in a Portal environment, since you'd mostl ikely be manipulating portlets within a portal page--and the individual portlets could not be manipulated with the browser nav buttons.
column92: 09/Nov/10 2:44 AM;bacsik;We are testing back functionality in liferay, and have problems with restoring the right portlet state, GET-After-POST is enabled on the portlet and putting the executionKey as Render Parameter (so it is submitted as a GET Request Parameter, if back is pressed) does not help either. We have seen that the executionKey ist stored in the javax.ViewState parameter and if there are more session based render informations then situation can become worse. I suggest that the only information is the executionKey and is stored as a request parameter and is read as a request parameter, as is in a non portlet environment.

column1: Portlet sample portlet.xml missing required tag
column42:
If you try to validate the portlet.xml file in the Spring Web Flow 1.0 RC1 samples (phonebook-portlet) it will not validate.  Here is the error as reported by the XMLBuddy eclipse plugin.

The content of element 'portlet' is not complete. One of '{"http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/portlet/portlet-app_1_0.xsd":supported-locale, "http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/portlet/portlet-app_1_0.xsd":resource-bundle, "http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/portlet/portlet-app_1_0.xsd":portlet-info}' is expected.	

Specifically, at least one portal (uPortal 2.5.2) will fail to render this portlet without this fix.  Adding in a simple <portlet-info> tag with a contained <title> tag fixed the validation problem and allows it to run in uPortal.

It is important to realize this is not a bug in any portal, the portlet.xml schema requires an element that is missing.  Some portals may more lenient then others in accepting portlet.xml code that does not validate.
column91: 08/May/06 9:18 AM;holdorph;The sample portlet application portlet.xml fixed so it will validate.
column92: 02/Jun/06 6:01 AM;kdonald;fixed 1.0 rc2

column1: Unhandled exception thrown during action bean method execution results in serialization failure
column42:
Portlet built using Spring MVC and Spring Web Flow.  Unhandled exception (does not seem to matter what class of exception) thrown during action bean method execution results in the following being logged, approx once every second:

[3/05/06 19:04:44:203 EST] 00000021 JMXObjectOutp E   ADMC0001E: Unable to serialize object: [ActionState@216170dd id = 'myAction', flow = 'flow', entryActionList = [ActionList@217630dd actions = list[[empty]]], exceptionHandlerSet = [StateExceptionHandlerSet@217430dd exceptionHandlers = list[[empty]]], actionList = [ActionList@217e30dd actions = list[[AnnotatedAction@203f70dd targetAction = exceptiontestportlet.MyFormAction@5f76b0df, attributes = map['method' -> [MethodSignature@20cf30dd methodName = 'doAction', parameters = [Parameters@20a6b0dd parameters = list[[empty]]]]]]]], transitions = [TransitionSet@217230dd transitions = list[[Transition@279e30dd matchingCriteria = [eventId = 'success'], executionCriteria = [TransitionCriteriaChain@27d1f0dd criteriaChain = list[[empty]]], targetStateResolver = [targetStateId = 'two'], attributes = map[[empty]]]]], exitActionList = [ActionList@217030dd actions = list[[empty]]]]
[3/05/06 19:04:44:516 EST] 00000021 GenericSerial E   ADMC0008E: The system failed to marshall the object of type [Ljava.lang.Object;: org.springframework.webflow.ActionState

Simple web flow definition as follows - doAction method merely throws java.lang.Exception:
<textarea>
<flow start-state="one">

  	<view-state id="one" view="1">
		<transition on="continue" to="myAction"/>
	</view-state>
	
	<action-state id="myAction">
		<action bean="myAction" method="doAction"/>	
		<transition on="success" to="two"/>
	</action-state>
 
	<end-state id="two" view="2"/>  	
	
</flow>
</textarea>

Typical application context as follows:
<textarea>
<beans>
	<!-- Creates the registry of flow definitions for this application -->
	<bean id="flowLocator" class="org.springframework.webflow.registry.XmlFlowRegistryFactoryBean">
		<property name="flowLocations" value="/WEB-INF/webflow/flow.xml"/>
	</bean>
	
	<!-- Implementation of the HandlerMapping interface to map from the current PortletMode to request handler beans -->
	<bean id="portletModeControllerMapping" class="org.springframework.web.portlet.handler.PortletModeHandlerMapping">
		<property name="portletModeMap">
			<map>
				<entry key="view" value-ref="viewController"/>
			</map>
		</property>
    </bean>
    
	<bean id="viewController" class="org.springframework.webflow.executor.mvc.PortletFlowController">
		<property name="flowLocator" ref="flowLocator"/>
		<property name="defaultFlowId" value="flow"/>
	</bean>
	
	<bean id="myAction" class="exceptiontestportlet.MyFormAction"/>
	
	<!-- ResourceViewResolver -->
	<bean id="viewResolver" class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.InternalResourceViewResolver">
		<property name="prefix" value="/pages/"/>
		<property name="suffix" value=".jsp"/>
		<property name="viewClass" value="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.JstlView"/>
	</bean>
</beans>
</textarea>

Problem does not occur if exception-handler is defined in the flow to catch the type of exception being thrown.  What is Web Flow trying to serialize here?  We are not even using continuations.

column1: Code in documentation section 5.3.1 is incorrect
column42:
The code samples in section 5.2.2 and 5.2.3 in the reference documentation currently read:

<bean name="/flowController.htm" class="org.springframework.webflow.executor.mvc.FlowController">
      <constructor-arg ref="flowExecutor"/>
</bean>

The code should read:

<bean name="/flowController.htm" class="org.springframework.webflow.executor.mvc.FlowController">
     <property name="flowExecutor ref="flowExecutor" />
</bean>

The problem is that there are no constructor arguments for FlowController.

column1: Context relative redirect after flow completion
column42:
The redirect: prefix isn't currently usable from an end-state (as it attempts to do a conversation redirect - which is not supported from a end-state) [it is resulting in a NPE].
Achieving a context relative redirect from an end-state using the externalRedirect: prefix is possible, but the syntax is not very nice.
The suggestion is to use the redirect: prefix from an end-state to perform a context relative redirect after flow completion.

Please see this thread details: http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?t=23020
column91: 22/Mar/06 4:00 AM;kdonald;Resolved as suggested.

column91:
17/Jan/06 3:08 PM;swamp_ig;If you've got a hidden field with the flow execution ID in it, you don't also need to have it set in the form's submit URL.

Set it in one place or the other, not both.

Generaly you're best off leaving it in the hidden field, if you have it in the URL then it will show up in the browser's URL on the page, and will be used in a bookmark if the user bookmarks the page, and since the ID is not valid for long periods the bookmark would quickly break.
column92:
08/Feb/06 10:10 AM;cyberyodacy;I have recently ran into similar situation, where I got the same error.
I reordered the search and details flows example. I wanted to reuse search flow in different places.
Therefore, at the selection page of the search flow, I use href="<c:url value="?_flowExecutionId=${flowExecutionId}&_eventId=finish&..."/>">.
When I clicked on it, it did bring me back to the parent flow, where I displayed editable details page.
When I tried to submit the form, I got the said error.

I think what happened is that the _flowExecutionId is only defined in my jsp page once as a hidden field. However, it is also part of the query string, when I used <a href...>.
I can remove the hidden field, but now the _eventId is alwaysequal to "finish".

Finally, I used javascript and hidden field in the selection page, and the problem went away.

My question is what I did wrong when I used the get option?

column1: NPE in ExpiredFlowCleanupFilter.
column42:
java.lang.NullPointerException
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.servlet.ExpiredFlowCleanupFilter.doCleanup(ExpiredFlowCleanupFilter.java:131)
	org.springframework.webflow.execution.servlet.ExpiredFlowCleanupFilter.doFilterInternal(ExpiredFlowCleanupFilter.java:106)
	org.springframework.web.filter.OncePerRequestFilter.doFilter(OncePerRequestFilter.java:76)

The problem is in the flowExecution.getActiveSession().getFlow().getId() call.

If you have an old flowExecutionId passed in for which there is no longer an entry in the session, it will come out to be expired, but there is no flow object, so getFlow() call returns null.

The way to reproduce the issue is to execute a flow, then bring down the tomcat, start it back up and just refresh the page.  This will cause the NPE.
column91: 25/Oct/05 10:33 AM;kdonald;I'm not sure why activeSession.flow would be null --- it should throw an IllegalStateException if anything, but the Flow definiiton should never be null.  In any case, this is incorrect: the logging stmt should printout flowExecution.getRootFlow().
column92:
26/Oct/05 4:15 PM;aantono;Keith, the reason the flow is null instead of the IllegalStateException being thrown is due to Tomcat's session persistance.

If you shut down tomcat, the session is being persisted on disk, and once started back up, that same session is being loaded back into the  HTTPSession.  So when the first request is being passed through the filter, the flow controller does not have a chance to throw any exceptions yet, but the flowExecution object is available to be grabbed from session.  And becuase the flow inside the activeSession object is transient, it does not get persisted during Tomcat's session saving, thus it comes out as null in this case.
column93: 14/Dec/05 2:42 PM;kdonald;Fixed 1.0 M1

column1: Error creating action bean logs only FlowArtifactLookupException with "chain exhausted" message
column42: If Spring has a problem creating an action bean (bad property being set or whatever), a flow that tries to use that action will log only a FlowArtifactLookupException with the mesage "Chain exhausted looking for flow with id: XXX". This is because the chain lookup class doesn't make a distinction between erorrs when it tries to call the flow artifact locators in the chain. It just swallows and ingnores all errors. It should ignore only bean not found errors...

column1: Conversion: source class assignable to target class is incorrectly considered for conversion

column1: validator method requires formObjectType to be set
column42:
When trying to use a validator method, I was getting a pretty deeply nested NullPointerException:

org.springframework.webflow.ActionExecutionException: Exception thrown executing action 'com.commercepoint.superquote.webflow.action.VendorSignupActions@a010ba' in state 'page1' of flow 'vendorSignupFlow'; nested exception is java.lang.NullPointerException: null
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker.getParameterTypesString(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:168)
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker.getSignature(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:206)
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker$1.create(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:65)
	at org.springframework.util.CachingMapDecorator.get(CachingMapDecorator.java:143)
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker.getDispatchMethod(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:217)
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker.dispatch(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:230)
	at org.springframework.webflow.action.FormAction.invokeValidatorMethod(FormAction.java:729)
	at org.springframework.webflow.action.FormAction.doValidate(FormAction.java:703)
	at org.springframework.webflow.action.FormAction.bindAndValidate(FormAction.java:554)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585)
	at org.springframework.webflow.util.DispatchMethodInvoker.dispatch(DispatchMethodInvoker.java:231)
	at org.springframework.webflow.action.MultiAction.doExecute(MultiAction.java:138)
	at org.springframework.webflow.action.AbstractAction.execute(AbstractAction.java:225)
	at org.springframework.webflow.ActionExecutor.execute(ActionExecutor.java:65)
	at org.springframework.webflow.AnnotatedAction.execute(AnnotatedAction.java:154)
	at org.springframework.webflow.ActionExecutor.execute(ActionExecutor.java:65)
	at org.springframework.webflow.support.ActionTransitionCriteria.test(ActionTransitionCriteria.java:87)
	at org.springframework.webflow.support.TransitionCriteriaChain.test(TransitionCriteriaChain.java:65)
	at org.springframework.webflow.Transition.canExecute(Transition.java:239)

[ETC ETC]

...which wasn't very descriptive of the problem, so I had to dig around in the source.  It seems that since setFormObjectType was not invoked, the parameter types of the validator method invoker was not set.  In my case, I wasn't setting formObjectType because I'm overriding loadFormObject.

At the very least, this issue report is asking for:  (1) more descriptive error reporting in case of improper use; (2) better documentation as to how custom validator methods may be invoked, perhaps within FormAction.

However, you may also want to consider removing the requirement that formObjectType must be set.  I see that it's now necessary since the validator method is typed to the form object type... but is this signature necessary?  Why not just use the same signature as Validator.validate()?
column91: 11/Aug/05 11:33 AM;jimn;Of course I mean formObjectClass, not formObjectType.  oops!
column92: 12/Aug/05 1:47 AM;klr8;I've changed FormAction so that it now only sets the parameter types and the target of the validateMethodDispatcher when it's actually going to invoke a validator method. If no formObjectClass is set, it just uses Object so in that case the signature of the validator methods should be something like 'methodName(Object, Errors)', if a formObjectClass is specified, it will be used as parameter type so the signature then becomes 'methodName(FormObjectClass, Errors)'.

column1: incorrect error message when NoSuchTransition from subflow to parent
column42:
This is reported against SWF Preview 3.

When a subflow completes successfully and its returned event does not match up with the transitions defined in the <subflow-state> declaration of the parent, the error message accompanying the stack trace incorrectly states that the NSTE happened in the subflow.  The error message is furthermore confusing because it contradictorily states that the transition doesn't exist, and goes on to list the signaled eventId and transitional criteria, which DO match up.  

In this example, "submitForApprovalFlow" is the subflow (which has already completed successfully according to the debug log):

org.springframework.web.flow.NoMatchingTransitionException: No transition was matched to the event(s) signaled by the 1 action(s) that executed in this action state 'bind' of flow 'submitForApprovalFlow'; transitions must be defined to handle action result outcomes -- possible flow configuration error? Note: the eventIds signaled were: 'array['success']', while the supported set of transitional criteria for this action state is 'array['success', 'error']'

at org.springframework.web.flow.State.enter(State.java:164)

column1: misleading NoMatchingTransitionException message on chained action-states
column42:
When i execute two chained action states where the second action bean fires an event with id that is missing the message in the thrown NoMatchingTransitionException refers to the first action instead of the second one. Definitely a minor thing but still annoying.

Consider this:

<webflow id="applicationFlow" start-state="action0">
	<action-state id="action0">
		<action bean="applicationAction" method="returnNext"/>
		<transition on="next" to="action1"/>
	</action-state>
	<action-state id="action1">
		<action bean="applicationAction" method="returnNext"/>
		<transition on="success" to="end"/>
	</action-state>
	<end-state id="end" view="end"/>
</webflow>

    public Event returnNext(RequestContext ctx)
    {
        return new Event(this, "next");
    }

executing this flow gives this exception message:

org.springframework.webflow.NoMatchingTransitionException: No transition was matched to the event(s) signaled by the 1 action(s) that executed in this action state 'action0' of flow 'applicationFlow'; transitions must be defined to handle action result outcomes -- possible flow configuration error? Note: the eventIds signaled were: 'array<String>['next']', while the supported set of transitional criteria for this action state is 'array<TransitionCriteria>['next']'

The correct message should refer to satate 'action1' and the TransitionCriteria array printed at the end of the message should contain 'success'.

column1: Errors not bound to BindingActionForm on exception
column42:
i mentioned this in the forums, but i figure it should be filed as a bug.

http://forum.springframework.org/viewtopic.php?t=5848#23203

to summarize, if an exception is thrown in the flow, the spring Errors object is not bound to BindingActionForm which means that your views will throw an exception if they try to access the form.

this is a problem if you try to handle the exception through the struts exception handlers and then return back to the original form.

since the binding of Errors to BindingActionForm occurs in a FlowListener, some possible solutions might be:

1. change this so the binding occurs in a finally block instead of in a listener

2. add a new type of flow event that gets called regardless of whether an exception is thrown, like requestEnded or something... then having the Errors->BindingActionForm stuff listen for this type of event.

#2 might be generally useful

column1: Sandbox -> Spring Web Flow -> MultiAction always uses "this" as delegate
column42:
This pertains to Spring Web Flow in the Sandbox.

org.springframework.web.flow.action.MultiAction

has a setter/getter for the property "delegate" which by default is set to "this"

However, getDelegate() always returns "this".  If someone sets the delegate property, it will be ignored.  getDelegate() should return "delegate".

column1: subflow form object with same name shadows main flow after returning
column42:
I'm attaching a sample test case (you'll need to change the package names from webflow to web.flow to test with PR3).  This test case works fine in SWF PR3, and causes an error in the jsp page for SWF PR4 and also the current snapshot of SWF in cvs.  

The scenario:

- A main form submits to a sub form, which collects and validates information and returns to the main form; there is a main flow and a sub flow
- The flows use different objects, but the form object names are the same (since flow scope is used, this should be okay, as far as I understand)
- If the sub flow returns without doing anything, there is no problem
** If the sub flow performs bindAndValidate before returning, the main form does not set a form object in the request, even when setupForm is first called; this results in an unexpected error on the page when trying to access non-existent fields on the named bean (in PR3, if setupForm is called, all is well, but if setupForm is not called, the same error occurs)

In the sample to be attached:

- clicking "ok" in the main form, and "cancel" in the subform causes no problem.
- clicking "ok" in the main form, and "ok" in the subform causes the following error:

org.springframework.beans.NotReadablePropertyException: Invalid property
'a' of bean class [SubBean]: Bean property 'a' is not readable or has an
invalid getter method: Does the return type of the getter match the parameter
type of the setter?
	at org.springframework.beans.BeanWrapperImpl.getPropertyValue(BeanWrapperImpl.java:652)
	at org.springframework.beans.BeanWrapperImpl.getPropertyValue(BeanWrapperImpl.java:644)
	at org.springframework.validation.BindException.getFieldValue(BindException.java:333)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.support.BindStatus.<init>(BindStatus.java:117)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.tags.BindTag.doStartTagInternal(BindTag.java:115)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.tags.RequestContextAwareTag.doStartTag(RequestContextAwareTag.java:68)
	at _jsp._WEB_22dINF._jsp._main__jsp._jspService(WEB-INF/jsp/main.jsp:11)
	at com.caucho.jsp.JavaPage.service(JavaPage.java:63)
	at com.caucho.jsp.Page.pageservice(Page.java:570)
	at com.caucho.server.dispatch.PageFilterChain.doFilter(PageFilterChain.java:159)
	at com.caucho.server.webapp.DispatchFilterChain.doFilter(DispatchFilterChain.java:115)
	at com.caucho.server.dispatch.ServletInvocation.service(ServletInvocation.java:208)
	at com.caucho.server.webapp.RequestDispatcherImpl.forward(RequestDispatcherImpl.java:268)
	at com.caucho.server.webapp.RequestDispatcherImpl.forward(RequestDispatcherImpl.java:106)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.view.InternalResourceView.renderMergedOutputModel(InternalResourceView.java:97)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.view.AbstractView.render(AbstractView.java:250)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.render(DispatcherServlet.java:928)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doDispatch(DispatcherServlet.java:705)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doService(DispatcherServlet.java:625)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.serviceWrapper(FrameworkServlet.java:386)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.doPost(FrameworkServlet.java:355)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:152)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:90)
	at com.caucho.server.dispatch.ServletFilterChain.doFilter(ServletFilterChain.java:99)
	at com.caucho.server.webapp.WebAppFilterChain.doFilter(WebAppFilterChain.java:163)
	at com.caucho.server.dispatch.ServletInvocation.service(ServletInvocation.java:208)
	at com.caucho.server.http.HttpRequest.handleRequest(HttpRequest.java:259)
	at com.caucho.server.port.TcpConnection.run(TcpConnection.java:341)
	at com.caucho.util.ThreadPool.runTasks(ThreadPool.java:490)
	at com.caucho.util.ThreadPool.run(ThreadPool.java:423)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:595)
column91:
19/Jul/05 7:39 PM;klr8;This is actually normal, at least with the current implementation.

The problem is not the form object itself, which -- as you indicate -- in in the flow scope and thus seperate for the main and sub flow. It's actually the Errors instance that's causing the problem. By default the Errors instance will be in the request scope, which is shared between main and sub flow since it is linked to the request which passes from sub flow back up to the parent flow (or visa versa).

Here's a scenario:
When the sub flow does a bindAndValidate, an Errors instance wrapping a SubBean with name "form" will be put in the request. The sub flow ends and the main flow continues.
The main flow performs a setupForm, which detects the existing "form" object in the main flow scope and as a result does nothing: e.g. the form object "form" in the flow scope and the errors instance in the request scope are left untouched. This is where PR4 differs from PR3: PR3 was always overwriting the form object and Errors instance with fresh copies.
We now have an inconsistent situation: the flow scope contains a "form" MainBean, while the request scope contains an Errors instance wrapping a "form" SubBean. When you hit the JSP, the spring:bind tag runs into trouble since it uses the Errors instance, which it expects to wrap a MainBean. So you get the exception you see: "Invalid property 'a' of bean class [SubBean]: Bean property 'a' is not readable or has an invalid getter method: Does the return type of the getter match the parameter type of the setter?"

There are a few possible work-arounds:
1: use different names for the form objects in the main and sub flow
2: put the Errors instance in flow scope by setting the "errorsScopeAsString" property to "flow"
3: use the new resetForm() action method offered by the FormAction when returning from the sub flow (this is now in CVS) -- keep in mind however that this will completely reset the parent flow form object and errors instance!

I'm going to discuss this with Keith to see how we can best solve this issue.
column92:
19/Jul/05 7:43 PM;klr8;Another possible work-around:

4) Configure the parent FormAction to do "bindOnSetupForm". This will cause it to overwrite the Errors instance in the request scope. This is ofcourse also a hacky solution...
column93:
19/Jul/05 8:30 PM;klr8;Been thinking a bit about this and some of the possibilities I see are:

- Don't do anything about it, just put some test code in the FormAction that verifies that the form object and Errors instance are in sync. If not, it throws a descriptive exception.
- Same as previous, but when the FormAction detects that the Errors instance is not in sync with the form object, it generates a new empty Errors instance (e.g. in setupForm()).
- Provide a new action execution method on FormAction: resetErrors(), similar to resetForm(), but it just resets the form
- We could have the EndState clear out all Errors instances in the request scope when ending a subflow. But this would also involve changing the FormAction so that it detects that it still has a form object, but there no longer is a corresponding Errors instance. Right now we're using the presence of the form object as an indication that both the form object and the associated Errors instance are there...this seems flawed and should probably change.


So far I'm leaning toward putting detection code in the FormAction and have it rectify the situation, e.g. regenerating a fresh Errors instance on setupForm().

Any other ideas?
column94: 21/Jul/05 3:53 AM;klr8;I've added detection logic to the FormAction to detect a situation where the form object is not the same as the target object wrapped by the Errors instance. If that situation is encountered, a new Errors object will be generated for the form object. An informative message will also be logged.

column91:
03/Apr/17 2:36 PM;martin-drozdik;The issue was probably caused by me having installed Java 1.9. instead of 1.8:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/43141563/how-to-solve-the-unable-to-find-asm-for-stackmap-generation-error-on-startup-o

After removing Java 1.9 and setting environment variables to Java 1.8. the problem went away.
column92:
04/Apr/17 7:12 AM;mlippert;Glad to hear that you found a solution to this and got it working.

And yes, the weaving that we use under the hood is not yet Java9 ready. We plan to be Java9 ready for the 3.9.0 release, scheduled for July 2017.

column1: In STS, sleuth causes the compile error: Build path is incomplete. Cannot find class file for org/tmatesoft/svn/core/wc2/SvnOperationFactory #667
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
If you create a spring boot application and you add spring-cloud-config-server and spring-cloud-starter-sleuth dependencies, STS (after cleaned and rebuilt) produce the error: 

"Build path is incomplete. Cannot find class file for org/tmatesoft/svn/core/wc2/SvnOperationFactory" 

I have created the next simple project as an example:
https://github.com/cesargithub5/ConfigServer

Also, this issue was raised first in:
https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-config/issues/667
column43:
OS X El Capitan 10.11.6, 
java version "1.8.0_77"
Spring boot 1.5.2.RELEASE
Spring cloud Camden.SR6
column91: 16/Mar/17 1:43 PM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column92:
22/Mar/17 9:18 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
After some debugging, a longer version of the error which has more inforamtion in it (but is only possible to get if you turn on some DEBUG constant in STS)... is this:

```
Class dependency error 'org/tmatesoft/svn/core/SVNException' occurred on aspect definition 'Aspect definition [/ConfigServer/src/main/java/com/test/conf/Application.java:-1] advise type [after] advise [org.springframework.cloud.sleuth.instrument.scheduling.TraceSchedulingAspect.traceBackgroundThread(org.aspectj.lang.ProceedingJoinPoint)]' while processing bean 'environmentRepository (-1) [org.springframework.cloud.config.server.environment.SvnKitEnvironmentRepository]'. Check if builder classpath is complete
```   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column93:
22/Mar/17 9:40 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Things we could consider doing:

 - not showing up any errors around building the aop-references model into project error markers (maybe we could try just showing them in error log or aop event trace log or something)
 - showing them, but demote them to warnings.
 - showing the more detailed version instead of the very confusing 'short form' we get now. The short form just leaves one totally in the dark which  aspect / advice was responsible for an error showing up 'out of the blue'.
 -  disable the AOP reference model builder by default.

I'm not really sure which of these options we should go for (if any). 

I guess a key question is, how many folks would miss the AOP reference model if was no longer being built by STS.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column94:
22/Mar/17 10:03 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
For the time being I'm just pushing a change the makes the error message more detailed (i.e. pinpointing the specific advice). That seems like it would at least be a safe / good to do.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column95:
23/Mar/17 9:53 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Making the error message more detailed sounds good to me. We still need to find out why this happens and decide then whether this is really an error that should be reported or more a warning.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column96:
23/Mar/17 11:30 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I'm guessing a bit, but I think the AOP references model is there to do somethings in AJDT ui, like showing advice markers and navigating into them.

If that's true then absence of this model doesn't break the project, but it could make this AJDT ui stuff not work (i.e. no advice markers etc.).

If I'm right about this, then its a bit confusing to show an error marker on the project, which to the users makes it look like there's something wrong with their project.

I just don't feel very confident about any of this, as I'm not entirely sure what tha AOPreferences model is really for.    
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column97:
27/Mar/17 2:24 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I would like to move this beyond the 3.8.4 release. Ok?   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column98:
27/Mar/17 3:03 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Sure.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141866135
column99:
07/Apr/17 8:18 AM;mlippert;We closed this issue tracker and migrated this issue over to GitHub:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues/105

column1: pom-Element "build/pluginManagement/plugins" leads to "Plugin execution not covered by lifecycle configuration"
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I followed the instructions in
https://docs.spring.io/spring-roo/docs/2.0.0.RC1/reference/html/#resources-issue-tracking, chapter 8
to create a roo-project witch Project-Type "Multimodule-Standard".
The main-module was the only Eclipse-Project without the Error "Plugin execution not covered by lifecycle configuration".
To solve this i copied the content from the pom-Element "build/pluginManagement/plugins" of the main-module to all other Modules in the workspace.
The component that creates Project-Type "Multimodule-Standard" should be corrected for generating working POMs.
column91:
14/Mar/17 2:38 PM;jcgarcia;Hi!

Which version of STS are you using? We've applied some improvements in the STS Spring Roo plugin that should solve your problem. 

This changes will be available in 3.8.4.RELEASE version .. but nowadays 3.8.3.RELEASE is the last release of the Spring Tool Suite.

If the error persist after the release, let us know!

Best Regards
column92: 14/Mar/17 5:11 PM;mlippert;So I mark this as resolved for 3.8.4.

If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: bean constructor argument validator erroneously checks abstract beans
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Create a minimal Spring project.

Add the following 2 beans in a bean definition xml file:


    <!-- This is an abstract bean, the constructor argument count validator should not report a problem, but it does -->
    <bean id="abstractParent" class="java.util.Date" abstract="true">
        <constructor-arg index="0" value="1" />
        <constructor-arg index="1" value="1" />
    </bean> 
    
    <bean parent="abstractParent">
        <constructor-arg index="2" value="1" />
    </bean>

The validator complained on the abstractParent bean that java.util.Date doesn't have a 2-argument constructor even though that bean definition is abstract.
column91: 12/Mar/17 11:57 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141554905
column92:
07/Apr/17 8:19 AM;mlippert;We closed this issue tracker and migrated this issue over to GitHub:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues/106

column1: Add Eclipse Data Tools Back into STS
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: In STS 3.7, there was a "data management" view available that had the Data Explorer. That is missing from the default 3.8.3 STS download, and can only be added back by manually installing the Eclipse Data Tools (http://download.eclipse.org/datatools/1.14.0.201701131441/repository/). It'd be great to have that back in the standard download of STS.
column91: 09/Mar/17 4:18 PM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141418931
column92:
09/Mar/17 4:20 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
We removed the Eclipse Data Tools from the STS distribution due to issues our users observed from having those components in their install. Therefore I am hesitant to bring them back by default.

Instead we will add an entry to the extension dashboard to make it a one-click experience to install them into an installed STS distro.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/141418931
column93: 11/Mar/17 8:32 AM;mlippert;I added Eclipse Data Tools as an item to the dashboard extension listing. Mark this as fixed for 3.8.4, but this is already available for all 3.8.x installs of STS.
column94:
07/Apr/17 7:52 AM;mlippert;We moved issue tracking for this project to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide.
If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Downloading 64 bit for windows - seems to be for 32 bit.
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: Please confirm that the 64 bit is the correct download. If not, why am I getting "STS - Java was started but returned exit code = 13..."
column91: 01/Mar/17 8:32 AM;mlippert;Yes, I can confirm that the 64bit version of STS is indeed the 64bit version of STS. Please make sure that you have a 64bit JDK installed on your machine and that JAVA_HOME is set to that JDK. You can also specify the exact location of the JDK to run STS in the sts.ini file (in a similar way than people do for Eclipse in the eclipse.ini file), for example explained here: https://wiki.eclipse.org/Eclipse.ini
column92: 10/Apr/17 11:39 AM;mlippert;I am closing this one here as works as designed. If you still come across this issue or would like to follow up, please open a new issue at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide (since we moved issue tracking over there).

column1: Freeze when right-clicking on project in project explorer
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
After starting a workspace, when I do a right-click on an existing project in the project explorer, Eclipse freezes on my system i. e. the context menu does not open and Eclipse does not react on input anymore. The freeze lasts serveral minutes.

When I disable the internet connection before loading a workspace then I can perform a right-click as usual. Right after the right-click, a "Secure storage" dialog promts for a password (see attached image). After entering the password the context menu opens and everything works - even when I enable my internet connection afterwards.

Thread dump:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=266810

Ticket on bugs.eclipse.org:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=511941
column91: 20/Feb/17 9:42 AM;nicolas.peifer;Password dialog
column92: 21/Feb/17 4:32 PM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/140328571
column93:
01/Mar/17 9:14 PM;kdvolder;I've addressed some problems were our code was blocking the UI thread. 

However, I do not know where the secure storage dialog is coming from and I do not see any hints in the stacktrace about this. So I didn't do anything about that.
column94: 02/Mar/17 11:56 AM;mlippert;The freeze is being resolved and committed, so I am closing this one here, with the 3.8.4 release to include the fix.

If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Maven dependencies with <classifier> tag are not resolved within the project opened
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
If I have a Maven project that use the <classifier> tag with the <maven-jar-plugin>, the dependency is solved only with the project closed.

The Maven Dependencies section reports the correct jar (with the classifier) only if its own project is closed.

If the project is opened in the workspace, the Maven Dependencies section includes the Project itself, but the dependencies are not solved because of the classifier.

I have reported this question in StackOverflow:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/42119023/maven-project-in-spring-tool-suite-dependency-is-not-resolved-with-classifier-t

I think this is a bug of STS, and should be solved!

Thanks in advance.
AlessandroC
column91: 09/Feb/17 9:45 AM;mlippert;This sounds like a bug or limitation in the general Maven support for Eclipse (the m2e project). Therefore I would recommend to report this against that project here: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=m2e
column92: 10/Apr/17 11:42 AM;mlippert;I am closing this one here as a duplicate of a possible bug at m2e. If you would like to re-open or follow-up with STS-specific issues, please file a new issue at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide (since we moved issue tracking to GitHub). Thanks!!!

column91: 31/Jan/17 7:12 PM;tristan107;After investigation, this bug is known for Eclipse Neon, and there are a few workarounds like switching to GTK2 : https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=497705
column92: 01/Feb/17 9:44 AM;mlippert;Ok, thanks for the follow-up. Will close this as a duplicate of the bug at Eclipse.
column93: 01/Feb/17 10:00 PM;tristan107;See here for a quick workaround : http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41983135/eclipse-neon-customize-perspective-provokes-a-stackoverflowerror
column94: 02/Feb/17 3:36 PM;mlippert;Thanks for posting the additional URL, much appreciated.

column1: STS crashes during normal UI operations (opening a class, using completion, etc)
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I am having repeated and unpredictable crashes using STS with Java 8u121.

Two recent examples were:

* crash on opening a class file in the project view
* crash on clicking an autocompleted object name

I tried upgrading from 3.8.2 to 3.8.3 but the problem persists.

29/Jan/17 4:51 AM;quiescer;I think the cause was a faulty RAM stick. After logging this I ran Memtest+ and found it was giving a *lot* of errors. Then I removed the stick and the system completed a pass without error.

column1: Source lookup for tcServer hosted apps is empty
column10:

column42:
Starting with STS 3.8.3, the Source Lookup for a web application hosted within a tcServer instance shows empty.
The tcServer works just fine and application functions normally, the problem is with debugging - especially into dependent libraries source code (like spring framework, etc).
Setting a break point in the code (including dependent libraries code) is being handled properly, the execution stops - but it shows a blank page stating it cannot find the source code (and a button to edit the source lookup path).

Note that versions 3.8.2 and prior were working just fine.
column91: 05/Jan/17 5:06 PM;mlippert;That is strange. I will take a look.
column92:
10/Jan/17 8:18 PM;nsingh;I was able to reproduce this issue when debugging a web app in tcServer in STS 3.8.3.

Adding a Tomcat source path computer using the following extension point seems to solve the problem:

org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcePathComputers

I've pushed the fix to master and should be available in the next snapshot build.

column1: Problem with boot dashboard deploying to cloudfoundry. Works with cf CLI
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I tried to deploy the following Spring Boot application (I tried with my own application first and go the same result):
https://github.com/hellokoding/springboot-jsp
I used STS 3.8.2 and the Boot Dashboard and the deployment seems to work with no errors. However when I issue the following URL http://my-url.cfapps.io/hello
I get the following response page:
{noformat}
Whitelabel Error Page
This application has no explicit mapping for /error, so you are seeing this as a fallback.
Wed Nov 02 02:53:00 UTC 2016 
There was an unexpected error (type=Not Found, status=404). 
/hello.jsp
{noformat}
Could it be that the folder src/main/webapp is not deployed with my application? When I try to run the same project locally in STS as a Spring Boot application it works, i.e. the hello.jsp file is found and returned.
If you find a document that describes why this error occurred I would appreciate if you could give me the information that I could have used to find it as I was unable to find anything to help.

You can see the details at this issue reported on cloudfoundry: [Issue 107810|http://support.run.pivotal.io/hc/requests/107810]
column91:
07/Nov/16 7:25 PM;kdvolder;Thanks for filing the bug and attaching a sample project. I've kicked it around a bit. Don't fully understand yet why this is happening but... here's what I found:

First I thought it might be because of jar versus war packaging. But that's not the case. Even turning sample to a 'jar' type project it behaves the same (i.e. works locally but not deployed).

Second. I see that `src/main/webapp` is not treated as a source folder by m2e. So its not on the classpath.

So indeed, that means it is not packaged-up by STS boot dash since our packaging is based on the Eclipse classpath which is configured for us by m2e.

It is a bit strange that running with 'Run As Boot App' does work though. It should be using the same classpath in that case (i.e. the one computed by m2e) so I would expect that also not to work, (because the jsps aren't on the classpath there either) but it does work. Perhaps some component in that local run is smart enough to look around the filesystem, outside of the project's classpath, for those files.

I have to admit I'm not all that familiar with how the jsp files are being found. I'll probably have to read-up / investigate that a bit to really understand what's going on.

Anyhow...  I can confirm this bug is real and can reliably reproduce it. 

Seems to be a packaging issue of some kind. Needs further investigation to get to the bottom of it.
column92:
07/Nov/16 7:43 PM;kdvolder;Actually... I think this *is* in fact related to jar versus war packaging. The converted into jar project I have here doesn't deploy correctly on cf cli either. I.e. the jsp stuff is not included in the packaging by spring boot's packaging either.

Boot Dashboard does not yet support war packaging. So I think that is really the root of the problem here. 

If you can repackage your app as jar instead of war so that it works correctly, then I think it will work correctly also in boot-dash.

For us (STS) to fix boot-dash so this sample works 'as is' we need to implement proper support for war packaged deployments. Unfortunately this isn't trivial.
column93:
07/Nov/16 7:57 PM;kdvolder;Seems like 'jsp' may not be really compatible with 'jar' packaging. I found this: 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21243690/is-it-possible-with-spring-boot-to-serve-up-jsps-with-a-jar-packaging

It mentions used to be not possible. Now it is supposed to be possible, but there are some limitations. To make it possible I assume spring-boot-maven plugin is probably also doing some magics that might not automatically carry over to STS boot dashboard.
 
So it looks like if someone needs to use jsp then they probably have little choice but to also use war packaging.
column94:
07/Nov/16 8:20 PM;kdvolder;Aha! Further down the SO page I found a solution (i.e. a way to get jsp working in executable jar, which means it should also work in boot-dash).

This blog-post from Gunnar explains it in detail: http://hillert.blogspot.ca/2016/03/spring-boot-with-jsp-in-executable-jar.html

In short, with embedded Tomcat, you can put the contents of webapp folder into `src/main/resources/META-INF/resources`. I tried this with the sample project and it seems to work fine.

We should probably think of this as a 'workaround' only for the real problem. The real solution is supporting 'war' packaging. However, given the complexity of war support, and seeing as spring-boot is really pushing on the 'use jar not war' theme and generally discourages using jsp altogether, I don't think fixing this is going be a high priority. Especially since there seems to be a reasonable workaround.
column95:
07/Nov/16 8:26 PM;marioja;Kris, this is excellent news.  However, WAR packaging is essential in two scenarios:

1. when server side scriptlet is required
2. when deploying spring boot to a container.

If Spring boot does not support deploying to containers it will loose traction in the enterprise use case as running inside the corporate container is always an mandatory requirement.
column96:
07/Nov/16 9:41 PM;kdvolder;Sure, and its definitely worth considering this. Doing proper war-support hasn't been on our road-map so far, things seem to be moving away from that. But probably something to bring up with the team. Up until now we haven't really had any substantial issues/complaints about boot-dash only supporting boot-dash apps packaged as jar.

BTW: To be clear, spring-boot does support war, and isn't planning on dropping that as far as I know. Its only a limitation of the boot-dash in STS. And there are ways to package and build a boot app that can be deployed as both. The jsp case seems to be just one of the more tricky ones to do, and this is partly because this is also a 'legacy' technology for which there are probably better alternatives if you are starting to build your next 'small microservice app' from scratch.
column97:
15/Nov/16 9:54 PM;kdvolder;Hi Mario... good news. After discussion with the team. We figured its not really that hard as I made it out to be. At least... assuming the projects is maven, then we can just run 'mvn package' to produce the war. (If we had to truly integrate with WTP that would be a different story :-)

So, I just implemented war support. 

Caveat, as said it works only for maven projects (gradle is harder to do, extra work). But I gather maven is what you care most about given the sample project you added here :-)

I've tested it with that sample and it works.

If you want to try it out. You can update STS from the latest snapshot CI build via this update site:

http://dist.springframework.org/snapshot/IDE/nightly

If you decide to try it, drop us a line let us know if it works for you.

column94:
27/Oct/16 12:07 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I looked at your example and now I understand what you are requesting. However, I am a bit hesitant to add those kind of compiler errors, since you really have to be sure that this is an error. Otherwise people are quite annoyed by the IDE and all those errors.

Here is what I could imagine. Let me know what you think about that:

If the class is a Spring component (annotated with a Spring component annotation somehow) and contains a field that is not annotated with @Autowired, we could generate a warning and offer a quick fix to add @Autowired annotation. But even in this scenario, I am not sure if that fits all the cases nicely. I am worried about situations where people use constructor injection or set the field as a side effect of another setter method what might be called by Spring.

As you can see, generating such an error would require quite some amount of code analysis.
   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/133252119

20/Nov/16 2:58 PM;mlippert;I haven't got anyone else yet who reported the JPA Event Handler issue. But that doesn't mean that you are the only one having this. The changes I made are not temporary, STS 3.8.3 will include them, especially if they increase stability and performance. And I don't have any plans to revert those changes for the next release.

The majority of the changes are packaging related. That means that an update of STS 3.8.2 to 3.8.3 doesn't automatically include those changes. It would mean to delete installed features from someones STS installation, which might not be what users want. Therefore downloading a fresh STS 3.8.3 release and start from that might be the best option for you.

28/Nov/16 8:25 AM;mlippert;The way you install the latest nightly doesn't cause those problematic bundles (those that cause the JPA Project Event Handler issues) to go away. If you update an existing installation like STS 3.8.2 that comes with those JPA support features, the STS features will be updated, but the other features will not be removed in all cases. It is quite difficult to cleanly remove those JPA support bundles in that situation.

Therefore I would like to ask you to start with a fresh STS 3.8.3 distribution instead. Please download the distribution package from that nightly page that I mentioned above and go from there. That is the only way that I know that makes sure that those JPA support bundles are gone.

I also believe that a fresh STS 3.8.3 install should solve this issue, too, since the JPA components are no longer part of the default distribution. Please also read my comments on that item.

Since the root cause of this ticket (the restart issue) is working again (as described in one of the comments above) and the latest comments are more about STS-4416, I will close this one as cannot-reproduce. Follow up discussions and issues around the JPA event handler problem should take place on STS-4416.
