column97:
09/Nov/16 1:45 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I am facing similar issues from time to time, but I am not sure how to reproduce those errors at the moment. Need to dive deeper into this.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/132322379
column98:
10/Nov/16 8:27 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
This seems to be related to the way you launch/start Eclipse or STS. It happens for Eclipse as well as STS.

If you launch Eclipse/STS on macOS by clicking on the "Eclipse.app" or "STS.app" icon, this additional folder is being created and configuration data is being stored in there (as well as additionally installed plugins). If you click on the executable inside (Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/eclipse), this doesn't happen and the configuration inside of the application bundle is used.

I have no idea at the moment why this happens and reported this to Eclipse:

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=507328

Lets see if they can shed some light on this.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/132322379
column99:
17/Nov/16 1:31 PM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I made some progress on this. There seems to be a problem when STS (or Eclipse) gets translocated my macOS Sierra at first start. This translocation is done by macOS Sierra (as a new security feature) and it somehow causes STS/Eclipse to be confused and create those random folders in ~/.eclipse/. Since those random folders seem to be different every day, installation information and settings are lost.

While I am trying to find out how to fix this in STS/Eclipse, so that it works in the translocated case, there are two workarounds for this problem.

If you start STS/Eclipse by starting the executable directly (which is inside of the STS.app package under STS.app/Contents/MacOS/sts), the app doesn't get translocated and everything is fine.

If you move the STS.app package after unzipping it into the official "Applications" folder of your Mac, the app isn't translocated either and everything is fine, too.

Both are just workarounds (not real solutions to this problem), but at least there is a workaround that I hope helps you right away.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/132322379
column100:
18/Nov/16 11:12 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I tried to find another solution to this in the Equinox launcher code, but failed. Gatekeeper seems to do this path randomization action after every restart of the machine. Therefore the launcher just don't know whether it is indeed a newly installed app or "just" a newly randomized app.

I detailed all my results in:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=507328#c12

So please, to avoid this, move the STS.app bundle to a different location using the Mac Finder. It looks like it doesn't have to be the "Applications" folder, it can also be a different one on your drive (whatever fits your needs).

If you want to verify that the app isn't moved by Gatekeeper, you can dive into the configuration details by going to the About dialog, select the Installation Details, click on the Configuration tab, and look for the "eclipse.home.location" property. It should point to the path where you put STS. If it starts with "/private/var", then Gatekeeper has moved the app to a randomized read-only location.

I hope this helps.

Side note: we might change the packaging of STS in the future and put it into a signed DMG file, so that our users have to move it to a location on their disc.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/132322379
column101: 18/Nov/16 11:13 AM;mlippert;Mark this as closed and "not applicable", since this is caused my macOS Sierra and not STS itself, as described above.

column92:
11/Oct/16 10:06 AM;kdvolder;Looks like some kind of conflict between installed bundles. Unfortunatley not much more I can see from the screenshots. Please paste the entire *text* of the error, the screenshot only shows a fraction of it that fitted on your screen.

If you cannot resolve the conflict, I suggest trying to download a full STS distribution rather than trying the upgrade route. It could be a mix of old and new things causing this problem so a 'clean' start might be the easiest way to resolve it.
column93:
12/Oct/16 3:19 AM;mlippert;The error message indicates a package use constraint violation, which means that the boot dashboard bundle is exposed to two different versions of the javax.xml.ws.handlers package. I am not sure why the OSGi runtime is not able to solve this constraint violation. I would indeed try to restart STS with a "-clean" flag. Sometimes that triggers the OSGi runtime to re-resolve dependencies and to find a different, better wiring solution.

Another way to work around this is to start with a fresh installation, as Kris mentioned.

In addition to that we can try to avoid this wiring issues by removing some of our dependencies (which is on our radar for the next versions anyway). But that doesn't help you immediately. Hope both workaround mentioned above help you.
column94:
12/Oct/16 8:56 AM;wolfmoonheart;Hey guys,

thank you for you responses. I guess I will then install a fresh installation in next time.

Maybe one info could be useful, I am using the same STS-Installation from 3.7.? version, and updated always when a new version came out.
It worked then all the time well for me expect the last update.

Have a good day,

Cheers,
Michael

P.S. Complete Stacktrace attached for your analysis

column97:
07/Apr/17 8:49 AM;mlippert;This project has moved its issue management to GitHub Issues:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues

Therefore we closed the majority of old issues, like this one here. If you think this issue is still valid and should be fixed or worked on, please feel free to file it as a new issue on GitHub (using the link above).

Please note that there is also related work going on for the 3.9.0 release to reduce bundle dependencies and as a side effect also avoid this update issue.

column1: IPv6 + Origin header + X-Forwarded-For header gives NumberFormatException (Safari10 / CORS)
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
When an IPv6-only client connects to our WebApp which uses Spring 4.3.2
And the browser sends an Origin header (Safari 10 does this under certain circumstances)
And the LoadBalancer/Reverse Proxy adds an X-Forwarded-For header (with the IPv6 address)

Then you get a java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "a51:0:920::30:20"
at org.springframework.web.util.UriComponentsBuilder.adaptFromForwardedHeaders(UriComponentsBuilder.java:691)

It appears that this CORS code is IPv4 only?
column91:
28/Sep/16 2:10 AM;mlippert;This is related to the Spring framework itself, not the Eclipse-based IDE for it, therefore please report this at:

https://jira.spring.io/browse/SPR/

column10:

column42:
no response on right mouse click on a spring-maven project
the app is not responding. After a moment the "no response" text comes up in the header. Then if I click again a "glass" pane blocks the whole GUI. I can only kill it with taskmanager.

I installed java new and sts too - more times. The issue is after new installation of java and sts not there, but on the second click on the project it starts blocking again.
I tried the -clean on the commandline and in the sts.ini file - no solution

I am blocked, because when this is not working I can stop working in eclipse. 

I need to set the proxy network settings in order to be able to go on the internet.

I have 1 example project loaded in the workspace, it is your standard webservice project, loaded from the new menue.

column91:
22/Sep/16 8:39 AM;kdvolder;> I need to set the proxy network settings in order to be able to go on the internet.

Most likely, but this is just a guess, when you click on the maven project there's something that kicks in as part of computing the menu contents that hits the network and gets blocked on the network proxy.

If it happens again you can try to collect a stackdump using 'jps' and 'jstack' (these are commandline utilities that ship with the JVM).

Attach the stackdump to this bug and maybe it will give us some hints on what's causing the hang and what we might do about it.

Looks like something is indirectly initializing StsProperties which is hitting the network. So if your proxy blocks that access it is likely why the UI freezes. You could try waiting a bit, I think it will likely timeout after some time and then proceed. Reading StsProperties from NW is only attempted once (per session) and after that it falls back to using default values. So if it times out, after that the problem should be resolved (until the next time you start STS).

Of course... we do realize this is very annoying, so should try to fix that properly somehow.

Your stacktrace is very helpful, as now we actually have some pretty specific info we can use to try to fix this. So thanks again :-)

Closing this one as a duplicate. I will raise priority on the other issue to reflect we have multiple reports of people being very inconvenienced by this.

column1: Spring Marketplace will not work
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: With any Spring IDE, Always says "No repository found at http://dist.springsource.com/release/TOOLS/update/ex.x." (x.x is because I have tried all versions). I tried loading it through 'Help->Install New Software' and added "http://dist.springsource.com/release/TOOLS/update/ex.x." and I get the following message: AccessDenied Access Denied A6304FA6C9C2791D 9dvZeK/RbwblcyG1RQVFZx8qJ7b5qeIo0JLn46n486aqUYhlad4zSpw7fUqcTwZ/CvbyANLvR+8=
column91:
19/Sep/16 7:17 AM;mlippert;Please keep in mind that those URLs do not serve index pages, so accessing them via a browser produces the given expended result. If you would like to check general availability of the repository, you could use this URL instead:

http://dist.springsource.com/release/TOOLS/update/e4.6/compositeContent.xml
That should return a relatively short XML document (which is a composite update site descriptor).

In addition to that I would suggest to delete those update sites from the preferences, restart STS, and add them back. This wipes out stale cache data and might help in this situation. It this doesn't help, you could also try to use "download.springsource.com" as the host of the update site and try that in the "install new software" dialog. Sometimes that helps, too.

Hope that helps!!!
column92: 10/Apr/17 11:50 AM;mlippert;I am closing this one as "cannot reproduce" and hope that my previous comment helped to solve this on your machine. If not and you still come across this issue, please open a new issue at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide (since we moved issue tracking to GitHub). Thanks!

column1: Slow builds after bootifing all maven modules
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Our project consists of 123 maven modules, containing 20 webapps, around 75 shared modules (libraries), around 20 spring batch jobs and other tools.

We bootified all our projects, where the shared libraries use spring.factories defining auto configuration files for the EnableAutoConfiguration key. The apps (webapps and batches) use @EnableAutoConfiguration to pick up all auto configs.

Since this change, builds have become very slow, esp. incremental ones.
A clean build finishes within 6-7 minutes (disable "Build automatically", clean all projects, re-enable "Build automatically") which is also much slower then before (I guess it took like 2-3 minutes before).
Incremental builds (e.g. when switching a branch and updating the maven configuration) now take much longer then before, sometimes even longer then a clean build.

When looking at the "Progress", most of the time is spent in "Loading 'mymodule/src/main/java/com/exaple/ModuleMainClass.java'".

Is there any way to profile this?
column91:
05/Sep/16 6:31 AM;mlippert;I guess this happens due to more Spring configurations are now auto-detected and taken into account when building the Spring beans model behind the scenes. This is what the progress message indicates.

There are two things that we should do about this. The quick fix for you is to turn off the feature to auto-detect Spring Boot apps in the preferences of those projects (Spring -> Beans Support -> Config Detection tab). That should avoid those heavy tasks to kick-off during the build and should significantly improve build times.

The second step would be to identify those boot apps that should be taken into account for building the beans model inside of the IDE (in case you need that) and configure exactly those manually.

As a third step, we should try to find out why building the beans model takes so long for your builds and probably improve performance issue itself. Do you have a profiler like YourKit at hand?
column92:
05/Sep/16 6:49 AM;ractive;Thanks for the quick answer.

I'm happy for  a quick fix at the moment because every code change in a shared module triggers a build that takes up to 5 min.

Has the "Disable Auto Config Detection" checkbox in the general "Preferences > Spring Beans Support" settings the same effect as disabling the auto-detect in the project preferences as you mentioned?
column93: 05/Sep/16 12:03 PM;mlippert;The "Disable Auto Config Detection" disables that detection mechanism globally. So yes, if you want to switch off all the auto-detected configs, you can use that.
column94:
07/Sep/16 5:39 AM;ractive;This helped BTW. I can work again and so far I do not miss the missing bean model.
When I find some time I may hook up a profiler and provide some snapshots.
column95:
08/Sep/16 2:49 AM;mlippert;Glad to hear that this quick workaround helped. Good news... :-)
And it would be great if you could find the time to hook up a profiler (YourKit would be preferred) and run some prof sessions. Let me know when you are ready for some more details what to record and what not.
column96:
07/Apr/17 8:47 AM;mlippert;This project has moved its issue management to GitHub Issues:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues

Therefore we closed the majority of old issues, like this one here. If you think this issue is still valid and should be fixed or worked on, please feel free to file it as a new issue on GitHub (using the link above). For that case, it would be great if you could capture the discussed profiling data and attach that somewhere for us to take a more detailed look. Thanks!!!

Once I have unzipped STS version 3.8.1 and Launch it.

It asks me for workspace location.

Once entered, it loads and then the IDE opens up.

Then it shuts down immediately after a few seconds.
column91: 01/Sep/16 5:31 AM;mlippert;Do you see crash logs being recorded somewhere?
column93: 01/Sep/16 11:24 AM;sathyarajesh.a@tcs.com;This is one log that I see is generated
column94:
01/Sep/16 11:26 AM;sathyarajesh.a@tcs.com;Could Not find anything under the above mentioned path

${workspace}/.metadata/.log
column95:
02/Sep/16 9:51 AM;kdvolder;Thanks for the log. Logs like that are generated when VM crashes in native code. I'm not sure of this, but it looks like JavaFX related. So probably related to the 'welcome dashboard page' because that uses JavaFX. 

It might be worth trying to disable the dashboard. Unfortunately that's a bit tricky if your STS always crashes on startup trying to open it as you won't get a chance to do anything to disable it.

However, we can 'hack' it by modifying some preferences files in the workspace. Do this a little carefully to avoid breaking the workspace.

First make sure you shutdown STS if its running before doing this.

Then, find this file in the workspace at this path: 
{code}
${workspace}/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime/.settings/org.springsource.ide.eclipse.dashboard.ui.prefs
{code}

Put this data in it (replace anything else that may be in it already):
{code}
eclipse.preferences.version=1
org.springsource.ide.eclipse.dashboard.uidashboard.startup=false
org.springsource.ide.eclipse.dashboard.uidashboard.use.old=true
{code}

This will make STS not open the dashboard automatically and if it does get opened use the old one which is non-javaFX-based.

However, depending on what got saved in workspace before the crash, Eclipse will also save the state of the workbench, including what views where open already. So because of that Eclipse may still try to restore the already open view again (and triggere JavaFX and crash again). So, we must delete the workbench state (this is okay, Eclipse will reinitialize it if its missing).

So delete this entire folder:
{code}
${workspace}/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.e4.workbench/
{code}

Now start STS, and hopefully it will not crash on you because its no longer using JavaFX.
column96:
02/Sep/16 11:33 PM;sathyarajesh.a@tcs.com;It worked. :)

Certain things to be noted is that the file that was said to be altered was not there in the first place.

Added it now and it is working.

The workspace folder that was to be deleted was also not present.

Thanks
column97: 04/Sep/16 4:28 AM;mlippert;Great to hear that you got it working. Therefore closing this ticket now.

column1: Run As... Spring Boot Classpath issue throws ClassNotFoundException with WebMvcConfigurerAdapter
column10:

column42:
Using the Spring Boot Dashboard and the Spring Boot Configuration for managing running the App within Eclipse. Everything has been working fine when running the Application through the Spring Boot Dashboard.

Adding an external property file to the application and reference it in the @Configuration class using @PropertySource(value = {"classpath:fee.properties" }). Also adding an 'external folder' location on the classpath through the spring boot configuration. Open the configuration, go to the classpath tab, press 'Advanced', then 'Add External Folder', adding the folder location of the property file.

When starting the application through the Spring Boot Dashboard per before, it reports a ClassNotFoundException on org.springframework.web.servlet.config.annotation.WebMvcConfigurerAdapter

Removing the external folder from the classpath tab in the configuration the App starts up fine until it hits the error because it cannot find the external property file.

Running the application as a 'Java Application', right mouse click on the 'main' class of the Spring Boot app, 'Run As...Java Application', with the external folder it starts up fine.

So at the start of the main program before any Spring activity occurs I added the following to view the classpath

ClassLoader cl = ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader();
URL[] urls = ((URLClassLoader)cl).getURLs();
for(URL url: urls){
    System.out.println(url.getFile());
}
When running from the Spring Boot dashboard several jars are missing from the classpath, when running either as a Java App, or without the external folder entry all the jars are present on the classpath.

Example of some of the missing jars are...

/Users/orlok/.m2/repository/org/springframework/spring-context-support/4.2.3.RELEASE/spring-context-support-4.2.3.RELEASE.jar
/Users/orlok/.m2/repository/org/springframework/boot/spring-boot/1.3.3.RELEASE/spring-boot-1.3.3.RELEASE.jar
/Users/orlok/.m2/repository/org/springframework/boot/spring-boot-starter-web/1.3.3.RELEASE/spring-boot-starter-web-1.3.3.RELEASE.jar
/Users/orlok/.m2/repository/org/springframework/boot/spring-boot-starter/1.3.3.RELEASE/spring-boot-starter-1.3.3.RELEASE.jar
/Users/orlok/.m2/repository/org/springframework/boot/spring-boot-starter-logging/1.3.3.RELEASE/spring-boot-starter-logging-1.3.3.RELEASE.jar
column91:
11/Aug/16 4:17 AM;orlok_assassin;Attached 'Spring_Boot_classpath.txt' as the output that fails with the ClassNotFoundException, 

'Java_app_classpath.txt' as the output that works running as Java App, and has all the jars present
column92:
12/Aug/16 8:49 AM;kdvolder;>  Also adding an 'external folder' location on the classpath through the spring boot configuration. Open the configuration, go to the classpath tab, press 'Advanced', then 'Add External Folder', adding the folder location of the property file.

I think this is probably the reason. If you go on the CLI/terminal and run 'mvn package' and then try to run the resulting jar produced by maven does that fail with the same error?

I think you are directly manipulating the project's classpath without telling the build of the classpath changes. The 'Run As Boot App' launcher tries to be consistent with the jar that maven would produce (as much as possible). So if the CLI/mvn produces a jar that has the same problem then I wouldn't actually consider this a bug.
column93:
12/Aug/16 2:11 PM;orlok_assassin;When I say 'Also adding an 'external folder' location on the classpath through the spring boot configuration. Open the configuration, go to the classpath tab, press 'Advanced', then 'Add External Folder', adding the folder location of the property file'.

This is not the Project Build Path , this is the 'Run Configuration' for the Spring Boot App.

I do this by right click on the Spring Boot App in the SB Dashboard, select 'open config' then follow the steps above.
The Run Configuration is separate from the Build, this is the instructions just how to run the Application.

I did as you said, I building the jar and ran it, and it ran with no problem at all.
Example 
java -Xms1g -Xmx1g -jar engine-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar --spring.profiles.active=dev --spring.config.location=/opt/engine/properties/fee.properties
column94:
12/Aug/16 2:21 PM;orlok_assassin;I added '--spring.config.location=/opt/engine/properties/fee.properties' to the Spring Boot App Run Configuration, 'open config', go to the 'Arguments' Tab and enter that in the 'Program arguments' text area.

By the looks of it changing the classpath per the issue I resolved is a bug.  I'd suggest either disabling the ability to add an external folder to the classpath on the run config, or it converts it, (under the covers), to the spring.config.location.

column10:

column42:
I know STS is specially enhanced to properly work for Spring projects, but since a very long time I'm also using it code on jenkins and jenkins-plugins.

But since I upgraded to the latest version (3.8.1) I'm not able to do so anymore... The reason is an error I get when ever I import a jenkins-plugin project (maven based, e.g. https://github.com/jenkinsci/config-file-provider-plugin/):

{code}
Only a type can be imported. com.cloudbees.plugins.credentials.impl.UsernamePasswordCredentialsImpl resolves to a package
{code}

While the message is true about the fact that there is a package called the same as a class, this is the case for many many classes in the source of Jenkins. This is actually a convention, all resources belonging to a specific class have to be places in a package with the same name as the class.

Is there anything I can do to ignore this error?

I also posted the question on SO: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38857327/only-a-type-can-be-imported-class-resolves-to-a-package and was pointed to this question pointing out a violation of the compiler spec... http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9584086/java-class-name-same-as-the-nested-package-name

column93: 20/Jul/16 8:43 AM;sahild;I just tried to install e46 to see what would happen and I didn't get the above errors when installing, but I then got the Initializing Java Tooling errors when restarting MyEclipse .
column94:
20/Jul/16 8:46 AM;mlippert;The e46 version of Groovy-Eclipse is definitely the wrong one, since your MyEclipse is based on Eclipse 4.5.1. No wonder that is produces the mentioned error while initializing the Java tooling.

The e45-based version seem to cause a versioning conflict with the JDT version that is included in MyEclipse. Will need to take a deeper look. Maybe we need an updated version constraint in Groovy-Eclipse to make it install into that version of MyEclipse.
column95:
20/Jul/16 9:22 AM;sahild;If there is something I can try let me know. 
Is there something that MyEclipse could do with what they install?
column96:
21/Jul/16 8:51 AM;mlippert;I tried this with a trial version of MyEclipse and I can see the same error. The problem is a fixed version constraint inside of MyEclipse, as far as I can see.

Groovy-Eclipse installs a patched version of JDT. Therefore the patch replaces JDT (with a different version). This works just fine, for example, if you download and install Groovy-Eclipse on the Eclipse Mars 4.5.2 JEE package (for example).

In the case of MyEclipse it seems like the package definition of MyEclipse defines a dependency on a specific version of JDT (not JDT in general, which the Mars JEE package does). Therefore the install dialog complains about the conflict: it can't satisfy the dependency from both (Groovy-Eclipse requires the patched version, MyEclipse requires a specific but different version).

I would go ahead and ask the MyEclipse guys how they define the dependency on JDT and whether they can relax that declaration so that patched JDT versions can be installed.
That is all I can do from here, I think. Hope that somehow helps.
column97:
21/Jul/16 9:04 AM;sahild;Martin you are awesome. I'll contact the MyEclipse guys and let them know what you found.
Thanks,
Steve

https://github.com/groovy/groovy-eclipse

column91: 16/Jul/16 7:31 AM;cforce;https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=498003
column92:

[~cforce] depending on what you would like to do, the boot dashboard in STS might be a nice option to work with CF in STS. But it really depends on what you would like to do, since the boot dash doesn't allow you to as much with CF as CFT does.
column93:
18/Jul/16 4:33 AM;cforce;Hi Martin,

the bug report indeed was on Spring Boot Dashboard CF feature not working on PWS. As i understood there are different vaiants of the plugin for Cloudfoundry support in Eclipse? Why? Which one is intended for what and do they work together in the same ide installation?. Which one is better supported an tested on PCFDev, Pcf and Pws?
column94:
18/Jul/16 4:53 AM;mlippert;There are two different CF integrations available, let me explain the background a bit.

There is the CFT (Eclipse Cloud Foundry Integration, being worked on as a project at Eclipse): http://www.eclipse.org/cft
This is a collaboration among IBM and Pivotal and an extension to regular Eclipse. You can install this into Eclipse (and STS, since it is an Eclipse distribution).
The purpose of this tooling is to provide a replacement for the CLI. And it integrates with Eclipse, lets say, using the old way of "working with servers".

The boot dashboard in STS is specialized for Spring Boot and extends the boot dashboard with CF integration. It doesn't replace the CLI, but allows an easy and quick access to CF instances from within the boot dashboard (as your spring boot dev center).Therefore it features all the boot dash features for boot apps, like support for Spring Boot Devtools, starting/stopping/deploying multiple apps with one click, tagging projects, double-click to jump to their route, etc.

The boot dashboard is tight to the STS release cycles and usually tested against all variants of CF, including PWS, PCF, PCFdev, etc. The latest version of STS (3.8.0) should nicely support all those variants. If not, please report that immediately to our issue tracker (or internally on the slack channel "eclipse-tools").

The CFT tools for Eclipse are usually tested against against non-Pivotal CF variants, namely IBM Bluemix (since they use CFT as a base for the Bluemix Tools for Eclipse). That project has its own release cycles and channels.

You can install and use both inside of STS. They don't interfere with each other.
column95: 18/Jul/16 6:37 AM;cforce;Tx for the extended explanation.So the issue for the boot Dashboard i reported here is at the correct tracker .
column96: 18/Jul/16 7:49 AM;mlippert;The boot dashboard works fine with PWS on my end. Did you see the above mentioned error just once or every time you try to connect to CF? If every time, does it work to connect to another CF instance? And do you see more detailed error logs in the Error Log View? If so, can you attach the stack traces?
column97:
18/Jul/16 8:57 AM;kdvolder;The error indicates some problem making network connection to PWS API endpoint over https. The 'check api version' is something that happens very early on and probably the first thing that happens and forces STS to connect to that end point.

Since, as Martin pointed out, this works for us, the problem may be due to something that's different in your network environment. Are there any 'special' things in your environment. e.g. proxies or firewalls? 

PS: I'm not necessarily implying its something wrong on your end (though I wouldn't rule it out either), but it could be a bug that only surfaces when networks has proxies and the like.

Here are the instructions on how to create a CF Server instance using CFT:

http://www.eclipse.org/cft/documentation/projectPageLink/CFTProjectPagedocumentation.html#h.n23f5n8jzrr4
column100: 18/Jul/16 1:42 PM;cforce;I am using a http proxy (no auth)which wasn't a problem in sts 3.7 at all. Futhermore the proxy works in Sts for Marketplace installations. well also
column101:
19/Jul/16 2:54 PM;kdvolder;We are trying to figure out how to setup a test env to reproduce. 

What really matters for us to know, I think, is what proxy/firewall, if any, affects your https traffic. 
The markeplace installations, I think probably use http to access the update sites (I guess it depends on how the update site urls are listed, but most are http)
column102:
25/Jul/16 4:38 PM;kdvolder;Status update. Yes, this is broken. Confirmed by testing with a proxy-firewall setup that I've created for this purpose. With proxy + firewall setup, boot dash can not do anything on PWS. It fails pretty much as soon as you try do do anything.

There's now a partial fix in master but we are still having issues with log-streaming through the proxy. See here: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/cf-java-client/issues/536
column103:
27/Jul/16 12:25 PM;kdvolder;Unfortunately full fix for this won't make it into 3.8.1 release. The problem with log-streaming depends on a fix for cf-java-client, which in turn depends on some fixes in reactor-netty. These changes aren't going to be done until probably about 2 weeks from now. So we cannot wait for this and hold-up the release. So we decided to release 3.8.1 with the partial fix we have at the moment.

This should be usable behind proxy, and should be fully functional except for the fact that console-log streaming disconnects after a short delay. 

Admittedly that could be quite annoying so we'll deliver the complete fix as soon as we can, in a snapshot build after 3.8.1 release.
column104: 02/Aug/16 11:42 AM;mlippert;Since we got the log streaming fixed, too, all those necessary fixes will make it into 3.8.1, which is going to be releases asap. Therefore marking this as fixed for 3.8.1.

column1: Showing same file multiple times in open resource when we have multi maven project
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Hi,

I have multi maven project like
om
     om-mod1
          om-sub-mod1
                a.file
          om-sub-mod2
     om-mod2
     ...

When i try to open a particular resource (ctrl+shift+r) or even Java file (Via Open Type [crtl+shift+t]) i see multiple records pointing to the very same file. i.e. :
if i search for a.file in structure above it shows me 2 or 3 records like:
a.file om/om-mod1/om-sub-mod1
a.file om-mod1/om-sub-mod1
a.file om-submod1

The reason why this issue marked as major is that if i pick first or second options i open the file like i opened it from out-side of it's project and my package explorer jumps to folders under the parent project. some times even auto build isn't working if i try to modify this files but it doesn't happen often.

here is the snap shot:
!https://postimg.org/image/o7hgummkx/!
column91:
12/Jul/16 12:20 PM;kdvolder;Yes, this 'normal'. Not saying it is good, but it works that way in Eclipse. The reason this happens is because the parent project contains the children, therefore those files literally exist in two different paths in the workspace. Once reachable directly from the nested projects and once via the root project.

You can 'fix' this yourself by adding a resource filter to the root project to filter the overlapping resources.

Right-click on the root project. Select 'Properties' then navigate to "Resource >> Resource Filters". Add a filter there removing the stuff in sub-projects from the workspace.
column92:
12/Jul/16 4:39 PM;hazhir;Thanks for the quick response Kris,

I personally don't see anything 'normal' with this behavior. Please do following in order to see the normal behavior:
Create a folder under temp/tmp directory, i.e. c:/temp/dir (i do it using windows explorer)
Create a sub-folder under above folder. i.e. c:/temp/dir/folder1
Create a file under the the sub folder let's call it test.txt
now go back to c:/temp and on the top-right side type "test.txt", how many results do you see?

Unfortunately filtering is not solution to this issue because this is a Major bug.
I can create a bug for eclipse in case this behavior can't be fixed from your side, please let me know.

Thanks.
column93: 13/Jul/16 2:39 AM;mlippert;Yes, this is behavior that is deeply embedded into the Eclipse resource model. Please file a bug against Eclipse for this.
column94:
13/Jul/16 6:46 AM;hazhir;Thanks a lot guys for dealing with this issue.
I have filed a bug against Eclipse and it turns out that there is solution for that (STS based on Eclipse higher than Mars is supporting it too).

Here is the link:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=497832

Best Regards,
Hazhir.
column95:
13/Jul/16 7:13 AM;kdvolder;Thanks Hazir. Its good to know about this option. I didn't even know that had been introduced in Mars. 

As is often the case with Eclipse there are options we may not even know about, that where introduced to fix problems with Eclipse.
But... these 'fix a problem with Eclipse' option are oftent turned off by default.

Effectively this means a lot of folks will still experience the problem simply because they have no idea there's a 'fix this problem' option for that.

So thanks to your persistence we now know, maybe STS could actually do something here, for example we could auto-enable the preference for STS users.

What do you think Martin?
column96: 13/Jul/16 7:14 AM;kdvolder;Reopening, maybe we can enable the preference to hide duplicate resources.
column97:
13/Jul/16 7:39 AM;mlippert;There is a discussion in the bug to do exactly that in the next Eclipse version. Would make a lot of sense, I think.
We can try to do this for your next maintenance release, too. Kris, wanna give it a try?
column98:
13/Jul/16 11:14 AM;kdvolder;They wanted a explicit enhancement request for that one. So I raised one.

Maybe that's all we should do, unless they reject that enhancement request, in which case we can reconsider to do it ourself in STS only.

column91:
06/Jul/16 11:02 AM;kdvolder;I downloaded Eclipse 4.6 for JEE distribution package. Then installed STS from the update site and I got no errors. It installed fine.

Maybe you didn't start from Eclipse JEE? Or maybe you installed a different selection of 'stuff' from the update site than I did (I pretty mich selected everything on the update site except 'commons' and 'resources'). The commons and resources bits should be installed as needed as dependencies of the rest.

Anyhoo.... I can't reproduce this and will close it as such. If you think there really is a problem (and I'm not saying there definitely isn't) you can post more precise instructions on how to reproduce it (i.e. what are you starting from exactly, and what are you selecting to install exactly etc.) we can reopen the ticket.
column92:
06/Jul/16 11:27 AM;amezick;I upgraded from 3.7.1.
Turns out I needed to add this update site to get this upgrade to work: http://download.eclipse.org/releases/neon/
I also needed to add this because groovy is now dead to STS: http://dist.springsource.org/snapshot/GRECLIPSE/e4.6/

On the download page there is only a link to the STS e4.5 update  site.  Is there a link to the 4.6?
column93:
06/Jul/16 12:04 PM;kdvolder;I would advise against upgrading from Eclipse 4.5 based version, especially if you are going to be mixing that with Eclipse 4.6 update sites. That seems like asking for trouble to me.

You are better of with a clean install based on Eclipse 4.6. Or if you must, stick to Eclipse 4.5, then stick to it all around (i,e. don't mix 4.6 and 4.5 update sites).

> On the download page there is only a link to the STS e4.5 update site. Is there a link to the 4.6?

Hmmm... right you are. We should get that fixed. There is of course a 4.6 update site and you can probably guess it from the pattern established by the other links. It is:

http://dist.springsource.com/release/TOOLS/update/e4.6/

Also let me check about the missing dependency with 4.5 site. See if I can reproduce that.
column94:
06/Jul/16 12:21 PM;kdvolder;Using Eclipse JEE 4.5 and installing STS from e45 update site seems to work fine for me. I think you probably where using an E45 based installation with a E46 update site which is why there was a problem.

I've asked someone to fix the missing link, so I think that that should take care of all the concerns raised. 

Feel free to add further comment if there's something else that needs our attention.
column95: 06/Jul/16 12:22 PM;amezick;I made sure to disable all of the update sites for 4.5 and 3.7.1.  So far it is working great!  A clean install is great but I can't go through the pain of having two versions of eclipse open side by side and I make sure all the settings have been copied over.  I think this issue can be transitioned to "Need better documentation around how to do an update on the downloads page."
column96:
06/Jul/16 12:32 PM;kdvolder;Okay if it works for you, who am I to argue :-) I'd just be worried if you update from Eclipse 4.5 to something based on Eclipse 4.6 some bits of E 4.5 might be 'stubborn' to remove. If you hit any problems later that look like classloader API incompatibilitty errors or the like... you might reconsider the clean install route.

Note that doing the clean install, you can still keep using your same workspace and keep all your settings. The settings live in the workspace not the install. Just point your new STS to your old workspace and it should all pretty much work.

When try to import a gradle project on the build model this occurs

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

Initialization script 'H:\sts-bundle\sts-3.7.3.RELEASE\plugins\org.springsource.ide.eclipse.gradle.toolingapi_3.7.3.201602250836-RELEASE\toolingCustomModel\init.gradle' line: 32

column43:
Version: 3.7.3.RELEASE
Build Id: 201602251025
Platform: Eclipse Neon (4.6)
column91:
22/Jun/16 8:00 AM;ted.poovey@gmail.com;Additionally, if I import and try to convert I get this error.
org.gradle.plugins.ide.internal.tooling.EclipseModelBuilder.<init>(Lorg/gradle/plugins/ide/internal/tooling/GradleProjectBuilder;)V
Could not fetch model of type 'HierarchicalEclipseProject' using Gradle installation 'H:\gradle-2.14'.
column92:
22/Jun/16 8:58 AM;kdvolder;Please disable 'Use Custom Tooling Api model' in the Gradle STS Preferences.

I was able to reproduce the problem by doing these steps:
 - create a simple gradle project (i.e. just via "New Gradle Project Wizard")
 - add a gradle wrapper to specify Gradle version 2.14
 - enable 'Custom Tooling Model' from Gradle STS preferences.

When I disable the 'Custom Tooling Model' option the problem goes away.

It looks like Gradle has made some api changes so the newer version of Gradle you are trying to use is no longer compatible with STS custom model builder.

We are not going to try to fix this model builder. Fixing is complicated, especially if we need to keep it also working with previous versions of Gradle. So its a bit of a maintenance nightmare, and the STS Gradle plugin is being phased out in favor of BuildShip.

So your options are:
 - try out buildship instead. Eventually probably you will need to make the move. 
 - stick with a version of Gradle that works with custom tooling model.
 - disable custom tooling model option.
column93: 22/Jun/16 8:59 AM;kdvolder;Reducing priority because it only affects 'custom tooling model'.
column94: 22/Jun/16 8:59 AM;kdvolder;Closing as won't fix for the reasons explained earlier.

column43:

Spring Tool Suite

Build Id: 201602251025
Platform: Eclipse Neon (4.6)
column91: 21/Jun/16 4:25 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/121935217
column92:
21/Jun/16 9:14 AM;kdvolder;Haven't seen that, but I have seen something similar once which affected macs. So although can't reproduce it on my machind I have a hunch why this might be happening.

Probably a 'loop' in some change/event propagation causes the text of the field to be set to the contents it already has when propagating a change event when user types a letter.
Some widget implementations will move the text cursor back to the front of the text whenever the text is set and this causes a 'reverse typing' effect.

column1: Spring Property Editor suggests spring.cloud.consul.discovery.prefer-ip-address
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: The Spring Property Editor for  suggests spring.cloud.consul.discovery.prefer-ip-address in application.properties while it should really be spring.cloud.consul.discovery.preferIpAddress
column91: 06/Jun/16 7:48 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/120959375
column92:
06/Jun/16 9:13 AM;kdvolder;> while it should really be spring.cloud.consul.discovery.preferIpAddress

You say 'should'. Why? Do you mean that it doesn't work if you use the name with dashes or that you would simply *prefer* to use camelCase instead?

As far as I know both should work and are treated as 'synonymous' by spring-boot property binding mechanism. Also spring-boot creates metadata always defining the properties with their hyphenated names. This why sts editor suggests them in that form as well. 

We have some open tickets support camelCase completions and a preference for users to indicate they prefer to use camel case instead of hyphenated form of property names in their files. That is however a fairly complex thing so support consistently in the props and yaml editor.
column94:
06/Jun/16 9:23 AM;kdvolder;The tickets I referred to above are here:

https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/118012453 (preference)
https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/118023107 (support camel case in completions)

Closing this one as a duplicate.

column91:
26/May/16 2:15 AM;mlippert;Since those features and plugins exist on the STS update site, I assume something else is causing this situation, maybe stale cache data. I would recommend to start STS, delete the main STS update site from the list of available update sites (in the preferences), restart STS, and add it back. That wipes out the cached data and helped many times in similar situations.

Let me know if that fixes the issue for you, too.
column92:
26/May/16 2:27 AM;staleks;I guess you are referring to marked one (see [attached image|https://issuetracker.springsource.com/secure/attachment/27969/STS-Update-Preferences.png])?

What about others? Do I need to delete/add anything else, out of this list?

Thank You
column93:
26/May/16 2:31 AM;mlippert;Yes, you marked the right one.
And no, I don't think you need to remove others.

But you could export them all, delete them all, restart STS, and re-import them all back - in case you want to wipe out EVERYTHING. Exporting and importing those settings makes it easy, you don't have to type them all in again.
column94:
26/May/16 2:51 AM;staleks;Done, right as You suggested.

1. Go to: 'Preferences > Available Software Sites'
2. Marked all, and 'Export', 
3. Closed STS
4. Started STS again
5. Go to: 'Preferences > Available Software Sites'
6. 'Import' from previously saved file.
7. Go to, 'Help > Check for updates'
8. Updated

It works, this time without any issues.


Thank You
column95: 26/May/16 2:59 AM;mlippert;Happy to hear that it is working now. Therefore closing this item now.

Version: 3.7.3.RELEASE
Build Id: 201602251025
Platform: Eclipse Neon (4.6)
Windows 10
Java 8
column91:
05/May/16 12:53 PM;kdvolder;Details about the app will be needed. When I debug a boot app I just created, this doesn't happen. So its probably something about the stuff on your apps classpath causing this exception. 

My first instinct is to think there's a problem with the app, rather than a problem with the debugging support in STS. 

I could be wrong though. If you have some good reason to beleave this is problem with the STS debug support, please provide more information for us to reproduce the problem.
column92: 05/May/16 12:53 PM;kdvolder;Closing as 'cannot reproduce' but it can be re-opened if more info is added.
column93: 05/May/16 8:30 PM;ranajyotic;When I execute the jar file from command line simply by java -jar it works perfectly. So I am not sure if this is a classpath issue. I am building this with gradle, so I simply do a gradlew eclipse to create the project. This problem was not there in previous version of STS. I recently removed the old version and installed this new version. The gradle build fro within STS is also working fine. I was looking up in the internet and some forums say that this is a conflict issue between STS and Spring.
column94: 06/May/16 4:44 AM;mlippert;Since you are running the project as an application, I can't see a relation to the issues that you mentioned (conflicts between STS and Spring). However, it would be great if you could attach a sample project and a few steps how to reproduce this, so that we can take a more detailed look.
column95:
06/May/16 9:35 AM;kdvolder;Its probably still a classpath issue, but if it works running from CLI then the issue may be that the classpath used by STS for running isn't quite the same as when running from CLI.

Actually... it is a known problem (see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=482315) with Gradle projects that classpath contains things that shouldn't be there such as test-related dependencies. This may very well be the cause of the problem.

The issue is most likely something like this and it is most likely caused by the Gradle tooling. Which one are you using? BuildShip or Gradle STS tooling? In any case, I think both suffer from classpath being polluted with test related stuff. Its due to a limitation of the tooling API.

Without a sample project, I cannot say for sure this is the problem. But it seems very likely.
column96: 06/May/16 2:12 PM;ranajyotic;Gradle STS. I will try to create a sampel project tomorrow and send you. But I don't know how to attach it to this issue.
column97: 09/May/16 1:21 AM;mlippert;There is a "attach files" action in the "more" menu above.

column93: 18/Apr/16 12:46 AM;mlippert;This exception seems to be coming from the external JAR type content assist. You can disable "Jar Type Search" from the list of content-assist proposals (as a workaround). Is it a Spring Boot project that you are working on? Or does this error happens for other projects, too? It would be great if you could attach a sample project from your workspace that reproduces this problem somehow.
column94: 18/Apr/16 9:44 AM;kdvolder;THe jar type error should be harmless its merely an indication that it only works for maven projects and its not implemented for gradle. Perhaps we should look at hiding the error from the log to avoid confusing people. However I don't think its responsible for the problem here.
column95:
18/Apr/16 11:33 AM;ranajyotic;Martin as per your suggestion I turned off the "Jar Type Search" and the problem still exists. 
It is indeed a Spring Boot project. I had created a general java project and tried on that one and it works perfectly fine. 
But I discovered a very strange thing, I created this general java project as TestJava, the annotation autocomplete  worked on the source file of that project and when that project was in the workspace if I type just @ and then Ctrl + space the list shows up and then you can type and search even on the Spring Boot project. But if you type even 1 alphabet after @, then Ctrl + space, it causes the issue in the Spring Boot project but not in the general java project. If I delete the TestJava project from the workspace, the problem is back, if you type @ then Ctrl + space you will get the error dialog. This is a bit bizarre but it happens. I wish there was a field to attach file in JIRA I could have created a screen capture video and send it to you guys. But now I at least have some kind of a weird workaround which will work for me. If you can please fix this issue as this is very irritating.
column96: 19/Apr/16 1:27 AM;mlippert;Can you create a short sample project that could help us to reproduce the issue? That would be great. You can attach that to this JIRA ticket with a few steps how to use it to reproduce the problem from a fresh STS 3.7.3 install, that would be awesome.
column97:
19/Apr/16 8:03 AM;ranajyotic;Martin
I created a Spring Boot project from STS new - > Spring Starter Project and annotations work there like a charm. The only difference I could see with my project and the new one are the # of gradle dependencies. That could be the only reason. Unfortunately  I cannot give the source of my project, so I would let it rest and continue with the error dialog. If you would want to reproduce this add about 30 dependencies in a project and try. Anyway, I truely appreciate your help. You can close this one if you want to.
column98: 24/Apr/16 9:31 AM;ranajyotic;Just to give you an update. I think I found out what is causing this issue. I am 90% sure that the Gradle STS problem is causing the problem. I installed the latest eclipse (Mars) installed the Gradle STS plugin and bingo!! There is the same error. I have cleaned up all installations and installed STS again and till now not encountered the issue. The same plugin in Mars is causing memory issues which is causing eclipse to crash. I have not seen this with STS.
column99:
09/May/16 3:56 AM;mlippert;Thanks for the additional feedback and detais. I moved this to 3.8.1 for further investigations and added the Gradle component as a marker. Would still be awesome if you could create a sample project that causes this issue with the Gradle STS support (in plain Eclipse, as you described).

A few things that might help as well: if the content-assist takes a long time to finish, capture a few thread dumps while is takes so long (using jps and jstack). Maybe that reveals some extra information what is causing the slowdown.

With regards to the memory issue, it would be great if you could capture a head dump and upload that somewhere so that we could take a look what exactly is causing the memory issues with this.

Thanks a lot for your help!!!

column92:
14/Apr/16 1:07 AM;mlippert;As mentioned in the stackoverflow comment, we can take a look at replacing the problematic JDK call with something else. This would address the crash issue that you can identify from the crash log (thanks for posting this).

With regards to the memory consumption it also looks strange and buggy to me. Can you capture a head dump when it reaches 1,5gb or 2gb of RAM and upload it somewhere (maybe dropbox or so), so that we can take a closer look what is consuming all the memory? Would be extremely interesting to see where all that memory is consumed. Maybe there is a leak somewhere that we can fix or some other room for improvement.
column93: 14/Apr/16 1:08 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/117601747
column94:
14/Apr/16 8:42 AM;kdvolder;Are you running Eclipse with SWT using GTK2 or GTK3 support? If you don't know then its probably GTK3 which is the default nowadays.

What's interesting is that stack trace shows a call terminating inside GTK2 library code. Generally using both GTK2 and GTK3 at the same time isn't a good idea and may well be reason for the crash. Try setting env var SWT_GTK3=0 before starting STS/Eclipse and see if helps reduce the number of crashes.
column95: 14/Apr/16 8:46 AM;kdvolder;BTW: just to be clear I'm not implying this is your fault in any way. But it seems the call passing through 'awt' JDK lib code implicitly uses GTK2 and that may be not compatible with the fact that Eclipse SWT uses GTK3 by default. So trying to confirm this hunch would be a good idea.
column96:
24/Apr/16 5:21 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
We discussed this in more detail and explored some options. There are no good options to avoid this call to java.awt.Desktop, which seems to be the cause of the crash in this case.

But we will move the code that uses this JDK class from the enable/disable check into the actual execution of the action. That means that this crash will not happen anymore every time the context-menu is used (that causes the actions to be checked for enable/disable state). That should solve the issue for most of the users.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/117601747
column97:
25/Apr/16 7:30 AM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Moved Display#isSupported call to action execution. If not supported or UnsupportedException thrown then error message would pop up. Also switched to "Open" action rather then "Browse" since "Browse" didn't work for me on Mac (might be the reason for this not to work on Linux as well).   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/117601747
column98: 26/Apr/16 2:00 AM;mlippert;I marked this as fixed, the code in question got moved as described.
column99:
07/Apr/17 7:51 AM;mlippert;We moved issue tracking for this project to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide.
If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Bean model slow to respond on 'CTRL' mouse hovers
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Update: lots of comments here about similar issues involving some kind of hangs. Focussing this issue on one of those problems only.

New description:

{quote}
I'm using spring-ide for a very large codebase project here at siemens (~500K LOC), many spring-bean etc. Sometimes it takes "some" seconds to open that special ctrl+mouseclick menu which then contains "open bean foobar ...". Maybe here is another point where huge performance improvements are possible if the calculated bean-tree is not calculated again and again ...
{quote}

Leaving old description below for reference.

One of my colleges have massive problems with freezing UI.
It seems that the freezes are (more often) occurred if the user is using the tooltip functions of eclipse very often.

column91:
06/Apr/16 8:30 AM;kdvolder;The stacktraces you pulled from the error log look like traces that where logged for diagnostic purposes during debugging. In other words they are not real errors but just logged traces that were meant for debugging. They were probably accidentally left behind in the code. 

However, they are not really a problem or an indication of one. They are not helpful in diagnosing the cause of the hang.

The next you or your friend experience the UI freeze please try and use 'jps' and 'jstack' to grab stacktraces of the 'stuck' JVM process.

jps and jstack are commandline tools part of a standard JDK installation and should already be installed on your machine.

Basically you type 'jps' to find out the process id of the Eclipse/STS process and then use 'jstack <PID>' to dump the stacks to system.out. Save the output to a file and then attach it to this bug report. 

That might give us a real clue why the process is 'stuck'.
column92: 07/Apr/16 11:24 AM;ahoehma;Ok. We will try this if the freezing is still there. Thxs.
column93: 04/May/16 7:06 AM;mlippert;Moving this to the 3.8.1 release cycle since we haven't heard back with more details yet.
column94: 25/Jul/16 10:46 PM;passion.lim@gmail.com;I have the same problem when the network is unstable or not connected to the Internet. Do you have any idea to disable it?
column95: 26/Jul/16 8:48 AM;kdvolder;Disable what? If something freezes up because of a network delay, we may be able to do something about it, but we need a hint about what it is that's freezing up. You can try and capture a stacktrace at the moment of the freeze using jps and jstack commandline tools. The stacktrace may reveal something such as a network call on the UI thread. That is then a bug we can try to fix and/or provide you with a possible workaround. Without knowing precisely what's 'stuck' however there's not much we can do.

column98:
22/Aug/16 11:08 AM;kdvolder;Yes the stacktrace shows a calling path from the UI thread is blocking on network access to read STS properties. THe network call should eventually timeout, though it depends a bit on the underlying library (Eclipse network transport service).

Thanks for the stack. It will be helpful trying to avoid this annoying blocking behavior somehow. And yeah, good point, maybe we should not just 'trust' the library to fail with a timeout but add an explict timeout of our own somewhere. I can't really be 100% sure the transport service doesn't block indefinitely (it may very well depending on how precisely the network access is being blocked... by firewall, cable unplugged, etc.).
column99: 24/Aug/16 7:22 AM;mlippert;Even having a meaningful timeout would cause the UI to freeze (pinball on OSX) until we hit the timeout... :-(
column100: 24/Aug/16 11:27 AM;ahoehma;That's right ... maybe its possible to introduce an "intelligent" caching for such resources, or 1-level (short timeout) /2-level (longer timeout) process of retrieving such resources,  may be a async+callback mechanism is also possible (of course only if the "consumer" of the resource can work with such "deferred" resources ... just some ideas :)
column101:
25/Aug/16 10:06 AM;kdvolder;Yeah, the right thing is to do something non-blocking. The problem is really that the data from these properties is used to configure constants (i.e. static final field) in several places. Reworking all the code that directly or indirectly depends on the constants isn't a trivial task.

I agree its bad, but a lot of code may need to change to fix this.
column102: 26/Aug/16 9:14 AM;ahoehma;What about a "no-network-aware" implementation of this property-provider ... I think it is okay to freeze the UI one time ... but then if its clear that there is currently no chance to get the remote resource it makes no sense to try this again and again ... But I don't know if its currently possible that a) such place exists and b) change is possible. Maybe spring-ide can read a system-property which override the behavior of loading remote-resources. Only ideas :)
column103: 26/Aug/16 9:33 AM;kdvolder;It only tries to read the properties once on startup and falls back to default values if it fails. It won't try to read them again until you restart STS. Or do you mean it should even remember the 'no network' status past restarts?
column104:
26/Aug/16 9:41 AM;ahoehma;I don't even know that this happens only one time per startup ... but now I'm aware of that :) 
The original problem of my workmate was a periodically freeze. Maybe the cause of his problem was/is a other one.
column105: 29/Aug/16 9:21 AM;kdvolder;Yeah its likely a different cause then. Though I suppose it could still be network related, but not related to reading the StsProperties if it happens periodically. Maybe something else reading stuff from the network.
column106:
30/Aug/16 11:12 AM;kdvolder;I've just experienced a problem/hang very similar to what the original poster of this ticket describes. I was moving mouse and holding down 'CTRL' key. A little window pops up, no contents in it, then total UI freeze. 

I colllected a stackdump of the stuck process. No obvious deadlock unfortunately. It looks stuck in native code on a call to making shell visible. This is on Linux.

{noformat}

column107:
30/Aug/16 11:25 AM;kdvolder;My case looks like this one: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=354842
Description does sound similar to the one in this report, but the bug seems very specific to Linux-GTK and the original report here was for Windows OS.
column108: 30/Aug/16 11:30 AM;ahoehma;@Kris I can confirm such effects too :) I'm using spring-ide for a very large codebase project here at siemens (~500K LOC), many spring-bean etc. Sometimes it takes "some" seconds to open that special ctrl+mouseclick menu which then contains "open bean foobar ...". Maybe here is another point where huge performance improvements are possible if the calculated bean-tree is not calculated again and again ... :)
column109:
01/Sep/16 11:28 AM;kdvolder;What I experienced was not really a performance problem. Seemed more like as the Eclipse bug report. Something going wrong in SWT widget toolkit at low-level causing it to enter some kind of infinite loop inside some native code. I.e you can wait for an hour and it doesn't come out of it, and consumes a whole CPU constantly.

If you experience problem of the hover being slow because of suspected performance getting bean model info. That seems like a well-defined and reproducible problem. 

This ticket is turning into a bit of a 'we don't know what's really going on' with lots of 'I get something similar too' comments though. And its clear they aren't all the same problem.

We should decide to focus on something, here and maybe try to fix that. And make separate tickets for other 'hang issues'. 

Since you raised this ticket in the first place, let's make this about the 'Bean model slow to respond on CTLR mouse hovers' as that seems to be your specific problem.
column110:
01/Sep/16 11:41 AM;kdvolder;Raised this ticket for the other 'hang' we seem to have a definite cause for:

https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4395

There also the SWT problem, but that is already covered by an Eclipse bug so we don't need a STS bug ticket for it.
column111:
01/Sep/16 11:44 AM;kdvolder;Changed priority to 'major'.  Slowness computing bean model is annoying but not a blocker. 

The hang for StsProperties is more serious I felt so I set that as 'Critical'.

If there's other kinds of hangs that we can identify a separate cause for, we should raise new tickets for those as well, and also set their priority on a case-by-case basis.

Feel free to raise new ticket if you think your issue isn't covered by either:

 - Eclipse SWT hang bug
 - StsProperties + network causing hang
 - Slow bean model hang
column112:
07/Apr/17 8:42 AM;mlippert;This project has moved its issue management to GitHub Issues:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues

Therefore we closed the majority of old issues, like this one here. If you think this issue is still valid and should be fixed or worked on, please feel free to file it as a new issue on GitHub (using the link above).

In addition to that we removed network access in order to load StsProperties, so issues around that are fixed in STS 3.8.4.

column1: STS crashes repeatedly
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues

column91: 07/Apr/16 12:21 AM;mlippert;Hm, hard to see what the exact problem with this JVM crash is. Looks like this is related to a persistence library. Do you have a small project that reproduces this issue? That would help a lot.
column92: 11/Apr/16 1:39 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/117323257
column93:
12/Apr/16 2:56 AM;mlippert;Thanks a lot for attaching the sample projects. I can indeed reproduce the JVM crash when importing all projects at once into a plain vanilla STS 3.7.3 on Eclipse 4.6 (importing them as existing projects). When I try to import them one project at a time, I can successfully import them and work with them in the IDE. Not exactly sure why, but maybe that somehow helps?!?

I also searched for an JVM crash issue around the persistence lib (which seems to be involved in this somehow), but can't find relevant information anywhere. I tend to close this here and report the issue to the JDK team (as a JVM bug maybe).
column94: 13/Apr/16 4:49 AM;mlippert;I filed a bug for the HotSpot JVM project. Once I get a bug number and an URL back from them, I will post an update here.
column95: 13/Apr/16 4:50 AM;mlippert;Do you have a workaround for this? Does this happen on specific actions/sequence of actions?
column96: 10/May/16 4:23 AM;mlippert;I was able to reproduce this, but the update to the newest JDK somehow fixes this. Looks like JDK 1.8.0_92 contains changes and fixes that prevents this from happening for me. Please verify.
column97:
10/May/16 4:25 AM;mlippert;btw, the JVM bug that I filed is here:
https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8154734

It got marked as not an issue (for whatever reason), so it is not a good resource here, but I thought I should at least keep the reference here.

column1: STS steals CPU when running tests/apps
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: Running a test has turned into a chore that takes minutes. I'll attach some thread dumps but it looks like STS is thrashing CPU.
column91: 31/Mar/16 11:39 PM;dsyer;Thread dumps showing `org.springframework.ide.eclipse` activity over a period of about 2 minutes (during which Eclipse was frozen)
column92: 01/Apr/16 4:48 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116764119
column93:
04/Apr/16 3:09 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I took a look at the thread dumps that you attached (thanks for that) and it looks very much related to https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4340, which is already fixed in master and recent builds. Can you verify that?   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116764119
column94: 04/Apr/16 3:16 AM;dsyer;Yeah that looks like a duplicate. I'll trust the OP in STS-4340 when he says it's fixed.
column95: 04/Apr/16 7:36 AM;mlippert;Ok, great, I will mark this as closed as a duplicate of STS-4340. Thanks!!!
column96:
07/Apr/17 7:52 AM;mlippert;We moved issue tracking for this project to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide.
If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Spring Boot Dashboard does not recognize when the app has started
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
When starting some boot apps, the boot dashboard does not recognize when the app has started completely and the arrows in front of the project keep spinning and spinning. This means that you can't click on the "globe" icon to open the URL for this app.

This only happens for our bootified web-apps. Using an off the shelf boot web-application from start.spring.io works fine and the icon turns green when the app has been started and I can click on the globe to open its URL.

Live Bean Support and Life Cycle Management is enabled in the lauch configs.

Any ideas what the issue could be or how to debug this?
column91:
31/Mar/16 9:59 AM;kdvolder;> Any ideas what the issue could be or how to debug this?

I don't have idea of the top of my head. Something must be going wrong with the lifecycle tracking bean. So STS must think somehow that this is 'supported' but somehow it doesn't work for your particular app.

If you could produce a 'sample app' that demonstrates the problem I can try to debug it.

Could you use one of your apps as a basis and 'cut it down' to something you are comfortable sharing with me (either in private or by attaching it to this tracker issue)?
column92: 31/Mar/16 10:00 AM;kdvolder;Is this problem new (I know you pulled in some snapshot updates) or did it happen with the release as well?
column93:
01/Apr/16 2:34 AM;ractive;The problem already existed in the 3.7.3 release version.

I could create a very simple project that shows this behaviour:
https://bitbucket.org/ractive/webapp_test
column94: 01/Apr/16 4:39 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116763649
column95:
01/Apr/16 1:22 PM;kdvolder;Thanks for the sample. I haven't gotten time yet to take a look at this. 

As a workaround you can try to disable the 'lifecycle management' in the launch config. We don't know yet why, but the lifeccycle management isn't working for that project, so you are better of disabling it. That way the Boot Dash will work a little better as it won't try to use it to make that spinning icon.
column97: 20/Jun/16 9:52 AM;kdvolder;I'm closing this as 'won't fix'. There's not much we can do about this. If a user goes out of their way to disable th JMX support STS relies on... things will break.
column98:
20/Jun/16 9:54 AM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Closed the Jira ticket as won't fix. I've added some info on why it doesn't work and how to fix it by adding the required Jmx support to the sample app).   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116763649
column99: 21/Jun/16 1:29 PM;ractive;Thanks for the clarification. Since we cannot (yet) use @EnableAutoConfiguration, the Jmx auto configs have not been loaded. We'll add those configs.

column1: dashboard doesn't work anymore after installing Groovy-Eclipse and SonarQube plugins
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: Spring boot Dashbaord disappers (bundle is lazy) a soon as Groovy for Eclipse plugin installed
column91: 23/Mar/16 8:51 AM;cforce;Update Site is http://dist.springsource.org/snapshot/GRECLIPSE/e4.5/
column92:
23/Mar/16 8:53 AM;cforce;"overview plugins -works" .. shows setup with working spring boot dasboard.
"overview -  problematic plugins" .. shows additional plugins that make dashboard disappear.
column93: 23/Mar/16 9:00 AM;mlippert;Does this happen when you install Groovy-Eclipse into a vanilla STS 3.7.3 for Eclipse 4.5 ?
column94:
23/Mar/16 9:43 AM;cforce;No, on a vanilla it seems to work.
Just tested that  sonarQube 3.5.0 (sonarsource) plugin cause the problem in combination with Greclipse 4.5

I also tested with new&northy Greclipse 4.6
-t he whole Eclipse fails with "An internal error occurred during: "Initializing Java Tooling". org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubMonitor.split(I)Lorg/eclipse/core/runtime/SubMonitor;" using Greclipse 4.6
- afterwards fails with Spring view http://dist.springsource.org/snapshot/GRECLIPSE/e4.6/ "Could not create the view: org.springframework.ide.eclipse.ui.navigator.springExplorer" and Boot View "Could not create the view: org.springframework.ide.eclipse.boot.dash.views.BootDashView"
column95:
23/Mar/16 10:06 AM;mlippert;This might be caused by the Groovy-Eclipse version that you used, which is for Eclipse 4.6. The error looks like an incompatibility when installing that into an STS that is based on Eclipse 4.5. Just guessing here though...

Can you point me to a few steps how to reproduce this from a vanilla STS 3.7.3 on Eclipse 4.5 ? Maybe including the update site URL from which you installed the SonarQube thing?
column96:
24/Mar/16 1:49 AM;cforce;The SonarQube URL is http://downloads.sonarsource.com/eclipse/eclipse/
Dependent what you you install first, the Sonar Plugin  or Greclipse either the dashbaord just disappears or stays but show error message  "Could not create the view: org.springframework.ide.eclipse.boot.dash.views.BootDashView".
column97: 24/Mar/16 2:01 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116277347
column98:
24/Mar/16 6:40 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
this is caused by a higher version of the com.google.guava plugin being installed and wired to the boot dashboard dependency. I am not yet sure why this is causing the exception.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116277347
column99:
30/Mar/16 8:48 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I added a use constraint so that the livexp from commons gets wired to the same guava library than the boot dashboard. This is necessary due to the guava types being used at the API of the commons bundle.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116277347
column100:
30/Mar/16 8:49 AM;mlippert;The issue with the boot dashboard is fixed now. The other issue with Groovy-Eclipse causing a strange exception is probably caused by the wrong version of Groovy-Eclipse being installed. I can reproduce this exception when installing a Groovy-Eclipse for Eclipse 4.6 into a 4.5-based STS installation. Using the right version of Groovy-Eclipse doesn't cause the issue.

Therefore I mark this issue as fixed now.
column101: 22/Apr/16 6:47 AM;vittualv;If i switch to 2.4 groovy compiler boot dashboard doesn't work in Spring STS 3.8.
column102: 24/May/16 1:48 AM;mlippert;I tried this again, installed a fresh STS 3.8.0 from the nightly downloads page and added Groovy-Eclipse to it (via the groovy-eclipse update site for Eclipse 4.6). It works just fine for me. Therefore I need more details how to exactly reproduce the issue you are describing. In addition to that, what do you see in the error log? Is there anything related to the boot dashboard?
column103: 02/Jun/16 3:02 AM;mlippert;This might also be caused by additional components being updated while installing Groovy-Eclipse. But please let me know if you have steps how to reproduce this.

column1: PropertyBeanReferenceContentAssistCalculator returns too many hits
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
In PropertyBeanReferenceContentAssistCalculator:62 a list of all interaces and super types is calculated and it is search for any bean that matches them.

This is incorrect. It should create only a single element in the List (respectively the parameterTypeName). That is because BeansCompletionUtils search for beans which fullfill any and not all of the submitted requiredTypes.
column91: 23/Mar/16 8:34 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217219
column92:
29/Mar/16 2:53 AM;mlippert;Thanks for this great report and the attached patch. This is fixed now and will be part of the upcoming STS 3.8.0 release.

For future reference, it would be preferred to sign the CLA and submit a github pull request... :-)

Thanks again for this great fix!!!

column1: CLONE - Code completion computer throws a runtime exception during normal editing
column10:
