This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Whilst editing the appended Groovy file, the Eclipse editor pops up a dialog informing me:

    The 'Groovy Code Completions' proposal computer from the 'org.codehaus.groovy.eclipse.codeassist.completion' plug-in did not complete normally. The extension has thrown a runtime exception.

This repeats each time the code completion dialog is triggered in this location, which has the cursor at the end of line 20, after 'it.'

Eclipse log and configuration also inlined, since I can't currently see a means to attach them.

This is the file I was editing: PathMatcherSpec.groovy
{code}
package com.controllis.rsc.manager.web.tests

import groovy.transform.Canonical;

import java.util.ArrayList;

import spock.lang.Specification
import com.controllis.rsc.manager.web.*

//@CompileStatic
class PathMatcherSpec extends Specification {

	@Canonical
	private static class PathMatcher {
		public PathMatcher(String path) {
			// Remove leading slashes before splitting, and wildcard processing
			components = splitPath(path).collect {
				if (!it startsWith '*') return it;
				// This is a wildcard; store the name and replace it
				it.
			}
			// find wildcards
			components.
		}
		public boolean isCase(Object value) {
			if (value instanceof String) {
				String[] components2 = splitPath(value)
				if (components2.size() != components.size())
					return false;
				for(int ix = 0; ix < components2; ix++) {
					if (components[ix] == null)
					if (components2[ix] equalsIgnoreCase components[ix])
						continue;
					break;
				} 
			}
			return false;
		}
		
		private static String[] splitPath(String path) {
			return path.replaceFirst(~/^\/+/, '').split('/');
		}
		String[] components = new String[0];
	}

	
	def "test 1"() {
		expect: path in new PathMatcher(template)
		
		where:
		template | path
		'/foo/bar' | '/foo/bar' 
		
		
	}
}
{code}

column1: Regression: STS forces me to create a keystore for CF passwords
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42: Previously I was able to click "Cancel" on the master password dialog and it would just go away (and I'd have to remember the CF passwords, but that is actually preferable to having to remember a master password per workspace in STS). Now it won't go away and I am forced to enter a master password if I want to use the CF support in the Boot dash.
column91: 23/Mar/16 8:35 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column92:
12/May/16 8:17 AM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Maybe we should have "Remember Password" setting in the CF target wizard and in the update password dialog? (I added it to my current solution). If yes, then perhaps "remember password" setting should be persisted with other target properties? This setting would tell us whether password should be stored in Secure Storage and whether Secure Storage needs to be checked for password. Thus, prompting to eneter Secure Storage password won't be annoying for those who don't use it.
What do you think?   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column93:
12/May/16 8:19 AM;pivotaltracker;Martin Lippert added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I like the idea of making this very explicit: should the boot dash remember and store the password or not? So a +1 from my side.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column94:
12/May/16 8:33 AM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I think it should. If it stores it then we don't have to look for password in secure storage guessing whether it's there or not... If persisted "remember password" is not set (at workbench start up) then secure storage won't be touched at all and hence user not prompted to enter any passwords.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column95:
12/May/16 2:01 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
> and hence user not prompted to enter any passwords.

He will still be prompted to enter passwords to connect to CF won't he? So that is still annoying.

I think we should explore an option so store a oauth token instead and stored that not in 'secure storage' which is a PITA, but just some file in plugin 'state location' with some fairly restricted access control (i.e. only read / write by the user themselves).

In other words... do something similar to what CF command on the CLI does.

If storing oauth token like this is good enough for CLI than why does STS have to try and do this stuff with secure storage?   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column96:
12/May/16 3:20 PM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Does oauth token expire? If it does then "Remember Password" is not applicable anymore... Yet, I think it's useful for the user to decide whether login credentials need to be remembered or not.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column97:
12/May/16 4:06 PM;pivotaltracker;Andy Clement added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
> In other words... do something similar to what CF command on the CLI does.
yep - i thought this is what we were going to do.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column98:
12/May/16 4:12 PM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I think the token does expire but its a very long time. At least I've had to relogin once every few months / weeks into CLI because my token expired.

But that's a lot less annoying than entering the secure storage password every time I start STS.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column99:
12/May/16 4:21 PM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
In that case I'll keep "remember password" work and try to change what's getting persisted and where. I admit i was completely unaware of these plans of not using secure storage and storing oath token...   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column100:
12/May/16 7:50 PM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Blocked by:
1. CF v1 and v2 client present (need to authenticate with both). Wait for v2 only based CF client wrapper
2. CF v2 Client is missing API to authenticate with OAuth Token
3.  (possibly) CF v2 client doesn't have API to get OAuth Token. Has #getAccessToken() method which is unlikely to return the Oauth Token.

OAuth Token authentication is moved into this story #119504403   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column101:
13/May/16 10:09 AM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Just a small correction. Actually 'getAccessToken' does return a Oauth token. But not the right kind for us. I am pretty sure its a very short-lived access token. So not much use to save that and try to reuse the next day. The longer-lived 'refresh-token' isn't exposed by the API.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column102:
13/May/16 2:46 PM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Pushed support for remember password and not remember password.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/116217253
column103:
07/Apr/17 7:51 AM;mlippert;We moved issue tracking for this project to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide.
If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Test classes annotated with @Configuration pulled in during Run/Debug as
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column91:
10/Mar/16 8:30 AM;kdvolder;A complete sample project would help, if you can attach one. 

I recall that we had a problem with test stuff being added to the classpath but this was fixed. It is a known problem with Gradle project's still and can't easily be fixed there due to tooling api limitations). But I see you are talking about a maven project, it should be fixed for those. Maybe a regression.

I'll try to reproduce but it would really help if you could attach a complete project that demonstrate the problem.
column92:
10/Mar/16 8:43 AM;kdvolder;I created a simple test project that sets up something similar to what you describe. There's a CommandlineRunner bean defined in the test sources. It should not run and it doesn't.

So the bug I remember fixing is not regressed. Perhaps this is a more complicated version of that bug and depends on specifics of your project or projects to occur. Without a complete example I can work its going to be hard to determine why this happens for your projects.

If that's not possible, maybe try at least to describe in more detail the layout and relationships between the projects and where the 'offending class' (i.e. the one that ends up on the classpath) resides relevant to the project that you are trying to "Run As Spring Boot App". My guess is it could have something to do with the multi-project structure.
column93: 10/Mar/16 8:46 AM;kdvolder;Attaching my simple sample project in "demo-doo.zip", (which unfortunately does not reproduce the problem).
column94: 10/Mar/16 12:22 PM;dpetrov;Kris, thanks for the quick response. I'll put together a test case for you within the next few days - I can't share the actual project it's happening in.
column95: 11/Mar/16 8:32 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115506005
column96:
16/Mar/16 9:42 AM;dpetrov;Well, this is embarrassing. The issue goes away if I clone the sources in a completely new folder, set up a new Eclipse workspace in it, and import the project. So it's something in the environment. I compared configurations as reported by Eclipse under Eclipse Installation Details, and while there are a number of differences, nothing jumped out as potentially pertinent. I can provide a diff of configurations if there is any interest, but otherwise the resolution seems to be to reset the workspace.

Can we keep this open until end of week, to make sure the new workspace behaves properly. Thanks!
column97:
16/Mar/16 1:05 PM;kdvolder;If I had to make a guess what the 'mystery factor' is. Maybe its launch configurations. When you created a new workspace, you lost (left behind) all your old launch configurations. The fix for the classpath issue I mentioned has some component of it that sets a property in launch configs. So perhaps because you had launch configs which were created before the fix... this is what caused the problem.

If you want to follow up that hunch... try deleting your old launch configs in the old workspace and see if it fixes the problem. Maybe backup or save those configs first, perhaps there is actually some kind of bug to be fixed here, and having a sample of these 'culprits' may be useful to reproduce the bug.
column98:
17/Mar/16 2:04 AM;ericmendillo;Hello, I'm not sure if you're talking about the same problem here but what happens to me is that it fails when I try to run an app with Run As -> Spring Boot App. It throws "Error: Could not find or load main class ~.Application". It also shows this error when I try to run the Application.java as a Java Application.

Moreover, when I create a new Spring Starter Project and I copy manually my src folder and pom.xml to this new project it starts perfectly. Nevertheless, since my project uses Git for versioning control I'm unable to sync the project. If you know how to trick this I would appreciate it. 

I have googled everywhere to find solutions: from adding -cp . to classpath to installing new IDE core software. 

Finally, as a matter of fact, my coworkers have the same project on Linux environment and works OK (they started the project and possibly didn't upload some configuration to the repo). I'm using OSX and also tried installing it on a Ubuntu VM and have the same problem on both operating systems with the same environment variables.
column99: 17/Mar/16 8:26 AM;kdvolder;Sounds like a different problem. Not sure what your problem is, but "~.Application" doesn't sound like a 'main class' at all. Sounds to me like there's something broken about your project or its config. Hard to say what, but this bug report isn't the place to discuss it. Maybe try a stackoverflow question?
column100: 18/Mar/16 11:14 AM;dpetrov;I copied the launch configuration from the good workspace into the bad one, but that did not fix the problem. I confirmed that the configuration was not modified by re-exporting it form the bad workspace.
column101: 21/Mar/16 9:04 AM;kdvolder;Okay, then I don't know why it might have gotten broken in your old workspace. I'll close this ticket as 'cannot reproduce'. Thanks for trying to reproduce with old launch configs.
column102:
18/May/16 10:44 AM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
Looks like ticket was closed on Jira already as 'cannot reproduce'.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115506005
column103:
18/May/16 10:46 AM;pivotaltracker;Kris De Volder added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
I delivered it, or should I just delete it? nothing got fixed. But its closed on Jira.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115506005
column104:
19/May/16 8:44 AM;kdvolder;Sigh.... pivotal tracker decided it was a good idea to reopen the ticket because I did something with its mirror-image in PT. 

Closing it again.

column10:

This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I have installed the STS module in my existing Eclipse (4.5.2) instance and I want to override some properties from the run configuration.

I can add a new line with the property and the autocomplete is displayed properly, however I don't have the chance to add a value for it, the editor goes to next line.
column91: 09/Mar/16 12:41 PM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115367049
column92:
12/Mar/16 7:12 PM;pivotaltracker;Alex Boyko added a comment in Pivotal Tracker:   
   
SWT Table on Win likes selection to be set. If one the items is in edit mode means that the row of the item selected. If selection on the table is not full then clicking on an item is the second column doesn't result in selection of the row and if row is not selected item cannot under mouse cannot be found, since it looks in the selected row it seems. Solution was enable full selection, so rows become selected vs first column.   
   
View this Pivotal Tracker story: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115367049

It also takes up to 20 seconds until e.g. a JUnit test or a spring boot application begins to start.

column91:
07/Mar/16 10:31 AM;kdvolder;I opened the launch config dialog and I'm not seeing any problems. So maybe need some more info on particulars of your situation that might cause this problem.

One guess... Do you perhaps have a lot of launch configurations in your workspace? If so maybe it is a performance problem caused by some kind of 'combinatorial explosion' which happens when there's are a lot of launch configs. 

Anything else you can tell me? Does it happen any way you open the launch config editor? Or just a specific way. Anyhow.. if you could give me some precise steps that you can perform and reproduce the problem for you, this helps taking the guess work out of it.

The traces that you pasted seem to all happen when our launch config tracker reacts to changes in the launch configuration working copy created by the dialog. This is a likely culprit as our tracker didn't use to care about working copies at all. I'm not sure yet though why it would take so long as to make it seem like a hang.

Anyhow. Next time I have some time I'll try and experiment a bit. In the mean time, if you can think of any more 'special' circumstances in your workspace that might factor into this it would be helpful.
column93: 09/Mar/16 1:09 PM;mlippert;I don't think that we have a switch to turn this off completely. There is a switch to hide individual Spring Boot launch configs from the dashboard view (in each Spring Boot launch config), but it looks like you are suffering from a different problem. I am trying to reproduce this now with a larger number of launch configs to see what is causing this.
column94:
09/Mar/16 1:13 PM;mlippert;From what I understood: you have a large number of JUnit test launch configs, but not a large number of Spring Boot launch configs, is that correct? And so the JUnit launch configs don't show up in the boot dashboard, but starting up anything or opening the launch config dialog takes forever, right?

Did you try to delete a large portion of those launch configs, just to confirm that this is related to the number of launch configs? Is it getting better if you reduce the number?
column95:
10/Mar/16 2:28 PM;mlippert;I created a workspace with more than 850 launch configurations, but I still can't reproduce this. Not sure what is causing this.
Another option would be to run a profiling session on your machine and transfer the sampling/tracing information over. If that is possible, it might help us to identify the underlying issue.
column96:
10/Mar/16 4:41 PM;kdvolder;If its not the number of configs, maybe its something about a 'strange' config. If you have lots, and been 'dragging' these along for a long time... maybe something corrupted or strange causing our code to go 'loopy'.

Anyhow... I don't quite understand why its blowing up somehow for you and causing a hang, but staring at the code for a bit, I did see a chance to avoid a few potential irrellevant calls to the 'refresh' methods that your stacks seem to blame.

It looks like refresh is called for changes to any configuration. This really not necessary since if a config is of the wrong type (e.g. a JUnit config) then it is irrelevant and refresh is not needed. Skipping those refreshes seems like a easy and good optimization to do and it might help with your problem.
column97:
10/Mar/16 5:14 PM;kdvolder;I pushed out the suggested optimization. Its bulding now. If you want to try if it helps for your problem.... keep an eye on this build:
https://build.spring.io/build/result/gotoBuildResult.action?buildKey=IDE-E43&buildNumber=970&returnUrl=%2Fbrowse%2FIDE-E43-970%2Flog

If its 'green' there should be a update site published with the snapshot here:

http://dist.springframework.org/snapshot/IDE/nightly

Point your eclipse install dialog ("Help >> Install new Software") to that site and install new version of "Core / Spring IDE" and "Spring IDE Boot Microservices Dash" (under 'Extensions').
column98: 10/Mar/16 5:49 PM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/115470521

column100: 14/Mar/16 6:04 AM;mlippert;Yes, that build has failed to upload the artifacts. I re-ran the build and the new version should be up there just fine. Please try again and sorry for the inconvenience.
column101: 14/Mar/16 7:23 AM;ractive;The changes from the nightly build solve the issue: I can now open the lauch config dialog again and starting a JUnit test is not lagging anymore. Thanks!
column102: 14/Mar/16 7:29 AM;mlippert;Great news, thanks for letting us know.
column103: 14/Mar/16 7:30 AM;ractive;Is it more or less safe to stay on the nightly build until the next STS release?

column1: Spring Beans Problem: Error occured processing XML 'org.springframework.beans.factory.support.BeanDefinitionBuilder.addConstructorArg(Ljava/lang/Object;)Lorg/springframework/beans/factory/support/BeanDefinitionBuilder;'. See Error Log for more details
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I have a "old" application which is using spring security 2.0.7.RELEASE.

D:\Dev\ApacheMaven\repository\org\springframework\security\spring-security-core-tiger\2.0.7.RELEASE\spring-security-core-tiger-2.0.7.RELEASE.jar

There I have a xml bean file which defines a spring-custom-filter:

83 <bean id="mandatorySessionFilter" class="com.siemens.spice.common.web.app.security.session.MandatoryHttpSessionFilter">
84    <security:custom-filter position="CHANNEL_FILTER"/>
85    <constructor-arg index="0" value="pleaseLogin.html"/>
86 </bean>

Error occured processing XML 'org.springframework.beans.factory.support.BeanDefinitionBuilder.addConstructorArg(Ljava/lang/Object;)Lorg/springframework/beans/factory/support/BeanDefinitionBuilder;'. See Error Log for more details	spring-beans-security-wsso.xml	/pcmplus-vaadin-webapp/src/main/resources	line 84	Spring Beans Problem

What's the problem? :D
column91:
04/Mar/16 2:59 AM;mlippert;Would be great if you could attach the error log and maybe a small sample project that reproduces this issue. That would be awesome.

My first guess at the moment is that there is a problem with the Spring framework version that is used inside of the IDE to create the bean model and the Spring framework version that is used in the project and compatible with that old Spring Security version. But that is just guessing.

A quick workaround is to remove the XML file from the Spring preferences of that project, so that it isn't used by the IDE anymore. But as a result, you also loose many of the Spring IDE features for it (like content-assist, validation, etc.). But at least it would quickly solve the problem with the exception being thrown under the hood.
column92:
04/Mar/16 3:03 AM;ahoehma;Currently I'm not able to provide a small version of that project :-( The project is quite big and is using a lot of "other" dependencies etc.

The errorlog ... where can I find what you need?
column93:
04/Mar/16 3:07 AM;mlippert;Take a look at the Error Log view in STS.
If you can drill this down to a simple spring project that would help us very very much.
column95:
07/Apr/16 12:20 AM;mlippert;This is indeed caused by the deprecated method being removed from BeanDefinitionBuilder. The easiest solution for this is to re-introduce this method back in the Spring Framework itself. Therefore I opened https://jira.spring.io/browse/SPR-14123 to get this back. As you can see from the comment from Juergen, he isn't extremely happy to re-introduce this back, but he did it to help with this issue. But this method will definitely be gone with Spring 5.

I will consume the next release of the Spring framework version for STS as soon as it is available. Then you will be able to deal with this from within the IDE again. For the meantime I am, unfortunately, not aware of any workaround for this. The only "solution" for this at the moment is to remove the Spring XML from the project configuration and therefore disable the Spring-specific tooling for this project.

Once Spring 5 is out, we will probably adopt that version in Spring IDE soon, so this problem might come back... :-( Sounds like we need a more decoupled mechanism inside of Spring IDE once Spring 5 is approaching.
column96: 07/Apr/16 12:24 AM;mlippert;Since this is fixed for now in Spring Framework, I close this one as fixed. Please watch STS-4360 for the adoption of the new Spring Framework version in STS.
column97: 07/Apr/16 12:25 AM;ahoehma;HI @Martin this sounds good. Thxs.

If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Properties/YAML editor offers log levels as lower case
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column91:
03/Mar/16 9:54 AM;kdvolder;If case matters then the spring-boot metadata should include the hints in the proper case. STS merely presents the values 'as is'. I don't think we should start have STS second-guessing and adding special cases into the code to convert some specific hints into upper / lower case etc.

This is where the values come from and they are in lower case there:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/blob/master/spring-boot/src/main/resources/META-INF/additional-spring-configuration-metadata.json#L186
column92:
03/Mar/16 9:59 AM;kdvolder;Raised issue against spring-boot to fix the metadata:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/5327
column93: 04/Mar/16 12:18 AM;snicoll;That link you gave has nothing to do with the issue. {{logging.level}} _is_ case insensitive.
column94:
04/Mar/16 8:40 AM;kdvolder;Okay, now I'm even more confused. If it is indeed case sensitive all the more reason that STS should not apply upper/lower case conversions to the values then.

If hint values are indeed potentially case-sensitive it is up to the metadata authors to spell them exactly right and not up to the tools to go second guessing which hints are subject to conversions and which ones are not.
column95: 05/Mar/16 6:47 AM;mlippert;From the conversation at the Spring Boot GitHub issue mentioned above it sounds more like an inconsistency between Spring Boot and Spring Cloud, where Spring Boot does this "case insensitive", but Spring Cloud reusing the same properties in a "case sensitive" way. The suggestion on the issue was to change this in Spring Cloud.
column96:
05/Mar/16 6:50 AM;mlippert;And looking at the related issue for Spring Cloud: https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-commons/issues/98 it looks like this is already fixed in Spring Cloud Commons.
Therefore I would recommend to close the issue here as a duplicate of that GitHub issue.
column97:
07/Mar/16 9:34 AM;kdvolder;If you want to re-open and re-close it with different kind of resolution, I have no objection. 

I'm still seeking clarification on the general rules about case sensitivity of valueHints. But if there's anything to be done there then that's a different issue.
column98: 07/Mar/16 11:31 AM;mlippert;No need to re-open and re-close, I think your solution looks fine. Need to keep track of the progress of that issue on GitHub.
column99:

column1: YAML Editor with List or Array inside of HashMap Object
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column91: 03/Mar/16 1:07 AM;mlippert;Kris, can you take a look? Thanks!!!
column92:
03/Mar/16 10:24 AM;kdvolder;Ouch. Yes Map<String,?> is a special case it is also treated as a special case by spring-boot itself. If such a map is used the stuff below it is 'flattened out' so that means nested structure inside it should be checked as if they are the same type again right down to the leaves.

It was put in place to support things like "logging.level.com.acme=INFO". The dots after 'logging.level' are not interpreted in the usual way but just eaten up into the 'keys' of the map bound to 'logging.level'.

But perhaps if the nested structure is a list and not another map, then its another special case (i.e. an exception to the special case).

I'll have to test a bit with spring-boot itself to determine what it actually does with these.
column93: 03/Mar/16 10:32 AM;kdvolder;Background info. This is the reason why Map<String> are treated as special cases: STS-4254
column94: 03/Mar/16 10:44 AM;kdvolder;Thanks for the excellent example by the way. That really helps :-)
column95: 03/Mar/16 10:45 AM;indaduke@gmail.com;No problem, it took me awhile to figure out that was the actual reason i was seeing the issue but was able to test that list inside and outside of the map and determined that to be the issue.  Thanks for your speed in looking into the issue.
column96:
03/Mar/16 11:29 AM;kdvolder;I've got a fix in my workspace, but there are some more similar cases to sort out. Will look into those and add regression tests for them before closing issue.

 - same special case handling to be added in content assist as well
 - make sure validation of stuff like this works when the nested list contains other values than strings (e.g. some kind of an Enum)
 - similar special cases in ".properties" editor.
column97:
03/Mar/16 1:42 PM;kdvolder;Added some regression tests for properties editor as well. 

Resolving issue.

column93: 29/Feb/16 8:53 AM;kdvolder;Looks like something gotten corrupted in the local maven repo. Last time this kind of thing happened I think it was because the app had exceeded its disk quota (maven repo groing too big I guess).
column94: 29/Feb/16 9:03 AM;kdvolder;Looks like same problem again. Over time the app runs out of disk for the local maven cache. I just restarted it and it should be good for a while again.
column95: 29/Feb/16 9:04 AM;kdvolder;I'd give it more disk, but 2G is already the maximum it seems.
column96:
29/Feb/16 9:10 AM;kdvolder;Don't think this is a blocker for the release. Its not actually a problem with the release. But the app providing the infos does seem to have a bit of an issue. Might need to think about doing something about it, but I don't know what we can easily do. The nature of the thing is that it resolves maven dependencies and so its going to fill up the maven cache over time. Probably we need to restart it periodically. 

If it needs more resources maybe its not something that can really run comfortably inside CF unless we can somehow give it more disk.

It was also at the edge of its memory requirements. This is something that can probably be worked on. It uses an in memory cache I can probably tweak to free up memory by removing old entries. But the disk requirements is not something I can think of a solution from at the moment.

In any case, the problem is not with the release.

column1: Gradle dependency container before JRE container results in compilation errors
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
I am converting a Java project from Ant to Gradle. The IDE of choice for our team is Eclipse. I have installed the Spring Gradle plugin for Eclipse, applied the Gradle project nature and enabled dependency management. The result is some compilation errors.

The compilation errors occur because the Gradle dependency container is before the JRE container in the eclipse classpath. Some jars on the classpath contain classes that should come from rt.jar (and they are incompatible with our code, presumably older versions).

The project is set to order dependencies as per the build script (as a workaround I can change it to order alphabetically by path).

When dependency management is disabled gradle dependencies come after the JRE container and it compiles without error. This is also consistent with my use of Eclipse/Maven/m2e where the the Maven dependency container comes after the JRE container in eclipse.

I tried to do it in my build.gradle using the eclipse hooks (whenMerged and withXml) but these seem to execute before the gradle dependencies are replaced with the container entry.

Window>Preferences>General>Key>

column95:
22/Feb/16 12:16 PM;yilativs;I'm using 14.04 Ubuntu 3.7.3.RELEASE (not a nightly build)
The keyboard layout is fine,  I'm using 4.5 Eclipse Mars without problem. All hot keys work in Eclipse Mars but not in STS.

column96:
23/Feb/16 10:11 AM;kdvolder;Not sure what we can do. It works for me so hard to say why it doesn't for you. I use those keys a lot (especially CTRL+1 so I would have noticed if it didn't, I've never had a problem with any version of STS). Here are some things to try that might give us info.

1. Check error log. Open the "Window >> Show View >> Error Log". Delete the current log. Restart eclipse. Then check the log for messages. Especially look for messages about keybinding conflicts.

2. Do you also get this with a fresh version of STS in a fresh workspace? Or is this a version of STS in which you have installed other stuff (if any of that stuff contributes conflicting keybindings it might explain the problem).

3. Open "Windows >> Preferences >> General >> Keys" and search for all bindings to CTRL+1. Maybe it shows something interesting.

22/Feb/16 10:20 AM;aboyko;Another workaround: type 'space' after each argument you type in. If an argument ends with a space next argument can start from the next line.

column1: Yaml content assist does nor correctly escape special characters / strings
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
When inserting values into yml from a content assist hint, some 'special' characters may cause parsing issues.

For example the completion of  this:

{code}
endpoints:
  cors:
    allowed-headers: <*>
{code}

Inserts a value '*' without quotes which causes a parse error.

The rules for when and how to escape are quite complex. A good summary is found in this article:

http://www.activestate.com/blog/2014/07/yaml-pro

Ideally we should implement something that correctly detects if a value needs escaping and then escape it correctly.
column91: 16/Feb/16 12:39 PM;kdvolder;Fix pushed. A bunch of cases are now supported (may still not be complete, in particular strings containing newlines are not handled yet).
column92:
07/Apr/17 7:52 AM;mlippert;We moved issue tracking for this project to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide.
If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Don't consider 'static' method when determining 'bean properties' in yml/props editor
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Some classes may have static methods that look like a 'property getter' if we don't take into account the fact that they are static.

For example 'java.util.Locale' class is used in a few places in the spring-boot properties. The static getter lead to invalid content assist suggestions for properties of this type.

E.g 
{code}
spring:
  jackson:
    locale: 
       <*>
{code}

Note: In this particular example the bug is actually masked by the fact that Locale is being treated as a 'special' type now.

The bug however is still there and will surface for similar situations where the type is not considered 'special'.
column91:
11/Feb/16 3:51 PM;kdvolder;Fix pushed. 

Note: Beside static methods also non-public methods are excluded.

If you would like to comment on or re-open this issue, please file a new issue at GitHub and refer to this one.

column1: Allow user to specify preference for property naming conventions
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
The user should be able to choose whether:

 - they prefer camelCase or hyphenated names for property names
 - they prefer UPPER_CASE or lower-case or camelCase for enum names

Right now these 'preferences' are more or less built-in and can't be changed. And in fact camelCase simply doesn't work on content assist for properties. But in enum names upper and lower case are both supported depending on what the user alsready typed.

See related issue: https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4228
column91: 20/Apr/16 7:57 AM;pivotaltracker;A Pivotal Tracker story has been created for this Issue: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/118012453
column92: 10/Apr/17 11:23 AM;mlippert;There is a tracker story for this, so I will close this one here as a duplicate, even though it is linked to that tracker story. We will move forward dealing with this enhancement request in tracker.

In the meantime you can disable the validation in the properties, if the error marker is too annoying.

column1: Adding custom property files causes deployment errors
column10:
The Spring Tool Suite™ (STS) provides the best Eclipse-powered development environment for building Spring-powered enterprise applications.
This Jira project is now archived as read-only, please file new issues at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues
column42:
Under the Servers/config add an application.properties file. Then deploy and you get an error as it trys to copy this to a backup folder.
{code}
Publishing the configuration...
Error copying file to C:/Java/sts-bundle/pivotal-tc-server-developer-3.1.2.RELEASE/base-instance/backup\application.properties: C:\Java\sts-bundle\pivotal-tc-server-developer-3.1.2.RELEASE\base-instance\conf\application.properties (The system cannot find the file specified)
C:\Java\sts-bundle\pivotal-tc-server-developer-3.1.2.RELEASE\base-instance\conf\application.properties (The system cannot find the file specified)
{code}

workaround is to manually place it into the backup folder so it exists.
column91:
19/Feb/16 3:10 PM;aboyko;I reproduced the issue.
The workspace config folder of the server instance in the IDE is "Servers/<server name>-conf". Contents of that folder are different from the server instance config folder because application.properties files was added. Now when backUpAndPublsih(...) is called on the server, WST code expects that all files under workspace config folder must exist under the server instance config folder, which is not the case due to this issue.
Goes over files under server conf folder in the workspace ("Servers/<server name>-conf") takes same name file in the server instance conf folder and copies it under "backup" folder if doesn't exist already (exception here for application.properties file). Then copies this file contents from workspace conf folder into server instance.
Tomcat doesn't run inti the same issue, because all Tomcat server in the IDE have "test-environment" attribute set to true which means that files are not backed up in the back-up folder but rather just copied over. Pretty sure the same issue can be reproduced fro Tomcat server instances somehow.
I'd rather fix this in WST. Otherwise, there is a possibility of making a hack fix in tc server integration by ignoring statuses with FileNotFoundExceptions for instance.

BTW, why was application.properties file there in the first place?
column92: 19/Feb/16 3:27 PM;aboyko;https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=488142
column93: 19/Feb/16 5:29 PM;aboyko;Also there is an option not to back up the the conf folder... but i'd rather try that after the release.
column94: 22/Feb/16 1:34 AM;mlippert;Moving this to the 3.8.0 release for further investigation and maybe some changes in WTP.
column95:
22/Feb/16 5:47 AM;mdiskin;To Alex's question why here is the first place, I can think of a few separate (wish they were actually worked better together) cases I have right now:

- Leveraging the TCSERVER split system properties to break out using catalina.properties. 
{code}
<Listener className="com.springsource.tcserver.properties.SystemProperties"
    file.1="${catalina.base}/conf/base.properties"
    file.3="${catalina.base}/conf/qa.properties"
    file.2="${catalina.base}/conf/dev.properties"
    file.4="${catalina.base}/conf/prod.properties"
    immutable="false"
    trigger="now"/>
{code}
- TCServer feature for encryption of properties supports splitting out the passphase into a separate file.
{code}
com.springsource.tcserver.security.PropertyDecoder.passphrase=${catalina.base}/conf/secure.file
{code}
- Support for Spring Boot external properties (we build spring boot war's each with it's own {war}.properties.

An error occurred while collecting items to be installed
session context was:(profile=DefaultProfile, phase=org.eclipse.equinox.internal.p2.engine.phases.Collect, operand=, action=).
No repository found containing: osgi.bundle,org.springframework.roo.wrapping.protobuf-java-lite,2.3.0.0001

column43: Running latest STS on OS X Yosemite
column91:
27/Jan/16 7:21 AM;mlippert;This sounds like a problem with stale cache data in p2 indeed. The bundle that this message complains about has nothing to do with Subclipse at all, but comes from an STS specific p2 repository. To get rid of this stale data, you can try to hit "reload" on the update site in the "Preferences -> Install/Update -> Available Udpate Sites" dialog (the STS one). If that doesn't help, I would recommend to delete that update site from the preferences, then restart STS, then add it back to the preferences. This usually wipes out the stale cache data and solves those issues that you mentioned above.

Hope that helps!!!
column92:
27/Jan/16 2:28 PM;patrickmcmichael;Tried reload approach - same error.

Tried remove site, restart STS, then re-add site - same error.

Tried manual delete of p2 cache data - same error.
column93: 29/Jan/16 3:00 AM;mlippert;Hm, that is strange... Can you try to delete all update sites from the preferences, restart STS, add them back, and try again? You can export and import the settings from that preference page easily, so you don't need to copy them manually.
